HEADLINE: Here's a Great Tax

BYLINE: By Fritz Hollings; Fritz Hollings, a Democrat, is Senator from South Carolina.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At his inauguration as President of Czechoslovakia, Vaclav Havel declared, "We have been lying to one other for 40 years . . . saying one thing and believing another." President Clinton echoed a similar sentiment in his own inaugural, challenging us to "break the bad habit of expecting something for nothing." We Americans have been lying to one other for 12 years, saying one thing and believing another. The mother of all lies in the Reagan-Bush era was the claim that there is a free lunch -- that deficits don't matter or that they can be eliminated painlessly, strictly by cutting spending. 
 Yet even if we eliminate domestic discretionary spending in its entirety -- some $214 billion -- we would still end up with a deficit of nearly $200 billion. Then cut $50 billion from defense and we are down to a $150 billion deficit. If we deny cost-of-living increases for Social Security and most entitlements, the money saved stays in the trust fund. We still have a $150 billion deficit and have done nothing to eliminate the debt.
We should provide an investment stimulus package, but it must be financed solely through budget freezes and cuts so it doesn't raise the deficit. We would still need taxes. And we can't afford to dally with political gamesmanship, such as demanding two-thirds in spending cuts for every one-third in tax increases. A trillion dollars is needed to eliminate the deficit in five years, and a cut of two-thirds of a trillion would destroy the Government.
We will never have a more determined spending cutter than Ronald Reagan, yet not even he could stanch the deficits through spending cuts alone. Mr. Reagan raised taxes repeatedly, as did George Bush -- taxing gas, tobacco, liquor and luxuries, while raising user fees and closing loopholes. Even this was utterly inadequate; the deficit continued to soar.
Today, it would be a mistake to launch yet another exercise in inadequacy by taxing the rich -- raising the top income bracket from 31 percent to 36 percent -- and levying an energy tax. These are half-measures. If President Clinton chooses this route, he will still end up with a deficit in 1996 almost as big as the one he inherited from Mr. Bush.
Face facts. The deficit and debt are growing faster than the economy. Interest costs are eating us alive. On this year's $400 billion deficit, additional interest costs alone will increase by $30 billion. So we find ourselves echoing Lewis Carroll: "It takes all the running you can do, to keep in the same place. If you want to get somewhere else, you must run at least twice as fast."
It will take real money to get rid of the deficit and debt, yet we must act with caution to avoid killing the recovery. A value-added tax, which is much like a national sales tax, is just what the doctor ordered. It would take at least a year after enactment to carry out a VAT, which would tax a good's increased value at each stage of production. This period would give the economy a chance for a firm recovery. At the same time, financial markets and Americans would know that we are finally on the road toward a pay-as-you-go government. Once instituted, a 5 percent value-added tax would bring in more than $100 billion. Every dollar of revenue would have to be put in a Deficit and Debt Reduction Trust Fund; not a dime would go for new spending programs.
A VAT is a tax on consumption. The more you consume, the more you pay. Yes, it is regressive. But nothing is more regressive than interest costs. And the economies of our international competitors certainly have not been hobbled by VAT taxes.
In Europe, the average value-added tax is 16 percent; in Korea it's 25 percent. And under the GATT rules of international trade, the tax is refunded on goods leaving a country. So a foreign good can be cheaper here because the value-added tax was eliminated by the time it got to the U.S. Thus, the huge disadvantage the U.S. now suffers in world trade could be alleviated if we had a VAT. Under current trade rules, the economist Lester Thurow says, any nation that does not have one is "stupid."
Best of all, this one-shot jolt avoids special-interest lobbying and is politically attainable. It calls for sacrifice from all. If we really want to promote investment, create jobs and restore confidence in government, now is the time to hit the problem head on, once and for all.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
Words Got The Best of Cal Coach

BYLINE: By TOM FRIEND, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 14

 BODY:
Lou Campanelli's post-game tirades, for mature audiences only, were ultimately what got him dismissed here last week from his job as the University of California's head basketball coach.
His words were perhaps no coarser than Coach Bob Knight's at Indiana. But the Cal athletic director, Robert Bockrath, inadvertently listened in on Campanelli one night recently, and that made the difference. 
 In essence, Campanelli was ruined by the strong acoustics of a locker room in Tempe, Ariz. On the evening of Feb. 4, after a loss to Arizona State, Bockrath entered "a wrong door by accident," he said, and found himself only a partition away from the locker room. He overheard a profane lecture by Campanelli to the team.
Bockrath once played football for Bo Schembechler at Miami of Ohio and maintains "I can swear with the rest," but he found himself appalled by what he called Campanelli's "personal attacks" on the players.
"There were things that were unwarranted and inappropriate and inexcusable," Bockrath said Friday. "It was so incredibly bad, I said, 'Sheesh, something must be done.' The players were beaten down and in trouble psychologically. Every other word was a four-letter one. Let me tell you, if I hadn't made that wrong turn, I wouldn't have known the fix the team was in."
Four days later, last Monday, Campanelli was a deposed coach.
The action was a further example of what appears to be a new, less-tolerant attitude toward college coaches with severe styles.
Just days before Campanelli was dismissed, Army fired its basketball coach, Tom Miller, for "publically degrading" his players even though he had been given two warnings. In November, Earle Bruce was fired as football coach at Colorado State for what school administrators called the physical and mental abuse of players.
Bockrath said he simply would not tolerate behavior by a coach that could be considered abusive. "Times have changed," he said.
The 54-year-old Campanelli, of course, sees the issues surrounding his dismissal very differently.
"What you say in a locker room should be between the coach and the players," Campanelli said Friday. "No one else's business. I may have used some curse words. From George Raveling to Bobby Knight to Dean Smith, there's not a coach in the country who doesn't."
 
Coaches Wonder: What the Heck?
 Across the country last week, coaches concurred with Campanelli. "If you fired every coach who swore or yelled, unemployment in this country jumps up 10 percent," said Raveling, the Southern California basketball coach.
Last Tuesday, Knight telephoned Pete Newell, the eminent former Cal coach, and offered his help to Campanelli.
Most of all, other coaches were concerned that Bockrath, hired by Cal in August 1991 after 11 years at Arizona, had removed Campanelli without giving him an opportunity to soften his caustic tongue.
"He wouldn't have changed," Bockrath, 49, said last week. "If you'd have heard him go off on these guys, you wouldn't have told him to lighten up, either. You'd have just wanted to put a cork in the dike."
Campanelli said: "Well, I did nothing immoral. When you commit a crime, you at least get a trial. All I got was a bullet to the head."
 
The Business of Winning
 The crux of the matter might be that Campanelli, a successful head coach at James Madison from 1972 to 1985 before joining Cal, acted like Knight but did not win like Knight. In his seven previous seasons here, his teams managed only one trip to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.
Also, Campanelli wasn't even aware he had driven such a wedge between him and his players. Last Monday, speaking with Bockrath, he could not even accurately name his allies on the team.
"When I told Lou last Monday he was fired," said Bockrath, who had received reports of player dissatisfaction with the coach for several weeks, "he sat in my office and said: 'Why? Why Bob? Go ask Jason Kidd about me. Go ask Brian Hendrick.' And I'm thinking: 'Lou, if you only knew. Jason and Brian aren't for you.' "
Hendrick is the senior captain of the team, Kidd its star freshman guard.
The discord traces to last season. Players say Campanelli had belittled the 1991-92 team, which finished with a 10-18 record. "We finally tuned him out the last two games and won them both," Alfred Grigsby, a starting forward, recalled Friday.
 
First a Loss, Then the Lunch Boxes
 Cal swept its first five games this season to gain a rare top 25 ranking. Then on Dec. 29, the team lost to James Madison, Campanelli's previous employer. In the locker room, Campanelli swept the team's box lunches off a table and kicked them. According to his players, the coach, who grew up in Springfield, N.J., said, "You have embarrassed me in front of my family," and then refused to ride in the team bus.
"We're like, 'Oh, uh-huh, he can't be with us now that we lost,' " Grigsby said. "And we were like: 'Wow, it's starting again like last year. We're getting the blame for everything.' It should be all of our faults, not just the players' fault."
Campanelli said of the lunch-box incident: "I just knocked them off the table. Come on. After the way we played back there, sure, I was upset."
As a result of Campanelli's explosion at the Meadowlands, the players were listless in a loss to Cornell the next evening. "Nobody wanted to play," Grigsby recalled.
By January, the friction had reached a new level. Although Bockrath didn't know it at the time, Stevie Johnson, who was redshirted as a freshman last season, had called his father in Baltimore and accused Campanelli of what Johnson considered a racist comment.
"I'm not suggesting my son's a saint," said Johnson's father, Leroy, a history professor who commutes to Boston to teach at Northeastern University. "And I don't know what Campanelli's intentions were because I wasn't there, and I don't know if it was intended to be a racist remark. But he told my son before I came out to visit this year: 'Stevie, you better get your dunks in when your father comes, because next year you might be back in Baltimore working in a factory or driving a pickup truck.'
"I got out there and my son was still talking about it. There are other ways to motivate people than to denigrate them."
 
'Gave Love and Care'
 Campanelli recalls the "factory" statement. When told that Stevie Johnson considered it a racial comment, the coach said: "Are you serious? I did everything to help that young man. Spent hours with that young man. Gave love and care. He was flunking out, and I was trying to spur him on. I said: 'What are you going to do when you're back in Baltimore? That's real life.' Stevie laughed."
Leroy Johnson said he has told his son not to discuss the incident. Bockrath said, "Part of Lou's problem is his way of spurring people on was kicking them down."
In a home game on Jan. 30 against Washington State, Cal allowed a 3-point shot at the end of the first half that reduced the Golden Bears' lead to 17. Campanelli berated them during intermission.
"We can take constructive criticism, but not destructive," Grigsby said. "We're up 17. He came in there yelling like we were losing."
Then they did lose that game, by 8 points. In the locker room, Campanelli called Kidd, widely considered the best high school player in the country the year before, a "prima donna."
"You think you know everything about the game," the coach said.
Kidd said last week: "I'm not saying coach wore out his welcome, but his tactics weren't working. We were a plane about to crash and burn, and we could've easily fallen to the cellar."
"Listen," Kidd continued, "Coach Campanelli had nothing to do with my decision to come to Cal. It was the assistant, Todd Bozeman, who got me. If not for Todd, I'm at Kentucky or Kansas."
Bozeman was named last week as Cal's interim head coach.
 
'A Dummy'
 It was also during the Washington State game that Campanelli called Murray, a starting forward, "a dummy" for not stalling when the coach had signaled for a slowdown. "Lamond just didn't see his message from the bench," said Murray's mother, Phora. "Lou pulled him out and called him a dummy in front of the whole team."
A week before the Washington State game, the team had managed to defeat U.C.L.A. by 22 points at Pauley Pavilion, leading observers to believe Cal was in unison. But sophomore forward Monty Buckley said the team was focused in Los Angeles only because the father of freshman Jerod Haase had died two days before.
"We blocked out Coach Campanelli and just played," Grigsby said.
Campanelli said Friday that Bockrath wrote him an encouraging letter after the U.C.L.A. rout, which he claimed made his firing more atrocious. But Bockrath said he simply passed along to the coach a nice letter from a Cal alumnus.
"I just wrote, 'Great game, keep up the good work,' down in the corner of it," said Bockrath. "There was no personal letter from me."
In January, Bockrath had begun to hear snippet accounts of Campanelli's player-bashing. Johnson and reserve guard K. J. Roberts spoke individually to him of the goings-on, and Roberts's father, Ken, called the athletic director as well.
Then, Bockrath heard Campanelli's wrath for himself at Arizona State.
 
Another Partition, More Words
 Bockrath said he contemplated dismissing the coach that night. Then, three days later, on Feb. 7, Cal lost to Arizona, and the athletic director heard Campanelli use more expletives in his post-game speech.
Bockrath listened to the coach through a partition -- "I walked in another wrong door by accident, I'm telling you," he said -- and heard Campanelli issue somewhat of an ultimatum to the team, telling players to "decide where they were going to go from here."
Straight to see Bockrath, as it turned out.
On a bus ride home, the players called a team meeting. Then, in the privacy of their locker room here, they voted to alert the athletic director of their discontent as a group.
"That day, that's when we knew it was time for a change," Grigsby said. "We said if one person didn't agree, then we wouldn't go to the athletic director. But nobody disagreed."
Hendrick, the team captain, alerted Bockrath last Monday that the team wanted to see him. Then Hendrick and Bockrath drove together to meet the rest of the team in the office of Vice Chancellor Daniel Boggan Jr. Ten of the team's 12 players were present, and the two who were not at the meeting -- Kidd and Haase -- told their teammates they would have been there if it had been possible. Kidd was ill that day, and Haase had a class he could not afford to skip.
What the players did not know was that Bockrath had already decided late Sunday night that he would fire Campanelli.
"There's the impression that the players came to me with threats of mutiny and all this kind of thing, which did not happen," Bockrath said. "As a matter of fact, I made the recommendation to dismiss Campanelli Monday morning, and I didn't know about meeting with them until 1 o'clock in the afternoon. I simply listened to them, and all they did was reaffirm in my own mind that what I did was right.
"They did not say that they wanted Lou fired, and they did not threaten to boycott or walk out. None of that happened."
 
Sparing the Censors
 At a news conference that night, Bockrath did not tell reporters he had fired Campanelli because of abusive language.
"I couldn't," he explained. "The TV censors would've had a hard time dealing with the copy if I'd described it."
Instead, Bockrath was initially vague, saying the program was going in the "wrong direction."
So, from afar, considering that Cal then had a 10-7 record (now 12-7 after a rout of Stanford today), the dismissal reeked of dirty pool. The National Association of Basketball Coaches got in touch with Bockrath to investigate.
Also, Campanelli was telling his coaching friends that the 29-year-old Bozeman, his top recruiting assistant coach, had undermined him to gain the interim job.
When Bozeman telephoned Campanelli to deny this, Campanelli refused to talk to him. Campanelli was so incensed that he asked the two other remaining assistants -- Jeff Wulbrun and Eric Hughes -- to resign, but only Wulbrun did. Hughes did not, he said, because he did not believe Bozeman orchestrated a player revolt.
 
A Freeze-Out for Coach?
 Bozeman said he has taken the interim job "because I've got a family to support." Bockrath said Bozeman may face a boycott within the coaching community.
"It has been suggested to Todd that he should bail out or his future in coaching is in jeopardy," Bockrath said. "I'm telling you, Todd had nothing to do with the firing."
Meanwhile, a skeptical Campanelli fumes. "I was fired over abusive language? That's ridiculous," he said. "Ask Brian Hendrick. He was with me five years. Ask Brian Hendrick."
Hendrick, the captain, rounded up later that day, said in a monotone: "Well, Coach was a screamer, to say the least. I'd grown numb to it myself, but it was to the point that the other guys felt it was getting too personal. I'm with them."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Bachrach Joan Mariel Tormey, Geoffrey Milton

 BODY:
Joan Marie Tormey, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James B. Tormey Jr. of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Paul Howard Milton, the son of Alice Milton of Langley, England, and the late Maj. Eric Milton. The Rev. Vincent Biaggi performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Church of St. Thomas More in New York.
Mrs. Tormey-Milton, 37, is a management supervisor, in Jamaica, Queens, for the in-flight services department of Delta Air Lines. She is also a freelance artist. A graduate of Georgetown University, she received a master's degree in painting from the Rosary College Graduate School of Fine Arts at the Villa Schifanoia in Florence. Her father is an obstetrician and gynecologist in Rockville Centre, L.I. 
 Mr. Milton, 45, is the general manager in New York for the Arab Banking Corporation, a bank based in Manama, Bahrain. He graduated from the London School of Economics. His father was a retired British Army officer. . The bridegroom's previous marriage ended in divorce.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 17, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A headline on Monday about the marriage of Geoffrey Milton referred to the bride incorrectly. She is Joan Marie Tormey.

HEADLINE: CLINTON TELLS MIDDLE CLASS IT NOW FACES A TAX INCREASE BECAUSE DEFICIT HAS GROWN

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
For the first time, President Clinton told middle-income Americans tonight that it was necessary to raise their taxes to help cut the deficit and put the nation on the path to prosperity.
Setting aside economic intricacies, Mr. Clinton used plain language in his first televised address from the Oval Office to prepare millions of viewers for the speech he will deliver Wednesday night, when he will lay out his often-painful remedies for the economy to a joint session of Congress. 
 Looking directly into the camera, his hands clasped on his desk as he delivered what he described as "a call to arms," Mr. Clinton delivered a message that was a far cry from the tax relief and other programs he promised in last year's Presidential campaign.
 
More Must Contribute
 "I had hoped to invest in your future by creating jobs, expanding education, reforming health care and reducing the debt without asking more of you," he said.
"But I can't -- because the deficit has increased so much beyond my earlier estimates and beyond even the worst official Government estimates of last year. We just have to face the fact that to make the changes our country needs, more Americans must contribute today so that all Americans can do better tomorrow.
"But I can assure you of this: you're not going alone, you're not going first, and you're no longer going to pay more and get less."
 
Blaming His Predecessors
 Seeking to leaven the blunt warning of sacrifice by taking aim at the wealthy, Mr. Clinton went on to say, "Seventy percent of the new taxes I'll propose -- 70 percent -- will be paid by those who make more than $100,000 a year."
The 10-minute speech was long on atmospherics and an appeal to long-held expectations. "Once, our living standards doubled every 25 years," Mr. Clinton said. "But at the rate we're going today, our living standard won't double for another hundred years, until our grandchildren's grandchildren are born. That's too long."
Mr. Clinton only hinted at the specific sacrifice that middle-class Americans would have to make. Without mentioning his Republican predecessors directly, Mr. Clinton sought to lay blame on those two men, who presided over a deficit that "roared out of control."
"But in the 26 days I've been your President," he added, "I've already learned that here in Washington common sense isn't too common, and you've paid a lot for that loss of common sense."
Seeking to play down the notion that the nation was in an economic recovery, Mr. Clinton noted that more than nine million Americans were still jobless. "If this were a normal recovery," he said, "more than three million would be back at work."
And Mr. Clinton seemed to define anyone who might criticize his plan as part of a "special interest" and questioned the patriotism of those opponents.
"Within minutes of the time I conclude my address to Congress Wednesday night," he said, "the special interests will be out in force." He declared that "every step of the way, they'll oppose it -- many have already lined the corridors of power with high-priced lobbyists."
 
Borrowing From Reagan
 He added, "When I was a boy, we had a name for the belief that we should all pull together to build a better, stronger nation. We called it patriotism, and we still do."
Mr. Clinton was borrowing heavily from the playbook of President Ronald Reagan, who presented his plans for a tax cut to the country in his first address from the Oval Office in 1981 before he gave them to Congress. But the charts Mr. Clinton used to make his points (with deep red for the soaring deficit) could not help but recall Ross Perot, who sometimes overshadowed him during last year's Presidential campaign by his repeated emphasis on taming the deficit through personal sacrifice in homespun talks to voters as he pointed to visual aids.
Asked about Mr. Perot, George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said today that "we'll make sure that that he understands the economic program."
In a response that was taped before the President's speech, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said, "We want to cooperate with President Clinton." But he warned: "We'll be working with you to make certain that 'sacrifice' isn't just a Presidential code word for more taxes, more spending and more mandates from Washington."
Though Mr. Clinton spoke mostly in general terms, many details of the plan have emerged in recent days, including increases in financing for programs like Head Start and a $31 billion package to stimulate the economy in the short term through jobs and public works projects. The most painful part of the program is a long-term effort to curb the deficit with about $500 billion in tax increases and spending cuts over four years.
 
'What He Stands For'
 Although Mr. Clinton had already delivered speeches and two radio addresses on the economy, White House officials said they believed that by speaking directly from the formal setting of the White House the President could most effectively communicate to the public the gravity of the situation and the importance of his economic program. The President has devoted hundreds of hours to line-by-line analysis of economic proposals, but his aides said they did not want him to talk in specifics tonight.
"It was important to establish a context and for Clinton to tell something personal about his values and what he stands for," said Rahm Emanuel, the White House political director. "He wanted to talk about where we are, rather than have people see the economy in a mechanical way."
The President consulted many political and economic advisers about the speech, and as is his way, he was still working on it moments before it was broadcast. It was quite a departure from the last 12 years, when the Oval Office addresses of Mr. Reagan and George Bush were almost always written in enough time to give copies of prepared remarks to reporters before they were delivered.
"He fiddles, he's a fiddler," said one White House adviser who helped fine-tune the speech tonight. "I was in there at 7, and he was still working through it."
Mr. Clinton's talk tonight was a prelude to a week of barnstorming that in turn begins a selling process that will continue as long as it takes for the plan to wend its way through Congress. Continuing his courting of lawmakers, the President had two more White House meetings today with groups of Democrats and has scheduled more meetings for Tuesday. Several lawmakers who have emerged from the sessions said they were generally supportive of the President but would stay noncommittal until they examined the entire economic package.
 
Question Session Possible
 White House officials said they were still considering an offer from Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, that the President appear in the House chambers on Thursday and take questions from lawmakers, much as the British Prime Minister does in Parliament.
White House officials said that Mr. Clinton was leaning toward making the appearance, but that some advisers were divided about the wisdom of such a move. Some were concerned that it would set a precedent, leading members to expect the President to appear in person on other major issues.
On Thursday and Friday, the President has scheduled a speaking tour, stopping first in St. Louis, then Chillicothe, Ohio, and probably Hyde Park, N.Y. The President will fly to the West Coast on Sunday for a two- or three-day trip.
One element of his program is very likely to be an energy tax, and Mr. Clinton suggested today that he was leaning toward something broader than a gasoline tax. He said today that he favored a broad system that would tax each unit of energy, no matter what the source.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Schools: Hobbled and Hurting

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Like the city it is supposed to serve, the Los Angeles public school system is a stricken giant, hobbled by financial problems, a threatened teachers' strike and racial and ethnic strife.
Overcrowded classrooms, leaky roofs, outdated textbooks, metal detectors and police officers patrolling schools are common in America's inner-city schools. 
 But no urban education system has faced as sudden a demographic and economic upheaval as the Los Angeles Unified School District, which serves a city reeling from immigration and recession.
And no other district must solve its problems in the tinderbox atmosphere that prevails here less than a year after rioting revealed the jagged fault lines between rich and poor, white and nonwhite, American born and foreign born in the nation's second-largest city and its suburbs.
 
Diversity vs. Divisiveness
 Volatile issues abound: the impending strike, a debate about dividing the behemoth district and a decision about a superintendent. The timing of these difficulties could not be worse, said John W. Mack, president of the local chapter of the Urban League.
"Diversity has almost become synonymous with divisiveness here," Mr. Mack said. "We don't need any more flash points."
Michael Casserly, executive director of the Council of Great City Schools, a lobbying group in Washington, said that part of the problem in Los Angeles is endemic to urban education. But part, he said, is "the scale of their operation and the complexity and diversity of their student body."
The Los Angeles school district, which sprawls over 708 square miles, includes all or part of 28 cities and, unlike the even larger New York City system, does not have a decentralized structure.
California's fiscal crisis, the most intractable in the nation, has eroded school spending statewide and turned a bellwether system into an also-ran, with spending per student now at $4,187, compared with about $7,300 in New York City. But even compared with other strapped cities in California, the toll has been harsh here, where immigrants, both legal and illegal, have swelled school enrollment to 641,000.
Nowhere is the impact of immigration more evident than in the district's classrooms, which absorbed 45,000 newcomers from 1989 to 1992, an 8 percent increase. Many of these new students are impoverished, illiterate Latin American or Southeast Asian immigrants who have never read a book or worn a pair of shoes and whose special needs are taxing the mostly white teaching corps.
"You feel inadequate if you don't speak another language," said Ed Zschoche, a sixth grade teacher at Gage Middle School. "You're accused of racism if you use discipline."
Even bilingual teachers are under stress. Irene Barillas, a native of El Salvador who teaches at Belmont High School, said, "I thought I would be doing what I learned in college, you know -- 'Let's read a novel.' " She said she empathizes with the white teachers, but added, "Wallowing isn't going to do anybody any good."
 
Still Losing Ground
 In the areas where two, three and four immigrant families live together in inadequate housing, school officials have been unable to keep pace. They have watched class sizes grow to more than 40 in high schools. They have put up portable classrooms, opened schools year round, adopted staggered schedules and bused 16,000 students to the less-crowded San Fernando Valley, clear across a mountain range and nearly two hours away on clogged freeways.
A particularly hard-hit area is Huntington Park, a Hispanic enclave southeast of the city. Within a few blocks of each other are an elementary school with 2,500 students, a middle school with 3,200 and a high school with 3,800 -- a combined student population bigger than most districts in the state.
The huge grade school remains hospitable. But the high school and junior high school are dirty, noisy places. Gail Rolf, a high school health teacher, said her room had not been swept for more than five weeks. And Mr. Zschoche's (pronounced SHOCK-ee) middle school students use rank bathrooms and a library without shelves.
Parents say their children deserve better. "If the place isn't half decent looking, you're not going to do your best work," said Sergio Palos, a printer with five children.
 
Strike Pends This Month
 Facing a 12 percent pay cut, teachers have called a strike for Feb. 23 unless Willie Brown, the shrewd Speaker of the California Assembly, succeeds in his mediation efforts. The cuts in pay and benefits would close half the $400 million gap in the district's $3.9 billion budget and would lower the teachers' salary ranking from first in the nation to seventh. The average teacher in Los Angeles is now paid $38,700, down from $44,000, compared with $41,000 in New York City.
Resentful Los Angeles teachers, who got a 26 percent increase over three years after a 1989 strike, say they are spending less of their own money on classroom supplies and less of their own time tutoring and supervising children. Parents, even those supportive of union demands, are angry.
 
'My Expectations Diminish'
 Students, for their part, seem sympathetic toward the teachers and well-versed in the sad saga of state budget cuts. "The government, they're the ones with the money, and they're hurting us a lot," said Ernesto Fuentes, a senior at Belmont High. "It just makes me not believe in the system. My expectations diminish."
Civic leaders worry that a long strike would coincide with verdicts in two trials related to last spring's riots: the Federal civil rights trial of four white police officers accused of beating a black motorist, Rodney G. King; and the state trial of three black men charged with beating a white truck driver, Reginald O. Denny, during the riots.
When schools were shut down during the April riots, high school and middle school students were among the looters.
Added to this already tense mix is the emotional debate about breaking up the school district.
Leaders of the breakup movement, based in the middle-class San Fernando Valley, argue that the sheer size of the system makes efficient management impossible. Critics, based in Hispanic and black inner-city neighborhoods, counter that dismantling the district would mean de facto segregation, more by class than by race.
 
The 'Black-Brown Thing'
 While black and Hispanic residents generally speak as one on the matter of dividing the district into smaller parts, they will compete fiercely for the superintendent's post. Sidney A. Thompson, who is black, got the job temporarily after the abrupt resignation in October of Bill Anton, the district's first Hispanic leader.
The interim selection of Mr. Thompson stirred up what he and others called the "black-brown thing." And that was only a dress rehearsal for the ultimate sweepstakes, which now includes Joseph A. Fernandez, a noted educational reformer of Hispanic descent who has been dismissed as chancellor of the New York City schools.
Administrators, teachers, parents and students have divided opinions about the strike, the break-up proposals and the search for a superintendent. But they share a sense of alarm about the day-to-day realities in and around their schools.
 
Disturbed, Sad, Embarrassed
 All are disturbed that teen-agers grind metal into weapons in the machine shop at Manual Arts High School because they feel a need to defend themselves in the streets.
All are saddened that the teachers' union locks its supply room during meetings so its members do not steal the paper and pencils that they have run out of at school.
All are embarrassed that deferred maintenance costs for the school buildings have balloonedto $611 million, with painting and roofing on 40-year cycles.
And all are frightened by the violent deaths of two fourth graders at Belvedere Elementary School in the space of a year in a neighborhood that is home to 31 gangs.
But this unanimity breaks down when the subject turns to the ethnic and racial fissures in Los Angeles, America's new port of entry.
 
Cultures in Collision
 Students on lunch break at Belmont High School, virtually all of them Hispanic, segregate themselves according to nationality and length of time in this country. For some reason, only the athletes speak English among themselves.
Some parents and Hispanic activists at Gage Middle School claim that white and black teachers are not suitable educators for their children.
And teachers throughout the district debate whether it is best to celebrate the language and culture of immigrant youngsters or to force them to adopt American ways.
Some complain that they spend more time commemorating Cinco de Mayo, the Vietnamese New Year and Kwanzaa than teaching reading, writing and arithmetic. Others counter that such criticism is sour grapes from those who are not certified to earn the extra $5,000 a year that goes to bilingual instructors.
Some point out that bilingual certification depends on passing a test about Mexican culture and history, with no mention of El Salvador, Nicaragua or other Latin American countries whose citizens have recently flocked here. And others yearn for seminars on how to teach these children or for sabbaticals to attend language school.
To Mike Roos, a former State Assemblyman who was an author of a plan to restructure the Los Angeles schools and whose daughter attends a public high school here, it is the district's ethnic makeup that is so confounding.
"If these were Euro-American kids, regardless of how they were doing, there would be less of a sense that things were going wrong," Mr. Roos said. "We don't know how to reach Salvadoran refugees, Vietnamese boat people, African-Americans whose neighborhoods are full of crack. There is a widening gulf between those of us in charge and the successor generation. We can't relate to their reality."

The New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: People Are Ready for Sacrifices, Poll Finds, and Expect Fairness

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

 BODY:
Although Americans are more judgmental about President Clinton's performance than they were about his two predecessors at this early stage, most remain open to the prospect of dramatic changes in taxing, spending and the way the White House is run, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
While the new President irritated many Americans by giving a lot of attention after his inauguration to the issue of homosexuals in the military, he still has the confidence of most people, who seem ready to make some sacrifices to fix the bedeviling deficit. 
 And in his prime-time television address last night, Mr. Clinton reached out directly to those people, saying the middle class would have to pay more taxes to restore the nation's economic health. In the poll, conducted last week, most Americans said they did think it would be necessary for the Government to increase their taxes, that they expected that it would be done fairly and that they would be willing to postpone any cut in taxes for the middle class.
 
Support for Hillary Clinton
 The poll found that there was applause for the revolutionary role of the First Lady, with 6 out of 10 Americans saying Hillary Rodham Clinton is qualified to head the President's health-care commission and a similar number saying it is appropriate for the President to appoint his wife to that post. By contrast, Vice President Al Gore seems to be suffering from "a Quayle effect," with the number of Americans who hold any opinion about him shrinking substantially since the election.
Although a majority of Americans still think the economy is in bad shape, the proportion who think it is getting better has continued to creep up. The country is still jittery about unemployment, with 40 percent of those polled saying the chances were high that an adult in their family would be out of work and looking for a job in the next 12 months. By comparison, in April 1991, in the afterglow of the Persian Gulf war, only 22 percent expressed that same anxiety.
"We own two small hardware stores, and times are tough," said Nancy Bowald, 30, a mother of four from Eureka, Ill., one of a number of people called for a follow-up interview to the poll. "I don't know if Clinton will cut the deficit or turn around the economy, but I'm optimistic that he's trying. He's not just in there to push a bunch of buttons and play at being powerful."
Sixty-seven percent of those polled said job creation should be even more of an immediate priority than deficit reduction for the new Administration.
The new poll, which included 1,154 respondents nationwide interviewed by telephone Feb. 9-11, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
Asked to Give More
 In his speech from the Oval Office, the President warned the majority of Americans, "those of you who gave the most in the 1980's," that higher taxes were coming. He said that while 70 percent of his new taxes would come from people making more than $100,000 a year, the remaining 30 percent would be from the bulk of the population with incomes below that.
The poll suggests that he was speaking to a receptive population.
Mr. Clinton said he was taking the difficult steps because the Federal deficit was so much worse than he thought during the Presidential campaign. In the poll, two-thirds of Americans said that if the President was to back out of campaign promises it would be because he discovered that problems were worse than he had thought.
A 54 percent majority said they expected it would be necessary to increase their taxes to reduce the deficit, and 56 percent said they expected that any tax increases would be carried out in a way that was fair to people like them.
 
Generosity Has Limits
 During his campaign, Mr. Clinton promised to cut taxes for the middle class, but the poll found that 7 in 10 Americans said they would be willing to delay such a cut to help reduce the deficit.
But while the public seems more receptive now to the idea of paying more taxes to cut the deficit, its generosity has limits.
In 1990, 47 percent of the respondents in a Times/CBS News poll said they would be willing to pay $100 more a year in Federal taxes to reduce the deficit, but in the latest poll, that percentage jumped to 58 percent.
When asked if they were willing to pay $500 more a year in taxes to reduce the deficit, however, the percentage who said yes melted to 14.
 
Energy Tax Unpopular
 And Americans are touchy about the kinds of taxes they are willing to accept, with an energy tax getting thumbs down from 57 percent of those polled compared with 41 percent who gave it thumbs up.
While any meddling with Social Security has long been viewed as political suicide, nearly half the respondents supported increasing the portion of benefits subject to tax.
The debates over taxes and Social Security seem not to have hurt Mr. Clinton. Fifty-three percent of Americans approved of the way he has been handling his job as President, while 30 percent disapproved and 17 percent expressed no opinion.
That level of approval is about the same as the 55 percent Ronald Reagan had in a February 1981 Gallup poll and a bit lower than the 61 percent rating George Bush earned in a February 1989 Times/CBS News poll.
 
Disapproval Is Higher
 But opinion seems to be solidifying or crystallizing sooner for Mr. Clinton than for recent past Presidents. His level of disapproval is markedly higher than those of his predecessors: Mr. Reagan had just 18 percent disapproval in his first act, and Mr. Bush had only 9 percent.
Unlike Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush, who won a majority of the popular vote, Mr. Clinton entered office with much more fractured support, since a majority of voters in November preferred either George Bush or Ross Perot.
In his debut months, Mr. Reagan was talking tax cuts, not tax increases. And because Mr. Bush did little of substance in his first 100 days, there were few major initiatives to stir up the public, one way or another.
What is striking about Mr. Clinton is that while he still has a cache of good will, people seem to be taking sides for or against him at a faster pace than they usually do. Both Mr. Bush and Mr. Reagan had a much higher proportion of people reserving judgment about their performance at this stage.
 
Misplaced Emphasis Is Seen
 No single event or theme jumped out in terms of what people liked best about the new President so far. Mr. Clinton received spontaneous praise from 9 percent of respondents for being a leader who cared about the people, from 8 percent for cutting the White House staff and from 5 percent for passage of the family-leave bill. His more liberal stance toward homosexuals, including his push to allow them to serve in the military, was also volunteered in a positive way by 5 percent.
When asked what they liked least about what Mr. Clinton had done so far as President, one answer swamped all the others: 31 percent spontaneously cited homosexuals in the military, with respondents upset by the priority and prominence given to the issue by Mr. Clinton, as well as by the issue itself.
"Let's be honest -- Clinton has a bunch of issues on his plate," said Scott Dunbar, 38, a salesman from Naperville, outside Chicago. "We have world hunger, terrorism, kids shooting each other in the inner city, the deficit, education, and the very first priority is getting gays in the military? He's not doing much of a job taking the pulse of the people."
Only 5 percent of the respondents mentioned being disappointed by the "clatter of campaign promises being cast off," as Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, put it, and another 5 percent mentioned the Administration's clunky efforts to find an Attorney General.
 
'Business as Usual'?
 A majority indicated that they were less than inspired by Mr. Clinton's appointments so far: 24 percent said Mr. Clinton had brought people with higher standards of conduct and public service to Washington, but twice as many, 53 percent, said the new people were just like all the rest.
"Lloyd Bentsen? More business as usual," said Steve Smiley, 40, the vice president of operations of a manufacturing company who lives in Mequon, a suburb of Milwaukee.
Nancy Bowald of Eureka gave the President a better grade: "I think he's trying for a higher standard, not the same old rich, elite silver spoons."
While 35 percent said that the women nominated for high office by Mr. Clinton have been subject to stricter standards than the men, 51 percent said there was not much difference. There was a gender gap on this issue, with 41 percent of the women seeing a stricter standard being applied compared with 28 percent of the men who saw that.
 
On Illegal Aliens
 On the issue of "Nannygate," 18 percent said they knew someone who at some time employed an illegal alien. But Americans were narrowly split on whether this should disqualify a person from high office: 44 percent said yes, while 47 percent said no.
Nineteen percent said someone in their household might at some time have paid domestic help $50 or more in a three-month period without paying Social Security taxes. And a majority, 54 percent, was eager for a change in the law requiring Social Security taxes to be paid even for occasional baby sitters and cleaning people.
Mrs. Clinton's use of her family name, her high profile in a West Wing previously dominated by the old boys' network and her lobbying on Capitol Hill have not yet produced the slings and arrows predicted by Republicans for the first career woman in the White House. She received a 45 percent favorable rating and 18 percent unfavorable one. By contrast, Barbara Bush premiered with a 34 percent favorable rating and a 3 percent unfavorable one, and initial readings for Nancy Reagan were 28 percent favorable and 10 percent unfavorable.
"I think it's really neat that Hillary has her own office and something of her own to do," said Jane Browning, 30, a waitress at the Leaf & Ladle in Columbus, Ohio. "They do share the same bedroom at night, so they can work out any differences privately rather than have them documented in memos that can later be leaked to the press."
Jewel Hutson, the 67-year-old owner of the Downtown Diner in Antlers, Okla., where the special is smothered steak, creamed potatoes and a salad bar for $3.75, took a more traditional view. "I think Clinton should have waited a while before he really threw Hillary at the people," she said. "There's a lot of talk around here in Antlers. They love First Ladies, but the want them kind of behind the President, not in front."
 
Silver Lining in Obscurity
 In the Incredible Shrinking Vice President category: In October, only 14 percent of registered voters said they did not know enough about Al Gore to express an opinion. That rose to 33 percent in January and to 44 percent in the latest poll. Dan Quayle suffered a similar disappearing phenomenon, going from 16 percent who said they did not know enough to express a view about him in October 1988 to 47 percent a little more than a year later.
There is, however, a silver lining for Mr. Gore. Those who had an opinion were, on balance, positive: 32 percent expressed a favorable view, while only 12 percent were unfavorable. By contrast, Mr. Quayle's negative rating remained higher than his positive throughout the Bush Administration.
 
How the Poll Was Taken

The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 9 to 11 with 1,154 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups of the population the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for black respondents it is plus or minus 10 percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: Traveling High-Tech Agents Help Update Small Factories

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DORNSIFE, Pa.

 BODY:
High technology arrived here one recent morning in a silver Volkswagen van with 107,000 miles on the odometer and James Bodnar at the wheel.
Mr. Bodnar, an engineer, and his partner, Zane Patalive, a computer specialist, turned up at Keim's Machine and Tool Company to tinker with Dave Keim's computer-operated lathe and one of Bill Clinton's industrial policy goals. 
 Like the agricultural extension agents who take their expertise up and down the dusty roads of America's farm country, the two men travel with similar intent. They respond to pleas for help from small manufacturers in the hills and valleys of central Pennsylvania who are trying to get more out of their computers, their production equipment and their workers.
 
 
A Possible Model
 The two are in the business of rendering technical assistance, and what they do is low key at this point. But government officials are looking closely at their program and others like it, seeking models for a high-stakes Federal and state effort to eke more productivity out of the small manufacturers who are so important in the food chain of American competitiveness.
On this afternoon, however, Washington seems very far away from Keim's Machine and Tool Company. Operating in the service area of a defunct Chevrolet dealership by the side of a lightly traveled road, Keim's embodies the "small" in small business. Mr. Keim has one full-time shop worker and two part-timers on his payroll. His wife, Nancy, manages the two-desk office that is one symbol of the company's progress. Until last year, when the office and the shop shared the same space, Mrs. Keim had to shout "turn off the machines" whenever the telephone rang.
The company produces precision parts that go into industrial tools and is what industrial analysts call a foundation firm -- one of the 360,000 or so small and medium-sized manufacturers that are the supply base for major corporations.
What has been troubling Mr. Keim is the single computer-controlled lathe that sits in his shop of mostly manually operated machine tools. The Hitachi Seiki lathe can automatically turn out parts following the instructions of a program, and Mr. Keim has taught himself how to write computer code to instruct it. But the controller's memory is so small that producing new parts requires Mr. Keim to kill out programming covering old parts. He does not want to do that in case customers reorder old parts. So he has called in Mr. Bodnar and Mr. Patalive to help him figure out a way to transfer the programming onto a high-capacity disk drive on his office computer.
The two men work for the Industrial Modernization Center Inc., a state-backed consulting and training firm in Williamsport, near here. It is one of eight not-for-profit corporations established by the State of Pennsylvania to provide hands-on services to small and medium-sized companies that probably could not afford private consultants, even if they knew the right ones to call.
Although many states offer some form of technological assistance to small manufacturers, only about a dozen provide the services of field representatives who, like agricultural extension agents, call on manufacturers and offer help. Besides Pennsylvania, they are Georgia, Indiana, Iowa, Maryland, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, South Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia, according to a compilation by the National Governors Association.
 
 
State Connection Played Down
 Given the suspicion that many small-business people have about government, the state connection is not heavily advertised. "If I showed up with a business card saying, 'I'm from the state and I'm here to help you,' I'd get tossed out on my ear," said one technical extension agent in another state.
Mr. Bodnar and Mr. Patalive bring technical credentials and practical operating experience to their clients. Mr. Bodnar is an industrial engineer with an M.B.A. degree, who spent 19 years in the steel industry before joining the center about four years ago. Mr. Patalive has a degree in computer science and worked as a consultant to I.M.C. and others before joining the staff early this year.
When they arrive, Mr. Keim does not mince words.
"We want to go from an all-manual operation to computerized without hiring a lot of computer people," he said. In addition to linking the office computer with the automated lathe, he wants to harness the computer's power to keep books and analyze the business.
"I want software to keep track of shop time so I can know which jobs are profitable," he said. "I want to know where to raise my prices and where to lower them."
Mr. Bodnar offers the services of I.M.C.'s demonstration center in Williamsport, where there are computers and software packages that Mr. Keim can test before buying. Mr. Patalive said he could start with a program called Shoptimizer, developed by the Industrial Software Company of East Providence, R.I., for operations like Keim's.
The ability to use computers effectively is one of the two great divides that separate old-fashioned, mostly small, manufacturing operations from those that are at the forefront of technology, said Robert W. Vandine, the executive director of I.M.C. The other is the ability to reorganize and retrain workers so they become participants in factory operations, rather than just automatons. If American manufacturers do not improve technology and workplace organization, they will not be able to compete internationally, he said.
 
 
Speaking From Experience
 "I feel passionately about this," he said, his own history coming through. In an earlier job, he had been manager of Bethlehem Steel's wire rope plant in Williamsport -- until the company was driven out of the business by imports.
"One of our major goals has been the development of understandable packages of computer-based technology," Mr. Vandine said. Most small manufacturers, he said, are too busy pushing products out the door -- to keep the cash flowing in -- to fight their way through the software jungle.
But their need for that equipment is evident. Small and medium-sized manufacturers are 25 percent less productive than big companies, a 1990 Census Bureau study found, largely because they are half as likely to use computer-controlled equipment.
Although strict free-market advocates will probably scream, the Clinton Administration plans to stimulate job and economic growth by increasing the technical assistance available to manufacturers. It is backing legislation that would expand the existing seven technology assistance centers operated by the National Institutes of Standards and Technology to a nationwide network of 170. Financing would grow from a modest $17 million this year to $150 million in the 1994 fiscal year.
Legislation to expand the network was passed in different forms by both houses of Congress last year -- without Bush Administration support -- but died before the House and Senate versions could be sorted out. Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, chairman of the Commerce Committee, has pledged early action this year.
"One of the functions will be to support state technical extension services," said Philip Nanzetta, director of the Manufacturing Extension Partnership of the National Institutes.
The various centers work in different ways. In Pennsylvania, recognizing that cutting and bending metal is a way of life in the central part of the state, Mr. Bodner's Industrial Modernization Center focuses on helping companies in those businesses. It helped PMF Industries, a company that forms stainless-steel products, with training in statistical process control to improve quality. Playworld Systems, which makes playground equipment in New Berlin, got help in converting hard-to-understand engineering drawings into renderings for sales pitches.
But that's not all the center does. In a gesture to the small cut-and-sew apparel operations that dot the area as well, it has bought automated machinery to generate the large paper markers used to guide cutters. Robert Cross, the president of Equinox Ltd., which makes camping equipment, said the center gave him access to equipment he could not afford on his own.
A Pennsylvania grant of $688,000 for the year allows Mr. Vandine to keep the prices of his five consultants' services down. "If it's a qualified project, for every $1 I collect from the client, I'll get 25 cents from the state grant," he said. He said the need to hustle business kept the center entrepreneurial and more attuned to the needs of the region than more formalized state programs would be.
At Keim's, the two technology agents and Mr. Keim walk out into the shop to take a closer look at the troublesome machine. Mr. Keim makes it clear he is thinking beyond a single used 1986-vintage lathe. "We need to develop more computer-controlled machinery in here," he said. "That's the way manufacturing is going in the United States."
Hence the problem.
"If I go to Hitachi Seiki, they will want to sell me a box to put on this machine," he said, referring to a specialized data storage unit. That would probably work well enough, but would not meet his goal of writing instructions in the office while the machine is operating and then quickly loading them to begin a new production run as soon as the previous one is finished. "You have no idea how much time that would save," he said.
Nor would it help control the other machines he hopes to add. Mr. Patalive closely eyes the lines of code displayed on the lathe's control unit and pronounces the problem solvable. The control unit has a cable port to connect with the office computer. Now all he must do is find software that will allow the two units to talk to each other.
 
 
A Proposed Solution
 A few weeks later he is ready to write a proposal for Mr. Keim. He has found software that will link the office computer to the lathe for about $500 plus a $250 installation fee. But he hopes to persuade him to spend a total of $1,000 for added programming that will let him simulate the cutting paths of tools on a computer screen to speed operations and to control multiple machines -- a strategy even more advanced than Mr. Keim thought possible.
Mr. Patalive said he would negotiate with the software supplier to get a fixed price for Mr. Keim, instead of the costs-plus-expenses formula the vendor prefers. I.M.C. does not charge a fee for its consultants' first visit, and is paid modestly for services rendered, like the software installation.
As for Mr. Keim's problem, Mr. Bodner considered it straightforward, easy to solve -- and typical.
"A lot of people have bought a computer and some software because they have been told they need one," he said, "but they do not know how to use them. That's where we can add some value."

HEADLINE: FEUDS AND KILLINGS IN NICARAGUA MAR DEMOCRATIC RULE

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Three years after President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro defeated the Sandinistas in elections, Nicaragua has fallen into a tangle of crises that are spreading fear of an upsurge in violence.
Despite Government efforts to pacify the countryside, unsolved killings with political overtones occur almost daily in the explosive northwest, scene of most of the fighting during the civil war. There, a dozen or more armed bands, mostly disgruntled former anti-Sandinista rebels or their families, are hunted alternately by the Army, which is still under Sandinista control, and by Government negotiators. 
 The latest threats to peace coincide with corruption charges against Mrs. Chamorro's Government and seemingly intractable political differences that have led to a rupture between Mrs. Chamorro and the political leaders who helped put her in office.
 
'We Can't Get Along'
 Resentment also still runs high among non-Sandinistas about the influence -- and at times the dominance -- that the Sandinistas exert throughout the Army and the Government.
"Unfortunately, we Nicaraguans can't get along, and we are doing our best to destroy Nicaragua," said Ramiro Gurdian, a banana grower who is president of Cosep, an influential group of business executives.
Frank Lanzas, the Mayor of Matagalpa, near the most unsettled area, said, "Family and personal feuds prevent the Government from dealing with the problems; everyone is always thinking about how to neutralize his opponents."
Unhappy with the growing influence of the Sandinistas, the Bush Administration last year suspended $104 million in aid to Nicaragua. About half was released toward the end of last year.
The Clinton Administration, which still lacks a chief policymaker for Latin America, has yet to address the issue of releasing the other half and risks a confrontation in Congress, where many Republicans and Democrats are critical of the continued Sandinista influence. The critics also want Nicaragua to move faster to resolve claims of people whose property was confiscated in the Sandinista period.
 
When Hopes Were High . . .
 Hopes for stability were high when accords were signed three years ago allowing 22,000 anti-Sandinista rebels, known as contras, and their families to return from Honduras, give up their arms and resettle in their home areas with assistance from the Organization of American States.
In return, the Sandinista Government of Daniel Ortega Saavedra held elections under international inspection.
Although most former contras have accepted the resettlement package, negotiators have had to deal with armed groups of contras who are dissatisfied with the settlement program or fear persecution. The O.A.S. says 173 former contras have been killed since July 1990. Most cases are unresolved, but a recent study of 10 deaths traced all of them to the Army or to other Sandinista-controlled groups.
 
Assessing the Chance of War
 Government officials, particularly Antonio Lacayo, Mrs. Chamorro's chief minister and son-in-law, see less potential for new warfare than do their critics outside the executive branch, but they do not deny that their political dreams are turning into nightmares.
For example Alfred Cesar, the recently ousted president of the National Assembly, said in an interview that he saw "the real possibility of the reinitiation of war." He cited recent conversations with former contras who, he said, felt they had nothing to lose in taking up arms again.
While saying that he thought a new war would gain nothing, Mr. Cesar added that if war came again, it would be "an autonomous guerrilla war directed by regional peasant leaders" without foreign backing and with no inclination to obey national figures.
The Government estimates the number of armed contras at about 700; a foreign diplomat who closely follows the pacification process estimated them at "550 and growing."
 
It's the Economy, Senora
 Mr. Lacayo says many problems with the former contras and the almost equally dissatisified ex-Sandinista soldiers are a result of the economic disaster inherited by the Government after more than a decade of Sandinista rule and civil war.
William Baez, an active critic of the Sandinistas who was recently appointed to the new post of Minister of Social Action, said Nicaragua was in a more difficult situation than the rest of Central America because "besides having had a war, we are changing from socialism to market capitalism -- a more dramatic change."
Unemployment is 40 percent, there is almost no investment, exports are a fraction of what they were in the 1970's and the country lives on foreign aid.
There are a few encouraging signs: the economic stabilization program that Mr. Lacayo started two years ago to halt runaway inflation is still working. But the Government says it needs a resumption of United States aid to keep the program going.
 
And Corruption, Too
 Mrs. Chamorro's Government is also beset by corruption charges, a complete break with the coalition that once backed her and a constitutional crisis brought on when she intervened at the National Assembly and ordered the election of her own leaders.
Early this month, the National Opposition Union, which ran Mrs. Chamorro for President in 1990, formally declared itself in opposition to the Government, accusing Mrs. Chamorro of abandoning her commitment to government by consultation. The next election is due in late 1996, but with the current turmoil, it is not even clear now what coalitions will form.
The rupture culminated a long-running dispute over corruption investigations and how to satisfy property claims by 6,000 people whose holdings were confiscated by the Sandinistas. Another source of contention was the Government's susceptibility to the influence of the Sandinistas, particularly its retention of Gen. Humberto Ortega as head of the Army.
 
A Particular Killing
 The National Opposition Union and many other non-Sandinista groups were also embittered by the killing of Arges Sequeira Mangas, who defended people seeking the return of confiscated property, and by the subsequent identification of three former army and police officers as the killers.
Mr. Sequeira was shot dead last November by three men who walked up to him while he was talking with workers on his farm in Leon. With technical help from the Spanish Government and a witness willing to testify, the police quickly identified the alleged killers, but no arrests have been announced.
The rebellion by Mrs. Chamorro's allies has left her largely dependent on the Sandinistas to govern. But the Sandinistas, most of whom support state control of the economy and class warfare, are unlikely to be reliable votes for a President who seeks free markets and respect for private property.
 
Accusations of Vote-Buying
 The Sandinistas are able to form a majority with a small group of breakaway legislators from Mrs. Chamorro's former coalition, though the National Opposition Union says the renegades were bribed by people working for Mr. Lacayo, the chief minister.
The ouster of the former Controller General, Guillermo Potoy, was a response to his efforts to investigate the allegations of bribery. The alleged corruption has been linked specifically to a former vice minister, Antonio Ibarra, who has since fled to Bolivia.
In interviews from Bolivia published and broadcast here, Mr. Ibarra has leveled a nonstop barrage of charges at Mr. Lacayo, claiming among other things that he ordered or suggested payoffs. Mr. Lacayo, in an interview last week, refused to respond directly to the allegation.
Mr. Lacayo was Mr. Ibarra's immediate superior, and after Mr. Potoy failed to obtain access to some of the minister's files as part of the investigation, Mr. Potoy invoked his independent powers to tell Mrs. Chamorro to dismiss Mr. Lacayo.
 
Antonio Stays, Guillermo Goes
 But Mr. Lacayo did not budge; Mrs. Chamorro, who has relied on Mr. Lacayo to run the Government, has stood by what she said when the bribe accusations first surfaced in mid-1992: "If Antonio goes, Violeta goes."
So Guillermo Potoy went. Earlier this year, Mr. Lacayo used the new majority of Sandinistas and the renegades from Mrs. Chamorro's coalition to remove the Controller General.
The political crisis is further fed by an undercurrent of struggles within and between families, which are a staple of Nicaraguan politics. Many Nicaraguans call the struggle "The War of the Brothers-in-Law" because it involves Mr. Lacayo and two of his brothers-in-law, three ambitious, fortyish men from families accustomed to power, each dreaming of becoming President someday.
For example Mr. Cesar, whom Mr. Lacayo ousted as president of the Assembly, is the husband of one of his sisters. And Mrs. Chamorro's elder son, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, also weighs in against Mr. Lacayo from his post as assistant editor of La Prensa, the family newspaper. With Mr. Lacayo's wife, Cristiana Chamorro, holding another high-level post at the newspaper, La Prensa often seems to have a split personality.
 
Cesar's Allies Ousted
 An outgrowth of the feud between Mr. Lacayo and Mr. Cesar has been the removal from high-level Government posts of most of the people politically close to Mr. Cesar.
But one Government official suggests a longer-term view to help explain today's woes.
"There's always been a pendulum swinging here," he said. "In the early years, when the Liberal Party won a war or an election, the Conservatives had to leave the country. When the Conservatives won, it was the Liberals who had to leave. Then when the Sandinistas took power, the bourgeoisie had to leave or lie low.
"Now, for the first time, we are all trying to live together in the same country."

HEADLINE: Dollar Mixed in Limited Trading Overseas

BYLINE: The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against leading currencies yesterday, while European stocks languished and United States Government bonds rose slightly in limited activity overseas.
Markets in the United States were closed for the observance of Washington's Birthday, which affected many foreign dealers who usually take their cues from their counterparts in the United States. 
 Foreign market participants were also reluctant to trade heavily yesterday ahead of United States economic data due later this week and President Clinton's speech last night previewing his plan for the economy. Details of the economic stimulus package will be disclosed in an address to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday.
The dollar began its holiday-shortened trading day in Tokyo by rising 0.70 yen from Friday, to close at 121.15 yen. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 129.95 yen. The British pound was unchanged at $1.4180 in late London trading.
Other late rates for the dollar in Europe, compared with Friday's late quotes, included: 1.6587 German marks, down from 1.6615; 1.5410 Swiss francs, down from 1.5415; 5.6108 French francs, down from 5.6225; 1.8682 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8705; 1,551.00 Italian lire, up from 1,547.00, and 1.2531 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2551.
Prices were mixed on the London Stock Exchange in light trading. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index was up 2.9 points, or 0.1 percent, at 2,845.9, and the 30-stock index rose 0.2 points, to close at 2,187.8. The 500-stock index finished up 1.85 points, or 0.1 percent, at 1,523.68.
In Paris, the CAC-40 index drifted down 12.48 points, to finish at 1,899.49 points.
In foreign trading of United States Treasury securities, the bellwether 30-year bond added 1/4 point, or $2.50 per $1,000 in face amount, while its yield declined to 7.10 percent, down from 7.12 percent in New York on Friday.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities traded on foreign markets, short-term maturities were unchanged to up 1/16 point, while intermediate securities gained 3/32 point to 5/32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $328.55 an ounce, from $328.35 late Friday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $328.30, from $328.50 Friday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.74, to close at $329.36.
Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $3.68 an ounce, from $3.70.

Stocks Lower in Japan
 TOKYO, Feb. 16 (Reuters) -- Stocks ended lower here today on arbitrage selling and profit-taking, with the Nikkei index of 225 issues falling below the psychological barrier of 17,000. Brokers said that buying by public pension funds was likely to limit further declines.
The Nikkei fell 201.67 points, or 1.18 percent, to 16,916.32, shedding most of its 266.48-point gain on Monday. An estimated 220 million shares were traded.
"It has been fairly predictable recently that, when the market rises one day, it falls the next day," one analyst said.
In Hong Kong this morning, stocks continued to gain after soaring on Monday amid speculation that China was ready to start discussing the colony's political future after months of bitter deadlock.
The blue-chip Hang Seng index jumped 67.71 points, or 1.12 percent, to 6,117.15, and the broader All Ordinaries index gained 25.70 to 3,248.23.
The Hang Seng had surged more than 200 points Monday afternoon before slipping slightly near the close of trading.
Brokers said the scramble began after local newspapers reported that Beijing, which regains control over Hong Kong in 1997, was ready to drop its demand that Chris Patten, the Governor of the British colony, must scrap his democratic reform proposals before any talks can begin.
