HEADLINE: Transcript of President's Address on the Economy

 BODY:
Following is President Clinton's address on the economy last night, as transcribed by The New York Times:
Good evening. I have chosen this day on which we honor two great Presidents to talk with you about the serious problems and the great promise of our country, and the absolute necessity for change if we're to secure a better future for ourselves and for our children. 
 On Wednesday evening, I'll address the Congress about the specifics of my plan, but first I turn to you for your strength and support, to enlist you in the cause of changing our course.
This is a momentous time for our nation. We stand at the end of the cold war and on the edge of the 21st century. For two decades, we've moved steadily toward a global economy in which we must compete with people around the world, a world which requires us to work hard and smart, a world in which putting people first is more than a political slogan -- it's a philosophy of governing and the only path to prosperity.
For 12 years, we followed a very different philosophy. It declared that Government is the problem, that fairness to the middle class is less important than keeping taxes low on the wealthy, that Government can do nothing about our deepest problems -- lost jobs, declining wages, increasing inequality, inadequate educational opportunity and a health-care system that costs a fortune but does too little.
During those 12 years, as Governor of Arkansas I followed a very different course, more like what you've done at home and at work. I invested in the future of our people and balanced the state budget with honesty and fairness and without gimmicks. It's just common sense.
But in the 26 days I've been your President, I've already learned that here in Washington common sense isn't too common and you've paid a lot for that loss of common sense. The typical middle-class family is working harder for less. Despite the talk of a recovery, more than nine million of our fellow citizens are still out of work. And as this chart indicates, if this were a real, normal recovery, three million more Americans would already be back at work by now.
In fact, there are more jobless people now than there were at what the experts call the bottom of this recession.
 
The Deficit's Effect

All during this last 12 years, the Federal deficit has roared out of control. Look at this -- the big tax cuts for the wealthy, the growth in Government spending and soaring health-care costs all caused the Federal deficit to explode. Our debt is now four times as big as it was in 1980. That's right. In the last 12 years, we've piled up four times as much debt as in the previous 200.
Now, if all that debt had been invested in strengthening our economy we'd at least have something to show for our money: more jobs, better educated people, a health-care system that works. But as you can see, while the deficit went up, investments in the things that make us stronger and smarter, richer and safer were neglected: less invested in education, less in our children's future, less in transportation, less in local law enforcement.
An awful lot of that money was just wasted. This matters. When you don't invest in jobs and education and economic opportunity, unemployment goes up and our incomes go down. And when the deficit gets bigger and bigger and bigger, the Government takes more of your money just for interest payments, and then it's harder for you to borrow money for your own business or to afford a new home or to send a child to college.
That's exactly what's been happening. Once, our living standards doubled every 25 years. But at the rate we're going today, our living standard won't double for another hundred years, until our grandchildren's grandchildren are born. That's too long.
We must act now to restore the American dream. Despite the enormity of this crisis, believe it or not, the status quo still has its defenders: people who point to hopeless statistics like the recent increase in productivity and consumer confidence and say we should do nothing.
Well, American business has been forced to become more competitive in this global economy. And I'm glad that consumer confidence is up since the election, but we're not generating jobs or making headway on these other long-term problems.
My message to you is clear: The price of doing the same old thing is far higher than the price of change.
After all, that's why you sent me here: not to keep this seat warm but to work for fundamental change, to make Washington work for all Americans, not just the special interests, and to chart a course that will enable us to compete and win in this new world.
 
More Cuts and More Taxes
 Here's the challenge I will offer the Congress and the country on Wednesday. We'll invest in our future by nurturing our children and supporting their education, by rewarding work and family, by creating the jobs of the future and training our people to fill them. Our every effort will reflect what President Franklin Roosevelt called "bold, persistent experimentation," a willingness to stay with things that work and stop things that don't.
Change must begin at the top. That's why I cut the White House staff by 25 percent and ordered Federal agencies to cut billions of dollars in administrative costs and to trim 100,000 Federal positions by attrition.
And in my budget there'll be more than 150 specific cuts in Government spending programs. Then, I'll ask the wealthiest Americans to pay their fair share.
That brings us to those of you who gave the most in the 1980's. I had hoped to invest in your future by creating jobs, expanding education, reforming health care and reducing the debt without asking more of you. And I've worked harder than I've ever worked in my life to meet that goal.
But I can't -- because the deficit has increased so much beyond my earlier estimates and beyond even the worst official Government estimates from last year. We just have to face the fact that to make the changes our country needs, more Americans must contribute today so that all Americans can do better tomorrow.
But I can assure you of this: You're not going alone anymore. You're not going first and you're no longer going to pay more and get less.
Seventy percent of the new taxes I'll propose -- 70 percent -- will be paid by those who make more than $100,000 a year and, for the first time in more than a decade, we're all in this together.
More important, here's the payoff: Our comprehensive plan for economic growth will create millions of long-term, good-paying jobs, including a program to jump-start our economy with another 500,000 jobs in 1993 and 1994.
And as we make deep cuts in the existing Government programs, we'll make new investments where they'll do the most good: incentives to business to create new jobs, investments in education and training, special efforts for displaced defense workers, a fairer tax system to insure that parents who work full time will no longer raise their children in poverty, welfare reforms to move people from welfare to work, vaccinations and Head Start opportunities for all children who need them and a system of affordable, quality health care for all Americans.
Our national service plan will throw open the doors of college opportunity to the daughters and sons of the middle class and then we'll challenge them to give something back to our country as teachers, police officers, community service workers taking care of our own right here at home. And we'll do it all while reducing our debt.
 
Calling for Support
 Change this fundamental will not be easy nor will it be quick, but at stake is the control of our economic destiny.
Within minutes of the time I conclude my address to Congress Wednesday night, the special interests will be out in force. Those who profited from the status quo will oppose the changes we seek -- the budget cuts, the revenue increases, the new investment priorities. Every step of the way they'll oppose it. Many have already lined the corridors of power with high-priced lobbyists.
They are the defenders of decline, and we must be the architects of the future. I'm confident in our cause, because I believe in America. And I know we have learned the hard lessons of the 1980's.
This is your country. You demonstrated the power of the people in the last election. I urge you to stay informed and to stay involved. If you're vigilant and vocal, we can do what we have to do.
On this Presidents' Day, we recall the many times in our history when past Presidents have challenged this nation from this office in times of crisis.
If you will join with me, we can create an economy in which all Americans work hard and prosper. This is nothing less than a call to arms to restore the vitality of the American dream.
When I was a boy, we had a name for the belief that we should all pull together to build a better, stronger nation. We called it patriotism and we still do.
Good night and God bless America.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
 
 President Clinton used plain language to appeal directly to the American public to support the tax increases and spending cuts he proposes. In his first televised address from the Oval Office, Mr. Clinton seemed to be preparing millions of viewers for the speech he will deliver tomorrow, when he will lay out to a joint session of Congress his often painful remedies for the economy. [A1.] 
 Most Americans remain open to President Clinton's changes in taxing, spending and the way the White House is run, according to a New York Times/CBS News opinion poll. [A1.]
President Clinton's health-care reform was to have balanced regulation and free-market competition. But so far, Federal health policy seems to emphasize price regulation. [A14.]
A Pennsylvania program to help small manufacturers eke out more productivity is being considered by the Federal Government as a model for larger efforts. [A1.]
California is considering a new system of car insurance that drivers would pay for through gasoline fees, so the cost would depend more heavily on how much they drive. [A12.]
Joint ventures by private companies and Federal laboratories shifting away from weapons development have been hobbled by bureacratic infighting and opposition in some industries. [D1.]
 
Companies
Xerox has been one of the most aggressive and innovative large companies pursuing lower health-care costs. But it continues to face jumps in health costs that it considers unacceptable. [D1.]
Sales of motor vehicles built in North America rose 6.3 percent in early February. While car sales were down 2.7 percent, truck sales were up 20.6 percent for the seven companies reporting. [D2.]
I.B.M. will introduce a series of more powerful minicomputers and software products today, hoping to rejuvenate its sagging midrange computer business. [D2.]
New problems are brewing for Steven Hoffenberg, the potential buyer of The New York Post. Shawmut Bank, a trustee for $200 million in bonds in Mr. Hoffenberg's company, Towers Financial, is said to be seeking an accounting of bondholders' money. [B3.]
 
International
Adidas is being taken over by a group that includes Robert Louis-Dreyfus, who for the last three years has helped stabilize Saatchi & Saatchi, the giant British advertising company. [D1.]
Japanese electronics companies are discussing digital VCR's, which would use computer technology to provide clearer pictures than existing VCR's, much like digital compact disks offer music free of the hisses and pops of conventional records. [D2.]
OPEC is close to reaching an accord to cut output and stabilize oil prices. At talks in Vienna, a major hurdle was cleared when Kuwait agreed to rejoin the group's output quota system. [D6.]
 
Markets
Interest rates on 30-year Treasury bonds could fall to 7 percent or lower if the credit markets believe that President Clinton can really cut the budget deficit. If it believes he cannot, the rally of 1993 could be dissipated in a hurry. [D1.]
The dollar was mixed, European stocks languished and Treasury bonds rose slightly in limited activity overseas. Markets in the United States were closed for Washington's Birthday. [D9.]
 
Today's Columns
Profits at Dell and Compaq are surging and are expected to continue to do so. Yet stocks of both personal computer companies have slumped over fears of a price war. Market Place. [D1.]
Gannett is promoting a new live radio service for airliners. USA Today Sky Radio is another attempt to establish a new medium that exposes consumers to advertising in places where there didn't used to be places. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D10.]

HEADLINE: Big Change Sought in Auto Insurance

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15

 BODY:
California is considering a new system of car insurance that drivers would pay for through fees at the fuel pump, so the cost would depend more heavily on how much they drive than on traditional factors like what type of car they use or where they live.
Insurance companies and trial lawyers hate the idea, which is intended to ease out-of-control increases in insurance costs and the huge problem of uninsured drivers. 
 Environmentalists have high hopes that the concept will catch on here and around the country, because, they say, it will raise the price of driving to reflect its cost more accurately, and that will discourage traffic.
State Senator Art Torres of Los Angeles, a Democrat who heads the Senate Insurance, Claims and Corporations Committee, said he would introduce "pay-at-the-pump" legislation calling for a fuel surcharge of 30 cents a gallon, as well as additional vehicle registration fees. The plan would provide a basic insurance policy to all drivers, although people who own expensive cars would probably choose to buy additional coverage privately, which would be permitted under the plan.
 
Addressing Uninsured Drivers
 The proposal's backers say it will address a crisis in automobile insurance in California, which has the one of the highest auto insurance rates in the nation. As many as 6 million of the state's 20 million motorists are uninsured, driving illegally because of the cost.
The new plan grew out of a book, "Auto Insurance Alert!" (Fireside-Simon & Schuster, 1993), by Andrew Tobias, a financial columnist for Time magazine. The current system is "horribly unfair and terribly wasteful," he said in an interview. "This plan would do away with all the selling, do away with all the lawyers and do away with uninsured motorists. I think that's a powerful concept."
Supporters say the new concept will also eliminate billions of dollars in waste. The California Department of Insurance says 44 cents of every dollar in insurance premiums actually pays for losses like medical expenses, lost wages and repairs. Under the proposed plan, that will increase to 72 cents of every premium dollar, the department estimates.
The proposal has won the support of the state's insurance commissioner, John Garamendi, who estimates it will save California drivers $4 billion a year, slashing the average amount a motorist spends on auto insurance by one-third. Although rates vary widely depending on a host of factors, the average driver 30 years old with no violations now pays about $556 a year for basic coverage. Under the plan, such a driver would pay $311, the insurance department said.
 
Support by Consumer Groups
 Some consumer and environmental groups have also endorsed the plan, praising its simplicity and its potential for unclogging roads and reducing air pollution with economic incentives for people to cut down their driving and switch to fuel-efficient vehicles.
But opposition to the plan has created an alliance between insurance companies and trial lawyers. They characterize the idea as unfair, unrealistic and rife with unanswered questions.
The pay-at-the-pump idea is not new. Maryland considered such a plan in 1972. Legislation was introduced in the California Assembly in 1975 but failed. Unlike the current proposal, that one would not have provided for insurance coverage regardless of which driver was at fault in an accident.
Under this "no fault" provision of the new plan, the insurance would provide a ban on lawsuits for pain and suffering, 100 percent coverage of medical expenses, up to $25,000 for lost wages and $5,000 in collision coverage. Additional coverage could be bought privately.
Although other states, including New York, currently have forms of "no-fault" insurance, they permit lawsuits for injuries of a specified severity or if damages exceed a certain amount. In Connecticut, which considers itself a a no-fault state, lawsuits are allowed if damages exceed $400.
 
Limits to Proposal
 New Jersey also has one of the highest automotive insurance rates in the nation. But most experts say a pay-at-the-pump plan would be impractical there, unless all neighboring states also had such programs, because it would be too easy for motorists to drive to New York, Pennsylvania or Delaware and buy fuel without the extra fees.
Under the California proposal, additional fees would be collected through vehicle registrations, These would vary depending on the car and the driver's record. A "good driver," one with no more than one moving violation in the last three years, would pay an additional $20 a year for a driver's license. That group would include 80 percent of all motorists. Drivers with tarnished records could pay hundreds of dollars more, depending on how many accidents and violations they had.
Backers estimate that the average car would cost an additional $195 to register, but that would vary with the model.
 
'It's a Good Idea'
 Though the state would collect all the money, the insurance would operate as a private system, with companies bidding to provide coverage for blocks of 2,500 to 5,000 motorists.
"It's a good idea," said Nettie Hoge, a staff lawyer with Consumers Union's West Coast regional office.
Ms. Hoge and other consumer advocates have expressed concern that the plan might create a disproportionate economic burden on low- and moderate-income motorists, but they said it could be remedied by offering lower registration fees to people below a set income level.
As to fears that motorists would drive out of state to avoid the fuel fees, Senator Torres's aides said the losses would be insignificant because 98 percent of California's population was too far from a border for such a strategy to be practical. They added that they had received inquiries from seven other states about the legislation, including neighboring Arizona and Nevada. They said that if California enacted the plan, other states would follow.
Many insurance industry officials welcome the no-fault component of the plan but complain that big-car owners will unfairly pay more for coverage, even though their inefficient fuel consumption does not constitute an insurance risk.
Trial lawyers, on the other hand, reject the no-fault component of the proposal. "In essence you are saying take money away from innocent victims and use that money to pay the people that caused the accident," said Will Glennon, a legal analyst with the California Trial Lawyers Association in Sacramento.
Should the legislation pass, it will ultimately be put before voters as a constitutional amendment. That is because the fuel charge is considered a tax, and the state Constitution limits the use of fuel taxes to road construction and repair and similar transportation expenditures.

HEADLINE: The Xerox Health-Care Model

SERIES: A Search for Limits -- A periodic look at prescriptions for an ailing health-care system.

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
Marie T. Lyons, a 28-year-old computer operations trouble-shooter at the Xerox Corporation, joined a health maintenance organization for the first time in late 1991, largely because the price seemed right.
As a single person, she pays $6.33 in monthly premiums, while her employer contributes the balance of the $183.43 a month that her H.M.O. charges. The big office machine manufacturer provides the subsidy to encourage workers to join H.M.O.'s that have met Xerox's standards for quality of care and service and, even more important, have held down costs. 
 Xerox, a $17 billion company with 55,000 employees in 47 states, has been one of the most aggressive and innovative large companies in the pursuit of lower health costs. It has given its employees strong incentives to join H.M.O.'s, in which care is offered for a prepaid price and patients are limited in their choice of doctors, and the company has fostered competition among H.M.O.'s for its contracts.
 
Rewards and Limits
 In its stress on managed care and competition, the Xerox method includes several elements of an approach known as managed competition that has gained the interest of many economists and President Clinton.
Yet Xerox, which has been refining its strategy since the mid-1980's, still faces jumps in health costs that it considers unacceptable.
Although one company with employees spread around the country cannot make the sweeping changes in the health system that many experts think are needed, its experience offers lessons about both the potential rewards and limits of managed care within the current system.
More than 60 of the 190 H.M.O.'s that serve Xerox employees are limiting their price increases for Xerox workers this year to an average of only 5.5 percent, well below the rise in health costs most companies face. But most of the H.M.O.'s have not held down cost increases as extensively.
And 16,500 Xerox employees -- 30 percent of the company's work force -- still choose to remain in traditional insurance plans despite the extra cost.
Like many Americans, including Xerox's chairman, Paul A. Allaire, they want to be able to choose any family doctor or medical specialist, rather than being limited to a list of H.M.O.-approved physicians who would control the patients' access to specialists.
"I love my doctor; he's the best," said Nancy-Jean Bono, a 29-year-old administrative assistant at Xerox headquarters in Stamford. To keep him, she pays $137.83 a month to cover her family. She could get similar coverage in an H.M.O. for less than $20 a month. But then she would need a new doctor. She said that her current physician prefers to remain independent.
So while nearly two-thirds of the company's employees have selected the prepaid health plans (and about 7 percent are covered by their spouse's benefits), Xerox's overall medical costs are expected to rise by a burdensome 12.7 percent in 1993, quadruple the projected national inflation rate. Projected costs per active employee jumped to $4,324 this year from $3,154 in 1990, the first year of the company's current system.
Even a company as large and profitable as Xerox blanches at the prospect of facing 12 percent annual increases, doubling its expenses every six years. If this continues, Mr. Allaire, the chairman, said, "it would clearly make us less competitive internationally." His main competitors are Japanese companies that spend far less than their American counterparts for employee health care.
The company uses many of the country's most admired health maintenance organizations, including the Kaiser Foundation's national network and two in Rochester, where the largest cluster of Xerox employees live.
 
'Not the Magic Bullet'
 Health maintenance organizations are the cornerstones of most proposals to address the nation's growing medical problems. But most have yet to demonstrate significant, steady savings. "H.M.O.'s are not the magic bullet," said Dr. Robert Brooks, health sciences director at the Rand Corporation, an independent research center in Santa Monica, Calif.
Following a practice called shadow-pricing, H.M.O. charges usually rise steadily at a rate that is just a bit lower than traditional health plans. Kaiser, for example, has increased its rates by an average of 12.8 percent a year since 1990, while national rates for traditional fee-for-service medicine were rising about 16 percent annually.
And too often, economists and other experts add, H.M.O.'s attract the younger and healthier members of a group who need relatively little care, but this is not reflected in lower rates. The fee-for-service plans, meanwhile, get more than their share of people who believe they have medical needs, said Helen Darling, Xerox's health-care strategy manager.
Kaiser, which is under pressure from large customers like the California Public Employees Retirement System and employers hit by the recession in its California stronghold, is raising its 1993 rates only 6.8 percent, on average, across the country. In several regions, Kaiser is wooing Xerox employees with 5.5 percent increases.
In Rochester, where Xerox has joined with other large employers to restrain medical spending, prices are 25 percent to 35 percent below national averages. But Rochester Blue Cross has also posted H.M.O. rate increases averaging about 12 percent for the last four years. In the same period, its fee-for-service increases averaged 17 percent a year.
Contrary to the common perception of health maintenance organizations as the lower-cost choice, Xerox said H.M.O. rates for its Rochester employees were currently higher than fee-for-service charges there.
 
Traditional Care
 Traditional medicine is expensive for Xerox and getting more so. It is expected to cost $6,322 per active employee in 1993, up 15.4 percent from last year. Xerox projects $3,846 per employee for H.M.O.'s in 1993.
And even though participants in the traditional health plans face steep deductibles before the company starts picking up most of the costs (they have to pay all charges until they reach 1 percent of their income), Xerox estimates it will spend nearly half of its $235 million health-care budget to cover these employees.
Xerox promotes enrollment in its lowest-cost H.M.O.'s by paying more than 90 percent of the charges. These H.M.O. members pay only $239 a year for full family coverage, which includes expensive items like fertility therapy as well as free checkups and other preventive care.
To steer people away from H.M.O.'s that charge more, the employees' share of the costs is increased. Employees pay the most, $1,654 a year for family coverage, for the company fee-for-service plan, which covers 80 percent of physician fees but only after the employee has paid 100 percent of the deductible.
 
6 Picked to Direct Network
 Patricia M. Nazemetz, Xerox's benefits director, chose six H.M.O.'s, including some of the nation's largest, to direct the network. The goal, she said, was to concentrate the company's buying clout, which had been dispersed across 250 Xerox offices and 180 H.M.O.'s.
"It struck me that I wasn't able to have a relationship with 200 H.M.O.'s," she said.
With the smaller group of H.M.O.'s, Xerox was able to insist on improvements in quality of care as measured by surveys that asked employees to assess their health plan's performance. "Some are doing a very good job," she said, "but it doesn't mean they couldn't get better."
"Can they say to a member, for example, 'You've just passed your 40th birthday; it's time for your mammogram?' " she asked. "Are they saying, 'the last time you had your blood pressure checked was 12 months ago; it's time to come back in?' "
 
The Choice at Headquarters
 Employees at Xerox headquarters in Stamford have a choice of three of the six H.M.O.'s in the company system: Kaiser Foundation Health Plans; U.S. Healthcare, whose home office is in Blue Bell, Pa., or Prucare, which is owned by the Prudential Life Insurance Company in Newark.
The other H.M.O. contractors are Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Rochester, where Xerox has 13,000 workers; FHP International, based in Fountain Valley, Calif. and the HMO Group in New Brunswick, N.J., an association of several nonprofit plans. Besides their own enrollees, these six also supervise the scores of independent Xerox-approved H.M.O.'s around the country, so employees usually have a choice.
Xerox is ready to "share our ideas with the Clinton Administration, if they're interested," Mr. Allaire said. But he avoided making specific recommendations. "I'm not sure we could say that what Xerox did is right for the country," Mr. Allaire said. "It sure isn't perfect."

HEADLINE: Swords to Plowshares: The Bureaucratic Snags

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
At first glance, it seemed like the perfect collaboration between Government and industry -- just what President Clinton championed, in fact, during his campaign.
With great fanfare, James D. Watkins, then the Secretary of Energy, announced plans in October for a $70 million venture among two major national weapons laboratories and Cray Research Inc. to develop a new generation of supercomputers. The project would advance technology, improve American competitiveness and benefit the environment with programs to map climate change. 
 But the project has drawn criticism from rival companies, which attack it as a sweetheart deal giving unfair advantage to one player in the supercomputer field. And now, the Energy Department says it is merely in "initial discussions" with Cray.
 
The Problems of Conversion
 The dispute highlights the difficulties that confront the new President in reaching his goal of redirecting Government research away from weapons development. Mr. Clinton has said that with the cold war over, and the economy in need of a competitive lift, the laboratories should designate as much as 20 percent of their combined budget of $25 billion for research ventures with private industry into new technologies.
Problems are presenting themselves, though, and not only with choosing one company over another or with picking the right project. Bureaucratic infighting at the Energy and Defense Departments, which share control of the nation's research laboratories; budget battles, and patent-rights disputes have created obstacles that even lab officials say make it hard to work with industry.
Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon and chairman of a House Small Business Committee panel that held hearings on the issue in December, says that much of the nation's economic health depends on overcoming these hurdles. "Taxpayers pay a fortune for all these labs, but unless we can excavate the fruits of all those dollars we're not going to be tapping our potential," he said.
Despite years of earnest prodding by both Congress and the Bush Administration, there are few demonstrable results from technology transferred out of the nation's biggest energy and military laboratories.
"There has always been a civil war between the labs and D.O.E. on technology transfer," one White House official involved in technology policy said. "The labs have been straining at the bit to be involved with industry, because they saw their old mission dying. But the central bureaucracy at D.O.E. didn't want that to happen."
Federally sponsored research and development goes on in hundreds of labs. The Energy Department oversees 21 huge labs, with a combined budget of roughly $6 billion and a work force of more than 70,000 people. These range from the Los Alamos and Sandia national laboratories in New Mexico, which have been primarily devoted to weapons research, to the Oakridge National Laboratory in Tennessee that works primarily on energy projects.
The Defense Department also operates a vast network of laboratories with a combined budget of about $7 billion and more than 60,000 employees. In addition, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration runs 10 labs, and the National Institutes of Health finances more than $9 billion in medical research, mostly through universities and other outside organizations.
The biggest debate focuses on the Energy Department, because its labs are huge and their expertise has potentially wide industrial applications.
In December, officials at three weapons labs -- Los Alamos, Sandia and Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in California -- urged the new Administration to formulate a series of "grand challenges," modeled after the Apollo moon program. Among the suggested projects were creation of a high-speed national communications "superhighway," development of an automobile that burns far less fuel and an effort to understand global climate changes.
"We feel the national labs have a significant amount to contribute," said Kay Adams, director of the Industrial Partnership Center at Los Alamos. Sandia, in Albuquerque, has formed 71 cooperative research and development agreements, or cradas, as they are known, covering $191 million in work, of which industry partners will finance at least 50 percent.
One prominent example, involving a number of laboratories, is research on battery technology for electric cars. There, the Energy Department is contributing $130 million over four years to the Advanced Battery Consortium of businesses, car companies and equipment manufacturers, and much of that money will pay for research at the Federal labs.
 
Lack of a Corporate Culture
 But experts in technology policy say the labs often suffer from a cultural gap that makes it hard for them to address business concerns. The biggest complaint is that the labs focus heavily on fundamental research while industry is market driven and has needs that are much more short term. Worse still, these experts say, the labs do not have enough authority over their operations so that even when they try to forge ahead, the agencies overseeing them often hold them back.
For example, officials of Motorola Inc. reported to Representative Wyden's Subcommittee on Regulation, Business Opportunities and Energy that they had often spent more than a year negotiating agreements with Federal laboratories -- and then simply gave up on many proposed agreements because of legal disputes.
Lab officials say they can accept only a small fraction of the industry proposals they receive, because they lack the authority to redirect money from other work. "I have in front of me 70 proposals for about $250 million in work over the next three years, but I have an available pool of $30 million," Daniel Arvizu, head of Sandia's technology transfer office, said.
A report last fall by the Council on Competitiveness, a nonprofit organization in Washington formed by corporate executives, academics and labor leaders, called for major changes in how Federal labs are controlled. The council urged that Congress require labs run by the Energy Department and NASA to assign at least 10 percent of their budgets to technology transfer programs. It also urged that lab directors be given the authority to negotiate and carry out joint research agreements on their own.
But lab officials say there is a strong reluctance in the Energy Department to shifting gears. "We haven't been real successful in re-allocating money," Ms. Adams of Los Alamos said. "It's sort of like changing the direction of a battleship."
Roger A. Lewis, director of technology utilization at the Energy Department, said the Government had improved its deal-making. Working with the computer industry, the Government drafted a model contract for collaborations that has speeded up the process of negotiation and approval. "A lot of the complaints are based on data that is a year or two old," he said. "A lot has changed."
In addition, Energy Department officials contend that they now think about technology transfer to industry much more broadly than before. Mr. Lewis noted that fully $1.5 billion of research money, in fields like clean coal technology and renewable energy, involve industry partners and the labs can often tap into this money even though it is not part of their official technology transfer budget.
 
Industry Rivalries
 Finally, there are the issues of fairness posed by the Cray controversy. When the Energy Department announced the "preliminary agreement" for a $70 million jointly financed program on Oct. 29, it said that Lawrence Livermore and Los Alamos labs would work with Cray on supercomputer programs for a range of environmental, industrial and military tasks.
What outraged rivals was that the Government also indicated that it would work on operating systems, the basic instructions that would run programs on Cray's new computers. Some of the rivals took that to mean that the Government would be underwriting Cray's next computer and giving Cray valuable business.
Those objecting included the Intel Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., Convex Computer of Richardson, Tex., and Ncube of Foster City, Calif. "We are incensed," Michael Mierer, president of Ncube, said. "They are effectively getting a $35 million Government contribution, and that gives us a competitive disadvantage."
Mr. Lewis of the Energy Department acknowledged the controversy but defended the plan. "When you are dealing with the private sector, you are going to have some folks object to having relationships with their competitors," he said, adding that other companies are still free to propose their own deals.
Nevertheless, Energy Department officials have retreated from the fanfare of the original announcement. They now say they are only in initial discussions and have made no decision about what form the collaboration with Cray would take.

HEADLINE: Amerika Journal;
Amerikans Ask Help, but Americans Pay No Heed

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMERIKA, Germany

 BODY:
After long years of proud success, Amerika is in evident decline. Years of misrule by short-sighted ideologues have led to economic collapse. Unemployment is chronic, and many residents fear that worse times lie ahead.
"We may all have to leave," groused Hans Friedrich, a leading specialist in Amerikan history. "Then we would have an Amerika without Amerikans. How would that look?" 
 The problems afflicting this Amerika are not likely ever to find their way to Bill Clinton's desk. It is not a vast continent but a quiet Saxon village 35 miles northwest of the Czech border. Its residents complain not about politicians in Washington, but about those in Bonn and Berlin.
Amerika's story is a microcosm of Central Europe's economic and political history. From its founding more than 150 years ago through its boom years to its ultimate collapse, it reflects the fate of many small industrial centers in what was once the Communist world.
 
100 Good Years
 According to Mr. Friedrich, who is reputed to know more about Amerika than anyone, the spinning mill around which this village was built opened in 1836. For generations it produced high-quality wool, much of which was used to manufacture rugs for export.
The mill was built beside a wide stream, and workers' housing was put up on the opposite side, with only a rickety, narrow bridge in between. Workers had to struggle to keep their balance as they crossed. On windy days it seemed as perilous as an Atlantic crossing, and workers setting out on such days would joke to each other, "We're off to America."
"The town didn't have a name, and after a while they just decided to call it Amerika," Mr. Friedrich said.
Amerika prospered for more than a century, but as the textile industry changed, the town was unable to change with it.
After World War II, Amerika and the rest of Saxony became part of East Germany, which had little money to invest in modernization. When the two Germanys reunited in 1990, the thousands of state-owned businesses became the property of the Treuhand agency, a new public corporation charged with selling the businesses to private bidders.
In Amerika, Treuhand inherited not simply the mill complex, but the entire village. The outmoded mill survived only a year after unification, and Treuhand began to seek a buyer who would remake Amerika.
Hoping that the village's name might attract foreign interest, Treuhand ran a small advertisement in several investment journals in the United States. It was headlined, "Amerika for Sale."
The advertisement described a 200-acre parcel of land in an "idyllic river valley" with about 40 buildings and 700,000 square feet of usable floor space. It suggested that investors might want to create a research institute or a "leisure time and adventure town" here.
 
Clinic 'Our Best Hope'
 "We thought maybe some American company would want to come and set up a theme park or a western saloon or something like that," said the Mayor, Gerald Merkel, who likes to call himself the first democratically elected leader in Amerikan history. "There was a little interest, but nothing really firm. Now it looks like the clinic idea is our best hope."
When it became clear that there would be no money-generating offers for Amerika, the Saxony state government stepped in. Officials were looking for a place to build a new hospital for patients with lung and respiratory ailments, and Amerika, a pristine and quiet spot, seemed ideal.
Saxony recently reached a quiet agreement to buy Amerika for $3 million, half the original asking price. If health agencies approve, the deal will be officially concluded soon.
"Ultimately there will be some jobs for local people there," Mr. Merkel said. "The clinic is going to need various support services, and there will probably be a hotel and restaurant to go with it. Everybody is happy that at last something is going to happen."
For many Amerikans, however, relief is tempered by fear that they may lose their homes. All of the village's 108 residents, 80 percent of whom are unemployed, live in two apartment blocks that are likely to be torn down. They are trying to organize a fund to buy the two buildings, but their financial resources are very limited.
As they await word of their fate, Amerikans maintain the quiet lives to which they have been accustomed since the mill closed more than a year ago. A few have jobs in nearby towns, but most spend their time puttering in their gardens or trading stories at the train depot.
 
Trains Still Pass Through
 The depot is nothing more than a small shed with a sign that says "Amerika." The rail link was built in 1870 to serve the mill, and several trains still pass through every day. Each weekday morning, the village's few children ride one stop to the next large town, Penig, for school.
Everyone at the depot has an Amerikan story to tell. There's the one about the woman from nearby Thuringia who sent a package to her son here, only to receive it back six months later covered with postal stamps from the United States. And there's the one about Gerd Hofmann's first day in the East German Army, when he was jailed for insubordination after telling an officer that he lived in Amerika.
Like many Amerikans, Mayor Merkel has had some depressing times lately, but is finally hopeful that life here is going to improve.
"Amerika has a long history and a positive history," he insisted. "A place like this does not simply die."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 6; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates Tied To Clinton Deficit Cut

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
For the bond market, this is the first important week of Bill Clinton's Presidency. Last night, from the Oval Office, he began a campaign for support of an economic program that he will outline tomorrow in more detail to a joint session of Congress.
So investors, traders and speculators will now be able to begin judging whether the President can really do what he has promised -- cut the record Federal budget deficit. 
 That judgment is crucial for interest rates over the next several months. If Mr. Clinton is believed, interest rates on the 30-year Treasury bond could fall to 7 percent or even lower. If he is not, a lot of the surprising rally of 1993 could be dissipated in a hurry.
 
Market's Bias
 Currently, the market's bias favors lower interest rates. Even those who have been astonished by the 1993 Clinton rally agree.
"I thought there would be more cynicism," said Joseph Liro, the chief economist at S. J. Warburg, referring to President Clinton's promises about cutting the Federal budget deficit, which has climbed back to record levels despite similar promises by Presidents George Bush and Ronald Reagan. "But the market wants to believe."
Mr. Liro had forecast late last year that the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond would fall to around 7.2 percent by midyear, but that it would be pulled down mostly by the market's growing confidence that inflation would continue to be minimal for some time to come.
 
Near a 7-Year Low
 But the 30-year bond's yield is already below 7.2 percent. It closed at 7.12 percent Friday, the lowest in almost seven years and just a normal day's trading away from 7.10 percent, the 1980's low reached in April 1986. Below that, one has to look back to the 1970's, when the long bond was a 20-year bond and carried yields close to 7 percent.
For the record, however, here are some of the concerns that skeptics like Mr. Liro and others have that could alter the market's bias toward lower rates.
One is the economy. Recent signs, from orders for durable goods to retail sales, show that the economy is picking up a little steam. That means instead of growing at a 2 to 2.5 percent pace at the beginning of this year, which would be slower than the 3-percent-plus rate for the end of 1992, the economy appears to be in a similar 3 percent stride.
This leads Donald Fine, another economist who has been surprised by the rally, to conclude: "Maybe rates will move lower now. But they won't end the year there; they will be higher."
The reason that Mr. Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc., predicts this resurgence in interest rates is that traders and investors will eventually pay attention to the stronger economy, something they have chosen to ignore for now. Then their expectations about inflation will rise as they calculate that stronger growth will lead to price increases. And that worry should bring down Treasury bond and note prices and push yields, which move in the opposite direction, higher.
But more immediately, the concern is President Clinton. He has brought on much of the bond rally by saying what the market regards as the right things about cutting spending and the Federal budget deficit. He is challenging all to sacrifice to reduce the deficit. Last night, he indicated that he had backed off his campaign promise of a middle-class tax cut, and he directly asked the middle class to pay more. This has all spelled commitment to many in the bond market.
Now the question is whether the President can actually achieve deficit reduction. Washington is littered with believable promises that could not be fulfilled. "He has said the right words," Mr. Liro said. "Now, the deeds have to follow."
As for this week, if the President gives the nation broad outlines and not much else, some in the bond market could get impatient. It appears that the hard details of his deficit-cutting may not be out until late March, when his budget is due in Congress.
 
Details and Reactions
 In addition to possible damage from waiting more than a month for real details, there will be the reactions from Congress and elsewhere to contend with. If they are not positive, that could hurt because it would make bond traders remember that it is much easier to propose deficit reduction than approve it.
And on Thursday, after Mr. Clinton's addresses to Congress, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, will deliver the central bank's annual policy statement to Congress. He has been very supportive so far but he will be asked to comment anew on the President's ideas.
There is also doubt over whether Mr. Clinton has the ability to push a deficit-reduction program through Congress. "I have become somewhat more skeptical about how much credible deficit-reduction we can get from Clinton," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "For a President to be effective he has to be feared by Congress."
Mr. Jones is not sure Mr. Clinton is. He noted that the "most credible" proposal mentioned by the new Administration was a freeze on the cost-of-living increase for Social Security recipients. But that was dropped quickly when the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said, "No."
Patrick Rothstein, a managing director at Merrill Lynch Government Securities, took a contrary view, arguing that Mr. Clinton's speech to Congress tomorrow should not be that important. He said the market is being driven now by what traders call technicals. In this case, it is the simple fact that the Federal Government has to borrow billions of dollars less than expected for the next several months.
As a result, there is a smaller supply of Treasury bonds to meet a steady demand. And this shortage is expected to support prices.
"The market right now is so myopic it is not even thinking about inflation," Mr. Rothstein said.
Yet, echoing the theme of Mr. Fine of Chase Securities, he sees some early inflationary signals, including a turn upward in the Commodity Research Bureau index and a rise in gold prices. And by the fall, he adds, the Government's borrowing needs will be increasing again. "Behind the scenes the seeds of discontent are being sown," he said.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
In Tough Times for Business, Videos and Much, Much More

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson

DATELINE: LAWRENCEVILLE , N.J.

 BODY:
BOB HAINES sold some Lotto tickets, then he weighed and took payment for a U.P.S. package to be shipped, and reminded the man at the copying machine to make sure he picked up his original.
Then he got back to his point, which was, "In the video business, you either grow or go out of business." 
 Even the big video-rental chains are selling compact disks, renting cameras and selling video games. Mr. Haines, the owner of Village Video here, is an independent in a world of franchise operations, however, and for every move the big guys make, he figures he has to make seven just to stay alive.
He sells another Lotto ticket. The jackpot is up to $15 million, and that is bringing the bettors in. A woman spends $60, of which 5 percent is his share.
Clinton Administration economists looking for ways to revive the national economy might consider business people like Mr. Haines, a 55-year-old entrepreneur who got out of the heavy-truck sales-and-service business six years ago and answered an ad for the video movie rental business. Macroeconomic policy may be made in bold strokes at the highest levels, but Mr. Haines operates at the micro level, in the slow working out of dozens of educated guesses as he and thousands like him try to stay ahead of the big operators on their way to becoming -- it could happen -- big operators themselves.
Mr. Haines's latest decision was to start a Tuesday special, three titles from the cheaper "B" list for three days for $4.99, a promotion that should bring the customer back into the shop on Friday evening, maybe with a couple of kids tugging at the sleeves and begging for one of the more expensive new-release "A" titles, "because there's no school tomorrow."
The Tuesday Special is just the latest effort to bring customers in the door. Besides the Lotto, the United Parcel Service and the copying machine, Mr. Haines rents Nintendo video game cartridges, sells and develops film, and operates a fax service. Mr. Haines said of his fax machine: "Income $30, expenses $90. I wondered, do I really need to be in the fax business?"
Moreover, Mr. Haines repairs video equipment, and sells money orders, movie posters, shipping boxes, used movie videos and candy and soda pop. Let the big chains go into compact disks, he said: he worked out a deal with Varsity Pizza next door to have the pizza delivered with a video.
(Another package for U.P.S. goes out. Mr. Haines collects and keeps about $1 over the standard cost.)
"The worse the economy gets, the more you have to try to keep ahead of what people want," Mr. Haines said in a moment of calm. "People used to come in and take out two or three titles for the weekend, but now they're talking about the General Motors plant closing in Ewing, there are some state workers who are hearing about layoffs, and more and more I see them coming in saying to the kids, 'O.K., we're getting one family movie tonight and that's it! O.K. one Nintendo cartridge too, but for one night, not three.' "
Because these are the suburbs, which are a kind of made-up world anyway, the local preference runs heavily to comedy and drama. Still, a steady number of men slip behind the embarrassing little walled-off area at the back of the store labeled "Adult Movie Room," where, instead of selecting the lurid tape in its box, they take little numbered tags that they discreetly hand over to Mr. Haines, who pulls the title from behind the counter.
(Lotto.)
(Film developing.)
(Two titles out: "Old Yeller" and "The Little Mermaid.")
"Rainy days in the middle of the week," Mr. Haines said, answering an awkward question about the smutty titles. "The construction workers get sent home early, the kids are at school and their wives are out working."
The rest of us also have our doubtful video habits, apparently. Many simply forget their tapes under the mail in the front hall or under the front seat of the car. This dilatoriness is part of a wider observed habit of the video renter, which is that everyone likes to go pick out the weekend movie, but after it has been enjoyed, no one wants to bring it back.
(Lotto.)
(U.P.S. box.)
Still, Mr. Haines often ends up forgiving part of the late charges, relying on the shopkeeper's oldest and hardest truth: "You make a choice," he said a little grimly, "to lose a little on the rental to keep a customer."
(Two tapes out: "Universal Soldier" and "Victoria Principle," not to be confused with the star of "Dallas.")
With the part-time help of three Rider College students from up the road, and his wife as the business's bookkeeper, Mr. Haines puts in about 55 hours of work, seven days a week, shipping packages, punching up lottery tickets, fiddling with the copying machine and renting about 1,000 titles. His last vacation was two years ago, and it amounted only to three days at the Jersey Shore.
This is a schedule that has him thinking from time to time about surrendering the splendid drudgery of being a sole proprietor and joining a video franchise. Why? "Forty-hour weeks," he said.
But a few square feet of unoccupied wall space next to his U.P.S. counter has given him one more idea to try first.
"Mailboxes!" he said.
(Lotto.)
(Lotto.)
(Lotto.)

HEADLINE: Health Initiative Tilting Toward Price Regulation

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
President Clinton's health-care initiative was to have been a delicate balance between Government regulation and free-market competition. But so far, a rush to monitor and regulate prices has been the policy's most conspicuous new twist, health-care experts say.
Late last week, the President and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, criticized drug companies and the prices they charged for vaccines. Over the weekend, Administration officials like Leon E. Panetta and George Stephanopoulos made clear that the President wanted to impose cost controls on health-care providers as a way to hold down Medicare outlays and as a prelude to sweeping changes in the health-care system. 
 "You have to lead with cost controls," said Mr. Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director. Mr. Panetta, the budget director, said that with spending of well over $200 billion a year on Medicare and Medicaid, "you've got to enact some cost controls in those areas, particularly aiming at the providers."
Such comments suggest that Clinton Administration officials think the Government can squeeze the revenues of doctors, hospitals and drug companies without adverse effects on patients.
 
Savings Before Access
 Concern about the Federal budget deficit has, for the moment, overtaken concern about how to guarantee access to health care for the 35 million Americans who have no health insurance. And the idea of regulating prices, perhaps by extending Medicare rates to private patients, looks much easier than the complex business of designing a system of "managed competition," in which networks of doctors and hospitals compete to offer high-quality care at reasonable prices.
Vaccines are cited by Federal officials and corporate executives as a test case. On Friday, a day after Mrs. Clinton attacked drug prices and profits as excessive, her husband took up the same theme, describing vaccine prices as "shocking." He complained that drug companies spent too much on advertising and lobbying and invited them to negotiate the supply and price of their products with the Government.
Today, executives from four vaccine manufacturers -- Merck & Company, Connaught Laboratories, SmithKline Beecham and Lederle-Praxis Biologicals, a division of American Cyanamid -- met with White House officials. Even as they lamented the attack on their industry, Mrs. Clinton met today with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Dennis Rivera of the hospital workers' union, who applauded her efforts.
But Barry P. Bosworth, who was director of the Council on Wage and Price Stability in the Carter Administration, warns Clinton Administration officials to "think long and hard before trying to impose price controls" on doctors or hospitals.
 
Warning of Distortions
 Such controls, he said, are not easy to design or enforce. He said that in the health-care industry "price controls can work for a short interim period, but at a cost."
"They cause distortions, which will make it difficult to introduce a more comprehensive health-care plan at a later date," Mr. Bosworth said.
In a special issue of the quarterly journal Health Affairs, two of Mr. Clinton's advisers, Prof. Paul Starr of Princeton University and Walter A. Zelman, an aide to the California Insurance Commissioner, say states should have "contingent authority to regulate rates" if managed competition fails to control costs.
But Clinton Administration officials, seeing an urgent need to control health costs and reduce the deficit, say they want to take immediate steps to limit payments to hospitals and doctors.
Dr. Jim Bob Brame, a family doctor in the small West Texas town of Eldorado, said today, "I fear we will be faced with more regulation, more ratcheting down, more restrictions on physician payment."
 
Expects Insurers to Pay Less
 Dr. Brame said he expected the Government to put "some strict expenditure caps" on Medicare payments for doctors' services, and he said he would not be suprised if the Government tried to freeze or reduce such payments.
And private health insurers may follow suit. "Unfortunately," Dr. Brame said, "the private health insurance industry will have no problem accepting a national fee schedule similar to the one used in Medicare. That would reduce their costs."
Private health insurers often pay hospitals and doctors more than Medicare pays. As a result, private patients and their employers indirectly subsidize Medicare. In some regions, for example, doctors charge private patients $28 or more for a routine office visit, while Medicare pays $19.
In their economic analysis of the drug industry, Hillary and Bill Clinton echoed Harry S. Truman's indictment of the steel industry. In 1952, just before moving to take over the steel mills to avert a strike, Truman complained of "outrageous prices" and said, "The steel industry has never been so profitable as it is today." Likewise, on Friday, Mr. Clinton said vaccine prices were excessive, and he declared, "We cannot have profits at the expense of our children."
 
A Difficult Transition
 Whatever changes are made in the health-care system, the transition will be difficult.
John T. Dunlop, who led the Cost of Living Council, which enforced wage and price controls under President Richard M. Nixon, said today: "Health-care reform is necessary, but what do you do to keep prices from going up while you develop the reform institutions? In the absence of some kind of cost-control mechanism, no reform measures will have a significant bite, a significant effect in retarding health costs, for three to five years."
Even as Mr. Clinton complains about vaccine prices, he praises biotechnology as a model industry, and biotechnology helps produce vaccines.
Lisa J. Raines, a vice president of the Industrial Biotechnology Association, said: "Any discussion of the possibility that the Government will regulate drug prices chills investment. It could lead to Government regulating the rate of return. Once you turn our industry into a public utility, then investors will put money into companies that make wrinkle creams and other cosmetics rather than companies that make life-saving drugs."

HEADLINE: Police Search For Motive In 6 Slayings

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Detectives investigating the execution-style deaths of six people in a Bronx apartment said yesterday that the killers had used at least two types of guns and that 600 rounds of live ammunition had been found hidden in the apartment. But they said they still had no idea of the killers' identities and motive.
As relatives and friends mourned the three adults and three teen-agers who were each lined up face down on a living room floor and shot in the head Sunday at 645 Prospect Avenue in the South Bronx, the police scoured the drug-infested neighborhood for witnesses and examined the live ammunition, as well as shell casings left by the assailants, $4,400 in cash and other clues found in the apartment. 
 The shell casings came from two types of guns, suggesting that at least two killers had invaded the sixth-floor apartment where three members of one family and three residents of other apartments were slain. This appeared to confirm the impression of neighbors who said they heard shots about 12:30 A.M. on Sunday and the footsteps of more than one person running down a hallway. The police would not disclose what types of guns were used.
 
One Victim With a Record
 While the police publicly placed no interpretation on finding a large sum of cash in a household receiving public assistance or on the hundreds of rounds of ammunition for guns of three kinds, neighbors and relatives of some of the victims said these items confirmed their suspicions that drugs were behind the shootings.
Several residents said that one victim, Edwin Santiago, a 17-year-old high school student, was known in the neighborhood as a low-level drug dealer and might have been the killers' intended target, while the other victims appeared to have been bystanders, shot to eliminate any witnesses.
The other victims were Mr. Santiago's mother, Julia Santana, about 40, and his sister, Maria Santana, 26, a factory worker, who shared Apartment 612 with him, and three neighbors: Miguel Camacho Rivera, 23, a handyman who was dating Maria; Annette Medina, 17, a friend of Maria's, and Christopher Hernandez, 15, an eighth-grade pupil whose presence in the apartment remained a mystery.
The police said Mr. Rivera was the only victim with a criminal record. They said he was arrested once for possession of drugs in 1991, but did not know the disposition of the case. His family said he was placed on probation and had not been in trouble since his arrest.
While there were a number of clues and dozens of investigators continued to question relatives, friends, neighbors and even drug dealers in the area, there were no eyewitnesses and detectives said that there had been little progress in the case.
"We're not completely up against the wall, but we don't have much," Deputy Chief Edward Cappello, commander of detectives in the Bronx, said at a late afternoon news briefing yesterday at the 40th Precinct station house at 257 Alexander Avenue. Noting that the police had received few calls on the case, he added, "We need the public's help more than ever."
The police urged anyone with information on the case to call (212) 583-0144 or (212) 577-TIPS, and to reach residents of the largely Hispanic South Bronx community, officers made appeals over Spanish-language radio and television stations. Some investigators said the lack of public response reflected fear that cooperation with the police would bring retaliation by drug dealers.
 
Remembering Victims
 Chief Cappello said any suggestion that Mr. Santiago was the intended target was speculation. "I don't know too much other than he is a streetwise -- was a streetwise -- kid," he said. While the police tended to rule out robbery, he emphasized that no motive had been established. Pressed about a possible drug connection, he said, "It could be drugs; it might not be drugs."
As mourners came and went at the six-story red-brick apartment building on Prospect Avenue at East 152d Street, relatives and friends gave poignant accounts of the lives of the victims and told of a daily struggle for survival in a neighborhood where poverty, unemployment and other problems lay beneath the more visible dangers of drugs and gunfire.
Ms. Medina was the mother of a 10-month-old girl and had lived with her mother and sister for seven years in Apartment 616, across the hall from the apartment where she died, said her sister, Doreen Rivera. She had planned to earn a high school equivalency diploma and to take a test to become a police officer. "She really wanted to be a police officer badly," Ms. Rivera said.
 
Envisioning Last Moments
 The father of her child, Jose Montanez, 22, a telephone operator who lived elsewhere but sometimes spent nights with Ms. Medina and the baby, said he had planned to marry her when they could afford an apartment. He said she worked at odd jobs as a cashier or clothing saleswoman. "After the baby came, she was really motivated," he said. "She wanted to do things with her life."
He tried to envision her last moments. "All I could imagine is how scared she must have been, knowing they were going to kill her," he said. "I'm sure she must have pleaded with them not to kill her. I'm sure she told them she had a baby."
Mr. Rivera grew up in the Bronx but went to high school in Puerto Rico and returned a few years ago, his brother, Jose, recalled. He said Mr. Rivera dated Ms. Santana for a year, but rarely visited her apartment. He said they and Ms. Medina were all wearing coats when killed, perhaps to go out dancing.
Jose Rivera said his family suspected that the killers were drug dealers and that Mr. Santiago was the target. "Our family firmly believes that Edwin was the cause of everything that happened upstairs," he said.
Christopher Hernandez, who lived in a third-floor apartment with his mother, 6-year-old sister and 17-year-old brother, was an avid artist, on the eighth-grade honor roll at Intermediate School 52, had attended after-school art classes for three years and wanted to go to La Guardia High to study art, his brother, Juan, said.
He said Christopher helped his mother clean house, washed and ironed his own clothes and always asked for permission when he went out. On Saturday night, he went to a party and was driven home by the uncle of a friend about 10:30 P.M. -- but never arrived home. He had nothing to do with the Santana-Santiago family, and it was unclear why he was with the other victims, Juan said.
He said his family had long feared the streets and wanted to move away. "It was getting too dangerous and violent here, but now it's too late," he said. "My brother had a life in front of him. He was talented. He had a gift."

HEADLINE: Scheme to Split School District Is Revived

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Labor problems and financial distress in the Los Angeles Unified School District have given new life to an old idea: divide the sprawling school system into smaller parts so it is easier to manage and more responsive to local needs.
The idea, discussed here from time to time, is now emanating from the San Fernando Valley, where middle-class families want to separate themselves from the misery of the inner city and take control of their own schools. 
 A prime mover in the drive to break up the school system is David Roberti, a Van Nuys Democrat and President pro tem of the State Senate whose new district, after reapportionment, includes the valley. He plans to introduce legislation shortly that would start the process.
Mr. Roberti hopes to split the 641,000-student district into six or seven parts with 100,000 students each. An alternative proposal by the State Department of Education suggests 30 districts, each with 20,000 to 25,000 students. In the San Fernando Valley, some parents hope simply to secede, forming a second district separate from the city.
 
Minorities Alarmed
 The various plans for breakup have raised alarms here in the black and Hispanic communities, which are often at odds, with the first group declining in numbers and influence and the second ascending. Both black and Hispanic parents fear that the inner-city schools will be left with less money, less-experienced teachers, older buildings and fewer white students than now. They contend that the proposals constitute de facto segregation, although by economic class more than by race because even the San Fernando Valley schools are mostly nonwhite.
Labor and school board officials are also against the breakup plans. Among them are Helen Bernstein, president of the teachers union, and Leticia Quesada, head of the elected Board of Education, both of whom would lose power and patronage if the district was dismantled.
Instead, Ms. Bernstein, Ms. Quesada and many others here favor another recent proposal for decentralized, school-based management, modeled on changes elsewhere in the last decade. This plan was presented with great fanfare this week by a coalition of business, civic and educational leaders led by Mike Roos, a former State Assemblyman.

HEADLINE: I.B.M. to Offer New Minicomputers

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
I.B.M. will introduce today a series of more powerful minicomputers and software products in an effort to rejuvenate its midrange computer business.
The AS-400 family of minicomputers has been one of the International Business Machines Corporation's bright spots in the last couple of years, posting strong growth and profits. But its minicomputer sales slipped alarmingly late last year, especially in Europe, where I.B.M. gets about half its minicomputer revenues, analysts estimated. 
 Some analysts said the sales slippage was mainly a result of the weak economies in Europe and Japan and was not a shift away from I.B.M. machines. By December, the AS-400 sales began to pick up again, they said.
Nonetheless, I.B.M. faces increasing competition in the market for midrange computers, which, broadly defined, are machines priced from $15,000 to $1 million.
 
Microprocessor Rivals
 Traditional rivals like Hewlett-Packard, Digital Equipment and NCR offer minicomputers with the Unix operating system, an industry standard software, or "open" system. And new companies like Sequent Computer Systems and Pyramid Technology have entered the minicomputer business with machines built around lower-cost microprocessor technology that also run on open software systems. The I.B.M. machine uses a proprietary operating system.
In the midrange computer market, I.B.M. still holds the largest share, at roughly 22 percent. The AS-400's big edge is the thousands of existing software applications, from data base programs to general accounting, that have been written specifically for the I.B.M. machine.
Still, the rival microprocessor-based machines are cheaper, and more software applications are being written to run on their open systems.
"The AS-400 has got to keep up with this new breed of minicomputers because that's where the industry is heading," said Gary Dvorchak, an analyst for Hambrecht & Quist Inc. in San Francisco.
 
New Software Products
 Today, I.B.M. will announce a series of AS-400 machines whose performance is 30 percent to 60 percent higher than previous models and will introduce new software products, according to consultants who were briefed by the company. I.B.M., they said, would also discuss its plans for moving to an open software environment.
There are sharply divided views on the outlook for the AS-400. Analysts' estimates of I.B.M.'s minicomputer revenues this year range from declines of more than 10 percent to growth in the double digits.
David Andrews, managing partner of ADM Consulting Inc. in Cheshire, Conn., said that the AS-400 family, if properly marketed, was still a growth business for I.B.M. This year, he expects the company's minicomputer revenues to increase by roughly 10 percent.
 
Still Popular Among Businesses
 The ease of use of the AS-400's operating software and its many applications, Mr. Andrews said, continue to make it the computer of choice in many corporate offices and factories.
Still, the biggest growth area for the AS-400 may not provide much comfort at I.B.M. headquarters in Armonk, N.Y..
"The hottest thing for the AS-400 is large companies shifting applications off mainframe computers onto groups of AS-400's," Mr. Andrews said, explaining that running the applications on minicomputers is often cheaper than on mainframes, I.B.M.'s traditional mainstay.
The minicomputer business remains extremely profitable for I.B.M., Mr. Andrews said. Last year, sales of AS-400 machines and its operating software amounted to $5 billion and generated pretax operating profits of more than $1 billion, he estimated. If all I.B.M.'s minicomputer-related peripherals, software and maintenance revenue were included, the revenues would reach $14 billion and pretax operating profits would be $2 billion to $3 billion, he said.
To date, the AS-400, first marketed in 1988, has been an extraordinary success. It resulted from a crash development effort, code-named the Silverlake project, at I.B.M.'s offices in Rochester, Minn. It was started after the company had faltered badly in midrange computers.

HEADLINE: Tax Proposal For Puerto Rico

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Senator David Pryor, a critic of prescription drug costs, said today that he would seek to repeal tax breaks for drug companies and other industries with manufacturing operations in Puerto Rico.
Mr. Pryor, a Democrat from Arkansas, said the tax breaks, embodied in Section 936 of the tax code, have become "nothing but a gigantic tax windfall for the pharmaceutical industry," costing the Treasury $3 billion a year. 
 He proposed a much less generous tax credit based on the actual wages the manufacturers pay workers on the island rather than their profits.
The drug industry defended the existing tax credit, contending that its incentives account for one-third of the 900,000 jobs in Puerto Rico.
Other industries, including electronics and apparel manufacturers, also make use of the credit.
Jeffrey L. Trewhitt, a spokesman for the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, said Section 936 has been "extremely important to the economy of Puerto Rico." Since 1950, employment in Puerto Rico has risen by half, he said, and the island's gross output has quintupled to $20 billion.

HEADLINE: An 'Unloved' Grass May Turn Hero In the Struggle Against Soil Erosion

 BODY:
VETIVER, a tall grass whose long, fragrant roots are commonly used in perfumes and soaps, could serve as an inexpensive and effective barrier against soil erosion, a panel of experts says.
Considered a leading threat to the environment, soil erosion results when nutrient-rich top soil is washed away by water or swept up by wind. Vetiver, when planted in rows across steep slopes, keeps soil and water from flowing past. 
 Experts on soil erosion and specialists on the vetiver plant, who collaborated on a recent study for the National Research Council, said that vetiver's roots, which are 6 to 10 feet deep, hold the grass barrier and soil in place from below while the plant's tall blades of grass form a barricade against runoff above ground.
 
Best Conditions for Plant
 Able to grow in acidic or alkaline, fertile or infertile, waterlogged or parched soils, vetiver does not deprive crops of nutrients or space. Its sharp grass blades do not seem to harm livestock but do discourage them from eating or disturbing the vetiver hedge, said Dr. Noel D. Vietmeyer of the research council, who directed the study.
Vetiver, believed to be native to India, grows best in tropical and subtropical areas where rainfall is heavy but frosts are rare. The researchers said the grass hedge is able to grow in drier climates, like those in areas of Africa, and in cooler but not freezing climates, like those in areas in the Southern United States.
The grass can take from a few months to a year to grow deep enough and tall enough to combat soil erosion produced by water. Generally, however, it is less effective against erosion caused by wind unless the grass is planted close together to form a dense wind barrier, the study said.
Some scientists say grasses were planted in various parts of the world to limit soil erosion as early as the 1920's. The new study, primarily financed by the Agency for International Development, was begun because vetiver has remained "unloved and unrecognized as a means of preventing soil erosion," said Dr. Vietmeyer. "It needed credibility."
Other plants that have been used to prevent soil erosion, like the vine kudzu, grow so rapidly and wildly that they become uncontrollable nuisances. He said vetiver was a self-leveling grass that grows tall enough to block erosion but does not grow out of control and, in that way, interfere with crops the way that kudzu, weeds and some other grasses do.
Vetiver is not effective in most of the United States, especially in parts of Iowa where the soil, among the richest in the world, is eroding at one of the fastest rates in the world, said Dr. David Pimentel, a professor of entomology at Cornell University who was an author of the new study.
He said the vetiver research findings should not detract from the importance of crop rotation and other erosion-control techniques that can be used alone in colder climates or in conjunction with vetiver in warmer areas. Dr. Pimentel said it takes 200 to 1,000 years to replace one inch of topsoil. "Once topsoil is lost, you cannot sit around and wait for it to correct itself," he said.
Dr. W. Doral Kemper, who directs the research unit on soil and water conservation for the Agriculture Department, is studying other methods to control soil erosion. He said rows of vetiver and other grasses should be planted more widely because the method was described about 50 years ago and works well. He said he was looking for other grasses that would withstand colder climates, like those in the Northern United States and Canada.
The researchers said that since a simple row of vetiver could keep large amounts of water on crops longer, they grow faster and denser. Dr. Vietmeyer said that in a poor economy when farmers tend to live hand to mouth, they see little incentive to protect the land from damage that might not become apparent for another decade.
"Increased moisture in the soil makes the crops and trees grow better," he said. "To the farmer struggling to feed his family this year, that may be the only important reason to plant vetiver."
