HEADLINE: Social Castes Found to Be Not So Rare In Nature

BYLINE: By CAROL KAESUK YOON

 BODY:
FOR years, an exclusive club made up of ants, bees, wasps and termites has ruled as the social elite of the animal world. The insects' well-run colonies of sterile workers devoted to serving their fat, fertile queens so impressed biologists as to acquire the scientific classification of social or "eusocial," a distinction even humans cannot claim.
But new studies indicate that many more species besides these well-known examples may be living eusocial lives, giving up their own chances of reproduction to help foster the offspring of others. 
 Scientists have now discovered eusociality in two species of thrips, a tiny insect. The eusocial thrips live as colonies in plant galls, defended by armed soldiers that never reproduce and will fight to the death against invaders. Eusociality has also been observed recently among a species of ambrosia beetles. The beetles live deep in tunnels inside eucalyptus trees, their sole purpose being to build and maintain their queen's labyrinthine world, never reproducing themselves.
Along with tree-dwelling aphids and the bizarre naked mole-rat, these species are helping to swell the ranks of those known to be eusocial.
Biologists say that the new additions may provide an important key to the puzzle of how such societies have come to exist. And researchers are happily predicting that many more such surprises are in store.
"A lot more animals are going to turn out to be eusocial," said Dr. Bernie Crespi, assistant professor of evolutionary biology at Simon Fraser University in British Columbia and the discoverer of the eusocial thrips. "People have thought that everything had been more or less discovered, but now that appears not to be the case at all."
Deborah S. Kent, a researcher with the Forestry Commission of New South Wales in Australia, discovered the ambrosia beetle's self-sacrificing habits by accident.
'We weren't even looking for the beetles being eusocial," Ms. Kent said. "We were looking at them because they're an economic problem in eucalyptus plantations and regrowth and have been for the last 40 years. People had already studied them but never recognized what was going on. The more people look the more they'll find."
Dr. William D. Hamilton, professor of evolutionary biology at Oxford University and a pioneer in understanding the evolution of eusociality, has a great respect for the phenomenon.
"It's the highest form of sociality," he said, "and it's what enables the ants to dominate the tropics. No organism but man so dominates everything that goes on in a tropical rain forest." Dr. Hamilton attributes the ants' success to their ability to organize their activities.
Dr. Hamilton was one of the first researchers to begin to solve the paradox of how the evolutionary struggle to survive and reproduce could give rise to creatures that never reproduce and spend their lives altruistically helping others to survive.
Ants, bees and wasps, known collectively as the hymenoptera, all share an unusual genetic system in which males carry only half the normal number of chromosomes, receiving a single set from their mothers. But a hymenopteran female, in the more conventional fashion, receives one set of chromosomes each from her mother and father.
Dr. Hamilton was the first to point out that the unusual genetics of the hymenoptera have the curious effect of making a female more closely related to her sisters than to even her own children, since she shares three-quarters of her genes in common with her siblings, but only half in common with her offspring. As a result, in order to propagate more of her genes into future generations, she can do better by staying in her mother's nest and helping to raise sisters rather than reproducing herself.
 
Looking at a Creature's Home
 The idea was a breakthrough in understanding eusociality, but not a complete answer. While all hymenoptera have the same genetic system of sex determination, not all are eusocial. In addition, termites, naked mole-rats and ambrosia beetles all carry the normal ratios of chromosomes from their mothers and fathers. So scientists have continued to search for a factor besides genetics that lies at the heart of the drive to become eusocial.
The new examples of eusociality hint that the nature of an animal's home may hold the answer.
As more eusocial species come to light, researchers note that a common thread is that of living inside a "valuable resource," like a hive or nest, that has taken much labor to build and maintain, and is valuable enough to die for.
In the near-deserts in eastern Australia, acacia trees dot the landscape, some daintily ornamented with small football-like shapes, inside of which hide the world's two known species of eusocial thrips.
Early in the growing season, female thrips, perhaps an eighth of an inch long, arrive at an acacia plant and begin eating one of its leaf-like stems. The stem will slowly develop into a gall in a football-like shape around the insect, creating a food-filled cavern in which she and all her offspring can live, safe from predators. Some of her offspring develop large front legs, armed with daggers pointing inward, which these soldiers use to kill those who threaten their home.
 
All-Important Home
 It turns out that there is only a short period during which a thrips can induce a plant to form a gall. Once that time is past, the thrips in the area must fight it out over those galls that have been created.
Dr. Crespi said the thrips were constantly fending off invaders, some of whom are other thrips that cannot make homes of their own and are specialized in stealing galls, as well as predators who come to eat the thrips themselves. Dr. Crespi's research on these creatures, financed by the National Geographic Society, was a decade in the making.
Researchers say the intense pressure to protect the all-important home base has driven the thrips, as well as others, to evolve a eusocial life style, complete with kamikaze soldiers that will defend it.
Similarly, eusocial aphids, like those discovered by Dr. Nancy Moran, an evolutionary biologist at the University of Arizona at Tucson, patrol and defend the tiny galls they have formed on the cottonwood trees of Arizona; the galls are both a home and a source of food.
Dr. Moran said the galls had only a single exit hole, exactly the right size for a soldier aphid to exit for her patrolling duty. When someone or something disturbs a gall, which can contain thousands of aphids, the soldiers come out to attack and have been known to jam their plant-sucking mouth parts into human as well as insect intruders. Other aphids use horns on their heads to deter attackers.
"I was excited to find it," Dr. Moran said of the North American eusocial aphid. "It was sort of a mystery previously as to why there hadn't been any discoveries in North America, nothing besides hymenopterans and termites. There's more out there, for sure. It's mostly a matter of having someone there to look for it. I was on a hike when I found these."
While valuable, the homes defended by aphids and thrips pale in comparison to those fashioned by the ambrosia beetle. These beetles build extensive galleries of tunnels in the inner deadwood of eucalyptus trees.
When a female begins to build her empire, she works alone for more than six months drilling an entrance hole into the tree. It is often more than a year later when she finally lays the eggs that will produce the help she so desperately needs to continue her tunneling work.
 
Named for Food of Gods
 Ms. Kent said these enigmatic beetles were named after the food of the gods because biologists could not figure out what the insects were eating. Researchers now know that the beetles feed upon a fungus that they cultivate in their elaborate tunnel system. Ms. Kent describes the fungus as a moist, black sheen on the tunnel walls.
Researchers identify trees containing a beetle colony by tiny entrance ways, a tunnel of eucalyptus resin that sticks out of the tree like a spout. Unable to observe the beetles without killing the trees, researchers collect their samples by chain saw. After surveying more than 300 different colonies, Ms. Kent said she had found that the fungus galleries created by the beetles could be maintained for nearly 40 years. Scientists do not know how long the beetles or their queen live.
The importance of the galleries, not only for food production, but for safety, has also become clearer to scientists. Ms. Kent said that in all her surveys, only one predator was found inside a beetle home.
Naked mole-rats, whose lives were recently described in detail in "The Biology of the Naked Mole-Rat" (Princeton University Press, 1991), also build cavernous tunnels in which they live and love. Now a popular zoo animal, the once mysterious creature, nearly as ugly as it is intriguing, is the only eusocial mammal known.
These buck-toothed rodents dig tunnels in the East African savannah, inside of which reign a reproductive queen and several stud kings. While the number of these mole-rats can range up to 300 in a single colony, many of these inhabitants will never reproduce.
Many question remain for researchers about the origins of eusociality. In particular, the naked mole-rat has kept biologists asking why no other mammal, including humans, has evolved sterile, worker castes.

HEADLINE: SPORTS MARKETING;
Gifted Russian Youths, Sign Up Here

BYLINE: By FILIP BONDY

 BODY:
Pro Sports of Moscow, a fledgling talent agency loosely modeled after high-powered companies in the United States, recently began signing contracts with the parents of Russian children.
For providing coaches and training facilities to these potential stars, Pro Sports will receive 35 percent of what the athletes between the ages of 18 and 28 earn, plus an additional 5 percent for coaches assigned to the program. 
 In another place, in another time, this arrangement might have shocked some people and sparked an internal debate on sports and exploitation. But in Russia, now the Wild Wild West of the Eastern sports bloc, hardly a head was turned in disapproval as parents and guardians rushed to sign off on their talented 11-year-olds.
"If it helps children and coincides with the Olympic program, why not?" said Barazby Sabanchyev, head of marketing for the Olympic Committee of Russia.
 
Flow of Resources
 For decades, the Government of the Soviet Union poured its resources into three areas of technology: military hardware, aerospace research and Olympic sports. Now, the former Soviet Union is officially fractured into 15 independent national sports federations with no public financing and a great deal of capitalistic casting about for the sporting buck.
In Russia, apparently top-level sports will survive, contrary to dire predictions offered not so very long ago. After producing 111 medalists for the Unified Team at the Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, the Russian republic remains the richest and most frenetic sports marketplace in the former Soviet Union.
National Olympic officials, along with a new breed of business opportunists, are forging new alliances each day with some of the most experienced, most impatient coaches in the world.
"If our coaches are the best in the world, they have to be rewarded what they're worth," said Aleksandr Koslovsky, secretary general of the Olympic Committee of Russia. "And they have to be patriotic enough to stay in a country where it is impossible to spend the money."
The money is arriving, some of it from surprising sources. The St. Petersburg Organizing Committee for the Goodwill Games in 1994, hoping to raise funds to support the international event and to maintain a strong national team, has begun a lottery at 50 rubles a ticket (about 9 cents) for a 2-million-ruble top prize ($3,571). This is the only lottery in Russia and figures to bring in enough revenue by itself to keep existing sports programs intact.
 
Financing Them All
 In January, Reebok International signed a breakthrough sponsorship agreement with the Russian Olympic Committee that will help finance all 20 of the Russian sports federations, from basketball to weight lifting, at least through the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta and possibly beyond.
Other developments represent a new attitude toward fund-raising. The Olympic Committee of Russia, which won an internal battle of its own to represent the country in dealings with the International Olympic Committee, has sealed a marketing agreement with Harvey Schiller, executive director of the United States Olympic Committee. Both federations soon will sell the other's emblems in merchandizing plans that range from pins to sweatshirts.
An American-style sports dinner was held in Siberia in October, co-sponsored by the Olympic Siberian Academy and the Olympic Committee of Russia, honoring past Olympic greats. There was a business seminar in Moscow last month, as six sports businessmen from the West tried to explain to Russian administrators and unlicensed agents exactly how events and organizations can attract sponsorship money.
 
Costly Meals
 In June, there will be a fund-raising dinner at the Moscow Concert Hall, where the Russian Athlete of the Year will be announced to diners who have paid dearly for their meals.
"We must raise not only hard currency but rubles," said Sabanchyev, who must operate in an economy beset by inflation, and where the average Russian earns about $5 a month according to the latest exchange rate. "That is why we need Russian companies for sponsors, in addition to Western corporations. We've just started looking for sponsors, but already experienced three or four."
The Reebok deal was important for reasons other than the sheer dollar figure, which remains undisclosed. Other than a relatively minor agreement with the Elf oil company of France, the Russians had been unable to convince any major corporation that they were stable enough to support a major sponsor.
"My perception is that the sports organizations in general have survived three different regimes, that the middle bureaucracy is intact, and that they will continue to survive," said Roberto Muller, president of Reebok's Sports Division. "If Russia is no longer a true superpower, then sports becomes the only vehicle for the people's pride."
Just in case of unforeseen political in-fighting, Muller made 20 separate deals with the 20 separate sports federations in Russia.
"Billy Payne, the head of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, wants $40 million for every sponsorship," Muller said. "Compared to that, these federations are a bargain."
 
'Now's the Time'
 Not all potential investors are ready to bite. Don Dixon, head of the Lifestyle Marketing Group in New York, was approached about getting American corporations to buy "signage" on the jerseys of Russian soccer and ice hockey teams. He also received a fax in December from organizers seeking sponsors for the 1993 Baltic Games, where 350 athletes from the former Soviet Union will compete.
"I tell clients, now's the time to make contacts," said Dixon, who attended the marketing seminar in Moscow. "But I tell them, don't put dollar one in until you see what happens with the Yeltsin Government. By the second quarter of this year, you're looking at a solid opportunity on high-volume, low-cost products. You can make inroads."
Steve Woods, vice president of sales and marketing for the ProServ agency in Atlanta, also attended the seminar. In the future, he said, ProServ might represent the American endorsements of Russia's top athletes. But the agency is unlikely to compete with Pro Sports or any other Russian company on Russian turf. The rewards are too few.
"They're so much in the infancy of marketing," Woods said. "You have to tell them that putting up a logo in an arena is a good thing. They say, 'Why?' Everything is so loose. It's hard to make appointments, poor phone lines. They're between five and 10 years away from basic concepts."
 
Looking at Ethics
 Woods has pondered the ethical behavior of agencies such as Pro Sports, which takes the concept of the American-style agent several steps beyond its current definition.
"All it takes for these agencies is for one player to make it to the N.H.L., the N.B.A. or a pro soccer team and all the investments pay off," he said. "I thought about it for a while, signing away a kid for 10 years, and I'm not sure if that system is beneficial or harmful. It's hard for us to judge. We don't see the pain or despair."
Sergei Guzkov, press information director for the Olympic Committee of Russia, is the most optimistic Olympic official around, perhaps because it is his job to present the proper positive image.
"Not all recommendations we can use from outside," Guzkov said. "TV income and big ticket sales is impossible. But we now know about licencing emblems and sponsorship. They will help."
 
Role of Benefactors
 Guzkov remains hopeful that the newest sports entrepreneurs will turn into great benefactors of Russian sports.
"How they use the money is important," he said, of Pro Sports and similar new businesses. "If they put it back into sports, that is good. If they keep it for personal use, that will be very bad."
Like most sports officials from Russia and the 14 other republics now recognized as independent by the international sports community, Guzkov still longs for the old days, before all the hustling.
"It is very difficult to destroy the ties," Guzkov said. "In our minds, we still take the field together."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Through Ups and Downs, Harazin Stays Solid as a Rock

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 15

 BODY:
Al Harazin's favorite piece of personal apparel is a dinosaur lapel pin. The pin, given to him as a gift by the Mets, is meant to symbolize Harazin's status as one of a disappearing breed in baseball, namely that of monolithic executive.
Harazin, the club's general manager, is also its chief operating officer, responsible for everything from contract negotiations to trades to stadium operations to marketing to broadcasting. 
 The dinosaur, one season and 90 losses into his tenure, was asked if he ever worried about sudden extinction.
"Maybe I'm hopelessly naive," said Harazin, "but I don't worry about job security."
 
No Hot Seats Here
 The general manager's chair at Shea Stadium has historically not been a terribly hot one, irrespective of the club's fortunes on the field. Frank Cashen was hired to start the 1980's, was retained through several difficult and dreadful transition seasons, was lauded when the Mets evolved into challengers and then champions midway through the decade, and then he was allowed to effectively retire on his own timetable as the Mets staggered through the early 1990's.
But Harazin, while confident and secure, hardly feels entirely immunized from the abrupt, often arbitrary, consistently uncharacteristic hirings and firings that dot and frequently mar the landscape of sports, both professional and amateur.
"I think the job of general manager in baseball has become more and more like the field managers," he said. "There is too much credit given them and too much blame. Our ownership has to evaluate how comfortable it is with its key executives. I think the track record of our owners is that they have staying power. That said, if there were to be a failure over a sustained period of time, I'm sure they'd be prepared to make changes."
There certainly appears to be no change being actively considered. Harazin met with the club owners, Fred Wilpon and Nelson Doubleday, here today for several hours and emerged smiling in the Florida sunshine. The Mets' 1992 season, with its 72-90 record, second straight fifth-place finish, myriad injuries and uproars, had at last removed itself from Harazin's horizons.
 
Finding No Fault
 "One of the owners said in the course of the meeting that for all that went wrong in 1992, he couldn't fault anything we did," Harazin said.
"Al's fine," Doubleday said in a brief interview after the meeting. "He may need to get more of his people in there over time, but the transition from Frank to Al has been smooth. He can do the job."
The job has had its share of upheaval in the 18 months Harazin has had it. To some, he was an aggressive and bold executive when he signed Manager Jeff Torborg while the man was under contract to the White Sox. To some, he was a baseball innocent and accountant gone mad when he signed off on huge checks to Bobby Bonilla, Eddie Murray and John Franco.
 
Trades and Turmoil
 To some, he was a genius for his acquisition of Bret Saberhagen. To some, he was less than brilliant in his quick decision to trade David Cone without creating as lucrative a market as possible for the star pitcher.
And through it all, there was the specter of what all the trades and turmoil and dollars meant in the corporate annual report. Attendance at Shea has shrunk from 3 million in 1988 to 1.8 million in 1992. Harazin, though, noted that the Mets still sold 2.5 million tickets in 1992.
"Have there been real financial implications? Yes," said Harazin. "You lose 90 games and finish fifth against the backdrop of a New York economy that has 13 percent unemployment, and that's a tough formula."
Asked what he considered his greatest accomplishment in his first season as general manager, Harazin said that was too tough a question.
"I'm not sure I'm entitled to say I've had a great accomplishment," he said. "It's been an accomplishment, I think, to have put Bobby Bonilla and Eddie Murray and Bret Saberhagen and Tony Fernandez on the roster. But it's not a genuine accomplishment until there are results. We haven't had those."
 
It All Adds Up
 As he entered his second spring training, Harazin said he has not found his lack of a pure baseball background to be a handicap, and that his training as a lawyer and negotiator has been a plus in an environment when so many considerations other than baseball talent enter into so many personnel decisions.
He said that with his assumption of Cashen's final title last month -- chief operating officer -- he has had to delegate more authority, and to that end he turned over all arbitration cases and all but multiyear contract negotiatons to Gerry Hunsicker, the club's assistant vice president.
"What has appealed to me throughout, and why I wanted the job cast as Frank had it, was the diversity," Harazin said. "I'm not like Joe McIlvaine. I didn't come up on the field. My interests have been broader."
The standard of evaluation, though, remains singular: win. Harazin understands it. And for the moment, he doesn't fear it.

HEADLINE: A Park in Peril

 BODY:
Just over 100 years ago, New York State's Legislature created one of America's outdoor treasures: a six-million-acre patchwork of state forests, timber tracts and private lands called the Adirondack State Park. Now in its centennial year plus one, the park faces threats from developers, from the changing economics of the timber business and from legislators who are not as prescient as their forerunners.
The Adirondacks are nowhere near as stressed as the national parks, which absorbed an astounding 250 million visitors last year. The Adirondacks, though larger than the Everglades, Glacier, Grand Canyon and Yellowstone National Parks combined, welcomed nine million. Albany does not therefore confront a salvage operation. Elected officials have only to muster the sense to preserve New York's jewel for future generations. 
 There's hope. Gov. Mario Cuomo and Assembly Speaker Sol Weprin propose to strike a balance between preservationists and the park's 130,000 proud and poor permanent residents. The Weprin bill, already approved by the Assembly, offers villages economic aid while increasing zoning protection for shorelines and wilderness.
Unfortunately, compromise is not in the blood of the Republican-controlled Senate, where the majority leader, Ralph Marino, has routinely deferred to his deputy, Senator Ronald Stafford of Plattsburgh, on matters involving the park. Mr. Marino's myopic view is that the fate of the Adirondacks is a regional issue best left to local residents and their champion, Mr. Stafford.
That argument ignores not only other New Yorkers whose taxes help the park but also the visitors, who do not come in search of subdivisions or dirty streams. That is what they may someday find unless Mr. Marino gets smarter. Housing construction jumped 50 percent in the last two decades, much of it in undisturbed back country.
Tougher zoning is a first step. Only money can solve another threat: the growing eagerness of timber companies to sell large holdings. Unlike timber interests in the national forests, Adirondack loggers have coexisted happily with backpackers, avoiding flagrant clearcutting while providing local tax revenue.
But New York's logging costs, mainly taxes, are higher than elsewhere. In a gesture reflecting both economic realities and a keen sense of public relations, the International Paper Company recently donated 22,000 acres of forest and white-water rivers to a conservation foundation. Unfortunately, miracles don't happen every day. Champion Paper may soon put 90,000 acres on the block.
Mr. Cuomo's budget thus proposes an environmental trust fund. The fund would offer owners tax incentives to keep their land intact, allow the state to compete with developers and compensate local governments for forgone tax revenues.
The fund earmarks only $10 million for the Adirondacks in the first year. But a little goes a long way up north; $10 million would have bought International Paper's tract with enough left over to bid for Follensby Pond, Ralph Waldo Emerson's picturesque 19th-century retreat and a talisman for preservationists.
Yet Mr. Cuomo's good intentions will mean nothing unless Senate Republicans can be brought to see what their predecessors saw a century ago: that the park is an issue of consequence to all New Yorkers, including generations yet unborn.

HEADLINE: Don't Worry, Be Happy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It amazes me that a panel of 11 experts from the National Research Council, part of a private organization, has announced that "AIDS was concentrated among homosexuals, drug users, the poor and the undereducated, and called them 'socially marginalized groups' with little economic, political, and social power" (news article, Feb. 5). 
 If this is the case, I am interested to hear their explanation of the increase of AIDS cases among women across America. Their belief that AIDS will disappear "because those who continue to be affected by it are socially invisible, beyond sight and attention of the majority population" shows only their ignorance to society as a whole. These unnamed experts go further by stating "the H.I.V.-AIDS epidemic has affected many transient changes in the institutions we studied and relatively few changes that we expect to be permanent."
AIDS has affected everybody, and for it to be compared to influenza or the bubonic plague (such as the panel did) is simply asinine. The prevalent attitude that only society's undesirables will suffer from AIDS is precisely what has allowed this epidemic to flourish.
 
GREGORY E. MURDZAK
Edinboro, Pa., Feb. 5, 1993

HEADLINE: On Making Good Manners Look Sinister

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I read with no small amazement your Feb. 5 front-page article on the letter Robert E. Rubin, President Clinton's top economic adviser, wrote to his Goldman Sachs & Company clients before taking up his post as head of Mr. Clinton's new National Economic Council. My amazement was not that Mr. Rubin wrote such a letter, but that you found it news. 
 When a person leaves one position for another, it is generally considered good manners to write such a letter to clients of his old company with whom he has dealt. About five years ago, I left a large law firm for a multibillion-dollar, publicly held corporation. At that time I wrote a similar letter to all of my clients. I praised my old firm and assured those clients they would continue to be well served by it. I also told each client how much I valued our relationship and urged that we remain in touch. A number of the recipients of that letter were suppliers of my new employer.
Reading your article causes me to realize that someone could have painted that letter as a subtle message that continuing business with my old firm might lead to favorable consideration on multimillion-dollar contracts with my new employer.
For Mr. Rubin not to have written a letter such as this one would have been ungentlemanly and disloyal to a company he spent years helping to build. That he is entering Government service, even at such a high level, does not change the dictates of common courtesy to business associates or obligation to former partners to minimize the disruption of an unanticipated departure.
For men of Mr. Rubin's ability, accomplishments and position to enter Government is no small sacrifice to them, their families and their business partners, to whom they feel a responsibility. Your article shows that in return for a 90 percent pay cut and the interruption of a brilliant career, one can be rewarded on entering public service with a baseless assault on one's integrity.
Such disincentives to public service, particularly when the country needs the best financial and economic talent available, is not in the public interest.
 
W. G. CHAMPION MITCHELL
Washington, Feb. 8, 1993

HEADLINE: Politics Complicates Formulas for Aid to Schools

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 15

 BODY:
In 1986, budget talks in the New York State Assembly hit a glitch: according to computer-generated calculations from a school aid formula, New York City would receive more money than legislative leaders had agreed on.
But no new negotiations were needed to solve this problem, just a few strokes of a computer keyboard. By changing a number in the city's equation by .125, a legislative aide made the city appear wealthier. And with that, the city's aid dropped by more than $40 million, aligning itself neatly with the leaders' agreement. 
 The budget was passed, and few in the public, the city schools or even the Legislature itself knew what had happened.
Critics of the state's school aid system often use that recalculation as the perfect example of what is wrong with the way the state apportions aid. They say it illustrates a long-honored but rarely discussed Albany tradition: the use of complex aid formulas to mask political decisions.
This year, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has proposed replacing 15 school aid formulas with one equation that would give significantly more money to poor districts and districts with high costs of living. The state Board of Regents is preparing to issue similar recommendations.
 
Opposition From Both Parties
 But Mr. Cuomo's efforts face a hard core of bipartisan opposition led by lawmakers who say the plan will help the urban and rural poor at the expense of the middle class.
The city is expected to try a different route to change. City officials said that they plan to sue the state, charging that they are not getting their fair share of the money.
The city's suit, which could be filed next month, mirrors a suit filed on behalf of 40 Long Island school districts which charged that the state's system discriminates against poor districts. In the last three years, similar suits in New Jersey, Kentucky, Texas and Kansas have brought major changes to those states' school financing systems.
To many experts, court action offers the best chance for revamping New York's system as well. Three times in the last two decades, state commissions have recommended making the system simpler and more equitable to the poor, and each time those efforts have fizzled in the Legislature.
"Attempting to change formulas is like a Russian novel: it's long, boring and in the end everybody gets killed," said John G. Augenblick, a consultant on school financing issues who is based in Denver.
A comparison of schools in North Shore School District in Nassau County and Community School District 6 in upper Manhattan illustrates the problems behind the school aid debate.
Nestled amid sand-swept streets near the Long Island Sound, North Shore High School offers its students a well-stocked computer lab that stays open after school, class sizes of 20 or fewer students and a 55-page catalogue with courses ranging from Japanese to Contemporary Film to Long Island Studies. Only about 3 percent of its students are poor enough to receive free lunches. Last year, 98 percent of its graduating seniors went to college.
 
Classes in a Locker Room
 The Eleanor Roosevelt Intermediate School in Manhattan's Washington Heights section packs 1,700 students, almost as many as in the entire North Shore district, into a building designed for 1,300. Classes average more than 30 students, a locker room doubles as classroom and the gym is used by five classes at one time. Lunch starts at 10:30 A.M. to insure that every student has time to eat.
More than 90 percent of its students speak no English at home, 86 percent are poor enough to receive free lunches and more than 60 percent are considered "at-risk" students based on low standardized test scores. About half will not graduate from high school or attend college.
Ranked by the state as above average in wealth, North Shore spends $14,000 a year on each student, raised primarily from local taxes. But the district also receives about $1,100 per student in state aid. New York City spends half as much as North Shore on each of its students, but receives just $2,000 more per student in state aid.
 
Closing the Gap
 To critics of the current financing system, the state should do more to close that $7,000 spending gap because New York City lacks the tax base to raise as much revenue as North Shore.
But superintendents from wealthier districts contend that spending differences are inevitable. And while many support giving more aid to poorer districts, they do not want their districts to pay for it.
"The goal of equality is unassailable," said Michael V. McGill, North Shore's superintendent. "What is assailable is that in the process of achieving that goal, you level everybody down."
Faced with that devil's choice, many legislators vehemently oppose changing the school aid system now. But even during the flush 1980's, school aid reform stalled in the Legislature. To understand why is to understand a process that has become known as "policy by printout."
To outsiders, it might seem a triumph of social science over politics: almost 30 formulas built from data about the wealth, size and needs of 718 school districts are run through computers that calculate aid for each.
 
'Working Backward'
 But the reality is quite different. Blending the smoke-filled back room with silicon-chip technology, legislative leaders decide how much money will go to each region, then have their aides tinker with the formulas until computers produce the desired results.
"It's a process of working backward," said Robert Berne, a professor of public administration at New York University and a consultant to the Board of Regents.
Though politics pervades decisions on school aid in most states, experts say that New York -- which spends more than any other state except New Jersey on education -- takes formula tampering to new heights. "In many other states, they have a formula which they may tinker with a little bit, but basically it holds for a few decades," said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States in Albany. "But in New York, it is up for grabs every year."
Part of the reason is that every legislator has a stake in school aid, unlike many other budget items. Not only is the $8.5 billion school aid package the state's largest expenditure, accounting for about a fourth of the $31.5 billion general-funds budget this year, but every legislator represents at least one school district that receives aid.
And since state aid can determine whether a district raises taxes, buys new books or increases class sizes, its impact is readily noticed by voters, many of whom measure their legislator's effectiveness by the amount of aid their district gets.
 
Tinkering With the Formula
 Some critics contend that the very complexity of the system helps obscure the legislators' machinations, providing an aura of mathematical legitimacy to political decisions. "The trickiness comes in the details," said Jerry Miner, a professor of economics at Syracuse University. "For years, the state has been able to diddle around with this formula because no one else understood it."
And the machinations are legion. In 1974, the main school aid formula -- known as the general operating formula -- was designed to give more money to poor districts. But in the last two decades, more than a dozen new types of aid have been created, many of which insure that affluent districts receive a steady stream of aid outside the main formula.
For instance, the Legislature created aid to help districts, many of them suburban, keep property taxes down. In the mid-1980's, when many suburban districts no longer qualified for that assistance, a new category, Supplemental Support, began to channel them additional money.
 
'Save-Harmless'
 And the Legislature established a fail-safe mechanism that prevented districts from losing money even if the general operating formula said they should. Known as "save-harmless," that mechanism enabled districts on Long Island and in Westchester to receive stable or increasing amounts of aid in the 1980's even as their student populations were shrinking.
"New York State is known for having one of the highest proportions of save-harmless districts," Mr. Augenblick said -- about half. "Any time you have that, it means that the formula, which should be the fair way of dealing with aid, is not being allowed to do its work for political reasons."
Suburban legislators say New York City has also benefited from formula-fiddling. During the 1980's, programs were created for at-risk students, magnet schools and reading programs that have given millions in aid almost exclusively to urban districts.
Mr. Cuomo's aides say that his plan would help remove politics from school aid calculations by eliminating the save-harmless mechanism and 15 of the assistance formulas, ranging from transportation aid to gifted-and-talented programs. His formula would give more money to districts with large numbers of students poor enough to receive free lunches.
 
Aid Reductions
 Among experts, there is much agreement that numerous formula changes have reduced the system's ability to close the gap between rich and poor because they have spread the school aid pot thinner. And while that was less of a problem in the 1980's, when school aid increased every year, it has become a major issue in the 1990's, when aid has been cut by $429 million. This year, Mr. Cuomo has called for another $130 million reduction.
The brunt of those cuts has fallen on more-affluent districts. But poor districts, which depend more heavily on state aid, have been hit as well. After losing $3 million in aid in 1991, Syracuse cut 117 teaching positions and saw the average size of its elementary school classes grow from 23 to 28, said Dr. Henry Williams, the superintendent.
"Rich districts can reach into their pockets to make up the difference; poor districts can't," said Daniel P. Levitt, an attorney for the Long Island plaintiffs.

HEADLINE: 2 Dozen New Taxes Weighed To Pay for Health Care Plans

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
The White House said today that it would cost $30 billion to $90 billion a year to carry out President Clinton's campaign promise of guaranteeing health care for all Americans, and Administration officials said they were considering two dozen new taxes as possible sources of revenue.
The taxes being considered are in addition to those the President will propose Wednesday to Congress to stimulate the economy and to help reduce the Federal budget deficit, Administration officials said.
 
Mrs. Clinton Visits Congress
 The White House made the disclosure as Hillary Rodham Clinton, chairwoman of the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform, visited the House of Representatives to lobby lawmakers of both parties on the issue. 
 Asked whether she and the President wanted to levy higher taxes to finance a national health-care plan, Mrs. Clinton did not answer directly. "There isn't a plan yet, so I'm not going to comment on that," she said. But she quickly added: "It's time this country faced reality and dealt with its problems. It's not going to be easy."
 
Engineering 'Massive Change'
 Confidential work papers from Mrs. Clinton's task force show that the Administration is considering taxes on insurance premiums, corporate health benefits, alcoholic beverages, tobacco products and guns, among other sources of revenue for health care.
White House officials emphasized that no decisions had been made. But the work papers show that the new social program that Mrs. Clinton and her aides are contemplating would be bigger than any created in more than 50 years.
"Reforming the health-care system will involve Government-led changes on a scale not attempted since Social Security," one memorandum says. "People are calling for massive change, yet their support for individual plans is very weak."
Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, welcomed Mrs. Clinton to Capitol Hill today. But in an interview, he said proposals being considered by her committee looked like "washed-over old-time bureaucratic liberalism, or centralized bureaucratic socialism."
The memorandum from the staff of Mrs. Clinton's task force says the Administration is determined to provide "universal access to affordable high-quality health care for all Americans."
"Depending on definitions and program structure," it says, "universal access could mean $30 billion or $90 billion of additional annual expenditure by the Government by 1997."
In contrast, Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, cost the Federal Government $129 billion in the last fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30; Medicaid, the program for low-income people, cost $68 billion.
 
Businesses to See Savings
 The memorandum says that businesses, not Government, will reap most of the savings generated by cost controls under President Clinton's plan. But it says the Government can "recapture" some of these savings, to pay for expanding access to health care and perhaps also to help reduce the Federal budget deficit.
In the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton said Government savings from controlling health-care costs would be used exclusively to expand access to health care, not to reduce the deficit. And Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, repeated that commitment at her confirmation hearings in January.
Among possible sources of revenue for the President's plan, the memorandum lists these possibilities:
*Taxing health insurance premiums.
*Raising a corporate tax to capture part of the savings that corporations realize from slower premium growth.
*Taxing benefit plans that offer coverage above a certain level, to encourage employers and workers to choose health maintenance organizations and other forms of health insurance that offer the best value.
*Increasing taxes on alcohol and tobacco products, pollutants, guns and other things that contribute to health problems.
In addition, a memorandum written in part by Ira C. Magaziner, senior adviser to the President for policy development, and first reported in today's Wall Street Journal says "about 20 other alternatives" are available to raise revenue for the health plan.
In the campaign, Mr. Clinton said American businesses could be more productive and competitive in world markets if their employees' health costs were not rising so fast. Now it appears that businesses may not be allowed to keep all the savings but may have to pay a portion to the Government in new taxes.
Moreover, the memorandum confirms that the President and Mrs. Clinton see an immediate need to impose cost controls on the health-care industry without waiting for Congress to revamp the nation's health system.
The memorandum says the Administration wants to "elicit voluntary controls from the health-care industry." But just in case doctors do not volunteer, the Administration is seeking "ways to extend Medicare rate regulation to private insurance systems."
Medicare imposed a national fee schedule for doctors last year. Leaders of the American Medical Association met today with Mr. Magaziner at the White House to make clear that they did not want the Government to regulate their fees for private patients outside the Medicare program.
In an interview tonight, Dr. Raymond Scalettar, chairman of the association, said, "There are so many flaws in the Medicare fee schedule that it could not possibly be used in the private sector."
The memorandum from Mrs. Clinton's task force confirms that the President still wants to require all employers to arrange health insurance for their workers and "to pay a percentage (perhaps 75 to 80 percent) of the cost of a standard plan for their employees and dependents."
"Hence, most people would continue to have largely employer-financed coverage," the memo says. "The Federal Government would assist small companies in the early years so that this requirement would not cause undue hardship."
 
Drug Makers Respond
 The memorandum seems to assume that drug prices will be controlled. Listing questions to be addressed by the task force, the memorandum asks: "How will drug price increases be controlled? Will this be done nationally? How can we insure that innovation is not stifled?"
Drug company executives tried today to answer criticisms of their industry last week by the President and Mrs. Clinton.
On Friday, President Clinton called vaccine prices "shocking," and said some drug companies were making excessive profits. "In a public clinic," he said, "the cost of fully immunizing a child has leapt from $7 to more than $90" in the last decade.
Dr. R. Gordon Douglas Jr., president of the vaccine division of Merck & Company, said today that "the President's data were highly inaccurate and misleading." Of the $83 increase in vaccine prices, Dr. Douglas said, 80 percent is attributable to Federal excise taxes and the development of new vaccines for hepatitis B and Haemophilus influenzae type b.

HEADLINE: FEW TO PAY MORE IN INCOME TAXES, PRESIDENT INSISTS

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Wary of early negative reaction to his plan to cut the budget deficit and stimulate the economy, President Clinton sought today to assure the public that most middle-income Americans would not be hurt. The White House said income taxes would rise only for families earning more than $180,000 a year.
The White House also said that to protect households earning less than $30,000 a year it would suggest tax breaks to offset a proposed tax on energy and any other new levies in the program he will announce Wednesday night. 
 As new details emerged about the economic plan, and as the stock market tumbled nearly 83 points, Mr. Clinton's aides continued to maintain that families earning more than $100,000 year, about 4.4 percent of the population, would shoulder 70 percent of the burden of new taxes.
 
More Demanded From Many
 But the plan would demand more money from all households earning more than $30,000 a year, if not in income taxes then in other ways. Beyond that, officials said the Administration was also considering two dozen other taxes to be introduced later this year to cover the costs of Mr. Clinton's still unfinished health-insurance program.
White House officials also said tonight that Mr. Clinton would probably propose an additional surcharge on those earning more than $250,000 a year that would raise the top income tax rate to 39.6 percent. Administration officials said such a tax would probably affect only millionaires.
Many details of Mr. Clinton's plan, which he will unveil on Wednesday in a speech before a joint session of Congress, remained ill defined. But on the day after Mr. Clinton's televised appeal for middle-class sacrifice, which he said was unavoidable, the White House scrambled to convince people that Mr. Clinton was not abandoning his pledge to protect the middle class.
 
Explaining a Shift
 During the campaign, Mr. Clinton said he would raise taxes only on those earning more than $200,000 a year, but aides said he felt forced to lower that threshold because the deficit was larger than expected.
Republicans, however, immediately accused Mr. Clinton of going back on his promise to protect middle-class Americans and blamed him for the drop in stock prices. "Watch your wallets," said Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, who denounced Mr. Clinton's program. "Boy, there are a lot of taxes in there."
As the President visited a construction site in Washington and addressed an economics conference in California by satellite, he and his aides dismissed the stock market decline as unrelated to the Monday night speech. They cited the relative stability of the bond markets as evidence that any judgment on the emerging plan is premature.
 
The Market in Perspective
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 82.94 points today. But since Mr. Clinton was elected, the market has been unusually strong. The closing figure today was still 57.01 points higher than it was the day after the election and 53.5 points higher than it was on Inauguration Day.
The final package of economic plans, said George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, would include $100 billion in nonmilitary spending cuts over four years.
Administration officials are predicting that 70 percent of the taxes Mr. Clinton will propose would fall on the upper 4.4 percent income group. Households with incomes under $30,000 -- roughly 50 percent of all Americans -- would not have higher taxes at all, they say.
Mr. Clinton also said that his short-term plan would create 500,000 new jobs through private investment.
 
More Than 'Raw Pain'
 "I think when you see the whole program it, it won't be raw pain," Mr. Clinton said. "I think most middle-class Americans, when you look at the cost plus the benefits, are going to be much, much better off. It's a very progressive program, and a lot of the wealthiest American business leaders I've talked to believe that their businesses will be much better off, with stable, long-term lower interest rates, and the availability to invest and grow."
Administration officials said today that the plan would increase the income-tax rate on families earning more than $180,000 a year and individuals earning more than $140,000 a year to 36 percent.
Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington State, the Speaker of the House, said the important thing about Mr. Clinton's announcement is that he is going to use "tough, realistic, conservative figures.
"There isn't going to be any shading or coloring of the economic statistics," he said after meeting the President.
 
Hard Hat and Jeans
 The President spoke to California business executives today and visited a road-paving site in Northeast Washington as he portrayed the program he will announce to Congress as one to create jobs rather than bleed taxpayers.
"I believe that Congress will be determined to cut the deficit, too, and to restrain spending," said Mr. Clinton, who wore blue jeans, cowboy boots and a hard hat. "I'm going to go to them for the first time in 10 years and practice truth in budgeting."
But Republicans clearly plan to use the President's speech to sharpen their assertions, made since the campaign, that Mr. Clinton is just another tax-and-spend Democrat.
"I intend to fight his tax-and-spend policy every step of the way," said Senator Phil Gramm of Texas.
 
Trudging Through Mud
 Negotiating the muddy site with Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly of Washington and Delegate Eleanor Holmes Norton, a nonvoting member of Congress for the District of Columbia, he sipped decaffeinated coffee and talked with a selected group of workers.
"They said that they would pay a little more if we were going to create jobs and reduce the debt," Mr. Clinton said afterward.
A senior White House official said today that the Clinton Administration had decided to use the most pessimistic available projections on how much the economy is likely to grow in the next four years, estimates from the Congressional Budget Office, which are gloomier than the figures of Mr. Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. In fiscal year 1997, the Congressional Budget Office projects growth of 2.2 percent, as opposed to the 2.5 percent projection by the council and the average of 50 private forecasters.
The deficit in 1997 without any changes in the law would be $346 billion under the assumptions being used. It would be about $40 billion less if the more optimistic forecasts were used.
"We intend to usher in a new era of integrity in dealing with the budget," the official said. "We need to go the extra mile to regain the confidence of the American people."
Mr. Stephanopoulos said today that the President planned to travel outside of Washington at least once a week to promote his plan.

HEADLINE: National Recovery Fattening Tax Revenue in Many States

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Evidence is continuing to build that the nation's economic expansion that took hold in the second half of 1992 is having a positive effect on battered state finances.
Tax collections, not including legislated tax increases, rose nearly 6 percent in the fourth quarter compared with a year earlier, according to a survey of state tax officials by the Center for the Study of States, a research concern in Albany. That is the biggest increase since the beginning of the recent recession and five times last year's rise. 
 Income and sales taxes -- each of which contribute about a third of state revenue -- are rising solidly. State income-tax collections are 6.4 percent higher than a year ago, sales tax collections 5.4 percent higher.
"We were seeing a much stronger recovery in the second half of 1992," said David Wyss, an economist at DRI/ McGraw Hill, "and with a large increase in consumer spending, that's showing up in state tax collections."
Tax revenue in the hard-hit Middle Atlantic region and in New England was surprisingly strong, rising about as much as the national average of 5.9 percent. Sales tax revenue, adjusted for changes in tax laws or in administrative procedures, rebounded in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
"It's good news for President Clinton," said Steven D. Gold, the center's director. "If state revenues are getting better, that's a sign that Federal revenues are going to get a little better too, and the improvement in state revenue will help avoid big tax increases."
 
Boon to Clinton?
 This improvement may make President Clinton's request to raise Federal taxes a shade easier politically. Many states that have been in awful budgetary straits may find their prospects improving, and some may be able to avoid further tax increases -- or even make good on promises of tax cuts.
What is more, preliminary results of a survey of legislative budget aides by the Denver-based National Conference of State Legislatures shows that more than 40 states are now meeting or surpassing the revenue objectives they set for the current fiscal year. A year ago, less than half were doing so.
"As far as revenues go," said Ronald Snell, the organization's budget analyst, "things are in good shape."
While some of the spurt in income tax collections reflects a rush by the rich to act before a Clinton tax increase, the rebound in tax collections confirms other signs of expansion.
Forecasters increasingly rely on state tax data for clues about the direction of the national economy. The group that sets monetary policy, the Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve Board, for example, uses state sales tax receipts to corroborate retail sales reports from the Commerce Department, which are often subject to huge month-to-month revisions.
 
Sharp Turnabout Seen
 If the state-tax improvement continues, the fiscal picture in many state capitals would brighten considerably.
"The states have been in terrible fiscal condition, running record deficits," Mr. Wyss said. "The healthier tax revenue should permit them to avoid big tax hikes or big further spending cuts in the coming year. In Massachusetts, there's a possibility we could actually end up with tax cut this year if the Governor can keep the Legislature from spending it first."
David Bowers, a public finance expert at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, added, "Construction surveys last fall were already showing substantial increases in planned spending on highways, roads and bridges for 1993."
Nonetheless, the economists warned, the state governments are hardly out of the woods. The revenue recovery remains highly uneven across various regions of the country. According to the Center for the Study of States, revenue rose about 8 percent in the Southwest and the Southeast where, other economic indicators show, growth has been the most buoyant. The West, weighed down by the struggling California economy, had the smallest increase, 3.2 percent.
 
Jigsaw of Economies
 There are big differences within regions. New Hampshire's economy appears to have bottomed out in 1991, while Connecticut is still suffering from big military and insurance-company layoffs. New Jersey is in a double revenue bind: not only is its economy weak, but it cut its sales tax last year.
The second major reason that states' fiscal problems are not over is the level of spending. "Revenues are only half the picture," Mr. Snell said. "Despite faster than expected revenue growth, there are still very serious budget issues."
The three money gobblers in state budgets, economists say, are education, health and prisons. During the fiscal crisis of the last two or three years, many states have postponed spending on education that has become more and more urgent because of the arrival of a second baby boom. And promises for salary increases and construction are coming due.
Similarly, states have put off prison construction for the last two or three years, something they cannot do much longer before the courts force action on overcrowding.
 
No Straight Line to Prosperity
 Medicaid outlays are being driven up by rising caseloads and steep medical inflation.
Finally, the national recovery has stalled a couple of times before and could do so again. And the expansion may continue to be slower than usual.
"In a typical recovery," said Bill Hall, director of the Illinois Economic and Fiscal Commission, "the year after the bottom you see growth of 5 percent. The comeback from this recession is much much more modest, and we have been projecting very modest growth.
"There just aren't a lot of new jobs being generated," Mr. Hall added. "Some Illinois companies are still laying off a few thousand workers. We figure those people won't be buying a lot of TV sets."

HEADLINE: Interior Secretary Is Pushing A New Way to Save Species

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
To head off conflict over endangered species, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt is preparing a major policy shift in the Interior Department's focus on wildlife protection.
He hopes to avert what he calls "national train wrecks" in disputes like the one over the spotted owl in the Pacific Northwest by avoiding having to impose emergency measures to protect suddenly endangered species. Instead, he seeks a policy based on preventive measures to insure long-term protection of whole ecosystems and all their inhabitants. 
 "We need to step back and look at the entire ecosystem and ask, 'Is it possible to intervene before the crisis?' " Mr. Babbitt testified yesterday before the House Natural Resources Committee in Washington.
 
Negotiated Settlements
 In an interview last week, he declared his intention to try to devise plans that would stop the decline of species before it became necessary to list them as threatened or endangered. This, he said, might avoid "the downward spiral of listing, and then the long, contentious legal process that is triggered when the Endangered Species Act takes hold."
The theory of such an approach, which has been backed by conservation groups, is that both conservation and business can be better served by negotiated settlements that plan the future of an entire ecosystem before any individual species are endangered.
There is more leeway for compromise under this view than when an area is severely degraded and options for protecting threatened species shrink.
Similar approaches have been tried with reasonable success. In one, the Nature Conservancy, an environmental group, has brokered a plan in the hill country outside Austin, Tex., to protect ecologically healthy areas while allowing development to proceed around them.
 
Ecology vs. Economy
 Some destruction of habitat by developers is to be allowed, with the most important areas reserved for wildlife. In some cases, developers' land is purchased in a swap agreement that lets them build elsewhere in the county. The larger strategy is to accommodate both the ecology and the economy of the entire region.
Mr. Babbitt told Congress, however, that it ought to be possible to devise conservation plans that mainly affect public lands rather than private ones.
If ecosystems are to be the focus of Federal conservation policy, Mr. Babbitt said, a national scientific assessment of ecosystem health -- a map, as it were, of the nation's biological diversity -- is required to spot problems before they get out of hand.
As things stand now, the Secretary added, ecosystem studies are split between several Interior Department agencies.
Mr. Babbitt said he was considering the establishment of a National Biological Survey to map species and ecosystems with the same scientific accuracy as the United States Geological Survey charts the country's geology.
In any case, he said in the interview, "everyone agrees we're going to need to revisit the concepts of the Endangered Species Act" and determine "if we can't find some way to look at ecosystems on a multispecies basis and ask how it is we can take reasonable steps" to "deal with the economic tradeoffs" before a crisis erupts.
 
'Anticipating the Problem'
 To avoid contention and lawsuits resulting from "repeated eleventh-hour listings" of species as endangered, Mr. Babbitt told the House panel yesterday, "we're going to have to manage the Endangered Species Act pro-actively, by anticipating the problem while we still have the flexibility to manage the problem."
He said in the interview that he believed this approach would uncover "a lot of unexplored possibilities" for conserving species while avoiding "economic collisions." If so, he added, it might be possible to avert what he called a series of "national train wrecks," like the conflict between loggers and environmentalists over preservation of the spotted owl in the Pacific Northwest.
Many conservationists consider the Endangered Species Act, which is up for reauthorization this year, to be the nation's single most powerful tool for preserving species. But many also say that despite the act, ecosystems have continued to decline and species are still becoming endangered.
Opponents of the act charge that too often economic interests and property rights are threatened when protection measures are taken on behalf of an endangered species on a crash basis.
 
Nature Conservancy Plan
 Although the act is up for reauthorization, Congress can simply extend it, as it has done with numerous laws. Mr. Babbitt said there was "a division of opinion" as to whether legislation reauthorizing the act should be undertaken this year or next.
He said he saw a "lot of merit" in a proposal by the Nature Conservancy that a national commission, sponsored by private foundations, examine the question and recommend what to do about the law by the end of this year.
The Bush Administration, in its closing weeks, settled a lawsuit with environmentalists by agreeing to add 400 more species, mainly plants, to its protected list in the next four years. This, coupled with the example of the spotted owl controversy and the requirement to declare still other species endangered, has imparted urgency to the reassessment of conservation policy.
"My most urgent task in my first month around here has been to try to assess how we're going to handle the generic issue of biodiversity," Mr. Babbitt said in the interview, "because we're not equipped to do it."

HEADLINE: Voters Skeptical on Clinton Plan, Lawmakers Say

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
On the eve of President Clinton's economic address to Congress, lawmakers returning to the Capitol reported today that many of their constituents were voicing skepticism and fear about what the President had in mind for them.
While polls indicate that the public is open to Mr. Clinton's economic ideas, many lawmakers who toured their states during a weeklong recess concluded that his support might be thin and tentative. 
 Reactions varied from region to region when it came to the details of the Administration's expected proposals for new energy taxes or cuts in entitlements. But lawmakers said voters almost universally worried that the White House and Congress were asking for sacrifice but were not really serious about deficit reduction.
"People are ready to sacrifice," said Senator Russell D. Feingold, a Wisconsin Democrat who strongly supports Mr. Clinton. "But the leading concern is that the money saved from spending cuts won't be used for new spending."
 
'They Don't Believe Anybody'
 Senator Dennis DeConcini, a conservative-leaning Democrat from Arizona who is a swing vote on economic policy, said he came away from a tour of his state concluding: "A big majority is prepared to accept sacrifice if they are really satisfied it's going to deficit reduction. But they don't believe anybody -- not me, not the President -- that it will go to deficit reduction."
The lawmakers noted that the constituents who called them or attended their town meetings were not necessarily representative of public opinion. But as the avalanche of calls that buried Zoe Baird's nomination as Attorney General demonstrated, the most highly motivated voters can make an impact on Capitol Hill.
Mr. DeConcini, for example, said he took directly to Mr. Clinton an idea that had strong support in his town meetings: setting up a national trust for tax payments that would be earmarked for deficit reduction. Mr. DeConcini said that Mr. Clinton did not immediately respond to his suggestion but that the President would have to eventually "if you want this Senator to vote for tax increases."
Congressional Democrats say it is too soon to assess how strong opposition will be against a program whose details are still not fully known. But Republicans say they are already working to limit tax increases and expand budget cuts, and they complain that Mr. Clinton did not consult with them as he had promised.
 
Republicans Find Skepticism
 The intensity of the reaction to Mr. Clinton's economic plans varied widely around the country. Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, Republican of Florida, said her office was flooded today with telephone calls from retirees fearful that their Social Security payments would be cut or taxed more heavily.
Representative Michael N. Castle, Republican of Delaware, said that he appeared on three radio talk shows last week and that the overwhelming reaction was "scornful about the President's reversal" on the middle-income tax cut he proposed during the campaign. And today, Mr. Castle said, his office had received 65 telephone calls responding to President Clinton's televised address on Monday night, with 62 of them expressing criticism.
"The general conclusion," Mr. Castle said, "is that you will get the Clinton tax increases and Congress will brush a lot of the spending cuts under the rug."
Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, described the mood in his state as "bitter" because "the taxes, environmental restraints and attacks on oil and mining and lumber all affect us."
 
Democrats Find Support
 In contrast, Representative Bobby L. Rush, Democrat of Illinois, said he observed a reservoir of support for Mr. Clinton in his district in south Chicago. "Most of the people in the district are poised to accept a fair tax increase if it is geared toward stimulating the economy," he said.
Other Democratic lawmakers, like Senators J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana and Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, reported that their constituents were generally withholding opinion about Mr. Clinton's plans until the address on Wednesday.
"I got a wait and see," Mr. Lieberman said. "But what I did find was that a lot of the media skepticism was not reflected in the public."
Senator Jim Exon, Democrat of Nebraska, suggested that Mr. Clinton had hurt himself in his Monday night speech by focusing on raising taxes rather than on cutting spending. Noting that telephone calls to his office today were running 80 to 20 in criticism of the speech, Mr. Exon added: "I hope he'll do a better job tomorrow night. He's got a tough sell."

HEADLINE: Charting a Course at the Pentagon, Aspin Uses His Congressional Map

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
You can take Les Aspin out of the Congress, but you apparently cannot take the Congress out of Les Aspin.
In his first three weeks as Defense Secretary, the former 11-term Representative from Wisconsin has drawn on his Congressional past. He has imported a dozen House staff members as top aides, ordered an overhaul of the department's foreign and domestic policy arms to focus on specific issues the way Congressional subcommittees do, and increased Pentagon planners' sensitivity to budget cuts that Congress might oppose. 
 Mr. Aspin wielded tight control over the House Armed Services Committee by using his command of military issues and rewarding loyal colleagues with projects in their districts. But he is now struggling to exert the same kind of influence over the sprawling Defense Department and its many competing fiefs.
In his handling of the Clinton Administration's pledge to allow homosexuals in the military, Mr. Aspin made confusing and contradictory comments on a national news program three weeks ago. Since then, he seems to have found his sea legs, impressing European ministers in meetings in Munich about the crisis in the Balkans and rushing to meet a tight deadline to produce a smaller Pentagon budget for next year.
 
Changes Big and Subtle
 "He's had a lot of things hit him all at once that'll take time to sort out," said Marvin Leath, a former Texas Congressman who is now a Washington lobbyist for several military contractors.
Transitions are always rocky for incoming administrations, even for one as familiar with the Pentagon as the Aspin team. Dozens of senior Defense Department posts remain vacant pending White House approval.
Associates say Mr. Aspin, a workaholic even by Washington standards, is dealing well with these inconveniences, just as he is with the change from Congress's rhythm of legislative marathons followed by recess to the Pentagon's calendar of perpetual crisis. Friends say a subtler switch for Mr. Aspin, a 54-year-old former economics professor, is adjusting from being a big man in Congress courted for his ideas and opinions to being a Cabinet team member, though a very influential one, carrying out President Clinton's orders.
"It's a striking difference," said Representative Norman Sisisky, a Virginia Democrat who was a longtime colleague of Mr. Aspin on the Armed Services Committee. "Suddenly he has to follow the President's policy. He's not running his own committee anymore, where he could follow the President's policy or not."
Nothing illustrates this better than Mr. Aspin's handling of the issue of homosexuals in the military. Associates said Mr. Aspin was eager to begin reorganizing the Pentagon bureaucracy and start moving on other issues he had given a lot of thought to while in Congress.
In his first week, though, Mr. Aspin found himself sparring with Gen. Colin L. Powell and the other members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff over Mr. Clinton's campaign pledge to allow homosexuals in the armed forces. Until a confirmation hearing on Jan. 7, Mr. Aspin had spoken barely a word on the issue, and confidants say he has little interest in the matter.
"Aspin really has never been known to dwell on personnel issues and was probably aggravated he had to spend so much time on the gays issue," said Representative Patricia Schroeder, a Colorado Democrat who also served on the Armed Services Committee. "He'd much rather focus on global strategy."
Appearing on the CBS News program "Face the Nation" on Jan. 24, Mr. Aspin was put in the embarrassing position of explaining an internal strategy memorandum by his staff that advised Mr. Clinton to consult with the Joint Chiefs and Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia. That was sound advice, Pentagon and Congressional officials said, but a written tactics paper smacked too much of a wily committee chairman plotting a legislative coup.
The memorandum hit a particular nerve with Mr. Nunn, who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee and supports the ban. Apparently offended that the Administration had not paid him proper deference, Senator Nunn threatened to challenge Mr. Clinton on the issue, putting a much sharper edge on his normally friendly rivalry with Mr. Aspin.
The Defense Secretary only seemed to make matters worse with his statements on the CBS program. Asked if the Administration could succeed in lifting the ban, Mr. Aspin said, "We're going to try and make this thing happen." A few minutes later, though, he said, "If we can't work it out, we will disagree and the thing won't happen."
Asked if Mr. Clinton would ask Congress to change the military code's ban on sodomy, Mr. Aspin said, "The answer is yes." Pressed further on that point, Mr. Aspin said, "No, not in this context necessarily."
Military officials said they took the confusion as a cue to intensify their public opposition to allowing homosexuals to serve in the armed services. Many senior officers said they had interpreted Mr. Aspin's comments to reflect the uncertainty they also felt.
"I'm impressed with Aspin," said one member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "He's trying his darn edest to work the President's problem under impossible conditions."
 
'Thinking Out Loud'
 Mr. Aspin declined to be interviewed for this article, but he told reporters traveling with him to Munich earlier this month that any reports of strains between the Administration and the Joint Chiefs were exaggerated.
Associates of Mr. Aspin say the kind of unfiltered dialogue weighing possible courses of action on the CBS program was vintage Aspin.
"Aspin's hallmark is to arrive at decisions by thinking out loud," said Sean C. O'Keefe, the Bush Administration's Navy Secretary and the Pentagon's former comptroller. "If you stay with him to the end, he's usually got something important to say."
Those who know Mr. Aspin well say that disciplining his flood of ideas would hamper his creative style. Affable and outgoing, Mr. Aspin relishes a spirited debate, even with reporters.
"You've got to let Aspin be Aspin," said Senator John W. Warner, a Virginia Republican on the Armed Services Committee who has known Mr. Aspin for years. "You're not going to change him."
 
No Uniformed Sentries
 Senator Nunn plans to hold hearings on homosexual issue in March or April, and Mr. Aspin has moved to more pressing matters until then. He has ordered that the Pentagon's policy branches be realigned to address human rights, arms proliferation and the conversion of military industries.
In a symbolic gesture reflecting his rumpled, casual manner, Mr. Aspin ended the practice of uniformed sentries' standing guard outside the Defense Secretary's Pentagon office, saying the decade-old tradition was unnecessary.
In Munich, for an international security conference, Mr. Aspin met privately with ministers from Britain, France, Belgium, Canada, Italy, Germany and the Netherlands in what one aide described as a "big-time NATO schmooze session."
"He'll be a man of big reforms," Leo Delcroix, Belgium's Defense Minister, said in an interview.
The big change he is working on now is the Pentagon's budget. Mr. Aspin directed the armed services last week to submit nearly $11 billion more in cuts on top of the $3 billion Mr. Bush had already proposed for the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1. Those reductions will be offset somewhat by programs that Mr. Aspin wants to add.
 
Approach Is Criticized
 Critics, including Congressional aides and former Bush Administration officials, say that Mr. Aspin has reneged on a promise to conduct a comprehensive review of Pentagon spending for the 1994 fiscal year and that he is using the same top-down approach that he criticized the Bush Administration for last year.
"If we reduce our forces from the top down, by simple subtraction, we will get a smaller defense budget and smaller forces, but the chances are good that neither the budget nor the forces will be the right ones," Mr. Aspin said on Jan. 24, 1992.
Defense Department aides say they had no other choice given the Feb. 25 deadline to submit a Pentagon budget to the White House. They promise a thorough review this summer for the 1995-99 period.
What is left in and what is dropped from next year's budget will probably reflect Mr. Aspin's Congressional experience. The Navy, for example, will probably receive more money for ballistic-missile defenses because it is a sure winner with lawmakers.
"They're very sensitive to how things will play on Capitol Hill," said one veteran Pentagon planner. "They know what's sellable and what's not."
