HEADLINE: President's New Pitch: Redefining Patriotism as a Banner for Peace, Not War

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
In telling Americans that it is their patriotic duty to support his economic program, President Clinton is trying to redefine "patriotism" from pulling together to face a mortal threat abroad to paying higher taxes to face an economic threat at home.
This is both a high-risk political strategy and an experiment in the politics of mobilizing mass opinion in the wake of the cold war. The biggest risk is that Mr. Clinton will discover what Jimmy Carter did when he declared that his energy conservation plan was "the moral equivalent of war" -- that most Americans found the notion so overstated that they scoffed at it, undermining his whole initiative. 
 While many Americans can understand an appeal to bipartisan support for an economic plan, they may balk at the notion that it is their patriotic duty to pay higher taxes.
"Patriotism and economics form strange bedfellows," said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, "One can make a national interest case for sacrifice, one can make a common sense case for sacrifice, but patriotism is when you risk your life, not when you risk your wallet."
 
New Political Vocabulary
 Nevertheless, Mr. Clinton's use of patriotism in his Monday night address to the nation is an experiment. It is based on the assumption that with the end of the cold war, and with the absence of any overriding external threat, the nation's patriotic fervor can be stoked up to confront an enemy that is depicted by bar charts and line graphs, not as the Red menace or Nazi youth. The deficit, health-care reform or low-wage jobs are concerns of every American, but how many people would kill for them?
In a way, Mr. Clinton is introducing a whole new post-cold-war political vocabulary, Mr. Leach said. The President is saying that the Government gets involved abroad, in places like Somalia or the Balkans, out of "compassion" and raises taxes at home out of "patriotism."
Another danger in appealing to patriotism in support of his budget is that Mr. Clinton could be courting more division than solidarity. Those who will not support his program on economic or philosophical grounds will not take kindly to being labeled as being against God, country and apple pie.
"I, like others, was uncomfortable with the use of the word patriotism," said Thomas Mann, a Congressional expert at the Brookings Institution, a research organization. "Patriotism is a word that can be used and misused too easily. It carries more baggage than Clinton would like. If you disagree with him, are you unpatriotic? I don't think he wants to be in a position where those who oppose his program might be accused of being unpatriotic, but that is a risk he is running."
 
A Vietnam Comparison
 If the debate really sharpens, it might be particularly ticklish for Mr. Clinton, who in the Presidential campaign defended his opposition to the Vietnam War as the product of his own interpretation of patriotism.
When Mr. Carter used the language of war to get Americans to accept a program of stringent conservation, higher energy prices and penalties for waste, his plan died three steps out of the starting gate.
"The big difference between now and 1977," said Jody Powell, who was President Carter's spokesman, "is that when we used the moral equivalent of war only about three people in the country believed that energy was such a big problem. A lot of smart-mouthed Washington pundits dismissed it, until oil prices started quadrupling.
"Hopefully, Clinton won't have to wait so long for vindication. I think what he has going for him is that most Americans believe that we have a big problem with the economy, that we need to pull together."
As Mr. Clinton put it in his address on Monday: "If you will join with me, we can create an economy in which all Americans work hard and prosper. This is nothing less than a call to arms to restore the vitality of the American dream. When I was a boy, we had a name for the belief that we should all pull together to build a better, stronger nation. We called it patriotism. And we still do."
Even though Mr. Clinton did not run a campaign based on the notion of sacrifice by the middle class, Mr. Powell argued, his message of sacrifice is "not a big surprise to people."
That is certainly the bet that Mr. Clinton is making, his aides say. He is betting that Americans are worried enough about their children being worse off than they are and Social Security not being there when they need it that they will be ready to contribute the same sweat and tears, if not blood, they would for a military crusade.
Mr. Clinton's personal poll taker, Stan Greenberg, said that also underlying Mr. Clinton's use of patriotism is the President's conviction that most Americans look back on the 1980's as a period of frustration over the lack of priority given to American domestic affairs and interests.
"The notion that we are all in this together was lost as people sought their separate fortunes," Mr. Greenberg said.
"What the President was trying to do last night was an attempt to recreate an ethic where people begin to feel responsible again for their own country," he added. "I think the public thinks the country is in crisis and that people have failed to pitch in and they are waiting to be called to duty."
But this is a very different conscription notice from the one to which people are most accustomed, or even from the one that Mr. Clinton prepared them for in the campaign. It is asking an indulgent consumer society to do what is the hardest thing possible: sacrifice now for deferred gratification. The question is how many will answer Mr. Clinton's patriotic call, and how many will dodge his draft?

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A.T.& T. to Take a Charge Of $7 Billion for New Rules

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
A.T.& T. said yesterday that its charge against earnings for new accounting rules for retiree health benefits would total about $7 billion in the current quarter. In December 1991, A.T.& T. had said the after-tax charge could range from $5.5 billion to $7.5 billion.
While virtually insuring a large paper loss for the full 1993 year, the charge does not hurt cash flow or dividends for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, whose stock is owned by more people than that of any other American company. 
 As previously reported, A.T.& T. had said its 1993 earnings would rise by $500 million because of another new rule that covers deferred tax liabilities. A.T.& T. had overestimated its likely tax bill. A.T.& T.'s net income last year was $3.8 billion, or $2.86 a share.
 
 
New Rules Require Charge
 As with other large corporations, A.T.& T. is required to conform to new rules covering its liability for current and future health care and other benefits for retired employees. Under the new rules, known as Financial Accounting Standards Board No. 106, A.T.& T. does not have to set aside new money, but must report the sum as a charge against earnings.
The charge is like requiring a family to estimate all of its children's future college costs and then report them on a financial statement.
The change in accounting rules, adopted in 1990, requires companies to report the likely financial effect of retiree health benefits, which have grown rapidly in the last decade. The companies must move away from a pay-as-you-go approach for figuring out health costs to one that more accurately reflects costs for employees now and in the future.
Under the new rules, for example, if a 25-year-old A.T.& T. employee earned $100 in retirement benefits today, that amount, allowing for inflation and other factors, must be reported in current financial statements even though the employee is decades away from retirement or may even leave the company. Under the old rules, the $100 of benefits would be accounted for only when the money was actually paid.
A.T.& T. had 141,000 retirees and 312,700 employees in December 1992.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Plan Leaves Gloom at Goldman

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
At age 54, Robert E. Rubin, who in December resigned as co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company to become President Clinton's economic czar, may be too young to remember Kate Smith's late 1940's hit song "Please Don't Talk About Me When I'm Gone."
But yesterday he might have appreciated the sentiment. 
 The details of President Clinton's economic program will not be disclosed until tonight, but the package of tax increases and spending cuts that Mr. Rubin helped to formulate not only got a dismal initial reception from the stock market, where the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted by 82.94 points, but also drew a chorus of boos from at least two of his erstwhile colleagues.
In a gloomy two-page memo to Goldman's clients, Steven G. Einhorn, one of Mr. Rubin's former partners, and Abby Joseph Cohen said that the economic package would have a distinctly negative impact on the stock market, and that Goldman was accordingly reducing its exposure to equities by 15 percentage points in its "model" portfolios.
 
Recommends Buying Bonds
 Goldman recommended that money coming out of the stock market be redirected into bonds.
The strategists listed five reasons for the asset shift. First among them is the Administration's fiscal package, one that Mr. Einhorn and Ms. Cohen describe as having "a less favorable tax increase/spending reduction mix than originally proposed."
"This change in mix is disappointing for two reasons," the memo said. "First, it suggests that Mr. Clinton has not fully confronted the politically more difficult issue of spending cuts. Second, there is the risk that Congress further dilutes the mix by postponing spending cuts but not the tax increases."
The authors also bemoan an attitude toward the health-care industry that is not only "bothersome," but reflects an "us versus them" mentality.
"If public vilification of the corporate sector is to be part and parcel of this Administration's policy," the memo said, "the implication for shares is not good."
Mr. Einhorn did not return phone calls, and Ms. Cohen was on vacation yesterday.
A telephone call to Mr. Rubin's office at the White House seeking comment about his old firm's analysis was also not returned.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Promises Aid for Small Businesses

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
Easing fines on grocery stores, publishing reference guides that decipher city regulations and introducing courses to teach city employees to be courteous were among the newest initiatives to ease the plight of small businesses that the Dinkins administration unveiled yesterday.
They received mixed reviews from business owners who noted that the city has a long history of mayoral promises to small businesses that never amounted to much. Still, several owners said this was the most comprehensive effort they could remember and hoped the outcome would be different this time. 
 The measures were the latest to come from an 18-agency task force headed by Wallace L. Ford 2d, Commissioner of the Department of Business Services.
Mayor David N. Dinkins created the task force in October 1991, a move some small business owners saw as a reaction to their intense criticism of the Mayor for what they perceived to be his indifference to their woes in the recession. The owners also gained an important ally when Barry F. Sullivan, a former banker, was appointed Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development last May.
Yesterday's report included some initiatives revealed in the Mayor's State of the City speech in early January and even earlier. These included proposed legislation to exempt some 28,000 small businesses from the city's commercial rent tax; plans for $2.5 million in grants to establish children's day-care centers; a 46,000 reduction in the number of summonses for minor sanitation violations, and some city loan programs.
 
Further Steps Indicated
 At a meeting at City Hall yesterday between city officials and business owners and organizations, Mayor Dinkins noted that his administration was also taking steps, including the appointment of ombudsmen at several agencies, to make it easier for small businesses to navigate the city's labyrinthine bureaucracy and regulations and to land city contracts.
"We need to do more to get Government off the backs of small businesses," he said, indicating that more measures were sure to come. Mr. Dinkins, like the other likely contenders in this fall's mayoral election, is wooing the small-business vote.
Some business owners and groups called the actions a welcome step.
"Over all it is good," said Abraham Mammen, owner of two Indian restaurants in Jackson Heights, Queens. "We had thought the Dinkins administration was anti-business."
 
The Height of Pickle Buckets
 He said he was particularly cheered by the establishment of a board of owners of ethnic food businesses to work with the Department of Health on changing the regulations and procedures so that owners have more flexibility in the way they prepare food.
Citing an example of a restriction he thought absurd, Mr. Mammen said the health department recently issued him a summons for the height of the bucket in which he aged lemon pickles. Department inspectors wanted them aged in a pan, he said.
Other members of the small business community said the initiatives did not go nearly far enough. Some called for big cuts in taxes and permit fees and for the creation of an arbitration system that would limit the ability of landlords to raise rents.
"What the task force produced is a good beginning, but much more needs to be done," said Stanley Schair, a partner of a small Manhattan law firm who chairs the Small Business Committee of the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry.
He was skeptical that individual agencies would ease up in fining small businesses. "It's against the laws of nature for an agency to reduce its importance and its budget by collecting less fines," he said.
 
Warning Instead of Fines
 Small-business owners and groups were disappointed that the Dinkins administration has not yet formulated a program for cracking down on unlicensed street vendors. Mr. Ford promised "a more complete announcement" on the issue within 30 to 60 days.
One new program announced yesterday was low-interest loans of up to $50,000 to enable small businesses to become more energy-efficient. Another was a pledge by the Department of Consumer Affairs to issue warnings rather than fines to grocery stores that commit minor infractions, like failing to post conspicuously their licenses or selling items that lack unit pricing and fresh dating labels.
Barbara G. Berger, co-owner of Food City Supermarkets, thought the change was long overdue. She told of an inspection at a recently renovated store at 94th Street and Columbus Avenue in Manhattan in which, after three hours, Consumer Affairs inspectors found six items without unit price tags. Her store was fined $750.
"I'm optimistic," she said of the initiatives, "because it's the first time I've ever seen the city trying."

HEADLINE: Clinton Makes Lobbyists a Target In Opening Battle Over Tax Rise

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
President Clinton has landed a street-fighter's punch in his opening battle to push tax increases and budget cuts through Congress: He charged that his opponents "have already lined the corridors of power with high-priced lobbyists."
"Special interests," he called his foes in his televised speech on Monday night. "Defenders of decline," he labeled their hired lobbying guns. 
 "Ludicrous," responded Tom C. Korologos, a high-priced lobbyist. Mr. Korologos, who is as much a legislative fixture as the spittoons on the Senate floor, was the only defender of decline visible outside the Senate today, even as scores of big-name Democrats huddled nearby to hash over Mr. Clinton's televised remarks on the economy.
Officials of the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee, where the President's tax proposals will first be scrutinized, reported that the corridors of power outside their offices were similarly vacant.
 
First-Degree Hyperbole
 To Mr. Korologos, this proves that Mr. Clinton is guilty of first-degree hyperbole, raising straw men with abandon in an effort to convince the people that tax increases are in their interest. "If you've got a tax increase to sell, blame it on the special interests," Mr. Korologos said.
Many Democrats said they agreed with Mr. Korologos. They also said the President was wise to do just that.
"It's a brilliant tactic," said Senator Richard H. Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, "because the public perception is that the corridors of Washington are lined with special interests and high-powered lobbyists. And the public believes that's one of the reasons nothing gets done around here."
A Senate aide who is in the thick of the tax debate said: "Nobody is lobbying now, but there will be opposition. And if Clinton can characterize it as illegitimate before it appears -- even if a great deal of it may turn out to be legitimate -- then it's worth trying."
 
Calm Before the Storm
 In fact, lawmakers and their aides liken the present lack of favor-seeking and logrolling to the gentle rustle of leaves that precedes a summer thunderstorm. Some lobbyists have called their nominal allies in Congress.
"A few of the interests are calling, wanting to know what I know," said Senator Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky, a coal-state Democrat who is the Senate's majority whip. "They're worried about a carbon tax on coal."
Mr. Ford grinned the crinkly grin of a man in the know. "I've been able to tell them there won't be a carbon tax," he said.
Lacking any legislation to lobby for or against, one lobbyist said, many in the business are focusing for now on the White House, working an unfamiliar corps of Democratic policy makers in an effort to shape Mr. Clinton's program even before it becomes public.
"A lot of it right now is letter-writing," said another lobbyist who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Letters are being written against an energy tax, some of which I've signed. Letters are being written arguing that you can't raise $40 billion more by taxing foreign corporations."
 
Recalling a Lobbying Frenzy Recalled
 On Capitol Hill, interest groups are so far engaging in what one Ways and Means Committee aide called "plotting," although, he added, "I'm not sure how I'd plot this time around."
"If you're too aggressive in trying to protect yourself, you could wind up isolated and even looking like a heel," said the aide, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.
Indeed, that is what happened in the last big lobbying frenzy, in 1986, when the Reagan Administration steered a major overhaul of the tax laws through Congress. At that time, after the House Ways and Means Committee approved an amendment that helped the banking industry, banking lobbyists celebrated so effusively in the Capitol's hallways that the embarrassed and angry lawmakers reversed themselves.
The House Ways and Means aide argued today that Mr. Clinton had placed lobbyists on the defensive and that he had "given the members tremendous cover by telling the public what these guys are doing."
Mr. Korologos rejected that as he stood outside the Democrats' meeting this afternoon. "White Houses always try to do this," he said.
Then, spotting a Senator, he pardoned himself, saying, "I've got some work to do, guys."

HEADLINE: Pretzels, Soda, and No Hint of a 'Meat Market'

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTPORT, Conn.

 BODY:
In the 13 years that Ronald S. Pavluvcik has been a member of the Westport Unitarian Singles Group, he figures he has dated more than 100 women.
The last time Helen Burns was out on a date was 25 years ago with her former husband, when she was 19. 
 Mr. Pavluvcik and Ms. Burns were among almost 200 people at a recent gathering of the singles group that, with more than 2,000 members and hundreds more who attend regularly, claims to be the largest of its kind in the nation.
 
Seeking Someone Special
 Both Mr. Pavluvcik and Ms. Burns began the evening with hopes of meeting someone special.
"When I meet a woman now and she asks me how long I've been coming, I joke that I'm not exactly a success story," said Mr. Pavluvcik, 45, a computer consultant from Stratford. "But that depends on how you define success. After all, I have had two long-term, serious relationships with women I met here, and I've made a lot of great friends. I'm a very contented single person and I don't have to be married to be happy."
Nearby, Ms. Burns, of Milford, talked to two other women and scanned the church lobby for desirable men.
"We haven't met the man of our dreams yet," Ms. Burns said. "But we're working on it."
 
'Frightening to be Single'
 Ms. Burns, 44, a secretary, said that after raising two sons and a daughter, she never expected to be dating again. A divorce last summer changed everything.
"It's very, very frightening to be single after 25 years of marriage, and especially these days," she said. "This is all so new to me. But I would rather come here than go to a bar. At least here, people aren't getting drunk, and it's not as much of a meat market."
That is important for many members who say that, in the age of AIDS, they're not interested in the casual sex of bar encounters.
 
Since AIDS, More Restraint
 "There is definitely a more restrained and less outgoing attitude now among members because of AIDS and the demands on people's time," said Gordon B. Thomas, 66, a former president of the group. "Because of the economy, many members are working more than one job and a lot more hours, and they just don't have time to devote as much energy to singles activities."
However, Mr. Thomas said, between 10 and 15 newcomers, ranging in age from 25 to 85, arrive at each function. More than 100 couples have married after meeting through the group, he said.
Not that everything always goes smoothly. Stephanie Simpson, 40, a registered nurse from New Zealand, recalled that after attending one of the group's functions for the first time five years ago, she left in tears.
"I made the same mistake that a lot of people make when they first come," she said. "I had unrealistic expectations and thought I was going to meet Mr. Right the very first night. The best advice I can give to people is to keep going and just try to make friends but not give up, because while we have a core group that are there every week, there are also many different people every time."
 
From Sex to Coping
 On this particular Wednesday, members and guests were mingling and waiting for the start of a special "healing hearts" lecture and workshop intended to help them cope with being alone, or for one of the regular weekly discussion groups.
Debera Johnson, an artist from Wilton now single after 12 years of marriage, opted for a discussion where the topics ranged from sex to coping with the realities of relationships.
"This is only my second time here, but I like it," she said. "I really don't know what the dating rules are now and it's awkward. And I still haven't figured out how to meet someone I notice across the room who I want to talk to. But it's comfortable being here with a lot of people who are in the exact same situation."
 
Dozens of Activities
 The search for an alternative to the bar scene prompted 29 members of the Unitarian church to establish the singles group 18 years ago. Initially, it was open only to members of the church and activities consisted of discussions and occasional parties. But a few years later, the group opened to the public and began growing rapidly, boasting more than 4,000 members by 1983.
The original one-page monthly calendar has developed into a 20-page publication that lists dozens of clubs and activities, from regular weekly discussion groups to dances, camp-outs, ski trips, hikes and lectures.
The organization now draws participants from as far away as New York City, Westchester and Rockland Counties, and West Hartford. Members pay an annual fee of $30 which provides them with weekly discounts for most events, including the regular Tuesday- and Wednesday-night mixers.
 
Outdraws the Church
 "The child just outgrew the parent," said Donald R. Delano, 45, an engineer from Fairfield who has been part of the group since his divorce a decade ago. "Even though we have had a decline in membership the past couple of years, there are still more people in the singles group than in the church."
Longtime members attribute the group's success to a combination of factors including its location in an upscale suburb, where it is particularly difficult for singles to meet, and to a large corps of volunteers dedicated to its survival.
"This group just couldn't exist in Idaho or many other places," said Mr. Pavluvcik, who despite not meeting the woman of his dreams on this night, said he had a good time. "There is such a high rate of divorce in this area and being right in the middle of Fairfield County, the corporate center of the United States, it's not surprising to me that this group has managed to survive."
Ms. Burns, who also didn't find a new love on this night, said she was just hoping to find a nice man to date. "He doesn't even have to be rich, or even normal," she said. "Just nice. And caring."

HEADLINE: New Venture Stirs Mexico Trade Issue

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
In a development that has inflamed opposition to the North American Free Trade Agreement, entrepreneurs in New York and Mexico have established an investment fund whose announced purpose is to buy small American manufacturing companies and move them to Mexico to take advantage of lower wages there.
The Mexican Government's largest industrial development bank is a "significant investor" in the venture, according to a prospectus distributed today by Richard A. Gephardt, the House Majority leader, a leading opponent of the trade pact. 
 "Funds such as this should not be allowed to operate," Mr. Gephardt said in a letter to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico. "But even more objectionable is the official participation of entities controlled by your Government in stealing American jobs."
 
Powerful Obstacle
 Likely job losses to Mexico are already the most potent political obstacle to Congressional approval of the the trade agreement, which would eliminate most barriers to trade and investment among Canada, Mexico and the United States. President Clinton has endorsed the agreement, pending negotiation of side agreements on labor, the environment and surges in imports as tariffs are reduced.
A senior American trade official said this evening that Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, would discuss the fund on Wednesday morning at his first meeting with Jaime Serra Puche, Mexico's trade minister. "Any Government-subsidized program to steal American jobs would not be tolerated by this Administration," the official said.
The Mexican Embassy had no comment on the prospectus last night.
Even without the Nafta, Mexicans may already buy American companies in many industries and legally move them to Mexico, while Americans can buy Mexican companies in some industries and move them here.
The Mexican Government's involvement in the fund, known as the AmeriMex Maquiladora Fund L.P., is particularly awkward for the Clinton Administration. In his election campaign, President Clinton strongly criticized a foreign aid program that provided financial incentives for American companies to move to Central America.
The prospectus said the fund's organizers are trying to raise $50 million they would use to buy 9 to 13 companies. But critics of the free trade pact cited the prospectus as evidence for their contention that many American companies would move south if the trade pact is approved.
Pat Choate, the director of the Manufacturing Policy Project, a Washington group that is seeking more protection from imports for ailing manufacturing industries, said that the fund could be the first in a wave of cross-border financial transactions to rival the leveraged-buyout boom during the 1980's, and that "hundreds of thousands" of American jobs would be lost.
The Mexican Government's involvement in the fund, "couldn't possibly be a worse move," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat.
The fund "is wonderfully revealing of the attitudes behind the enthusiasm for the Nafta," said Tom Donohue, the secretary-treasurer of the AFL-CIO, which opposes the pact.
But most academic studies have predicted that the pact would create more American jobs than it would destroy or send to Mexico because jobs added in Mexico would ultimately mean more demand for American goods. More than two thirds of Mexico's imports come from the United States.
The prospectus estimated that manufacturing companies now paying $7 to $10 an hour to their workers in the United States can pay Mexican workers just $1.15 to $1.50 an hour. By moving to Mexico, the companies would save $10,000 to $17,000 per employee each year, excluding relocation costs, the prospectus said.
The fund would buy companies with annual sales of $10 million to $100 million, move them to Mexico within a year and a half, and then resell the company after three to eight years.
"The fund anticipates that moving the manufacturing operations to Mexico will significantly reduce the labor costs of production and enhance the profitability of these companies," the prospectus said.
The prospectus identifies two men as the fund's organizers: R. Paul Sprague, a New York consultant and financial deal maker, and Adolfo Peniche Perez, who is the Secretary of the Treasury for the state of Yucatan in southeastern Mexico. Mr. Sprague declined to discuss the fund, saying that it was in the process of raising money and that he was legally bound not to make any comments.
Mr. Peniche did not return two telephone calls to his office in Merida, the capital of the state of Yucatan.

HEADLINE: Two Diesel Giants Set Alliance

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 16

 BODY:
The Cummins Engine Company, the world's leading independent maker of heavy-duty diesel engines, and Komatsu Ltd., Japan's top construction equipment manufacturer, today joined the list of huge multinationals pooling their resources to manufacture existing products and develop new ones.
"Capital-goods companies all over the world are caught up in intense competition for what is essentially a mature market," said Henry B. Schacht, chairman and chief executive of Cummins, which is based in Columbus, Ind. "Everyone is looking for an edge."
 
'We All Learned'
 The partnership was formed less than a decade after Komatsu led a charge of Japanese engine makers at the United States market. That effort ultimately failed at great cost. Cummins had slashed prices to keep Komatsu, Mitsubishi, Nissan and other Japanese companies from gaining a foothold, but the American company had to make painful cuts in its operations to control costs. "We all learned something from that," Mr. Schacht said. 
 Trucks are the biggest end users of the types of engines Cummins makes, but the company's engines are also used in construction equipment, boats, industrial machinery and as power generators.
Before attacking the American market, Komatsu had been a longtime customer of Cummins and a licensee for its engines. Analysts said that the resurrection of the ties between Cummins, with revenues last year of $3.8 billion, and Komatsu, which is more diversified and nearly twice as large, highlights the pressures on companies to think globally. They said it also shows how the investments by American engine makers in technology to comply with stricter air-quality controls have created a useful bargaining chip in forming alliances.
 
 
Technological Advantage
 "Komatsu had to link up with Cummins to stay competitive with Caterpillar," said John E. McGinty, a heavy-equipment analyst in Boston for First Boston. Caterpillar Inc., which is based in Peoria, Ill., is a leader in the construction equipment industry as well as a leading maker of diesel engines. Analysts say that Cummins, Caterpillar and the Detroit Diesel Corporation, the third major American maker of diesel engines, all hold a substantial technological advantage over most foreign engine manufacturers in environmental controls.
Cummins and Komatsu said the first step in their partnership would be to make the popular 3.9-liter and 5.9-liter Cummins engines, which range in horsepower from about 70 to 200, in one of Komatsu's Japanese factories. Komatsu will use much of the output in its construction equipment, and Cummins will use the plant to expand its sales throughout Asia.
The second step, the companies said, would be a joint venture to build a huge 30-liter Komatsu-designed engine with horsepower ratings up to 1,100 in one of Cummins's domestic plants and sell it through Cummins's large American dealer network. That could allow Cummins to chip away at Caterpillar's dominance in engines for huge off-road construction equipment. The companies said that other forms of cooperation could follow.
Mr. Schacht said that the companies hoped to finish negotiating the terms of their joint agreements by this summer and to begin production of the Cummins engines in Japan within two years. Analysts said any benefits would not be felt for several years.
Cummins's stock ended trading today on the New York Stock Exchange at $82.75 a share, down $2.125, in a sharply plunging market.
 
 
Increasing Pace of Cooperation
 The announcement comes at a time when the pace of industrial cooperation is accelerating both domestically and across borders. Within the United States, for instance, auto makers are working together on electric cars.
The growing pressures for global sharing of costs have recently been highlighted by the aerospace industry, in which the Boeing Company and Airbus Industrie, its bitter European rival, are discussing cooperative development of a huge new aircraft.
Global relationships in the heavy- equipment industry go back several decades. Caterpillar, for example, has a joint venture with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries dating back to 1963 that supplies a wide range of equipment to Japan and exports certain types of Caterpillar excavators, loaders and tractors around the world.
"I don't see any end to it," said Robert Z. Aliber, professor of international economics and finance at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business.

HEADLINE: Flower District Fights Move to South Bronx

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Faced with the loss of four major flower wholesalers who plan to move to the South Bronx, the rest of New York City's flower industry is fighting to remain in Manhattan, where it has been rooted for more than 100 years.
Despite traffic congestion, lack of space and prospects of rezoning, many flower wholesalers and retailers have banded together in an effort to find a way to stay in the present Flower District or relocate to some other site in Manhattan. 
 In recent weeks, the flower community has formed the first industry-wide group, the New York Florists Association; gained the support of elected officials; held talks with the Department of Transportation to ease traffic congestion and parking problems, and called on city officials for support in considering the rezoning of the Avenue of the Americas.
"The vast majority of the industry not only prefers, but needs to stay in Manhattan to survive," said Annie Zamoiski, president of the new association, grouping more than 50 wholesalers, retailers and suppliers. "Because we are a service industry, it is critical for us to stay near our clients: hotels, restaurants, designers, the gift market, caterers and retailers. Our customers are here and we need to be here to serve them."
 
Problems of Growth
 In a direct appeal to city officials, Ms. Zamoiski asked for help to remain on 28th Street or if relocation was necessary, to find another site in Manhattan, "perhaps to Pier 40." She said the flower industry was at "a critical juncture," citing the problems associated with growth, like congestion, and "even greater pressures" with the relocation of the four largest wholesalers and the proposed rezoning of the Avenue of the Americas from manufacturing to commercial and residential use. The Flower District is an oasis of greenery, bright-colored blossoms and exotic plants, situated in the form of a cross on 28th Street between Seventh Avenue and Broadway and along the Avenue of the Americas between 26th and 29th Streets. On most mornings, the market bustles with buyers and sellers, double-parked cars, trucks, express mail vans and tourists.
Contesting the Mayor's recent announcement that the flower market was relocating to the Bronx, Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger and City Councilman Tom Duane said that only a small portion of the industry was willing to relocate to the Bronx and "most of the firms remain committed to Manhattan."
In a joint letter to Barry F. Sullivan, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, Ms. Messinger and Mr. Duane called on the City to resolve the problems of the Manhattan site: traffic, parking, threat of displacement. They noted that the flower market was an important part of the neighborhood's economy, accounting for hundreds of jobs and giving the area "a unique character."
 
Concern About Future
 Officials from the flower industry have been meeting with city transportation officials to resolve immediate problems of traffic and parking. At the same time, the group has been seeking a solution to long-term space and rezoning problems and is looking into the possibility of relocating to Pier 40, which is part of the West Side Waterfront project.
"Most of us have walk-in trade and operate best together in this full-service market, which has everything from dried and silk flowers to potted plants and earthen pots," said Jim Weisse, treasurer of the Florists Association and a co-owner of Caribbean Cuts, a wholesale firm at 137 West 28th Street.
Although the flower industry is "in good health and expanding," Mr. Weisse said, the market faces problems: traffic congestion, lack of warehouse space and deteriorating buildings. He said talks with the city Department of Transportation have brought some relief from parking tickets and efforts are under way to extend commercial parking hours.
But wholesalers and retailers alike expressed concern about the future of their district, located in a manufacturing zone, which the City Planning Department has said should be opened to residential development. And as they discuss possible solutions, many of the flower people suggest Pier 40 as their favorite option because of the space and location on Manhattan's West Side, opposite Houston Street.
 
'A Lot of Restrictions'
 Last week, the leaders of the Florists Association took up the issue with Tom Fox, president of the Hudson River Park Conservancy, a subsidiary of the state Urban Development Corporation, charged with the development of the waterfront from Battery Park City to 59th Street. "There are a lot of restrictions but it could be a reasonable compromise," Mr. Weisse said after the meeting.
But with public review and approval procedures, Mr. Fox said, it will be two to three years before the long-term use of the pier will be decided.
Councilman Duane, who represents the area that includes the Flower District, said this week that the city had been "extremely shortsighted" in encouraging developers' plans that would allow the construction of large apartment blocks in the area. A rezoning measure, currently under review, could mean the end of the Flower District by raising rents and land values beyond the reach of most flower companies, he said.
"I wouldn't dream of moving to the Bronx; all my customers are here," said Ms. Zamoiski. A freelance retailer better known as Annie Z., she works out of an office at 245 West 29th Street, providing floral arrangements for corporate clients, weddings, dinner parties and other special events.
 
Caught Off Guard
 Ms. Zamoiski said other wholesalers and retailers were surprised by last month's announcement that four wholesalers would move to the abandoned Penn Central Rail Yards in the Bronx in the next two years.
The four, who have signed leases in the new Bronx development project, do most of their business by telephone and are not dependent on the central location, their colleagues said. When they announced the move, they said it would be easier to truck tulips deeper into New Jersey and Connecticut from the Bronx.
Mitchell Vlachos, whose family business, Harry Vlachos Inc., is one of the wholesalers planning to move to the South Bronx, said he would prefer a facility on Manhattan's West Side, like Pier 40. "That would be great for all of us and for the people we serve," said Mr. Vlachos.

Annie Zamoiski, president of the new group, and Jim Weisse, a member and co-owner of a wholesale operation, argue that they need to stay close to the people and places they grace. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Clinton Borrows Freely From Capra to Tap Middle-Class Ideals

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
You may catch a whiff of Ronald Reagan in President Clinton's direct approach to the television audience or a touch of Ross Perot in the President's display of colorfully doleful charts, but his public introduction of the Administration's economic prescriptions owes even more to the spirit of Frank Capra.
In the radio talks, the video "town hall" meeting and the brief television address that have led up to tonight's message to Congress, he took the role, familiar from so many Capra movies, of the young, idealistic outsider calling for the support of solid middle-class Americans in his challenge to high-priced lobbyists (who ever heard of a low-priced one?), special interests (or an unspecial one?), status-quo pols and other "defenders of decline." 
 On Monday night you could practically hear the big us-against-them speeches of James Stewart and Gary Cooper as the youthful-looking President pleaded, "We're all in this together" and perorated with an evocation of patriotism and the Almighty. All that was missing was a small boy looking on, aglow with admiration.
 
Teacher and Politician
 That is not to take away from the performance. Mr. Clinton is proving himself a more sophisticated politician than the Capra heroes and a more adept teacher than recent Presidents and aspirants. In the "town hall" appearance especially, it was impossible to imagine Mr. Reagan or Mr. Perot, not to mention George Bush, answering questions so lucidly, showing due sensitivity to the concerns of the unemployed defense worker, the family in need of medical coverage, the working mother worried about child care, without quite promising all things to all of them. In such a forum complexities are inevitably glossed over, but Mr. Clinton at least alluded to them and offered considerable context.
The style was classroom homely. "Let me tell you why I did what I did," he began one answer and then actually offered an explanation for his restrictions on Haitian refugees. He called health care "the most complicated problem I ever messed with." By comparison, the rote response of Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican and minority leader, came over like Edward Arnold, the Capra-era actor who specialized in rich, greedy, powerful characters.
The "town hall" hour was a smartly conceived and smoothly directed show. The studio was small enough to give the scene the feeling of a gathering of individuals instead of an audience. Mr. Clinton rose almost at once from his chair, stepped off the stage and spoke mostly from the edge of a low platform, almost within touching distance of people in the front row.
Questioners had evidently been screened: no loonies allowed and not too many white men. And there were useful if mild follow-ups from the local television personalities in four cities. A decision had plainly been made to stay away from network stars and high-power journalists.
The one-on-one feeling was sustained even after the last question, when the camera showed the President stepping down onto the studio floor and chatting with a woman. When Mr. Clinton said, "I'm going to try to stay in touch with you this whole four years," everyone knew he was not addressing Dan Rather.
 
Different View of World
 It is by now evident that Mr. Clinton finds no rewards in going out of his way to encounter the national news media. "We don't see the world the same way," he said last week. What he may have meant was that more professional, less respectful interviewers might harp on the campaign promises that have gone by the way or the awkward start to his Presidency, and might press harder for details of his plans. Other politicians, too, have learned that going direct to the people via radio and television call-in shows is a means of avoiding scrutiny by reporters who can bring experience to their questions and don't mind being a little pushy.
As for the voters themselves, it is useful to remember that Frank Capra's movies carry an ambiguous message. Although happy endings were invariably imposed, with the ordinary Joes and Janes doing the right thing by the honest young hero, the more interesting and unsettling parts of the better scripts showed how quickly the citizenry can turn into a mob, how fickle, frightened and prone to manipulation people can be.
Well, Mr. Clinton is showing himself to be no mean persuader. If the polls indicate that the nation is readier for more reality than has been asked of it by its leaders in recent years, that is in part a tribute to the talent and theatrical know-how the President is bringing to his case.

HEADLINE: Secretary Sees a Vital Role For Labor in U.S. Growth

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 16

 BODY:
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich told the leaders of organized labor today that unions were vital to the new Administration's hopes for economic growth and that he intended to help them regain the power they have been losing for decades.
In a discussion covering nearly three hours at the annual winter meeting of the executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Mr. Reich, who has emerged as the Government's most influential Labor Secretary in economic policy in at least a generation, told unions that management has gained an unfair advantage in resolving conflicts with unions. 
 "Undoubtedly, we need to restore a level playing field in this country," Mr. Reich told reporters after his discussions with the unions. "In the last 10 years, working men and women have been penalized for even trying to create unions." He called the labor movement "the most articulate, indeed the only voice of the front-line worker in America."
 
Liked What They Heard
 Mr. Reich came here to seek support for President Clinton's economic plan from organizations that gave Mr. Clinton around 10 million votes in November, and he appears to have left them enraptured.
Despite a refusal to assure the unions of unequivocal support for several issues they consider vital, like lifting President Ronald Reagan's ban on hiring the air-traffic controllers he dismissed for striking illegally in 1981 and on raising the minimum wage, the leaders liked just about everything they heard.
Vincent R. Sombretto, president of the National Association of Letter Carriers, called the session with Mr. Reich "the most extraordinary executive council meeting I've attended in the last 12 years."
"He's seeing an important role for the labor movement," Mr. Sombretto said. "He sees collective bargaining as a key element to raising the standard of living in this country."
Morton Bahr, president of the Communications Workers of America, said, "He's saying all the right things."
Despite the tax increases that the unions' many middle-class members face under Mr. Clinton's plan, the president of the labor federation, Lane Kirkland, said, "The President is going in exactly the right direction."
 
Speaking From Notes
 Mr. Reich addressed the presidents of 32 unions and staff in a cavernous, windowless hotel conference room from which the press was excluded. He did not prepare a speech, using notes written on the front of a manila folder instead. But at a news conference later he reported on the meeting, and union leaders confirmed much of what he said.
He told the federation nothing of the President's economic plan beyond what has been already disclosed. But Mr. Kirkland said the federation "will do its level best to be strongly supportive of this plan, including all of its components."
Unions pine for their power of four and five decades ago, when their political agendas were the same as those of the Democratic Party.
But in the 1980's, especially, unions lost such ground that in industries like retailing and many services their membership is so small they are close to irrelevant. By last year, their representation in the work force had shrunk to 15.8 percent, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, from above 20 percent in the 1970's.
 
Voice of the Workers
 Mr. Reich said that unions, in collaborating with management, help define the more efficient factories with multiskilled workers that Mr. Reich sees as the industries of the future. "All the evidence suggests that when workers have voice, the yield is higher productivity," he said.
He assured the unions that Mr. Clinton would fulfill his campaign promise to support legislation, opposed by the Bush Administration, that would prohibit companies from dismissing workers who go out on strike and permanently replacing them with nonunion workers.
And he said that within two weeks he would appoint a commission to examine the laws and regulations that organized labor says business exploits to undermine unions and thwart their efforts to recruit new workers. "It may be time to revisit some of the assumptions" embodied in the laws, Mr. Reich said.
Labor leaders said the Secretary assured them that the commission would make its recommendations within a few months.
 
Choosing Words Carefully
 Mr. Reich said he told the unions that the commission "would be looking at employee participation in the future and recommend back to the Administration changes in labor law that would facilitate labor-management relations in the future."
In an interview, Mr. Reich said he was considering a thorough reorganization of the plethora of Government services that help unemployed workers seek training, re-employment services, financial aid and counseling. He suggested a "comprehensive program for one-stop shopping."
The shops, he said, would be managed by "local labor market boards" that would pull the services together. "We need to have one single job retraining, job-search service," Mr. Reich said, that would be similar to Commerce Department and Agriculture Department extension services. "It's an option we're seriously considering," he said.
At the news conference, Mr. Reich said the President had not reneged on his campaign promise to require employers to spend 1.5 percent of the wages they pay on employee training, although Mr. Clinton evidently has done so, at least for now.
"The Administration will not be mandating the 1.5 percent training tax right away," Mr. Reich said. "I want to use it as a last resort."

HEADLINE: Report Warns of Scheme Directed at Low-Income Minority Homeowners

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Eutha M. King, a 68-year-old woman living on Social Security payments, has never stopped regretting the day a door-to-door home-improvement contractor appeared at her threshold. He talked her into getting a loan for $25,000 worth of repairs for new electrical wiring and kitchen remodeling for her home in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.
Since that day three years ago, Ms. King said, her life has become a roller-coaster ride, shifting from coping with poor and incomplete construction work to teetering on the brink of foreclosure on the house she has owned for more than 25 years. 
 She said the contractor tricked her and did not reveal the fine print of the contract. Facing monthly payments of $1,600 -- instead of $900 -- she asked relatives to help and took in a granddaughter, who offered to assist with the payments.
"The company never finished the kitchen work, and my family and friends had to patch things up as best as they could," Ms. King said. "The payments were much higher than what the contractor told me they would be and the bank kept threatening to foreclose. This has been a nightmare."
A report issued yesterday by New York City's Consumer Affairs Department suggests that Ms. King's troubles represent a scenario facing thousands of low-income black and Hispanic homeowners who have been systematically deceived by some home-improvement contractors into obtaining high-interest second mortgages for work that is usually shoddy and seldom completed.
The department said more than 32,000 minority homeowners in neighborhoods in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx have been victimized in the last seven years by home-improvement sales representatives who are essentially agents for finance companies and banks, who then charge interest rates as high as 21 percent. The home-improvement contractors target low-income minority areas, the department said, because homeowners in those neighborhoods often cannot obtain financing directly from banks.
"A dual home-improvement lending system has been created in New York City," said Mark Green, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs. "One with lower interest rates for white and middle-class neighborhoods, the other with high interest rates for lower-income and minority neighborhoods."
 
Inflated Payments
 Often the homeowners have been duped into believing that the amount of the loan is less than the number written on the contract. Under the terms of those contracts, the finance company pays the contractor, who typically does little or poor construction work. The homeowner is then responsible for the inflated monthly payments. A homeowner unable to make the payments then faces eviction action from the bank, which has bought the mortgage from the finance company.
Mr. Green said the working poor and older homeowners living on Social Security have been the most common victims.
 
Changes in Laws Urged
 He said he has urged banks that buy home-improvement mortgage obligations from finance companies to stop all dunning or eviction actions until they investigate whether there was fraud in the circumstances connected with the loan and whether the contractor was paid before the work was satisfactorily completed.
"Major banks have to stop looking the other way when they know they're foreclosing on people who were deceived into 20 percent mortgages for work never done," Mr. Green said.
The report also recommends that state law be changed to make it illegal for home-improvement contract sales staffs to act as agents for finance companies. The report also urges that laws be changed to make it illegal for finance companies to pay contractors directly unless one of their own inspectors has personally visited and signed off on completed work.
Ms. King has found some consolation in the fact that since reporting her situation to the consumer affairs officials, the bank has been willing to negotiate refinancing the mortgage. Nonetheless, she remains bitter.
"The way this contractor did me was so dirty and underhanded," she said. "We still have no light in the kitchen and we never got the washer and dryer he said we would get. I hope no one else will have to go through this."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Are Mostly Higher

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of government securities remained firm yesterday despite the turmoil in the equity market, as bond traders reacted favorably to President Clinton's economic talk of Monday night.
The benchmark 30-year bond made gains in early trading, and at one point the yield fell as low as 7.07 percent -- its lowest level since the Treasury began selling the long bond in 1977. But the bond gave back its gains later on some profit taking, and late in the day, the long bond was offered at a price of 99 25/32 , down 9/32 , to yield 7.14 percent. 
 Issues with shorter maturities, however, continued to post gains throughout the day.
 
Corporates Up Slightly
 With government bond prices firm, the corporate issues followed and prices edged up slightly. Bond traders said the key to the future direction of bond prices depended on whether the Federal budget deficit could be controlled by tax increases and spending reductions.
Some investors and economist say inflation is so contained and the economic recovery so weak that if bond yields move higher it will slow the economic recovery further and force another round of interest-rate cuts.
On Monday, President Clinton proposed increased taxation for the wealthy and the middle class along with reduced Government spending. The market reacted positively yesterday morning, especially among issues with long maturities, before slipping in the afternoon.
Some analysts cautioned that bond investors should not ignore the steep selloff in the stock market, as the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 82.94 points, to 3,309.49, in reaction to the President's proposals.
Many investors are beginning to realize that the fiscal medicine of tax increases and spending cuts is likely to slow economic activity.
Unlike bond prices that advanced on expectations of a reduced Federal deficit, weak economic growth and low inflation, stock prices generally fell on worries regarding the effect of strong deficit-reduction measures on economic activity.
Charles E. Rhoden, managing director and head of fixed-income investing for Josepthal, Lyon & Ross, said there were no unusual movements yesterday in government or corporate trading. He said his people concentrated yesterday on 5- to 10-year maturities for their portfolios.
 
'Experiencing Rate Shock'
 "There are two things in this market that are coming to a head," he said. "One is that the market has had a huge rally and other is that investors in the market are now experiencing rate shock. The comfort factor is being disturbed, and investors are uneasy about taking an overbalance in the market."
While the outline of President Clinton's plan was well received by the Treasury bond traders, it has also cast a great deal of uncertainty in the corporate and junk bond markets.
 
Corporates
 The yield spreads between corporate bonds and Treasury securities remained relatively tight. Narrow yield spreads indicate that this year's early deluge of corporate bond issuance primarily represents the refunding of outstanding higher-coupon corporate bonds, with a sizable part of this year's bond issuance also financing the paying down of short-term debt.
The first corporate issue to take advantage of lower borrowing costs yesterday was Michigan Bell Telephone, with a $200 million debt offering of 30-year debentures through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The issue, rated Aa-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Company, was priced to yield 7.545 percent, or about 44 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than Treasury securities with a comparable maturity.
 
Auction
 The Treasury yesterday sold $23.2 billion of new three- and six-month bills at auction, with the average discount rate slightly lower than those offered last week.
For the three-month bill, the average was 2.93 percent at auction, making it the seventh consecutive week that the rate has dropped. So far this year, the average rate has fallen 12 basis points. The average discount rate for the six-month bill was 3.08 percent, down for the second consecutive week and down 20 basis points since the beginning of the year.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Dow Off 82.94 As Most Stocks Take a Beating

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Traders and investors sold stocks with greater fury yesterday than on any day since November 1991, apparently registering apprehension about President Clinton's economic plans.
Selling was concentrated on the technology stocks that have led the market higher since investors began drawing confidence last October from the likelihood of Mr. Clinton's election. Just two weeks ago, most market averages stood at record levels. 
 But yesterday, the Nasdaq composite index, dominated by technology stocks, suffered a 3.6 percent decline.
 
Trading Is Heavy
 The Dow Jones industrial average of larger stocks fell 82.94 points, or 2.4 percent, to 3,309.49. Trading was heavy, with 332.9 million shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange.
Bond investors reacted with less alarm, keeping prices steady yesterday, as many continued to believe that Mr. Clinton would succeed in narrowing the deficit. [Page D14.]
In explaining yesterday's stock market plunge, analysts cited the President's confrontation with drug companies over pricing and the threat that his plans for cutting spending and raising taxes would retard the recovery.
"If Clinton's program goes through, it will dampen the expansion for the rest of the year," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. The growth of corporate profits, which has propelled the market higher since last fall, would then slow or cease, analysts said.
Other analysts added, however, that with stock indexes near record highs, a retreat was in order among investors anxious to preserve their profits.
"This market was already rolling down the hill," said Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist for Morgan Stanley. "A few things came along to push it."
The success of Mr. Clinton's economic plans depends in part on the response from investors, since their actions help determine how readily companies can raise capital. The smaller high-technology companies that the new President most wants to aid have had great success in marketing their shares lately, but suffered the largest losses yesterday.
President Clinton shrugged off the market's drop, saying, "The people in the stock market have known in general all along what was going to be in the program, and the stock market's gone up markedly since the election."
Analysts mocked the White House comment. "I was not aware that they had hired any market analysts there," said Laszlo Birinyi, whose financial consulting firm bears his name.
Mr. Clinton's attacks on drug companies and his threat of cost controls contributed to a recommendation yesterday by Goldman, Sachs & Company for clients to reduce the stock portion of their investment portfolios by 15 percentage points.
"If public vilification of the corporate sector is to be part and parcel of this Administration's policy, the implication for shares is not good," Goldman analysts said in their message to clients.
 
Parallels With Steel
 Some strategists, including Mr. Metz, saw parallels between yesterday's selloff, after Mr. Clinton's assault on the drug companies, and the market retreat that followed President John F. Kennedy's attack on steel companies and their price increases three decades ago.
On Monday night, President Clinton spoke of broad themes in a brief televised speech, preparing the nation for the sacrifices he will seek in an address to Congress tonight. Traders said yesterday that the details they have learned so far caused them to fear that Mr. Clinton was more eager to tax away corporate and personal income than to curb Federal spending.
"The market's just sending a big old message," said Bill Allyn, who manages the listed equity desk at Jefferies & Company. "People don't mind taxes so much as long as the Government does its part."
Yesterday's stock selling was determined but not panicked. Steven E. Norwitz, a spokesman for T. Rowe Price mutual funds, saw no surge of redemption orders. Some callers, he said, saw the pullback as a buying opportunity.
 
Nasdaq Off 25.15
 And Mr. Wien of Morgan Stanley saw the possibility of renewed advances once investors realized that Mr. Clinton's proposals might not pass Congress intact.
On the Nasdaq market yesterday, where the composite index dropped 25.15 points, many of the most popular computer and biotechnology issues fell several points. Intel lost 5 1/8, to 105 7/8; Microsoft 3 1/2, to 80 1/8; Amgen 4, to 49 7/8; Biogen 4 1/2, to 30 3/4, and Legent 6 1/4 to 43. Smaller issues suffered proportional losses.
The Dow's 83-point plunge was the largest in one day since a 120-point loss in November 1991, also after many averages had reached records and biotechnology stocks had soared. Big Board losers outnumbered gainers yesterday by more than four to one.
Among the Standard & Poor's 500, drug and diversified health-care companies were the two worst performing groups. Merck fell 2 1/2, to 37 7/8; Pfizer 4 1/8, to 60 1/8, and Johnson & Johnson 2 3/8, to 42 5/8.
Retailers, auto makers and other cyclical issues that have ridden the strengthening economy also toppled yesterday, with Chrysler down 3 3/8, to 36 1/2; G.M. down 2, to 38 5/8; Goodyear down 4 3/8, to 66 5/8; International Paper off 3 5/8, to 64 3/4, and Dayton Hudson off 3, to 79 1/4.
Nike fell 9 1/8 to 73 after the company said late Friday that it was unlikely to meet analysts' earnings estimates.
The Dow Jones transportation average fell 63.46 points, more than 4 percent, to 1,515.48, as fears of an energy tax and OPEC cutbacks intensified the selling of airlines, truckers and rails. UAL fell 6 1/2, to 119 1/2; Xtra Corporation 4 1/2, to 82 1/2; Conrail 3 3/8, to 53 3/8, and Delta 2 3/8, to 49.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
BellSouth to Spend More on Service

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The BellSouth Corporation, the largest of the regional Bell companies, said yesterday that it planned to spend nearly $9 billion to modernize its local telephone service by 1995.
The amount is an increase from the $8.5 billion allotted in its previous three-year budget. 
 BellSouth, which covers nine states in the fast-growing South, has experienced stronger growth than telephone companies in other regions, like California, where the persistent recession and high unemployment have hurt the Pacific Telesis Group. BellSouth, based in Atlanta, is assuming an annual growth rate of 3.5 percent in the number of telephone lines, compared with growth rates of 1 percent and 2 percent elsewhere in the country.
 
 
More Digital Switching Systems
 Besides replacing old or damaged telephone lines, the BellSouth money will go toward the further deployment of digital switching systems, which increase the number and speed of telephone calls on the network. They also allow the use of sophisticated computer programs that can provide new services like caller-identification or videoconferencing.
While the overall spending rise is modest, less than 6 percent over three years, what is more important is that BellSouth is not only maintaining a robust level of spending, but increasing it, said William M. Ferguson, BellSouth's group president for network and technology.
 
 
New Telephone Lines
 The largest portion of the budget, about $5.7 billion, has been set aside to add telephone lines to the 18.5 million lines in Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina and Tennessee. Some of the budget will also be used to replace damaged or worn equipment, including $45 million for damage related to Hurricane Andrew in Florida last year.
Most of the remaining money will be used to modernize the network. About 61 percent of telephone lines are digital, where voice and data are carried in the code understood by computers, instead of the older analog language. By 1995, about 81 percent of the lines will be digital.
These digital lines make possible the use of what is known as Signaling System No. 7. This computer hardware and software system provides more efficient routing of calls.

HEADLINE: 90's May Be a Decade of Growth

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The nation may be poised for faster economic growth during the 1990's than people have previously believed, according to economic heavyweights like the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan.
Just as the Clinton Administration is starting to concentrate on the economy's long-term troubles, some economists are focusing on tantalizing signs that America's economic engine packs more horsepower than it used to: last year's productivity growth was the fastest in 20 years, profits are rebounding despite weak sales growth and business has gone on a high-tech spending spree. Job growth may finally be picking up, too. 
 "By the second half of the 1990's, the United States may post consistently faster noninflationary growth than was possible during the past two decades," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
 
Hardly a Panacea
 Faster growth would not put most Americans on Easy Street anytime soon. The turmoil of bankruptcies, corporate restructurings and white-collar layoffs will almost surely continue as once-prosperous economic leaders like I.B.M., General Motors and Sears struggle to remake themselves and a wave of new technology wipes out entire occupations.
"Like other rich countries, the United States was caught in a slow-growth trap since the early 1970's," Mr. Steinberg said. "But now, the great productivity slowdown of the past 20 years may finally be over." Productivity refers to the amount the average American worker can produce in an hour or, more generally, to the economy's efficiency.
This would not be the first time that a long stretch of stagnation gave way to buoyant growth, economic historians say.
 
New Age of Innovation
 Like the 1970's and 1980's, when business entered the computer age, the late 1860's through the 1880's was a period of technological innovation. The typewriter, telephone and light bulb were all invented or developed in usable form, but without measurably increasing the nation's output. It was not until the 1890's and early 1900's that these inventions propelled industrial or commercial productivity.
"We should realize just how long the gestation of technology is," said Claudia Goldin, an economic historian at Harvard.
Increases in productivity may be reviving now, economists say, in part because corporations are learning to take advantage of the $1 trillion they invested in the last decade in computers and other high-tech equipment.
Charles Ferguson, a technology consultant based in Cambridge, Mass., remarked, "There's no doubt that in the remainder of this decade, U.S. corporations are going to use computers much more effectively than they have been."
Among those who believe that this is a possibility is the customarily cautious Mr. Greenspan. "A new synergy of hardware and software applications may finally be showing through in a significant increase in labor productivity," he told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress on Jan. 29. "These far-reaching changes in the production processes and manufacturing, and in the means by which services are produced and distributed, have apparently yet to run their course."
If the increase in productivity continues, Mr. Greenspan said, "we have underestimated the potential long-term economic growth of the economy; that is, that in fact, it can grow faster than most economists have recently been forecasting."
President Clinton was considerably less optimistic during his Oval Office address Monday night on his forthcoming economic proposals, dismissing signs of faster productivity growth as statistics cited by "defenders" of the "status quo."
What makes Mr. Greenspan's speculation powerful is that in his role at the central bank, he functions as a sort of state trooper for the economy -- the man who cruises into traffic to remind drivers not to exceed the speed limit. In effect, Mr. Greenspan was telling worried Democrats that he might soon be standing on the side of highway, arms folded, smiling.
"The higher potential growth, the more likely that the economy will actually grow faster," Mr. Steinberg of Merrill Lynch said, "and the longer it takes before the bottlenecks develop or the economy runs into growth barriers like more restrictive monetary policy."
 
A Meaningful Percentage Point
 Until recently, most forecasters agreed that the economy could not safely grow much faster than an average of 2 percent a year: the labor force is expanding by about 1 percent a year and productivity growth has been stuck at about 1 percent a year since the early 1970's. But lately some economists have started wondering whether last year's higher productivity might be pushing potential growth closer to 3 percent.
The difference between 2 percent and 3 percent growth, year in and year out, can be the difference between living standards doubling in one generation, versus taking two or three generations to achieve the same progress.
But, Mr. Greenspan and others warn, higher growth is a possibility, not a certainty. Hard evidence that the United States has broken out of its two-decade-long slump in growth will not be available for several years, when long-term trends can be viewed apart from the ups and downs of the business cycle.
Robert Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University, is one of those who is skeptical that there has been an authentic turnaround. "Productivity grew in the last year and a half," he said, "but it was extremely bad from 1988 to 1991. Much of the turnaround is just getting back to where we were."
Nonetheless, Mr. Greenspan and some others cite concrete evidence that prospects of faster growth are not pie in the sky.
They refer to three measures: First, the increase in productivity, while similar to those in past recoveries, is extremely rapid, considering the slow growth of output. It is not unusual for productivity to bounce up when sales are booming, but sales have been tepid this time around.
Second, this is the first time that all of the production increases during a recovery were a result of greater productivity, rather than from an expansion of the work force.
And most of the action has been outside manufacturing. While factory productivity, which recovered from its 70's slump a decade ago, is behaving quite normally, service productivity, which has not budged for a decade, has been rising almost as fast.
"When business was booming in the 1980's, service companies used technology to woo customers," said Bill Lewis, director of the McKinsey Global Institute, an arm of the worldwide consulting company. "Now that sales are slow, they are refocusing the efforts on cost reduction."
A third sign is that profits have made a strong comeback despite a relatively weak rebound in sales. "This is a business-led, profits-driven recovery," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear Stearns, who served as chief economist with the Office of Management and Budget during President Ronald Reagan's first term. "It's out of some old industry economics textbook written long before we heard of John Maynard Keynes and demand-side economics," he said.
Profit margins have increased in the last year. During periods of high inflation, companies could repair poor profit margins by raising prices. Nowadays, potential customers may simply refuse to buy and, as a result, companies have to dig into costs and raise efficiency. The operating earnings of the companies on the S. & P. 500 list, stripped of special charges, jumped 13 percent in 1992 -- as much as in 1983 even though revenue rose half as much.
One reason for this is the heavy spending by companies on new equipment. Such spending, especially for high-tech equipment, did not fall as much during this recession as it usually does and has been rising in the last year at nearly four times the rate of consumer spending -- 11.9 percent versus 3.2 percent.
"This is the first recovery I have seen in many cycles," Mr. Kudlow said, "when the expansion of business profits and recovery of business balance sheets is leading to business investment, which in turn is pushing up hours worked and providing incomes even while long-term downsizing is taking place."
Today, high-tech equipment accounts for a bigger share of economic output than cars and trucks.
"That gives at least a reasonable reason to think that we'll see fast productivity growth sustain itself," said Bradford De Long, a Harvard economist whose studies suggest that more spending on equipment explains why some countries grow faster than others.
As George Belonogoff, vice president and manager of engineering systems for Bechtel Software Inc, says: "We've reached the point where you can design a facility on a computer. Before we used to build plastic models that cost millions of dollars and thousands of man hours."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Cattle and Grains Decline; Oil Off in Reaction to OPEC

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market's plunge sent shock waves through the cattle and grain markets yesterday, and crude oil prices fell amid skepticism about an OPEC agreement to trim production.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell nearly 83 points, as investors worried about President Clinton's plan to raise taxes. 
 The stock market's tumble "kind of cast a shadow over everything," said Martyn Foreman, a grain analyst with Agrivisor Services Inc., a subsidiary of the Illinois Farm Bureau in Bloomington, Ill.
An early rally took live cattle futures to a record high of 83.75 cents a pound in the opening minutes, eclipsing Friday's peak of 82.75.
 
 
'Traders Started Worrying'
 "When the stock market tumbled, the cattle traders started worrying about the economy and what a tax increase on the middle class might mean as far as consumer purchasing power," said Chuck Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in Chicago.
February live cattle futures managed to finish with a slight gain, reflecting deterioration of cattle feedlot conditions because of weekend snow in the Southern Plains.
Mr. Foreman of Agrivisor said losses in grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade mainly reflected beneficial weekend snow in the winter wheat belt. The stock market's plunge was a contributing factor.
"It's hard to tell how much it hurt," he said. "It certainly didn't help."
Oil prices fell sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange after bickering ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to cut output by 1.5 million barrels a day.
 
 
'Severe Question'
 William O'Neill, senior strategist with Merrill Lynch Futures in New York, said the meeting's acrimonious tone "brings into severe question whether there will be full compliance with the new quotas."
Light crude for March delivery fell 45 cents, to $19.53 a barrel; March heating oil fell 0.49 cent, to 55.14 cents a gallon; March unleaded gasoline plummeted 1.3 cents, to 52.28 cents a gallon, and March natural gas climbed 5.5 cents to $1.765 per 1,000 cubic feet.
Tight supplies and strong demand drove lumber futures to a record high for the 16th consecutive session on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The March contract rose $5, to $400.70 per thousand board feet.
