HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Dragged Lower By Selloff in U.S. Stocks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday in hectic trading on world currency markets, following the plunge in stock prices in New York.
Gold prices rose worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $333.00 an ounce, up $3.40 from Friday. Republic National Bank said gold added $3.20, to a late bid price of $332.00. Markets in the United States were closed on Monday for Washington's Birthday. 
 The dollar-selling began overnight in Europe, where traders began assessing President Clinton's plans to increase taxes.
The plan unnerved the stock market in New York, where the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 82.94 points amid fear that higher taxes could derail the economic recovery.
 
 
'Dollar Just Followed the Dow'
 "The dollar just followed the Dow," said Frank Pusateri, a vice president at the Bank of Boston. "Clinton's package is 100 percent" of what is driving the market, he said.
Analysts, however, were quick to emphasize that the market still saw strength in the dollar. The United States currency had gained ground in recent weeks after interest rates began to decline in Europe. With many European economies still depressed, interest-rate differentials are expected to remain in the dollar's favor.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 120.62 yen, down 0.53 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 119.65 yen. In New York, the dollar fell to 119.93 yen, from 120.65 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.4475, from $1.4180 late Monday. In in New York, one pound cost $1.4495, up from Friday's $1.4205.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates included: 1.6285 German marks, down from 1.6586; 1.5040 Swiss francs, down from 1.5385; 5.5165 French francs, down from 5.6080; 1,541.00 Italian lire, down from 1,542.00, and 1.2583 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2546.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $331.65 an ounce, from $328.55 late Monday. In Zurich, gold rose to a late bid of $329.95, from $328.30. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold was up 12 cents to $329.48.

HEADLINE: Banks Show Drop in Yields

BYLINE: By DEAN BAQUET

 BODY:
Yields of bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit for the seven-day period that ended yesterday continued to edge downward.
In the New York market, average six-month certificate yields were lower than at 20 major banks across the country, while money market yields were about the same. 
 In the New York area, yields on money market accounts were down an average of 2 basis points, to 2.64 percent, according to the latest survey by The Bank Rate Monitor. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Money market account yields have now fallen for eight straight weeks.
The average New York rate for three-month certificates of deposit dropped a basis point, to 2.75 percent, as did the average yield on six-month accounts, which fell to 2.95 percent.
 
 
Sharp Changes in New York
 The institutions in the New York market that posted the sharpest changes this week included Carteret Federal Savings in New Jersey, which reduced its money market accounts by 36 basis points, to 2.94 percent. First Fidelity Bank in New Jersey lowered its yield on six-month certificates by 10 basis points, to 2.90 percent, while National Westminster Bank dropped 5 basis points off its three-month account, to 2.53 percent.
Outside New York, yields at 20 large banks were largely unchanged, at 2.63 percent. Six-month C.D.'s fell by 1 basis point, to 2.98 percent.
 
 
'A Critical Juncture'
 "This is a critical juncture for savers and borrowers," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor. "Everything hangs on the markets' reaction to President Clinton's tough economic proposals."
At the Treasury's weekly auction yesterday, the average discount rate for three- and six-month bills was again slightly lower. The three-month bill fell to 2.93 percent, the seventh consecutive week it has dropped. The average rate for a six-month bill was 3.08 percent, down a basis point. The weekly Treasury auction is one measure of how banks may set deposit rates in the weeks ahead.

HEADLINE: Hospitality to Acquire Super 8 Motels

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Hospitality Franchise Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $125 million for Super 8 Motels Inc., which operates 949 budget-priced motels in North America.
The move rounds out Hospitality Franchise's lineup of hotels and motels, which includes the higher-priced chains Ramada in the United States and Howard Johnson and Days Inn worldwide. 
 "It makes a whole lot of strategic sense," said William Smith, an analyst at Renaissance Capital, a research and money management firm in Greenwich, Conn.
 
'Critical Mass' in Budget Market
 Henry R. Silverman, chairman and chief executive of Hospitality Franchise, which is based in Parsippany, N.J., said the acquisition would afford Super 8 franchisees greater economies of scale, saving them between 5 and 10 percent on their expenses. In addition, he said, "it gives us instant penetration with critical mass in the budget segment, which is the fastest-growing part of the market."
The transaction would also intensify Hospitality Franchise's spirited rivalry with Choice Hotels International, whose chains include Comfort, Quality and Econo Lodge. In 1990, Hospitality Franchise outbid Choice for Ramada and Howard Johnson, paying Prime Motor Inns Inc. $175 million. The company itself does not own any hotels outright.
Investors in the company, which went public at $16 a share in December, applauded the move by bidding the stock to a new intraday high of $27.375 yesterday. But the stock came under pressure from the overall market's plunge, and it ended the day up only 12.5 cents, to $26.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Higher Earnings Estimate
 Michael G. Mueller, an industry analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, said yesterday's announcement prompted him to raise his earnings estimate for Hospitality Franchise to $1.30 a share this year from $1.15, and to $1.65 a share next year from $1.45.
Hospitality Franchise said it expected the transaction to be completed by mid-April. The company also said yesterday that it was trying to refinance its debt with Chemical Bank, a move that should lower its expenses further if it is successful.
Mr. Mueller considered the purchase price, which is roughly seven times cash flow, a good deal for Hospitality Franchise. In 1992, franchise revenues for Super 8 were $34 million, and earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization were roughly $15.4 million. Mr. Mueller said that figure should rise to $18 million this year.
Mr. Silverman said that Hospitality Franchise did not plan any noteworthy shifts in strategy for Super 8, which owns 48 motels that will not be acquired in the deal. The retained properties will be reorganized into a new company that will remain based in Aberdeen, S.C., where the first Super 8 motel was built in 1976.
The controlling interest in Hospitality Franchise is owned by Blackstone Capital Partners, which in turn is owned by the Blackstone Group, a leveraged-buyout firm formed in 1985 by Peter G. Peterson and Stephen A. Schwarzman.

HEADLINE: Japan's Trade Surplus Up

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus jumped almost 40 percent in January from a year earlier, another stark reminder of the heavy pressure Tokyo faces to stimulate its stagnant economy and increase imports.
The customs-cleared trade surplus for January, unadjusted for seasonal factors, widened to $5.29 billion from a revised $3.79 billion a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today. The figure was higher than most economists' predictions. 
 Its surplus with the United States rose to $2.95 billion from $2.45 billion in January 1992, while the surplus with the European Community widened to $2.74 billion from $2.16 billion.
Adjusted for seasonal factors, the total January surplus widened to $9.82 billion from a revised $9.48 billion in December, the ministry said.
Exports tend to be above normal in the last four months of the year and markedly below normal in January.

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Sheila Rule

 BODY:

Trying to Be Seen
Along with the exploding popularity of country music has come a deluge of new artists eager to join country's constellation of stars. With so much competition, record labels increasingly must find ways to make their fledgling acts stand out from the pack. Mercury Nashville has come up with its own solution. 
 The label is promoting three new solo artists -- John Brannen, Toby Keith and Shania Twain -- by packaging them together and taking them directly to the record-buying public. Accompanied by a band, the three are going on a 15-city "Triple Play" tour of country-music clubs, beginning on Feb. 26 in Louisville, Ky. Their new singles are being released separately, and all three debut albums are to hit record stores on April 20.
Luke Lewis, the president of Mercury Nashville, said that presenting the artists together rather than separately would create greater interest among radio stations, record stores, the press and consumers and would also be more economical. And because live performances are so compelling, he said, a club tour seemed to be a good marketing strategy.
"This arena has gotten really competitive, and you have to make a particularly strong impact from the get-go with new acts these days," Mr. Lewis said. "The tried-and-true method would be to go to the big major markets, do showcases and invite key industry people. But that wouldn't be as consumer-oriented. We're hitting markets where radio stations are more receptive to playing new acts and where there's a particularly efficient retail environment so we can see an instantaneous reaction."
This is not the first time Mercury Nashville has tried something new. About a year ago, it was looking for a way to fuel the career of a young Kentuckian. Rather than take the well-traveled route of having his music video appear on country television networks and getting his debut single played on radio, the label released the video to dance clubs and created a dance and dance contest to go with the song. Fill in the blanks with Billy Ray Cyrus, "Achy Breaky Heart" and the Achy Breaky.
 
On South Africa
 If you ask Jon Secada about his "overnight success," the singer and songwriter might tell you it involved earning a bachelor's degree in music and a master's degree in jazz vocal performance, working for over five years with the musician and producer Emilio Estefan and his wife, Gloria, as well as a lot of perseverance.
"It was a slow process but a good one," Mr. Secada said in an interview. "Emilio had told me that it would take a while to get established and have a career that would be respected and last. I've always been in it for the work and love of my craft; that's why I studied music. From the beginning I believed I was lucky because I could work in the industry."
Mr. Secada, who was born in Cuba, is up for a Grammy Award as best new artist, and his debut album (SBK Records) has been nominated as best Latin pop album. He'll find out if he won one week from today. For now he can still savor the global success of his album and first single, "Just Another Day." He currently has two songs on Billboard's chart of the top 100 singles, with "Do You Believe in Us" at No. 31 and, at No. 50, "Angel," one of the singles with the greatest sales gains.
The singer recently visited South Africa and said he was touched by the way he was greeted.
"Black media and radio people in South Africa accepted me a lot better than black radio stations here," said Mr. Secada, who with his family settled in Miami when he was 8. "My music's not played here on black radio stations, but over there it was like 'welcome home,' " he said. "I'm black, I'm Hispanic; my music might not be rhythm-and-blues completely, but it's got flavors of it. The feeling there was, you are here in our country and we accept you with open arms."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mets Casting Their Eyes On Dominican Sandlot

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 16

 BODY:
Morning had broken noisily in the Dominican Republic and traffic had snarled in Santo Domingo one day last December. Spread out smack in the center of the entrepreneurial madness and automoble exhaust is a humble baseball diamond, one full of holes and hopes, and on this day, a dozen or so of the country's unemployed leaned on a fence and watched as a makeshift instructional league game went on.
"It's a public park," Eddie Toledo, the top Dominican scout for the Mets and the man in charge of the organization's developmental program in the country, said. "It's tough to keep up. You fix something, and who knows who is going to break it." 
 But Toledo's greatest concern, the project he goes to bed worrying about protecting from any kind of damage, was standing out in right field, breathing in the smog and the scene's air of ordinariness.
 
Quick Bat, Nice Arm
 "Good quick bat," Milciades Oliva, one of Toledo's coaches, said of Rafael Guerrero. "Nice arm. Perfect body. Desire."
The high praise for the right-handed outfielder, who is 6 feet 2 inches tall and weighs 175 pounds, runs clear to the top of the Mets' organization.
"Rafael Guerrero has more physical talent than any Dominican player who has ever come into our system," Gerry Hunsicker, the Mets' vice president for baseball operations, said recently. "He has a chance to be a dominant major league player."
And so, as the Mets prepare to open spring training here this week, before speculation turns in earnest to Eddie Murray and Bobby Bonilla in 1993, it is tempting to look further into the future and transport Rafael Guerrero, 18, from right field in that Santo Domingo public park to right field at Shea Stadium. It's a huge projection, to be sure, but it's what springtime imagination is all about in baseball.
 
'This Kid Seems Special'
 "You look up the word scout in the dictionary, and it says 'explorer,' " said Toledo. "So there is always a chance you are wrong, that the path your instincts lead you on will be wrong. This kid seems special. He was ready to be signed at 15, but you had to wait until he was 17. He's different. He's got charisma. He's going to be big. He's going to be, maybe, a cornerstone of the outfield for the Mets."
Hunsicker said: "He's a very young kid with many miles to go. But he's got great raw power. He can be an exciting player."
Guerrero, with all his lack of polish and hype, did nothing to blunt the excitement the Mets feel for him with his first season of professional baseball last year. He hit .278 in 56 games in the Gulf Coast League, driving in 36 runs and leading the club in slugging percentage.
"He held his own," said Hunsicker. "I see him being able to move quicker."
 
A Challenge for Youngster
 Guerrero will arrive here for the organization's minor league spring training in March. And a strong showing could earn him a spot on a full season minor league club, perhaps with the organization's Class A team in Columbia, S.C.
"It would be a tremendous leap," said Hunsicker. "But he could do it."
The Mets believe that as an organization they have put in place more than the normal set of resources to help a player like Guerrero in his accelerated climb through the North American baseball system. Their annual budget for developing Latin American players has grown from $25,000 three years ago to $150,000 today. English classes are offered and Felix Millan, a former member of the Mets, has overseen the entire Latin American program as its salaried coordinator.
"But it remains not as easy as it should be for, say, a young Dominican player to get integrated and advance," said Hunsicker. "There is still prejudice. There remain additional challenges."
 
A Diamond in the Rough
 The hurdles were manifestly obvious at the diamond in Santo Domingo in December. The baseballs looked like broken pieces of coal and bounced about as well. Grass grew amid the infield dirt. There was no such thing as a routine grounder or flyout.
"God is the only one who waters our field," said Oliva.
Dust and dirt swirled across the field. Guerrero's face was covered with it as he comes off between innings. A smile, though, could clearly be detected.
"It was very hard for me at the beginning," said Guerrero. "But I still feel like a kid. There are no questions for me. There are no doubts. Shea Stadium -- that's going to be the place for me."
"I hope so," said Toledo. "My bonus is at stake."
Baseball in the Dominican Republic is all about great leaps -- of faith as well as effort. Guerrero has taken both and so far landed with an impact felt throughout the Mets' organization.

HEADLINE: Royal Indiscretions

 BODY:
In Britain, the odds offered by bookmakers seven weeks ago against doing away with the monarchy by the year 2000 were 100 to 1. Incredibly, they have since fallen to 8 to 1. According to a recent Gallup Poll, only one person in three believes Britain gets good value from the cost of the royal family, and four in five say too many of the royals lead an idle, jet-set life.
This dramatic collapse in public esteem owes much to telephonic garrulity. It would seem half of Britain has read or listened to apparently authentic recordings of Princess Diana tittering her secrets to a male pal who calls her "Squidgy" while her husband, Prince Charles, swaps off-color snickers with Camilla Parker-Bowles, wife of a courtier. And who eavesdropped? Most likely, some royal-watchers say, Government snoopers at the supersecret signals interception facility at Cheltenham, who may have leaked the tapes, with or without approval of superiors. 
 In just months, these disclosures have done more damage to the royals than a century of anti-monarchical agitation. The opposition Labor Party is now discussing a proposal to make the Queen liable to inheritance taxes and to take away her power to dissolve Parliament and choose a prime minister. Not since the English Civil War has the royal family become a subject of such furious party debate.
All of this confirms the acute prophecy of Walter Bagehot, the Victorian-era editor of The Economist: "When there is a select committee on the Queen, the charm of royalty will be gone. Its mystery is its life. We must not let daylight in on magic." What Bagehot could not have foreseen is that an agency associated with the James Bond mystique of unquestioning fealty to Queen and country should be the prime suspect in bringing the Crown into disrepute.
Americans can now better understand the unwritten prohibition against quoting the table talk of members of the royal family. It prevents disclosure of the awful secret that, in private, royals can be even more banal than their humble subjects.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
HONDA, SUBARU, MITSUBISHI SALES FALL IN EARLY FEBRUARY

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
Sales of cars built in the United States by three Japanese automakers fell in the Feb. 1-10 period, the companies reported yesterday. The Honda Motor Company, suffering a sales decline in recent months, extended that weakness with a 17.8 percent drop in the period. For the year, Honda sales are off 23.4 percent. Subaru of America, a small competitor in domestic car sales, reported a 43.9 percent decline compared with last year. For the year, Subaru sales are up 3 percent. Mitsubishi Motors, another small contender in sales of cars built in the United States, said its sales slid 18.1 percent in early February. For the year, sales of Mitsubishis built in the United States are up 23.1 percent. 
 Separately, Honda said that it was raising the price of cars sold in the United States by nearly 1 percent. A company spokesman said an average of $149, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, will be added to the price of economy models sold under the Honda name, while the average price of its luxury Acura models will rise $187, or eight-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: A Tax on Gasoline? Better Get Used to It

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Timid Stimulus Package" (editorial, Jan. 30) argues that President Clinton's plan of $15 billion to $20 billion in additional Federal spending is not sufficient to stimulate the economy and reverse "huge layoffs at I.B.M., Boeing, Sears and other corporate giants." 
 But a gradual increase in gasoline and other consumption or value added taxes for investment financing would stimulate the economy without igniting inflation and discouraging technological improvement. This measure, which can be considered as a hybrid of the Keynesian demand side (increase in investment spending) and the supply-side (increase in production) economics, would also reduce foreign trade deficits and make the dollar stronger.
Among the symbols of American life, "mom, apple pie and cheap gasoline," the third will have to be reconsidered by consumers.
In almost all other countries the price of gasoline is higher, up to $4.50 a gallon. Although such a tax would at first hurt the average family, it would in the long run help to reduce budget deficits, pollution, accidents and the dependence of the United States on foreign oil.
 
NICHOLAS V. GIANARIS
Professor of Economics
Fordham University
New York, Feb. 2, 1993

HEADLINE: Hopes for a New Boston Garden Dim With Political Quarreling

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
For years the Boston Garden has been a special symbol to Bostonians. Part shrine, as the home of their beloved basketball Celtics and hockey Bruins, it has also been a frustrating reminder of the petty politics and lack of civic leadership that have blocked repeated efforts to replace the grimy old Garden with a more modern arena that would have air-conditioning and seats with good views.
Last spring, when Boston's three largest banks agreed to lend $120 million to build a new Garden, salvation finally seemed at hand. The steel had been ordered and 700 construction workers, out of jobs for several years with New England's recession, were set to start work on March 1. 
 But late last week, on the very day the Massachusetts House of Representatives passed a bill giving state approval to the deal, the developer backed out, accusing the politicians of making unfair changes in the contract. The action by the developer, Jeremy M. Jacobs, the owner of the Delaware North Corporation of Buffalo, has thrown Boston into turmoil.
"This is a town where there are three pastimes: politics, sports and revenge," said Lawrence C. Moulter, the president of the New Boston Garden Corporation, which is owned by Delaware North.
"I think this a community that is dysfunctional," said Mr. Moulter, who has been working for years to put together a complex package that would allow a new arena to replace the outdated one, built in 1928. "We are saddled by the baggage of 300 years of decaying politics. It started with the Puritans, who made us feel that we have to beat ourselves to prove we are having a good time."
What caused the deal to collapse is a matter of bitter dispute. Mr. Moulter said the Legislature had demanded too many petty financial concessions. Legislators say Mr. Jacobs, his boss, tried to enrich himself by sneaking through changes in the construction plans for the new Garden, which will be in air rights over state-owned land. Businessmen familiar with the deal say strong egos and abrasive personalities on both sides played a role.
In the eyes of Mr. Moulter, and many others here, the collapse of the deal has raised a question about whether Boston really is a world-class city and whether a growing effort to make the city a site for the summer Olympics is just a foolish dream.
"There's a subculture of meanness, intolerance and pettiness, of putting down people instead of putting up people," said Paul G. Garrity, a former state judge.
"It's really an intolerance of people who are not only different from you in race, ethnicity and religion, but it's people who don't come from your neighborhood," said Mr. Garrity. "Jeremy Jacobs isn't from around here. He isn't a member of the Boston tribe."
The unraveling of the plan to build the new $190 million arena has also called into question the leadership of the state's two most powerful politicians, Gov. William F. Weld, a Republican, and the president of the Senate, William Bulger, a Democrat. Governor Weld has been frequently mentioned as a potential candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996. A strong advocate of Delaware North's plan for the new Garden, he has nonetheless appeared powerless to get the Democratic-controlled Legislature to pass a bill that Mr. Jacobs and Mr. Moulter will accept.
Mr. Bulger, from the heavily Irish-American working-class section of South Boston, held up an earlier bill last December, before the previous session of the Legislature expired, arguing that it gave away too much state land and money to Delaware North. There may also be elements of a personal quarrel in the dispute between Mr. Bulger and Mr. Jacobs. In 1988, a former aide to Mr. Bulger who is one of his closest friends, Francis X. Joyce, suggested that Delaware North was connected to organized crime. Mr. Jacobs filed a libel suit and the Massachusetts Convention Center Authority, a state agency headed by Mr. Joyce, paid $100,000 to Mr. Jacobs as a settlement.
In addition to the Boston Garden, Delaware North owns the Boston Bruins, food concessions in many sports arenas around the country, a greyhound parimutuel betting organization and was recently awarded the right to operate the concessions at Yosemite National Park.
Mr. Bulger could not be reached for comment. His office said he was in Hawaii attending a conference on health care.
But Joseph Brady, counsel to the State Senate, said Mr. Bulger had opposed the initial deal with Delaware North because the concern was violating a 1988 state law under which, in effect, the state permitted Delaware North to build the new Garden above a state-owned railroad station, South Station. Specifically, Mr. Brady said the developers' plans showed they would have built a ticket office and sports shop on property intended for the train station.
Mr. Brady also asserted that Delaware North's plan would have lowered the air space above the train tracks to 30 feet from 35 feet, making it impossible to use double-decker commuter trains. Mr. Brady said the developer also planned to build an office tower on the ground, instead of in the air above the station, further encroaching on state property.
Mr. Moulter, in turn, charged that it was the Legislature that was making changes in the original agreement. After Mr. Bulger killed the first bill in December, Mr. Moulter said, Mr. Jacobs made a number of financial concessions.
Then last week, Mr. Moulter said, after a final meeting with legislative leaders at which agreement was reached, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Thomas M. Finneran, a Democrat, called Mr. Moulter back in.
"They told me, 'There is one more thing you have to do,' " Mr. Moulter said. Mr. Finneran, he said, wanted the developer to kick in $3.5 million in so-called linkage payments, in which Delaware North would provide that amount to Boston area parks for ice skating.
That was when Mr. Jacobs decided to cancel the deal, Mr. Moulter said.
 
Effort to Rescue Deal
 Governor Weld has been trying this week to put a deal back together, and today he met with bankers and Mr. Moulter. One banker said the plan might still be saved. If it is not, the 700 construction jobs will be lost, the Celtics and Bruins may carry out threats of leaving Boston, and the state will be out $25 million worth of construction that Delaware North agreed to do as part of the new station.
Howie Carr, a columnist for The Boston Herald and a talk show host on WRKO radio, said the incident showed that "nothing's really changed" since the days of Mayor James Michael Curley, who presided with pomp over a Boston in economic decline during the first half of the century and eventually went to prison for corruption.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 18, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the collapse of plans to rebuild the Boston Garden misidentified the train station over which the new arena would be built. It is North Station.

HEADLINE: Resorts;
In San Antonio, Hyatt Defies U.S. Trend

BYLINE: By LETTICE STUART SAN ANTONIO

 BODY:
A Japanese-American group will open a 500-room Hyatt hotel here despite a depressed and overbuilt national hotel market in which new construction is at a near standstill.
The $100 million 200-acre Hyatt Regency Hill Country Resort is one of only a handful of major new hotels completed in the United States in the last 12 months and is the first to be built in Texas in five years. The opening is scheduled for Wednesday, Feb. 24. 
 The project was developed by the Woodbine Development Corporation of Dallas and is owned by the Hyatt Corporation of Chicago, the Hunt Realty Corporation of Dallas, the Shimizu Land Corporation of New York, and the Kawasaki Steel Corporation of Tokyo. Financing was provided by the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan.
"In an industry where 'no new hotels' is a rule of thumb right now, this project certainly is an exception," said Robert J. Crawford Jr., president of Lodging Solutions Inc., a hotel consulting firm in Natick, Mass.
Mr. Crawford said the industry is suffering from the nationwide frenzy of hotel construction between 1984 and 1989 that left the country with 2.5 million hotel rooms and an average vacancy rate of 40 percent.
He estimated that 60 to 70 percent of the hotels in the country currently were unable to service their debt. More than 3,000 hotels have been taken back by lenders in the last three years, and another 2,000 are likely to follow in the next 24 months, he said.
Lenders, who are reselling these properties at 30 percent to 40 percent of replacement cost, may be forced to finance acquisitions, but capital for new construction is virtually nonexistent, Mr. Crawford said. He predicted it would be five or more years before the industry begins to recover.
But John Field Scovell, president of Woodbine Development, the developer for the Hyatt resort in San Antonio, is unfazed. "We think San Antonio is the best hotel market in the country right now," Mr. Scovell said.
Bruce H. Walker, president of Source Strategies Inc., a hotel consulting and market research company in San Antonio, said that the city's hotel revenues increased 13 percent in 1992, and that occupancy rates at the city's hotels, which have a total of 20,000 rooms, averaged nearly 75 percent. Mr. Walker believes the market will support an additional 5,000 rooms over the next three or four years.
The reason for his optimism is San Antonio's $2 billion annual tourism industry. According to the Texas Department of Transportation, San Antonio draws 11 million visitors a year and is the state's No. 1 tourist destination. The Alamo landmark in the heart of downtown is the leading attraction.
The growth of San Antonio's tourism business has been no accident. For years city officials and civic leaders have sought out and supported developments that bolstered tourism. In 1986, a $32 million expansion of the Henry E. Gonzalez Convention Center was completed, increasing total exhibit space to 240,000 square feet. In 1988, the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation opened the $220 million Rivercenter Mall downtown on the San Antonio River. Sea World of Texas, a 250-acre aquatic theme park, opened the same year.
San Antonio's newest attraction is Fiesta Texas, a $100 million 200-acre musical theme park set in a limestone quarry and surrounded by 100-foot cliffs. The park, which opened in May, was developed by Opryland U.S.A. Inc. of Nashville and the United Services Automobile Association, better known as USAA, an insurance and financial services company in San Antonio. Fiesta Texas is expected to bring an additional $4 billion to the local economy during the next 15 years.
In addition, the 65,000-seat Alamodome Stadium is nearing completion and is scheduled to open in the spring.
The site for the Hyatt resort was carved out of a 2,700-acre cattle and agricultural ranch that lies within the city limits in the northwest section off State Highway 151. The resort consists of a 500-room hotel; an 18-hole golf course; tennis courts; a jogging path; a health club; and a four-acre water park with two swimming pools, a waterfall, an outdoor spa, sand beaches, gardens and a 1,000-foot river for navigating by inner tube.
The hotel's 27,000 square feet of meeting space includes a 5,700-square-foot ballroom aimed at attracting convention and group business. Designed by Hill Architects Inc. of San Francisco to reflect the region's typical architecture, the hotel's limestone facade is accented by wood-trimmed porches.
Room rates will range from $165 to $220 a night, according to Kenneth A. Pilgrim, the hotel's general manager.

HEADLINE: Bosnia Neighbors Nervously Seek Pacts

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SKOPJE, Macedonia, Feb. 17

 BODY:
A flurry of diplomatic activity has swept the Balkans in the last week as political leaders from this volatile area have taken steps to strengthen regional ties to prevent sparks from the Bosnian war from igniting nationalist conflicts that could engulf their countries.
In the first visit to independent Macedonia by an important head of state, President Turgut Ozal of Turkey today discussed military assistance to this former Yugoslav republic, which was left without a military when the Yugoslav Army withdrew last spring, taking with it even faucets from barracks sinks. 
 In the last week, the Balkan countries bordering the former Yugoslav republics have strung a web of friendship pacts and economic-cooperation agreements.
Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis clearly signaled over the weekend in Athens that Greece is angling for a compromise solution to its blockage of European Community recognition of Macedonia as an independent state.
 
'A Panic Setting In'
 "You're seeing a panic setting in in the Balkans that there may be a coming conflagration, and no one wants to be isolated and on the losing side," a Western diplomat said. "Neighbors are taking another hard look at each other. Everybody is trying to sign as many agreements as possible."
On Sunday, Romania and Greece signed an agreement on political and economic cooperation, including a pledge to refrain from using force to settle regional conflicts.
After a two-day visit to Albania by the Bulgarian President, Zhelyu Zhelev, the two countries signed a friendship accord on Sunday that calls for construction of a highway running from Black Sea coast of Bulgaria through Macedonia and on to the Albanian port of Durres.
Bulgaria and Greece agreed on Friday to strengthen relations and take steps to help prevent the Bosnian war from spreading to Macedonia, whose territory has been contested over the last century by all four of its neighbors.
 
Turkish-Romanian Accord
 Again last week, the Turkish Foreign Minister signed a political and economic agreement in Bucharest after two days of discussion of the Yugoslav war and other issues with the Romanians.
It is no surprise that much of the diplomacy is centered on Macedonia, the economically weakest component of the former Yugoslavia and the only one of its breakaway republics to be denied diplomatic recognition by the European Community and the United States.
In addition to concern that animosities between this country's majority Slavs and minority ethnic Albanians might explode, Macedonians fear that if major clashes break out between Serbs and the Albanian majority in Kosovo province in Serbia, the Albanians here will drag Macedonia into a war with Serbia that could ensnare Albania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey.
In a preventive measure last month, the United Nations deployed a multinational peacekeeping force here. And the United Nations Security Council is reportedly preparing a resolution recognizing Macedonia.
At the end of December, the United States warned Serbia not to take military action against the ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.
 
Ozal's Balkan Tour
 Mr. Ozal's visit to Skopje is the second stop on a Balkan tour that began in Sofia, Bulgaria, and continues on Thursday in Tirana, Albania. Though it is billed as an effort to end the war in Bosnia, the trip is clearly intended to put Europe on notice that Ankara has a strong interest in Macedonia and other Balkan countries that emerged from the Ottoman Empire after the Balkan wars of 1912 and 1913.
Turkey has been the most outspoken advocate of United Nations military intervention in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which was an Ottoman province until 1908.
Slobodan Casule, a longtime Macedonian journalist who heads the national radio station, said: "The point of Ozal's visit is to establish a Turkish stronghold here and especially in Albania. This is Turkey's link with Europe, and the Turks are telling both Serbia and Greece 'hands off.' "
 
Athens Blocks Recognition
 Athens has blocked European Community recognition of this mountainous, land-locked country for more than a year, asserting that the very name Macedonia represents territorial pretensions on the Greek province of Macedonia.
Over the last year, Turkey has become Macedonia's most important trade partner. Turkish footwear, detergent and other goods are replacing merchandise from the former Yugoslav republics on Skopje's store shelves. Scores of Turkish-Macedonian companies have formed.
At a news conference today, Mr. Ozal repeated his assertion that Turkey is responsible for looking after the well-being of the Muslims in the Balkans.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: Impact on Individuals;
Middle Class and Wealthy To Bear Brunt of New Taxes

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
President Clinton's new tax plan reaches into the pockets of a broad swath of Americans, increasing income taxes on the rich, hitting the middle class with a new energy tax and raising taxes on Social Security benefits of the affluent.
For average Americans, the most visible change brought by the new plan will be higher prices for gasoline, electricity and heating fuel. Administration officials say the annual energy bill for a family with a taxable income of $60,000, currently around $3,000, will rise by $133. 
 With news of the energy tax angering many middle-income Americans, Administration officials strained today to assert that Mr. Clinton's tax plan would strike the rich far harder than the middle class.
They said that for households earning $250,000 a year, the new package would raise taxes from all sources by about $10,000. For households earning $80,000, taxes would go up by about $560 and for a family earning $45,000 taxes would rise about $225. For a family earning $25,000, taxes would remain essentially unchanged, inching up about $25.
 
Shift on Lower Incomes
 Administration officials said Americans with incomes of under $20,000 would be no worse off and would sometimes be better off despite the new energy tax. These low-income families, they said, would be helped by more generous food stamp benefits, larger subsidies to heat their homes, and increasing the earned-income tax credit.
On Tuesday, Administration officials had said the President's tax package would not increase taxes on Americans earning less than $30,000. But Treasury officials acknowledged today that under the plan, taxes for families with incomes of $20,000 to $30,000 would rise by one-tenth of 1 percent -- a figure they said was so low that it did not represent an increase.
Mr. Clinton proposed many other tax changes, including an increase in the top rate for estate taxes and prohibiting taxpayers from deducting the price of meals and real estate expenses when they move. Among the proposed tax measures are these:
 
Income Taxes
 Mr. Clinton would hit the rich hardest by increasing the top personal income tax rate to 36 percent from 31 percent for couples with adjusted gross incomes of $180,000 or more and single people with adjusted gross incomes of $140,000 or more. Income taxes for families earning less than $180,000 are to remain unchanged.
According to the Administration, this increase would hurt 1.2 percent of American households. Under the proposal, according to an example given by the Treasury Department, a family of four with an income of $275,000 would see its overall taxes jump by 11 percent or $8,969 to $90,537.
The plan also creates a 10 percent surtax on households with taxable incomes of $250,000 or more, which translates into adjusted gross incomes of $305,000 or more. This would raising their top tax rate to 39.6 percent.
For a family earning $500,000, taxes would jump by 22.4 percent, or $32,845, to $179,573. That would increase the effective tax rate to 35.9 percent from 29.3 percent.
During the campaign, Mr. Clinton said this tax would be a millionaires' surtax. In unveiling the surtax today, Administration officials responded to criticisms that the threshold for the tax had been lowered by asserting that 85 percent of households with taxable incomes of $250,000 or more had more than $1 million in assets.
These income tax increases are expected to raise $26.3 billion in the fiscal year 1997, according to Treasury estimates.
In another measure hitting the rich, the President proposed to eliminate limits on earnings subject to the 1.45 percent Medicare payroll tax. Currently, the tax is applied only to the first $135,000 in earnings.
If Congress approves the increase in the top income-tax rate on the rich, there will be a wide differential between the top tax rate on income and the tax rate for capital gains. Mr. Clinton's plan would raise the highest income tax rate to 36 percent -- and 39.6 percent if the surtax is included -- while the capital gains tax rate remains at 28 percent.
That is a sharp change from the Tax Reform Act of 1986, which set the top income tax rate and the capital gains rate at 28 percent with the goal of ending any preference between earned income and investment income. The 1990 budget deal raised the top income tax rate to 31 percent.
President Bush tried unsuccessfully to cut the capital gains rate to 15 percent, saying it would unleash a flood of investment. But now, with the top income tax rate expected to rise well above the capital gains rate, wealthy Americans may do precisely what the Democrats who opposed Mr. Bush's capital gains cut feared they would do: they might rush to find loopholes and shuffle assets to convert earned income into capital gains income to be taxed at the lower rate.
 
Social Security
 The Administration proposed taxing 85 percent of Social Security benefits for relatively well-off recipients; currently, 50 percent of benefits for people in this group are subject to taxes. The higher taxes will apply to couples with incomes of more than $32,000 and single individuals with incomes of more than $25,000.
According to Citizens for Tax Justice, a Washington-based research and advocacy group, subjecting 85 percent of benefits to taxation would mean that for elderly households with incomes of more than $100,000, annual Social Security benefits would in effect drop $1,359 to $7,644. For households with incomes of $50,000 to $100,000, benefits would fall $843 to $7,904. A family with an income of $40,000 to $50,000 would see its benefits fall $378 to $8,113, and for households with incomes between $35,000 and $40,000, benefits would fall $82 to $8,305.
 
Earned Income Tax Credit
 In discussing the nation's economic troubles during the campaign, Mr. Clinton often noted that many families where one or both parents worked still lived under the poverty line. To remedy this, the Administration proposed today to increase the earned income tax credit, a Government subsidy that goes to low-income workers.
Under the proposal, a two-parent family earning $10,000 could receive a $2,400 credit, up from the current maximum of $1,998. Partly to offset the effects of the new energy tax, the ceiling for receiving some benefits under the credit would increase to $30,000, up from the current ceiling of $23,760.
The proposal called for creating such a credit for households without children. Under the plan, workers who earn less than $9,000 a year would get a 7.65 percent credit, giving them a maximum credit of $306. For workers whose incomes are so low that they owe no income taxes, the credit is refundable, and for low-income workers who pay taxes, their taxes are reduced by the amount of the credit.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: The Energy Plan;
Fuels Tax: Spreading The Burden

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
President Clinton wants to add some new letters to the Government's tax-code alphabet soup: B.T.U.
His proposed broad-based energy tax would apply to the energy content of nearly all fuels, as measured by the British thermal unit, or B.T.U. -- the quantity of heat needed to raise the temperature of a pound of water by 1 degree Fahrenheit. 
 When the tax is fully in force, the Treasury estimated, it would increase the $2,242 energy bill for a family of four earning $25,000 by $105.
 
Increase for Gasoline
 The new tax would raise the price of gasoline by 2.5 cents a gallon next year; in 1996 the tax would be 7.5 cents a gallon higher than it is now. With the average household using about 1,000 gallons of gasoline a year, that means an increase cost of about $25 the first year and $75 the third year .
Treasury officials said the energy tax would result in a 75-cent increase in the average home's monthly electricity bill, now $67, in the first year, and in a $2.25 increase in the third year.
Administration officials said they chose the new energy tax because it would encourage conservation, reduce pollution and not hurt any one region much more than others. Mr. Clinton selected it after criticizing a gasoline tax during the Presidential campaign on the ground that it would hit the middle class disproportionately. But many experts say that a broader energy tax would still hit the middle class harder than it hits the wealthy.
 
Sparing Renewable Energy
 The tax would not be imposed directly on consumers but on producers, refiners and transporters. It would then be passed on to consumers in the form of higher prices.
Administration officials propose to phase in the tax over three years, with the first third taking effect on July 1, 1994. The new tax would increase energy costs for the typical household by about 4.5 percent once it is fully phased in after July 1, 1996.
The new tax would increase the cost of gasoline, natural gas, home heating oil and electricity coming from coal, hydropower and nuclear power. But the tax would not apply to renewable sources of energy, including wind, solar power and geothermal power.
A specific amount of fuel would generally be taxed according to the B.T.U.'s it produces: for example, a tax of 25.7 cents for each million B.T.U.'s of coal and natural gas, 59.9 cents for each million B.T.U.'s of oil. The price of a million B.T.U's of natural gas varies by season, but is about $2. The same unit of heavy oil, the kind used in competition with gas and coal, is around $2.50. That unit of coal is around $1.50.
 
A Higher Tax on Oil
 Administration officials said they proposed to tax oil more because it pollutes more than natural gas and imposing a similar levy on both fuels would have raised the price of cleaner-burning natural gas far more proportionally than it would have raised the price of oil. The Administration proposed the same B.T.U. tax for coal and natural gas even though coal pollutes more; coal is far cheaper, so proportionally the tax would be higher.
The Administration also proposed to extend a 2.5-cent-a-gallon Federal gasoline tax that was scheduled to expire in 1995.
Industry officials today welcomed the news that the energy tax would not be placed on raw materials that are components of other products, like oil derivatives used to make plastics. But they said they were disappointed that the Administration did not plan to refund the energy taxes paid on exported goods, adding that the tax would make such goods less competitive abroad.
The Administration plans to collect $1.5 billion from this tax in the fiscal year 1994, $8.9 billion in 1995, $16.4 billion in 1996 and $22.3 billion in 1997.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: Impact on Business;
Some Businesses Face Tax Rise, but Most May Get Incentives

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
For American business, the Clinton Administration's economic plan holds a large array of new taxes and other proposals, including an increase in the corporate income-tax rate that would have the 2,700 largest corporations pay a maximum of 36 percent instead of the current 34 percent.
At the same time, businesses would be offered substantial incentives to invest in new equipment. Reflecting a general inclination by the Clinton team, small businesses, the main provider of new jobs, would be particularly favored. 
 Among other things, the plan would discourage corporate lobbying, further reduce the deduction for business meals and entertainment and deny corporations deductions for pay of more than $1 million a year to an individual unless tied to a still-to-be-defined standard of productivity.
The initiatives, some little discussed, are part of an overall strategy to insure continued economic recovery in the short term and to put both the economy and the Federal budget on sounder footing for the long term.
 
Corporate Income Tax
 Raising the corporate income tax will generate $30.6 billion from 1993 through 1998, according to Treasury estimates, while tax credits for businesses will cost the Government $28.9 billion.
The tax rate would be 36 percent for companies with taxable incomes of more than $10 million. Businesses in that group account for about one-tenth of 1 percent of American companies but the overwhelming majority of corporate tax payments. While companies could pay as much as 39 percent on some earnings, none would pay more than an average of 36 percent. Once a corporation earns $15 million, however, all of its profits would be taxed at the 36 percent rate.
 
Investment Tax Credits
 The plan provides two kinds of investment tax credits, depending on a company's size. Medium-sized and large companies would get a 7 percent credit for two years for buying new equipment, but not buildings, if that is a significant proportion of what they spent in an earlier base period.
They could choose either the three-year period of 1989 through 1991 or the five-year period of 1987 through 1991. In either case the new investment in the first year must be more than 70 percent of the base level, while investment in the second year must exceed 80 percent of the base level.
Companies with receipts of less than $5 million will receive a 7 percent credit for all investment for two years and then a permanent credit of 5 percent.
For any company, the credit could be applied to reducing liability under the alternative minimum tax, a tax paid by corporations or people whose deductions or tax-exempt income would otherwise leave them owing little or no tax. The credit could be used to offset up to 25 percent of the amount due, the Treasury said.
 
Capital Gains Tax Cut
 Small business would also have the benefit of a special cut in the capital gains tax, an idea pressed by Senator Dale Bumpers, an Arkansas Democrat who is a friend of President Clinton. In the Administration version, people investing in companies with capital of up to $25 million and holding the investments for at least five years, would be taxed on only half of their capital gains.
 
Securities Tax
 The Administration also seeks to require securities dealers to "mark to market" their inventories, reviving a Bush Administration proposal from last year to tax unsold securities. Under current law, dealers may choose between valuations based on the lower of their cost or the current market value in computing their taxable income and pay the tax only after the security is sold. The effect is to give the Government tax revenue from unsold securities if their value rises.
 
Energy Tax
 Corporate America would be subject to the Administration's proposed tax on energy, a levy based on the heat content of fuels as measured in British thermal units or B.T.U.'s. But to minimize damage in international competition, companies would not have to pay the tax on feedstocks, such as the oil that actually becomes part of a tire or plastic product.
There would be no rebate for energy used in goods that are exported.
 
Foreign Corporations
 Following up on another campaign theme, the Administration's package also has measures to obtain more taxes from foreign corporations by narrowing benefits and tightening enforcement.
One measure would require foreign companies to provide documents at the time goods are sold to subsidiaries in the United States to show whether the prices are reasonable, not artificial. Another measure would limit deductions for bank loans guaranteed by a parent corporation abroad, making it harder for foreign companies to reduce their profits by swelling the debt of their American operations.
The international operations of American companies would also come under closer scrutiny. One provision would increase the effective tax rate for oil companies. Another would end the indefinite deferral of accumulated earnings of foreign subsidiaries of American companies, taxing them at current rates once the earnings exceed 25 percent of the subsidiary's assets.
 
Miscellaneous
 The proposed $1 million limit on full deductions for corporate pay, a highly contentious issue, could be linked to profits or the corporate balance sheet but the Treasury said no decision on the benchmark seemed imminent. This was projected to raise $646 million over the six-year period, including a $19 million loss this fiscal year because executives accelerated income into late 1992.
Breaking new ground, the Administration also proposes, with some unspecified exceptions, to deny companies deductions for lobbying Congress or the executive branch. But this would not affect payments to trade associations, which are tax-exempt.
Deductions would no longer be allowed for meals and real estate expenses when workers move or club dues for employees. The deductibility of business meals and entertainment, cut in 1986 to 80 percent from 100 percent, would be further cut to 50 percent.
Picking up another idea that has received previous legislative scrutiny, the Administration proposed barring the buyers of failed thrift institutions from taking tax deductions for bad loans for which they were reimbursed by Federal insurance.
The credit for wages paid Puerto Rican workers, now 100 percent, would be reduced to 65 percent. This would produce a $7 billion gain to the Treasury over six years.
Still other measures in the Clinton plan would permanently extend a credit for research and experimentation that expired in 1992 and lift the ceiling on the amount of bonds that could be sold to finance high-speed rail lines.

LENGTH: 1079 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: The Campaign;
Gambling That a Tax-Cut Promise Was Not Taken Seriously

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
In selling his economic plan, President Clinton is gambling that voters never took seriously his campaign promise to lower the tax burden of the middle class and will respond favorably to an aggressive pitch based on equal measures of hope, fear and class revenge.
After months of polling and research, Mr. Clinton's top political advisers say they are convinced that middle-class voters will support higher taxes. The advisers say the voters will see the new taxes as the price of great improvements in Government service and as inflicting a just punishment on the rich who profited during the Reagan and Bush Administrations. 
 There is a lot of evidence in recent polls to support these hopes, but they rest on a risky political premise: the assumption that middle-class voters will forgive Mr. Clinton his broken promise of tax relief or will accept the contention that he did not unconditionally promise such relief.
"Voters never believed in the middle-class tax cut, because they have never seen anyone get a tax cut," said Mr. Clinton's chief poll taker, Stanley Greenberg. "They always believed their taxes would go up whether Bill Clinton became President or George Bush was President.
"They voted for Bill Clinton because they believed he was going to submit a program to change the direction of the country, to improve the economy and to create jobs. They will be mad as hell if their taxes go up and there's no genuine commitment to change. But if there is, they will be willing to contribute."
"It is critical," Mr. Greenberg said, that the rich be seen as punished most by Mr. Clinton's tax increases.
 
'A Very Big Signal'
 "This says to voters that this is a President who is not a captive of the wealthiest people but who is instead responsive to the middle class," Mr. Greenberg said. "That is a critical issue. Since they are not going to see the results of economic growth for a long time, it is critical that you send them a very big signal about whose interests are being advanced."
The first challenge in selling Mr. Clinton's plan to raise taxes on the middle class would seem to be overcoming the voluble history of his many specific promises to the contrary.
As candidate, Mr. Clinton promised to offer tax relief to families with incomes of less than $80,000 a year. He said he would raise taxes on only "the wealthiest 2 percent," those with incomes above $200,000 a year, and impose a surtax of 10 percent on those with annual incomes of more than $1 million.
He said that over four years he would squeeze an additional $45 billion out of foreign corporations doing business in the United States. He dismissed as an outrageous falsehood the Republican assertions that his spending programs would mean additional taxes on families making as little as $30,000 a year.
Now, Mr. Clinton proposes to increase income taxes to 36 percent from 31 percent on couples who have taxable income of more than $140,00 a year and on unmarried individuals with taxable income of more than $115,000.
And the "millionaire's surtax" would be imposed on households with taxable income of more than $250,000 a year. As tax experts predicted, the amount expected to be gained from foreign corporations will be only a few billion dollars. And virtually every family making less than $30,000 a year would not bear the costs of the higher taxes.
 
'He Never Said It'
 In interviews on Tuesday, James Carville and Paul Begala, Mr. Clinton's chief political advisers, outlined what would be the central arguments against accusations of political betrayal.
"The first defense is that he never said it," Mr. Carville said. "Clinton never made a George Bush-style read-my-lips pledge. He said that that would be irresponsible to do."
Further, Mr. Begala and Mr. Greenberg said their polls and focus group sessions showed that voters accepted the argument that Mr. Clinton had promised only that he would not raise taxes on the middle class to pay for the new Government programs he would propose. They said the research also showed that voters believed Mr. Clinton when he said he had been forced to reluctantly accept middle-class tax increases when he found out, after the election, that the budget deficit was worse than he had thought.
But Republicans, and others, can be expected to point out just how many examples of disparity there are between Mr. Clinton the campaigner and Mr. Clinton the President.
It is true that, beginning about a month before Election Day, Mr. Clinton took care to say he was not making a read-my-lips pledge on middle-class taxes. He was making the more narrow pledge that he would not raise taxes to pay for his new spending programs. But the overall thrust of what he promised ran in the opposite direction.
Mr. Clinton introduced the promise of a tax cut for the middle class in a speech in November 1991 at Georgetown University. "I will offer middle-income tax cuts," he said. "The average working family's tax bill will go down about 10 percent, a savings of about $300 a year, and I won't finance it with increasing the deficit."
As late as 10 days before the election, Mr. Clinton was still promising a tax cut for families making less than $80,000. On Oct. 24, a reporter asked him if it was true, as advisers were saying, that he might postpone the middle-class tax cut for a year if elected, in the light of gloomy economic projections. "Absolutely not," Mr. Clinton said. "I make the economic decisions in this Administration."
 
The Critical Question
 The question of whether the difference between Mr. Clinton's campaign proposals and what he is now proposing is regarded by voters as "a threshold issue," as Mr. Begala put it, that Mr. Clinton must successfully answer to gain acceptance of his plan.
He is doing so successfully right now, Mr. Begala said, adding: "The research is clear on that. Now, to keep things going in the right direction, we have to have the debate focus on two points of view: One, 'I don't want to pay more in taxes because I don't want Bill Clinton's changes.' Or two, 'I am willing to pay more, but he better come through with real changes.' "
To this end, the campaign will play off voters' fears that the nation has reached a crisis point, which, unaddressed, could lead to disaster.
"What I'm trying to get people to focus on is the thought: If you don't do this now, think of what the country will look like in five years," Mr. Carville said.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: The Spending Cuts;
A Wide Swath, on Earth and in the Sky

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
President Clinton's economic plan proposes making $253 billion in spending cuts over four years by eliminating some programs and cutting back others, including a plan to scale back the $30 billion space station to eliminate cost overruns.
The plan he presented to Congress would also cut benefits for retirees, veterans and the poor by $91 billion over four years and impose or raise fees on many Government services. 
 As part of an effort to convince Americans who would pay higher taxes that his plan to reduce the deficit would be fair, $8.3 billion of the savings would be accomplished by freezing Federal workers' pay for one year and reducing future scheduled raises.
 
Earlier Presidents
 "I recommend that we make 150 specific budget cuts, as you know," Mr. Clinton said tonight. "And that all those who say we should cut more be as specific as I have been."
Mr. Clinton is not the first President to demonstrate his commitment to fiscal austerity by proposing pain for Federal workers. Two months before Election Day last year, President George Bush suggested cutting the pay of Federal officials earning more than $75,000 a year by 5 percent.
Mr. Clinton's plan would reduce military spending by $76 billion and non-military expenditures by $54 billion over four years, cutting a swath through a bewildering array of specified programs. They range from the elimination of special extension grants at the Department of Agriculture to freezing financing for the Appalachian Regional Commission.
 
Wool and Mohair
 One spending cut that would save $212 million in the Department of Agriculture would limit payments to farmers who provide wool and mohair. That subsidy, Administration officials said, was designed to protect the supply of materials for soldiers' uniforms and was carried out in World War I.
A review of the proposed cutbacks follows:
 
Agriculture
 The Administration proposes to save $374 million by reducing loan subsidies under the Rural Electrification Administration, which Mr. Clinton championed as Governor of Arkansas.
 
Commerce
 By eliminating trade adjustment assistance and terminating demonstration programs of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the department would save $250 million over four years.
 
Corps of Engineers
 Some $235 million would be saved by reducing construction financing for low-priority water projects.
 
Defense
 The Pentagon would cut $60 billion beyond what President George Bush had proposed through 1997, mainly by paring an additional 200,000 troops and greatly reducing spending on the Star Wars anti-missile defenses. An additional $18 billion in savings would be made through a pay freeze next year and smaller-than-expected salary increases through 1997.
 
Energy
 Money for the superconducting supercollider project would be stretched out over four years instead of being allocated immediately.
 
Environment
 The Administration proposes to save $4.1 billion by phasing out waste-water treatment grants that were to expire.
Health Care
 New limits would be placed on eligibility for benefits under Medicaid at a projected savings of $4.5 billion. User fees for the Federal Drug Administration would be increased, at a savings of about $1 billion over four years.
 
Housing
 The budget would cut $565 million in special-purpose grants by 1998. These pet projects have been derided as Congressional "pork barrel" spending and were also singled out during the Bush Administration. But Congress restored the cuts. Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros outlined cuts that would produce an annual savings of $1.5 billion over four years.
 
Justice
 Spending on prison construction would be reduced by $331 million.
 
Interior
 Low-priority water projects would be eliminated, saving $163 million.
Space Agency
 The space station would be restructured and stripped of much of the money that had been set aside for its development over the next four years. An Administration official said that the station was being redesigned to avoid cost overruns and that the savings had been redirected to other projects.
Transportation
 Low-priority projects would be eliminated at a savings of $1.3 billion, Coast Guard pay would be reduced, and fees would be increased on general-aviation aircraft and tonnage.
Veterans' Benefits
 Fees for housing loans, now free, would be set at 2 percent, and veterans would pay part of their G.I. Bill benefits, a policy change that would raise about $1 billion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Jack Brooks, top left, with Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, on the House floor as they awaited the arrival of President Clinton for his address last night. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Australia Campaign Takes an American Tone

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 17

 BODY:
When Prime Minister Paul Keating and John R. Hewson, his opponent in the national election on March 13, met for their first television debate last Sunday, Channel 9 viewers here were startled to see a squiggly white line inching across the screen as each candidate spoke.
Called "the electronic worm" by the press, the line was a graphic rendering of the audience's reaction to the debate. Each of the 128 audience members controlled a dial registering everything from total disapproval to complete agreement. 
 When Mr. Keating praised his and the Labor Party's record, for example, the worm crept downward on the screen. When he attacked Mr. Hewson and the Liberal Party, the line started up again. After a Kennedyesque peroration by Mr. Hewson about how "our limit should be the extent of our dreams," the worm soared. A dull bit about the 2000 Olympics sent it plunging again.
The instant-response gadget is used regularly by market researchers to test new products. It is not often used in politics in Australia, but then neither the Prime Minister nor Mr. Hewson are new products.
Mr. Keating has been Prime Minister since the end of 1991 when he ousted former Prime Minister Bob Hawke in a Labor Party coup.
In the 1980's Mr. Keating was Mr. Hawke's Treasury Minister. Under Mr. Keating, the economy has declined precipitously and unemployment climbed to a post-World War II high of 11.4 percent last November. Currently it is about 11.3 percent.
Mr. Hewson, a former economics professor, heads a right-of-center coalition that wants more decentralization and an unpopular goods and services tax. Mr. Keating, who now campaigns strenuously against the tax, proposed a similar levy when he headed the Treasury in the mid-1980's -- as Mr. Hewson delights in pointing out.
The electronic worm gave Mr. Keating a slight edge in the debate but opinion polls in the next few days gave Mr. Hewson the win. Mr. Keating appears to have learned that attacking his opponent garnered more points than advancing his own agenda. In recent appearances he's concentrated on slashing attacks on Mr. Hewson.
Recent Liberal victories in two states have done little to enhance Labor's image. Victoria ousted its Labor government last year; Western Australia did the same this month. Exit polls indicated that many voters in Western Australia had been influenced by the United States elections and had also decided it was time for a change after 10 years of Labor rule.
While the first debate gave neither candidate a significant advantage, it did manage to divert attention from several issues both sides could do without.
In the months before an election date was declared, prominent issues were Mr. Keating's shares in a pig farm and Mr. Hewson's exceptionally low taxes. Both turned out to be completely legal.
 
The Bike Accident
 Then there was the Speaker's bike accident. In 1990, Leo McLeay, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, fell off a bike he had borrowed from the Parliament gymnasium in the capital, Canberra. He suffered a broken arm and filed a claim for damages from the Government. In a brief time he received about $45,000 in compensation funds.
When the story broke recently, Mr. McLeay, a political crony of the Prime Minister, tried to face down his critics. But when he became the butt of cartoons and jokes, party leaders pressed him to resign, which he did last week.
Within what seemed like hours after the election date of March 13 was announced, the opposition coalition began broadcasting a television commercial showing unsuspecting citizens caught in the cross-hairs of a rifle telescope. The voice-over said many Australians were "looking down the barrel of unemployment," adding: "No one is safe. Labor must go."
Mr. Keating said the commercial recalled American campaign techniques. Mr. Hewson said: "People are scared stiff. We make absolutely no apologies."
