HEADLINE: Teaching the Hard Sell of Soap to Eastern Europe

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
Since Unilever N.V. purchased a laundry detergent factory in Poland for $20 million a year and a half ago, the plant's Pollena 2000 detergent has become a surprisingly strong seller for the British-Dutch consumer products company.
Riding the popularity of an advertising campaign developed months earlier by the plant's Polish managers, Pollena 2000 quickly made Unilever the market share leader in detergents here. Built around a bit of clever wordplay among characters from Polish popular literature, the campaign has become more ubiquitous in the popular culture than "Where's the beef?" ever was in the United States.
 
Easy Victories the Exception
 The brand's success shows the potential for rapidly increasing sales of consumer goods in the formerly Communist nations of Central and Eastern Europe. But such quick and easy victories are the exception for Unilever and the other Western companies that have invested hundreds of millions of dollars in the last two years in Poland, Hungary, the Czech republic and Slovakia, and that are edging into the poorer nations of the region including the former Soviet republics. 
 In setting up operations in countries that are undergoing the wrenching transformation to market economies, such companies have faced an array of problems, from outdated plants to a lack of trucks and warehouses for distribution to a local dearth of advertising expertise.
More fundamentally, they often find themselves faced with the daunting task of teaching local managers and workers not just more efficient production and marketing techniques, but the very basics of a free-market economy.
"We had to help develop the awareness that the marketplace decides what's good, not the state," said Hans Overgoor, who heads Unilever's operations in Poland.
Like its competitors from Western Europe and the United States, Unilever has spent heavily in Eastern Europe, more than $150 million so far, to buy and revamp state-owned factories and distribution systems and to begin introducing its own brands. In Hungary it has purchased an ice cream producer and taken an 80 percent stake in a large maker of soap, margarine and detergents. Last year in Czechoslovakia it bought the leading soap and margarine business. In Poland, in addition to the detergent company, it has acquired the largest margarine producer.
Although their executives say they are dedicated to making their operations respond to the needs of the market, Unilever and its competitors have sometimes found it difficult to determine just what consumers do want.
Market research is scarce, even on such basic questions as average income or the number of homes with washing machines. And consumers themselves sometimes seem overwhelmed by the new choices available and by the flood of advertising messages.
The Procter & Gamble Company saw sales of its Wash 'n' Go shampoo plummet for several months last year when it was unable to quash rumors in Poland that the product would cause hair to fall out. Gossip, long the antidote to official propaganda, is still sometimes given more credence than advertising.
In 1991, the Colgate-Palmolive Company came close to purchasing Caola, Hungary's state-owned producer of toothpaste, shampoo and other personal-care products, but pulled out at the last minute when it discovered that Caola's sales were falling precipitously under an onslaught of Western competition. The French food company BSN said some of the production equipment in plants it bought last year in Czechoslovakia was about as advanced as the machinery in France immediately after World War II.
"I wouldn't say it's third world," said Hajo Valk, the regional director for Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in Eastern and Central Europe. "It just takes a lot of ingenuity and a very flexible attitude from the people you have there, because a lot of things we take for granted in the West you can't take for granted there."
 
400 Million Consumers
 Unilever, as one of the first companies to make acquisitions in Eastern Europe and as one of the more aggressive marketers of Western brands in the region, has had its setbacks. But its executives say they are there to stay.
The region's population of 400 million, barely smaller than the 430 million in Western Europe, cannot be ignored, said Hans Eggerstedt, the director of the company's European operations. Average incomes in the region are approaching the levels of Portugal or Greece, he said, meaning that consumers increasingly have money to spend.
Finally, he said, residents of Eastern Europe, unlike those in Africa or Asia, share the same basic culture and attitudes of Western consumers, suggesting that the process of marketing products to them should proceed more smoothly.
"We must be able to succeed in doing business in Eastern Europe, which is so similar to Western Europe and in the end is in the heartland of our business," Mr. Eggerstedt said. "It is not only an opportunity for us. It is a must for us."
 
Keeping the Ice Cream Frozen
 Mr. Eggerstedt said Unilever's sales in Eastern Europe, now more than $375 million a year, should triple within five years, primarily through increased sales rather than from additional acquisitions.
But the company has already recognized the hurdles it will face along the way. When Unilever bought an ice cream company in what was then Czechoslovakia in 1991, it encountered one of the most common problems facing consumer products companies in Eastern Europe: the lack of a reliable distribution system to get its products into stores. Forced to rely on the old state-run system of trucking and storage, Unilever's ice cream often reached stores half-melted.
Unilever executives said they have subsequently had to spend much of their time and money setting up a system of wholesalers and transportation in all of the Eastern European countries.
Unilever got a similarly bad surprise when it examined the financial management of the detergents business in Poland. Although inflation in Poland was running at about 70 percent at the time, the factory's local managers, who had never worried much about the bottom line, were resetting prices only once or twice a year. Quickly, Unilever put in place a policy of reviewing prices at least four times a year.
 
Introducing Western Brands
 Over all, though, Unilever executives said they had been able to move steadily ahead with their primary strategy of squeezing the greatest possible sales from the stronger of the local brands they acquire, while modernizing and expanding local factories and regularly introducing their own brands.
In Poland, for example, the company reformulated Pollena 2000, using technology brought in from the West, to make it more powerful in removing stains. It invested in new equipment to eliminate production problems that often made the quality of the detergent vary from box to box.
Unilever is spending more than $24 million over five years to double the production capacity of the detergent factory and to add the capability to make liquid detergents. Mr. Overgoor said it had no plans to phase out Pollena 2000, but the company has been busy marketing one of its Western European detergent brands, Omo, as a more effective -- and more expensive -- alternative.
"Our main aim has been from the very beginning to establish a strong position for our international products and brands," Mr. Eggerstedt said.
 
Tailoring the Message
 Yet marketing consultants in Warsaw said Unilever might learn a lesson from the advertising for Pollena 2000 and Omo. The popularity and effectiveness of Pollena 2000's advertising, they said, shows the value of a campaign designed solely for the nation in which it appears. That is especially important when dealing with consumers whose brand loyalties are completely in flux and who have little experience sorting through a barrage of advertising messages.
The campaign centers on an imposing 17th-century Polish nobleman and his sons, known to almost all Poles from a series of popular books. In the first commercial, one of the sons spills wine on his clothes during a banquet. In the ensuing silence, the other son turns to the father and asks whether his brother should be beaten -- but he uses a word that can also mean cleaned. The father replies menacingly with the same word, and is then seen happily washing the stained clothes with Pollena 2000.
Omo, on the other hand, is advertised with a campaign adapted from Western Europe, and ends with women saying, "Thank you, Omo." While Mr. Overgoor said the commercials had been effective, Polish consumers widely mocked them, apparently unable to swallow the Western conceit that a grateful housewife would thank a laundry detergent.

HEADLINE: Mexico Pulls Out of Fund That Has Roiled Trade Issue

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Under sharp pressure from the United States, Mexican officials said today that the Government's main development bank would withdraw from a private investment fund set up to buy American companies and move them to Mexico to take advantage of lower wages.
The announcement came almost immediately after the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, told his Mexican counterpart that he would not begin new negotiations on the North American Free Trade Agreement until Mexico resolved the issue of its role in the fund. 
 "I indicated that it would not be productive to begin these talks until we addressed an issue that was potentially explosive," Mr. Kantor told reporters in Washington after his first meeting with Mexico's Foreign Trade Secretary, Jaime Serra Puche.
 Mr. Kantor said he had asked merely for "a clarification" of Mexico's participation in the fund. But he made it clear that when Mr. Serra telephoned him less than an hour after their meeting ended to tell him of the withdrawal, he got what he wanted. "He acted quickly and effectively," Mr. Kantor said, "and I was very impressed and pleased with the results."
Opponents of the trade agreement had seized on the little-known investment fund as hard evidence that Mexico intends to use its relatively cheap labor to steal American manufacturing jobs.
A prospectus for the fund, a limited partnership based in Delaware and called the AmeriMex Maquiladora Fund L.P., said it would try to raise as much as $50 million to buy between 9 and 13 small and medium-sized American companies to be moved to Mexico.
The Governments of Mexico, Canada and the United States concede that the trade accord will not only remove tariff barriers but encourage manufacturers to move their operations where they can produce more efficiently. Yet all three have sought to play down the prospects for such movement because the opposition of American and Canadian labor groups concerned about job losses could threaten the agreement's ratification.
 Mr. Serra and Mr. Kantor met today precisely to begin discussing what measures their countries could take to ameliorate any job losses the accord might cause, or environmental damage that might result from the movement of American companies seeking looser pollution laws in Mexico. President Clinton supports the pact, but has said he would not endorse it until further agreements are negotiated to safeguard the American environment and work force.
Just what Mexico, Canada and the United States may agree to along those lines remains unclear, particularly to the Mexican Government.
For instance, although it is expected that at least the United States and Mexico would commit to greater public spending and stricter standards for labor and environmental protection, it is doubtful that any of the countries would accept an independent, supranational body to enforce those standards. Mexico and the United States are also expected to discuss some sort of accord on sugar imports that would complement the broader agreement.
The question of enforcement aside, Mr. Serra's hurried response to Mr. Kantor this morning suggested that Mexico might make significant concessions to insure the trade agreement's approval by the United States Congress. Its ratification in by the Mexican Senate is assured, because the legislature is dominated by the ruling party.
 
Seeking to Avoid Delays
 As negotiated, the agreement is to take effect on Jan. 1, 1994. Mexican officials are eager to see it through the Congress before the August recess, fearing that any further delays could make its ultimate ratification more difficult and jeopardize the flow of needed investments into Mexico.
After hearing from Mr. Serra, Mr. Kantor announced today that Mexican, Canadian and American officials would meet March 15 in Washington to begin discussing the parallel agreements.
The Mexican trade secretary, meanwhile, disputed that the AmeriMex fund was established to move companies from the United States to Mexico. But the fund's prospectus states that it will buy established United States companies "wherein a portion or all of the manufacturing will be relocated to Mexico to take advantage of savings in the cost of labor."
Mr. Serra also described the fund as "very, very small" and the role in it of Mexico's largest development bank, Nacional Financiera , as "very limited." However, other Mexican officials acknowledged that the $3.75 million invested by the bank represented 25 percent of the fund's capital and probably was the largest single stake of its 14 partners.
 
 
Mexican Official Is Partner
 And while the bank, known as Nafin, technically cannot control the fund's investments, it appeared likely that it would be able to influence them through a Mexican official who is one of the fund's two general partners. The official, Adolfo Peniche Perez, is Finance Secretary for the ruling-party Government in Mexico's southeastern state of Yucatan.
In an interview this afternoon, the president of Nafin, Oscar Espinosa Villareal, said the bank had always intended its role in the fund to be temporary and was already in the process of divesting. He noted that the bank, which has assets of about $22 billion, was involved in many operations that aimed to capitalize on the two countries' growing economic integration.
"Basically we thought about the return," he said of Nafin's decision to invest in the fund, which was made before he assumed control. "There was never a political criteria involved in deciding whether or not to invest."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Cummins Engine is tuned up for a boom in the truck market.

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
ANALYSTS say the Cummins Engine Company is humming on all cylinders. After several years of heavy spending on new products, the diesel engine maker, based in Columbus, Ind., has halted the erosion of its market share in the heavy-duty truck business and sharply increased its share of the pickup truck sector.
Last Friday's encouraging fourth-quarter earnings report signaled a long-awaited return to healthy profitability. And Monday's announcement of a long-range partnership with Komatsu Ltd. of Japan underscored the global leverage Cummins has acquired through its investment in emission-control technology for its new engines. 
 "You have to give management credit for resurrecting this company," said Eli Lustgarten, who follows Cummins and other capital equipment companies for Paine Webber.
In fact, investors have given Cummins a lot of credit during the last two years. Cummins stock, which dipped under $32 in late 1990, rose as high as $86 early this month. The shares have since slipped, on fears of higher fuel taxes. Yesterday, they closed at $80.75, down $2 each, on the New York Stock Exchange. The record high of $94.75 was set in 1987.
The consensus is that earnings will jump sharply this year and next. The highly cyclical North American heavy-duty truck market, Cummins's largest source of business, is enjoying its biggest boom in years with new production rising 35 percent last year and another double-digit increase expected in 1993. In addition, Ford last year joined Chrysler as a major customer for Cummins's diesel pickup truck engines. The company also sells engines for the marine, construction and utility markets, all of which are expected to grow.
At the same time, Cummins's severe cost-cutting measures of the late 1980's and early 1990's have raised profit margins. Last year also saw a sharp drop in warranty payments, which had swollen during the late 1980's when the company rushed a poorly designed product to market.
The only thing that kept Cummins from reporting a profit for full-year 1992 last week, after five losses in six years, was a one-time charge of more than $251 million to cover changes in the way it accounts for retiree health-care costs.
The debate now concerns how high Cummins's earnings will leap and how much of the jump will reflect operations, as opposed to tax benefits built up during money-losing years. Skeptics like Mr. Lustgarten see earnings of between $9 and $10 a share in 1994, including up to $2 in tax benefits. Optimists like Larry D. Hollis, who follows the company for Robert W. Baird in Milwaukee, say earnings could near $12 in 1994.
Cummins's current stock price fully anticipates the pace of the earnings growth that Mr. Lustgarten is forecasting. Mr. Lustgarten is thus among those who are neutral on the stock, expecting it to do no better than match the market. But a performance like that projected by Mr. Baird could well push Cummins shares past the $100 level. Mr. Baird last week joined those recommending that investors with a moderate to long-term perspective buy Cummins shares.
Most analysts are concerned about what impact, if any, President Clinton's economic proposals will have on the length and strength of the recovery. The trucking industry has traditionally been one of the first sectors to grow during a recovery. The longer and stronger the early stages of the recovery, the more appealing the stocks of truck makers and their suppliers remain to investors who usually switch funds to other, later-blooming sectors as the recovery matures.

HEADLINE: NORFOLK JOURNAL;
Struggling Town Pins Hopes on Theater Revival

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORFOLK, Conn.

 BODY:
WHEN the Apple House grocery here closed last spring, a once distinctive stretch of Route 44 suddenly looked seedy. And in a town that could give lessons on how to be the quintessential New England village, seedy just doesn't fit.
People here now say they should have seen it coming as more and more buildings in the town's small commercial center were abandoned. 
 But for years the unused structures were easily overlooked in favor of their historic neighbors, particularly the 1904 Royal Arcanum Building, up the street, and at the green, the Battell-Stoeckel estate that the Yale Summer School of Music calls home.
It wasn't until the Apple House closed that the sights sank in. And now, a group of residents is hoping to turn things around by reviving a long-abandoned theater, known as the Opera House, on the second floor of the building where the Apple House operated.
"I think we've had trouble envisioning the impact the closing of the Apple House would have on the town," said Hank Tremblay, a selectman and owner of Manor House Bed and Breakfast Inn. "Things just weren't the same anymore."
His wife, Diane, vice president of the Merchants Association, agrees. "When times were good, people just didn't have time to care if the center was functioning. Once people realized that the town couldn't even support a grocery store, they started thinking."
Many merchants want to see Norfolk become a retail center, siphoning traffic off Route 44 to a shopping complex complete with stores, restaurants and connecting walkways. Not only would their own businesses benefit, but jobs would be created and the empty buildings put to good use.
There are those, however, who would prefer that Norfolk remain the sleepy community it has always been, where weekenders come to relax and day trippers to hear classical concerts on warm summer nights.
"There's something about living nowhere," said Rosemary Gill, a local artist. "I feel like this is Brigadoon. I'd just as soon see it have a tiny drugstore and nothing else."
Ms. Gill's father, the New Yorker writer Brendan Gill, is passionate about retaining the town's architectural integrity and small-town feel, but is sensitive to its economic realities, too.
In the 1860's, he said, Norfolk was already known as a summer resort.
"Today, 135 years later, it is still successful as a place for people who want a picturesque village," he added, but small towns like Norfolk "are finding it increasingly difficult to find a successful economic basis of their own."
"Most have to depend on a tourist economy," he said.
Mr. Tremblay says no one wants to turn Norfolk into the Northwest Corner's equivalent of Nantucket or Martha's Vineyard, but a retail center would improve the town's economy and appearance.
"We're not looking to create a tourist attraction," he said. "Hopefully, it will just mean people being able to come here and spend time downtown."
The difference between hoping and doing, however, is vast. Starling Childs, an owner of the Brick Block, a housing complex destroyed by fire in 1986, says that six years ago he proposed virtually the same retail plan that merchants are contemplating now. The problem, he said, is that no one seems to be able to agree on what the town needs.
"Basically, we have a dysfunctional town," said Mr. Childs. "Do you detect a note of bitterness? There are people going around saying the Brick Block is a diamond in the rough, but no one's willing to put any money into it. The trick is, someone has to come in and buy the whole town."
At least one solution may come from the Connecticut Theater Arts Consortium, a year-old group that is raising money to buy the Village Hall, where the Apple House and the Opera House reside. Its plan is to turn the Opera House into a cultural center and open the first floor to retailers.
The 1883 theater looks almost as it did the day it closed in 1940. Handpainted canvas backdrops still hang above the stage, weighted by old ropes and sandbags. The red and green trim, the ornate wooden molding and overhead beams are pristine.
In the dressing rooms, visiting acts chronicled their appearances in pen on the walls: "H. Mack, the Singing Comedian," "Baum Bros., Comedians-Vaudeville," "Jerry Leroy and Adams George, Comedy-Acrobats." Dates are scrawled throughout: 1907, 1922, 1931, 1915.
"This is for the town," Mr. Tremblay said. "The thrust of those interested is not in turning us into a Lenox or a Stockbridge. I think we're gearing toward a resident center instead of a tourist center. I think it just means having things to do."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Eichner, a real-estate agent, in the 1883 theater called the Norfolk Opera House. The Connecticut village hopes to convert it into a cultural center and turn the Apple House into space for retailers. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Does raising the minimum wage in fact mean fewer jobs?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
ROBERT B. REICH, the new Secretary of Labor, says he will use his considerable muscle to lever an increase in the $4.25-an-hour minimum wage. And to organized labor's friends celebrating the Democratic victory at the polls, the declaration was a welcome call to arms: "The idea of anything less than $5 makes no sense," declared Representative William D. Ford, chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee. "I don't know of any part of this country where anybody could subsist on less."
But to many economists, including many liberal ones, the minimum wage is one can of worms they would just as soon not crack. For while all agree that $4.25 an hour does not buy a piece of the American dream, there is no longer a consensus on the likely impact of a higher minimum on either jobs or poverty. 
 The reassuring "new view" that the employment effects are, in fact, trivial is being challenged by the "new, new view," which is much like the old: The price of higher-paying jobs may well be fewer jobs or stingier fringe benefits.
According to the textbooks, the minimum wage cuts both ways. A higher minimum does indeed mean higher incomes for low-wage workers who are employed. But over the decades, myriad studies have confirmed that employers respond to wage regulation by cutting their payrolls; most put the damage at roughly a 1 percent loss in jobs for a 10 percent increase in the minimum.
The difficulty of this choice was underlined by Ed Gramlich of the University of Michigan. Many minimum-wage workers, he discovered, were the dependent children of the middle class. Thus, much of the gain from a higher minimum would go into surfboards and stereos -- not into rent and baby formula. It is far better, then, mainstream economists concluded, to increase the living standards of the working poor with tax breaks or to improve their earning power with training.
But this near-consensus has broken down. For one thing, today's opponents of the minimum wage do not have much to offer the food stamp generation. There is little public support in the deficit-ridden 1990's for an expensive attack on poverty. And while President Clinton will no doubt shoehorn some cash for education and apprenticeship programs into the budget, Mr. Reich is the first to acknowledge that it will take a decade to see much sign of progress.
For another, there have been a handful of intriguing studies -- two by David Card of Princeton University and one by Lawrence Katz of Harvard and Alan Kreuger of Princeton -- suggesting that the 27 percent increase in the Federal minimum wage in 1990-91 had virtually no effect on jobs. And these studies will probably weigh heavily on Administration thinking: Mr. Katz is now the chief economist for the Labor Department.
If the Card-Katz-Kreuger analyses were as widely accepted outside the Clinton Administration as in, everyone could relax. At very worst, patrons of Taco Bell would end up paying an extra dime for their chicken fajitas so that the nice college kids behind the counter could spend spring break in Fort Lauderdale.
No such luck. The Employment Policies Institute, a Washington organization financed by big retailers who oppose the minimum wage, is publicizing a critique by David Neumark of the University of Pennsylvania and William Wascher of the Federal Reserve Board. Their findings support the once-universal academic view that the minimum has modest but noticeable effects on employment.
So, too, does a freshly minted study of California labor by Lowell Taylor and Taeil Kim of Carnegie Mellon University that used more detailed -- and arguably more accurate -- data than the New View analyses.
"The evidence just doesn't give me confidence in Card's results," concludes James Heckman of the University of Chicago.
Daniel Hamermesh, an economist at Michigan State University and a veteran of the minimum wage wars, thinks, in the end, the issue is a diversion from the nuts-and-bolts problems of creating a more productive work force. Hardly any professional economist, he suggests, would willingly take the risk of a very large increase in the minimum -- say to $6 or $7 -- that might cut a wide swath of unemployment through the unskilled labor force. But by the same token, he argues, the sort of modest increase that could be pushed through Congress would not make a big difference in employment or poverty.
Mr. Hamermesh's compromise of choice: Throw organized labor a bone in the form of a token increase, and then index the minimum to average wages so the issue will not soon again absorb the energies of policy makers.
That, in fact, may be what Secretary Reich has in mind. He has hinted at a $4.70 minimum -- a dollar less than the unions want and a small enough sum to have a minimal impact on average labor costs.

HEADLINE: Building of New Homes Dropped 7.2% in January

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Construction of new homes fell 7.2 percent in January, the Government said today. Analysts attributed the drop to bad weather and an unsustainable increase in December.
If bad weather is not a factor this month, the analysts added, housing starts should turn up, helped by favorable mortgage rates and a gradually improving economy. 
 "The economy is growing more strongly, interest rates remain low and consumer confidence continues to be high," said David Berson, an economist at the Federal National Mortgage Association. "All that will translate into more starts."
 
Biggest Drop Since April
 The Commerce Department reported that housing starts in January were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.19 million, the lowest level since last July, when new construction dipped to a rate of 1.11 million. Last month's decline was the largest since starts fell 16.9 percent in April.
Starts were down sharply in the Northeast and West and also fell in the Midwest. They rose in the South.
"Hopefully, this starts number was an aberration," said David Lereah, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association. "Our projection is well over 1.3 million for 1993. But it's not a good way to start the new year."
Analysts noted that starts had jumped 4.8 percent in December, to a annual rate of 1.29 million, and ended the year 18.4 percent above 1991. But they said growth this year would only be about 9 percent, and that the 4.8 percent advance in December overstated the industry's strength.
Sales of both new and previously owned homes rose in December, reducing inventories and providing incentives for further building.
At the same time, mortgage rates were at a 20-year low, and the Mortgage Bankers Association said loan applications, a leading indicator of sales, had remained strong.
 
Permit Applications Slip
 Applications for building permits, often a barometer of future activity, edged down 1.7 percent, to a rate of 1.18 million rate.
"This decline in permits would not suggest as drastic a decline in starts as 7.2 percent," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in New York. "We expect a bounce-back in starts in upcoming data."
New construction of single-family homes was off 5.6 percent, to a 1.07 million rate, the first decline in six months. Starts of single-family homes rose 4 percent a month earlier.
But starts of multifamily homes, which are overbuilt in many regions, fell even more, to a 122,000 rate, or 19.7 percent. Construction of larger apartment buildings -- five units or more -- dropped 21.7 percent, to a 94,000 rate, the lowest on record. The previous low was 98,000 in December 1991.

HEADLINE: Dinkins's Word to Tokyo: Don't Leave New York

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
In an effort to maintain Japanese investment while steering more business to New York City, Mayor David N. Dinkins leaves tomorrow for an eight-day visit to Japan in a trip that will test the Mayor's salesmanship in meetings with business executives and public officials.
In the last year, the Mayor has been increasingly urged by business leaders and his deputies, particularly Barry F. Sullivan, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, to appeal directly to foreign business leaders. Last June, the Mayor took a weeklong trip to Britain, France and Germany. 
 Some officials contend that the Mayor's trip is intended to smooth relations with Japanese leaders, who reportedly felt slighted by Mr. Dinkins's abrupt decision to cancel a trip to Japan during the Persian Gulf war in 1991. He was scheduled to go there for the dedication of a municipal government building in Tokyo and instead sent Sally Hernandez-Pinero, who was then the deputy mayor for finance and economic development.
Mr. Sullivan, who had been a senior executive at the First Chicago Corporation before going to City Hall last year, will accompany the Mayor, along with about a dozen New York business executives.
 
Most Pay Their Own Way
 The delegation will be headed by Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York City Partnership/New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, a group of business leaders. The Partnership will cover the travel expenses of Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Sullivan and two members of the Mayor's staff. Other executives will pay their own expenses, Mr. Shelp said.
Among the executives going on the trip will be Robert B. Catell, president and chief executive of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company; James S. Gordon, chairman of Burson-Marsteller; James A. Harmon, president and chief executive of Wertheim Schroder & Company; Caroline Jones, president and chief executive of Caroline Jones Advertising, and Clarence O. Smith, president of Essence Communications Inc.
In a difference from the European trip, the Mayor will be less involved in pursuing new investment than in urging Japanese companies to retain their existing operations in New York, Mr. Shelp said. The current recession in Japan has caused concern among New York executives and City Hall that some Japanese companies will pare down or close their New York operations.
Japanese companies in New York have become an increasingly important part of the city's economy. Of the nearly 5,000 foreign-based companies with operations in New York, Japanese operations account for nearly a quarter, according to the New York City Partnership/Chamber.
 
Seminars on New York
 Mr. Dinkins, who will stay mostly in Tokyo, will hold seminars for financial service and communications concerns and real-estate firms on the merits of operating in New York City.
On Tuesday, the Mayor will give a keynote address at the Keidanren's Council for Better Corporate Citizenship in Tokyo, the premier business forum in Japan. The next day, he will address the American Chamber of Commerce, the major group of American business leaders in Tokyo.
"The trip to Europe had a quicker payoff when you consider the fact that we are now having meetings with 26 European operations considering operating in New York," Mr. Shelp said. "We hope this will lead to investment and expansion, but we think it will be over a longer period."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS - ADVERTISING;
Michael Jackson's revival may not win him any new endorsements.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
HE'S famous, but infamous, too. He's dangerous, but perhaps not as much as before. He's bad, but he's not evil. And while he's not the thriller he used to be, his ratings have been a killer.
The celebrity in question is Michael Jackson, who has recently embarked on a series of public performances and appearances after years of reclusive behavior. Entertainment industry executives have attributed the singer's about-face to a desire to bolster his image in the wake of what are considered disappointing American sales for his latest album, "Dangerous" -- the first fruits of his much-heralded $65 million contract with Sony -- as well as to draw attention to Heal the World, his charitable foundation. 
 For some time, advertisers have shied from associations with Mr. Jackson, believing that consumers had lost interest in him since the peak of his popularity in the mid-1980's, when his "Thriller" became the world's all-time best-selling album. They also feared that his unusual behavior, from wearing surgical masks to befriending a chimpanzee named Bubbles, would diminish the value of his endorsements.
"The feeling was that the weirdness turned off Middle America," said Marty Blackman, president at Blackman & Raber, an entertainment and sports consulting and talent company in New York. "They thought he was O.K. along the West Coast and the East Coast, but in between, he was just a little too extreme."
But Mr. Jackson's recent forays into the spotlight have attracted enormous audiences nationwide. His live 90-minute interview with Oprah Winfrey on Feb. 10, for instance, was the fourth-most-watched entertainment program in television history. A report this week in Inside Media estimated that advertisers paid $160,000 to $270,000 per 30-second spot, which meant they enjoyed ratings approaching Super Bowl levels at prices a fifth to a third of what it cost to buy commercial time during Super Bowl XXVII.
Not that Super Bowl advertisers had much to complain about, thanks to Mr. Jackson. Dick Ebersol, president at NBC Sports, said the singer's performance at the halftime show on Jan. 31 was "a significant factor" in retaining viewers through the second half of the lopsided contest, which became the most-watched television program ever.
Experts like Mr. Blackman say that the attractiveness of Mr. Jackson to advertisers has been enhanced by his burst of activity, because it is serving to rehabilitate his reputation. In particular, they pointed to his statement that a skin disorder called vitiligo caused his changing skin color, which, they said, could effectively counter criticism that he had intentionally lightened his skin.
"Positive press is always good," said Noreen S. Jenney, president at Celebrity Endorsement Network in Woodland Hills, Calif., which represents advertisers in securing celebrity endorsements.
"And so is the lack of negative press," she added.
Still, even though during the Winfrey interview, Elizabeth Taylor popped in to praise Mr. Jackson as "the least weird man I've ever known," the endorsement experts doubt whether Mr. Jackson could suddenly become another Michael Jordan, who has amassed a list of endorsements as long as he is tall.
A primary reason, according to Ms. Jenney, is Mr. Jackson's timing: his publicity blitz coincides with a weak economy.
"I'm finding that in this climate, advertisers are looking for ways to accomplish their goals without blowing their whole budgets on celebrity talent," she said. That puts stars like Mr. Jackson, whose past fees have ranged as high as $7.5 million to $10 million, at a serious disadvantage.
And he is also handicapped, she added, by a perception that "those advertisers who went with him for major dollars haven't gotten out of it what they hoped." She cited a $10 million breach-of-contract suit filed against him last September by L.A. Gear Inc., which suffered an embarrassing failure with a line of buckle-bedecked Michael Jackson shoes. (Mr. Jackson filed a $44 million countersuit.)
Mr. Jackson's one current significant marketer relationship is with the Pepsi-Cola International division of the Pepsi-Cola Company, which signed him last February to an 18-month sponsorship agreement -- not including the American market -- pegged to his worldwide concert tour in support of "Dangerous."
The company "looked into the possibility" of buying time during Super Bowl XXVII to expose Mr. Jackson's latest Pepsi International commercial to American viewers, said Andrew Giangola, a company spokesman. When that did not prove feasible, he added, the spot was run during telecasts of the game in more than a dozen foreign countries.
"As hot as Michael Jackson is," Mr. Giangola continued, "and as much attention as is focused on" the so-called King of Pop, Pepsi-Cola, which ran commercials featuring him in this country during the 1980's, is not considering a permanent return engagement. The reason, the spokesman explained, was that the company believes "he is synonymous with the 'Choice of a New Generation' campaign, which continues to be our tagline overseas. He has never been part of 'Gotta Have It,' " Pepsi-Cola's current American campaign.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Jackson performs in a current commercial as the tagline for Pepsi-Cola's overseas 'Choice of a New Generation' campaign. (Pepsi-Cola Company)

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Hewlett Net Surpasses Forecasts

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17

 BODY:
The Hewlett-Packard Company surprised Wall Street today by reporting profits, revenues and orders all in excess of analysts' estimates.
The news lifted Hewlett-Packard shares, which closed at $72.25, up $4.675, today on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Earnings were $261 million, or $1.03 a share, 10 to 15 cents a share higher than analysts expected. In last year's first quarter, Hewlett-Packard would have earned $302 million, but reported a loss of $30 million because of an after-tax charge to cover a change in accounting for employees' post-retirement health benefits.
Profit margins have come under pressure from the company's shift to lower-margin items, like printers, personal computers and work stations. But Robert Herwick, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist, said Hewlett-Packard's orders were surprisingly strong, particularly internationally, where weak economies had caused some concern.
"They've built up a lot of international backlog unintentionally," he said, which will translate into sales in the second quarter, ending in April. In addition, a work force reduction of 1,200 employees during the first quarter will result in lower costs and higher profit margins in the second quarter, he said.
 
Revenue Up 18%
 For the three months that ended Jan. 31, Hewlett-Packard had revenue of $4.57 billion, up 18.4 percent from $3.86 billion a year earlier.
Hewlett-Packard's results were strong compared with the performance of the International Business Machines Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation, the only larger computer manufacturers in the nation. Both those companies are mired in losses and only partway through painful restructurings.
Analysts said one part of Hewlett-Packard's successful strategy was early adoption of open systems, a computer approach based on published software standards and the availability of hardware from multiple sources.
 
Record Orders
 "We're extremely pleased with our growth in orders, which was well balanced by business and geography," Lewis E. Platt, Hewlett-Packard's president and chief executive, said in a statement.
Hewlett-Packard said orders for the quarter were a record $5.2 billion, compared with $4.2 billion in the first quarter of 1992. Orders in the United States totaled $2.1 billion, up 18 percent from a year earlier, while orders from outside the country grew by 28 percent, to $3.1 billion.
"The year is off to a good start," Mr. Platt said. "Our challenge is to turn strong order growth into higher profitability. We're cautious, however, because continuing order growth depends in part on worldwide economic conditions, which still show signs of weakness in key geographies."
Noting that sales from Hewlett-Packard's computer business alone were up 27 percent from a year earlier, Mr. Herwick of Hambrecht & Quist added, "Not only is this a big and profitable computer company, but it is growing."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Prices for Wheat Advance On New Hope for Exports

BYLINE: By ReutersReuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Wheat prices jumped today on signs of a revival in exports, but trading in many other commodities was cautious ahead of President Clinton's speech tonight on the details of his plan for the economy.
Meanwhile, oil prices sank for the second consecutive day amid skepticism over OPEC's ability to maintain the discipline to hold to its new quotas. 
 In the wheat pit at the Chicago Board of Trade, traders said the market was ready for a rebound. "We were heavily oversold, and finally we've seen some business, which has been nonexistent for a long time," one analyst said.
Corn and soybean prices edged up slightly, as conflicting forces kept futures on those commodities from establishing a trend in either direction.
March corn rose 1/2 cent, to $2.12 1/2 a bushel, and March soybeans added 2 1/4 cents, to $5.73 1/4 a bushel.
President Clinton's proposals to increase corporate and individual taxes have hit the equity and commodity markets, including the sensitive soybean market.
At the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, lumber prices soared to yet another new high, while livestock futures were mixed.
 
Energy Prices
 Oil prices declined in light of the shaky agreement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to cut production by a million barrels a day starting on March 1.
"As far as the fundamentals are concerned, the agreement is good," said Cyrus Tahmassebi, chief economist at Ashland Oil, referring to OPEC's new ceiling of 23.6 million barrels a day. "But certainly a credibility gap is there."
But trading was cautious ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's data on domestic inventories, along with President Clinton's speech, which was expected to include some form of energy tax.
"Don't expect President Clinton's speech to have any market impact, barring big surprises," said one trader in Houston. "A general energy consumption tax should have no short-term market effect."
Crude oil for delivery in March fell 20 cents, to $19.33 a barrel; March heating oil lost 0.51 cent, to 54.63 cents a gallon, and March unleaded gasoline dropped 0.21 cent, to 52.07 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off Again on Worry Over Clinton Economy Plan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly lower on world markets yesterday, hurt for the second consecutive day by concerns over President Clinton's economic package.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $331.00 a troy ounce, off $2 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold lost $1.90 an ounce to a late bid price of $330.10. 
 Dealers sold the dollar overnight in Europe, and the selling continued in spurts when trading shifted to domestic markets. "It's been the worst two days of the year," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the advisory firm IDEA.
In the last two sessions, the dollar has fallen nearly 4 pfennigs against the German mark and neared post-war lows against the Japanese yen.
"The market is responding to the prospects of a slower economy and a heavier tax burden," Mr. Chandler said, referring to Mr. Clinton's plan.
Higher taxes will siphon off money from consumers and businesses alike, stemming economic growth, dealers fear.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 119.25 yen, down 1.37 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at a higher rate of 119.43 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 119.65 yen, down from 119.93 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.4435, from $1.4475 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.4455 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.4495.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6250 German marks, down from 1.6285; 1.4990 Swiss francs, down from 1.5040; 5.5025 French francs, down from 5.5165; 1,542.00 Italian lire, up from 1,541.00, and 1.2636 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2583.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6285 German marks, down from 1.6315; 1.5050 Swiss francs, down from 1.5065; 5.5165 French francs, down from 5.5285; 1.8335 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8370; 1,546.00 Italian lire, up from 1,540.00, and 1.2613 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2566.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $330.30 a troy ounce, from $331.65 bid late Tuesday. But in Zurich, it rose to a late bid of $330.30 from $329.95. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.27 to close at $331.75 an ounce.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Average Money Fund Yield Was Flat in Latest Week

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The average yields on money market funds were little changed in the latest reporting week, reflecting the policies of the Federal Reserve Board, analysts said yesterday.
"What we're seeing is the stability of the Federal Reserve policy of holding interest rates where they are now," said Walter S. Frank, the chief economist at The Money Fund Report, a research publication that tracks money market funds. 
 With rates stabilized, Mr. Frank said he doubted that the Fed would change course and raise interest rates, which would put a drag on the economy.
President Clinton's program to cut the deficit by raising taxes, he said, will create some slowdown in the economy. "You can't imagine the Fed coming over and creating additional drag by raising interest rates," he added.
According to The Money Fund Report, the average seven-day simple yield on taxable money market funds fell 2 basis points, or hundredths of percentage points, to 2.71 percent in the latest reporting week. The average compounded seven-day yield was down a basis point, to 2.75 percent.
The publication said the average 30-day simple yield fell a basis point, to 2.74 percent, while the average 30-day compounded yield was also down a basis point, to 2.78 percent.
The average days to maturity for securities held by taxable funds was unchanged at 61 days. Total assets in taxable money market funds dropped by $9.8 billion, to $477.8 billion.
 
Top Funds
 The top-yielding taxable general-purpose fund was the Olde Premium Money Market, with a seven-day yield of 3.57 percent. The fund is distributed by the Olde Discount Corporation of Detroit.
Another top-yielding fund was United Services Government Securities Savings, which invests only in Government securities and had a seven-day compounded yield of 3.62 percent. It is distributed by United Services Advisors Inc. of San Antonio.
For tax-exempt funds, the average simple seven-day yield was down 6 basis points, to 1.92 percent, and the compounded yield was also down 6 basis points, to 1.94 percent. The average 30-day simple yield was up 4 basis points, to 1.94 percent, and the 30-day compounded yield was also up 4 basis points, to 1.96 percent.
The average days to maturity in tax-exempt funds was 53 days, unchanged. Assets of tax-exempt money market funds increased by $365 million, to $102.5 billion.
The top-yielding tax-exempt fund was the Evergreen Tax Exempt Money Market Fund, with a rate of 2.66 percent, down 5 basis points from the pervious week. The fund is distributed by Evergreen Asset Management of Purchase, N.Y.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Owners Link Salaries To Revenue Sharing

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Major league club owners took what they viewed as a major step today toward forging a new economic relationship with the players. The owners' action, though, didn't prompt the players' union chief to run outside his Manhattan office and do cartwheels down Third Avenue.
The owners, meeting for the sixth time in less than six months, established in a unanimous vote a "linkage" between revenue sharing on their part and a salary cap on the players' part. 
 "We're saying today there is linkage between these two things," Bud Selig of the Milwaukee Brewers, chairman of the major league executive council, said at a news briefing. "It's often been said by the Players Association, let them solve their own problems first. Let them go to revenue sharing. The clubs took a step today to acknowledge there is a direct linkage."
 
Fehr Is Unconvinced
 Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, reacted skeptically to the owners' action.
"Just because they said so doesn't make it so," Fehr said by telephone from his office in New York. "Maybe one day they'll explain to us what the linkage is. I'm glad they did it; I'm sure they got an enhanced feeling of solidarity. I hope they feel better. But the real linkage is the big-market owners won't share with small-market owners unless the players give them back the money. That's the only linkage we've heard about."
The vote came during a presentation to the owners by Richard Ravitch, their chief labor executive, who has been lobbying among them in recent months for a plan under which the 28 clubs would share more of their revenue than they do now.
Ravitch has emphasized that the players will not accept a salary cap without increased revenue sharing among the clubs. The owners want the players to accept a percentage of their revenue for their salaries; they call it revenue participation, but in reality it creates a salary cap.
Clubs currently share national television revenue equally, and they receive minor shares of local cable revenue and home gate receipts. But small-market clubs say it has become increasingly difficult for them to compete fairly with large-market clubs because of the great disparity in local television and radio revenue, as well as gate receipts.
Large-market clubs, in the past, have opposed such sharing, but the views of some apparently are changing. For example, Peter O'Malley of the Los Angeles Dodgers long had vigorously opposed other clubs dipping into the Dodgers' lucrative local revenues, but he recently has indicated a willingness to share at least some portion of that money.
A major league official said that even George Steinbrenner of the Yankees, an ardent opponent of greater revenue sharing, has said he would be willing to explore the idea. The Mets, however, are said to remain adamantly opposed to a new sharing plan.
Ravitch has not proposed a specific revenue-sharing plan. When he does, the unanimous vote that occurred today may not be so unanimous. Clubs might be willing to accept the philosophy of the idea but balk at the reality when they see the percentages Ravitch has in mind. Moreover, if the players reject a salary cap, the owners' revenue-sharing intentions most likely would evaporate.
Ravitch left immediately after the meeting and was not present at Selig's news briefing.
"We don't have a specific plan," said Selig, a major proponent of the idea. "But I'd say it's more than philosophical. While you don't come to a specific result, you come to a practical conclusion of establishing the linkage that 28 clubs acknowledge exists. There is a definite relationship between the two. One can't exist without the other. The clubs now start with an economic premise. You can't get one without the other."
The players, however, have always balked at the implementation of a salary cap. They say they have to be shown the current system isn't working before they would consider a new system.
 
Reports Is Finished
 Among other matters, Selig said the long-awaited report from the restructuring committee, which will define the commissioner's role and authority, has been completed. He said it will be sent to him in a day or two.
Selig said the committee studying possible realignment of the leagues should have its report completed either by the next meetings March 3-4 or the meetings, as yet unscheduled, after that.
The committee designated to search for a new commissioner met for the first time today. Some owners want the committee to wait until baseball's other major matters -- a new labor agreement, new television contracts and realignment of the leagues and playoffs -- are resolved before selecting a commissioner.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Welfare Compromise for Auto Makers

 BODY:
Trucks carry cargo. Cars carry passengers. The distinction is obvious to everyone -- except Detroit auto makers. They're pressuring the Clinton Administration to reclassify Japanese minivans and sports utility vehicles as trucks.
The Big Three aren't confused, just greedy. Once minivans are mislabeled as trucks, tariffs would automatically rise from 2.5 percent to a whopping 25 percent. 
 The tariff hike would drive Japanese minivans out of the U.S. market and provide cover for the Big Three to jack up minivan prices by $1,500 or more -- a blow to the middle-class families President Clinton swore to protect.
If that's not bad enough, there are two other reasons to oppose the tariff hike. It would not create many jobs for auto workers. Detroit already controls over 90 percent of the minivan market and thus wouldn't reap many additional sales as the Japanese drop out, especially if minivan prices soar. And reclassification would likely be ruled in violation of international trade rules, leading to Japanese retaliation against U.S. exports.
Three strikes, but Mr. Clinton will probably grant Detroit's wish anyway. He promised as much during the Presidential election campaign. To woo Michigan voters he attacked the Bush Administration's decision to keep minivans classified as cars. Coming off his economic speech, in which he proposed tax hikes on the middle class, the President is unlikely to renege on another campaign pledge.
But there's a middle ground, proposed by Representative Charles Schumer of New York. He calls on Mr. Clinton to tie reclassification to a pledge by the Big Three that they will not increase minivan prices faster than inflation. Should they try, the tariff would come tumbling back down.
The pledge would provide a measure of protection for consumers. But it isn't a perfect solution. Who will check that Detroit doesn't try to get around the pledge by imposing hidden price hikes -- for example, by removing expensive accessories from its minivans?
Yet Mr. Schumer's two-sided bargain fits well with Mr. Clinton's campaign theme of a "new covenant" between citizens and government. If reciprocal obligations make sense for welfare-seeking families, why shouldn't the President demand no less from welfare-seeking corporations?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 723 words

HEADLINE: Bill Clinton's Moment

 BODY:
New Presidents are given very few opportunities to define themselves to the country and define what they expect from the country. Some seize the chance, some don't, but the truth is that these moments of definition rarely return.
Bill Clinton's address to Congress and the nation last night on economic policy was just such a moment. He knew that and tried to seize it. Battles are sure to be fought over the details of his program, but Mr. Clinton cannot be faulted for squandering his chance to stake his turf. 
 It was also a moment rich with irony: the last President to use this setting so ambitiously was Ronald Reagan. Twelve years ago, Mr. Reagan appeared before Congress with his own economic package wrapped in a beautiful dream. There can be gain without pain, he said; cut taxes and watch the economy soar.
Last night, from the same podium, Mr. Clinton pronounced that dream dead, and offered in its place the wholly contrary notion that, after a decade of fiscal excess, there can be no gain without pain, and plenty of it.
The success of Mr. Clinton's proposals will depend on two things: whether, taken together, they are perceived as fair; and whether they are seen to be the correct response, immediately and in the long term, to two decades of sluggish productivity and wages. The program he announced last night is a credible attempt to meet both challenges.
First, he stressed fairness. The rich would pay the most, largely in increased income taxes. The middle class would shoulder its share of the burden largely through increased energy taxes. Corporate America would pay more, and Government programs would be trimmed.
As to economic strategy, Mr. Clinton squarely faced a conundrum: The U.S. suffers two problems that cannot be solved with the same medicine. In the short run, factories are idle and millions of Americans remain unemployed or underemployed despite the fact that recovery is more than a year old. For this problem, Mr. Clinton proposes a $30 billion stimulus package that temporarily increases the deficit.
In the long term, the economy suffers from too little saving and therefore too little investment and growth. That's the reason middle-income households are suffering. People cannot earn more until productivity rises faster. To solve this problem, Mr. Clinton proposes substantial increases in public investment in infrastructure, training and education and tax subsidies for private investors.
The centerpiece of his strategy is a deficit reduction package consisting of $500 billion in spending cuts and tax increases spread over four years. That will free needed funds for the private capital markets. By 1997 the deficit would fall to about $200 billion -- a fiscally prudent target.
Indeed, if Mr. Clinton has erred he has done so on the side of making his stimulus too brief and his deficit reduction too hasty. The economy could stand serious stimulus in 1993 and 1994; but under the Clinton plan, deficit reduction kicks in during 1994, offsetting the effect of the stimulus package. The plan would be less risky if he upped the stimulus package and postponed the long-term deficit reduction until 1995.
But this timetable reflects Mr. Clinton's political judgment, and it is a gamble he may win.
The Clinton plan is 180 degrees away from the Reagan economic plan delivered 12 years ago. Mr. Reagan stimulated the economy by increasing consumption and defense spending; Mr. Clinton would do so with investment -- the only way to spur long-term economic security. Mr. Reagan based his plan on phony budget estimates; Mr. CLinton's estimates -- subject to careful screening over the next couple of weeks -- seem honest in their economics and canny in their politics.
After several weeks of floundering, Bill Clinton has given focus to his Presidency by seizing on exactly the same issue that eventually gave definition to his campaign: the economy.
The difference is that he presents the issue more honestly. Gone is the pretense that he could resurrect the economy merely by soaking the rich and taxing foreign companies. Gone is the promise that he could grant tax relief to the middle class. In their place is a summons to Congress "to break the old habits of both political parties" and to help him deliver on his commitment to restore the economy.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Great Leap Backward

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
That squishy sound you heard throughout President Clinton's economic address -- the weakness at the core of his proposals -- is a refusal to deal with the explosion of Federal spending.
A decade ago, Speaker Tip O'Neill snookered President Reagan in a deficit reduction deal: For one dollar in tax increase, promised the Democrat, Congress would cut three dollars in spending. Never happened; Democrats claim there never was a deal. 
 Three years ago, George Bush made the "deficit reduction deal" with Democrats that helped torpedo his Presidency: For every dollar in new taxes, two dollars were to be cut in spending. But taxes were front-loaded and spending cuts back-loaded; the deficit soared.
Now we have similar snake oil from Mr. Clinton. Only weeks ago, we heard from his budget chief that for every dollar in new taxes, two dollars would be cut out of the spending stream. Now even that ephemeral goal has been abandoned: it's to be "in rough balance" -- a dollar cut for a dollar taxed.
Even if that were true, contrary to all recent experience, such "balance" would mean that the debt would continue to grow because each year's deficit compounds itself.
In the storm of projections, keep in mind a few bedrock principles:
Economic stimulus -- jargon for "government spending" -- adds to the deficit, the interest on which is killing us. Accept no Clintonite protestations that this is just for now, and next year, boyoboy will they become deficit-cutters. Never happens.
Higher taxes do not help, and could abort, a recovery. We're on the way back up to brisk growth, with productivity increasing; now is not the time to snatch money out the pockets of people able to spend it.
A true fair sharing of the pain would be to reduce our debt by slowing the growth of government services, not to take more tax money for more services. No wonder we have seen so little of Lloyd Bentsen in the pre-speech hype: Clinton's plan, rather than "growing the economy," grows the Government.
Cutting the deficit is not an excuse for raising taxes when you are not really cutting the deficit.
Now we are at the heart of the matter. Mr. Clinton, sold as "a different kind of Democrat," is the same kind of Democrat on economics: he is answering the Reagan revolution with a plan for a Clinton counter-revolution. His promised "new direction" is a reversion to 1979.
How to sell this Great Leap Backward? In 1971 Richard Nixon told his aides, "We've got to have a villain." We tried to make inflation the villain, which led to the misbegotten wage-price freeze, but not until anti-war demonstrations engulfed the Democrats did a villain emerge that guaranteed Nixon's re-election.
In his post-election campaign, Clinton has selected no fewer than four villains to be the anvil on which he hammers counter-revolution.
The first is "the rich," the definition of which has widened to all those not poor. He takes this sanctimonious appeal to class warfare from F.D.R.'s blast at "economic royalists."
Second is the "special interests," Truman's villain, now defined as those lobbyists and lawyers outside the Clinton Cabinet who oppose proposals to raise taxes, slash defense or treat Social Security as welfare.
Villain number three is the pharmaceutical industry, for the sin of conspicuous success. Price controls on children's vaccines have populist appeal, but if advertising is penalized and price controls on new drugs result in shortages, black markets and cutbacks in medical research, this villain will be quickly de-demonized.
The fourth villain is the one most despised: that ol' debbil deficit. Its puissance was exploited by Ross Perot, who could rightly claim that the debt begun by Democrats was tripled under Republican Presidents.
"Revenue to lower the deficit" is cited by Clinton as the reason for his flip-flop on a middle-class tax cut. His excuse is that deficit projections leaped after his election, but that stretches a wild guess about 1997 from the Democratic Congressional Budget Office (Clinton's favorite projector). The high projection justifies tax-hike plans he concealed from the electorate in 1992, and makes it easier to come under in the 1996 campaign.
In Monday's infelicitous "call to arms," and in last night's "new directions" ramble, Bill Clinton raised taxes, raised spending, raised deficits and raised doubts.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Fearing Voters . . .

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Candidate Clinton tried to teach Americans a critical lesson -- that domestic policy is foreign policy is domestic policy. But President Clinton seems to be running away from world affairs, fearful of displeasing voters who might think him overly engaged abroad and insufficiently attentive to America. And through his tentativeness, he could be inadvertently encouraging the very isolationist impulses he warned against during the campaign -- and jeopardizing his mantle of leadership.
So far, Mr. Clinton has kept international issues at arm's length, at least publicly. And last night, in the space usually reserved for the State of the Union address, he offered an economic speech, serving to shield his deliberate scanting of the outside world. 
 Voters, particularly the volatile middle class, do want Mr. Clinton to focus on fixing up America, and he must heed them. But he may be overreading their signals and treading far more cautiously in foreign affairs than politically necessary or internationally wise.
Most Americans in opinion surveys consistently tell the President two things: Put America's problems first. But also play a leadership role in the world -- and especially tend to humanitarian crises such as Somalia and Bosnia.
The "America first" message is so stark as to brace even the most internationally minded President. A recent Wall Street Journal/NBC News Poll asked people to rank government priorities. Reducing the deficit came first with 31 percent, then stimulating economic growth with 24 percent, followed by reforming the health care system with 18 percent. Only 4 percent of the respondents gave top priority to foreign policy issues.
Americans answering a New York Times/CBS News Poll last week underlined those anti-internationalist priorities. Asked about the current level of military spending, 39 percent said it was about right, 6 percent said it was too low -- and 50 percent said it was too high. Fifty percent support for cutting Pentagon spending is incredibly high, perhaps a record high.
Hearing these hoofbeats, Mr. Clinton disappeared from the Bosnia crisis. Quite deliberately, Secretary of State Christopher, not Mr. Clinton, presented the Administration's approach last week.
In search of the middle-class mind, CBS's "Sunday Morning" news program recently visited Sioux Falls, S.D., and asked a resident what he would like to hear from Mr. Clinton in his upcoming address. "Let's get out -- get out of the other countries and let's pay attention to what the people need in this country," came the clarion call. "He's our President, not their President."
It is hard not to be overwhelmed by such forthright demands, and Mr. Clinton's address last night demonstrated he was listening -- too well. Which means he is not fully hearing the public's second message, namely that most Americans do not want to scamper away from tough situations abroad.
In a Times/CBS Poll last month, 69 percent favored the U.S. military intervention in Somalia. Eighty-four percent said they would approve of military action against Iraq if Saddam Hussein violated U.N. restrictions. While the responses on Bosnia were somewhat contradictory, particularly on the issue of European versus U.S. responsibility, 67 percent favored sending U.S. troops to get food and medicine through to needy civilians.
These remarkably high percentages strongly suggest most Americans will back using U.S. military power where humanitarian or strategic stakes are high and where policy is clearly explained. Put another way, whatever Americans are saying today about domestic priorities, they will hold Mr. Clinton accountable if he abdicates world leadership, if foreign leaders complain of a weak Washington, or if world crises are not contained.
Mr. Clinton may well misunderstand the public's unhappiness with George Bush's priorities. Many middle-class swing voters rejected Mr. Bush not because he paid so much attention to foreign affairs, but because he paid so little attention to America.
Mr. Clinton justified his speech's near-total inward focus by arguing these are not ordinary times. He's right. In extraordinary times like these, there is no alternative to America's world leadership. His campaign litany -- domestic policy is foreign policy is domestic policy -- still rings true, and still needs preaching.

HEADLINE: There They Go Again

BYLINE: By Ronald Reagan; Ronald Reagan, President from 1981 to 1989, heads the Reagan Center for Public Affairs.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Less than one month ago, our nation showed the world the strength of our democratic system with the peaceful transfer of Presidential power from one elected citizen to another and, incidentally, from one political party to another. While it is no secret that I would have preferred a different scenario that day, I have great respect for our constitutional system and would like to support our new President.
I had every intention of holding back any comments on the new Administration until it was well in place and its policies became clear. Unfortunately, the policies are already becoming alarmingly clear. With campaign promises dropping like autumn leaves, I can't refrain any longer. 
 "First, we're going to raise the taxes on the people that did well in the 1980's," the Clinton Administration says. Did I hear that right? I'm afraid so! Do they really believe that those who have worked hard and been successful should somehow be punished for it? Is success in the 1980's, or any time for that matter, supposed to be something we as Americans are to be embarrassed about?
I hate to confuse their economic thinking with a few facts, but if they were to look at the 1980's, they would find that America experienced its longest period of peacetime economic expansion in our history. They would find that America led the world out of a global economic recession and that our economy was the envy of virtually every other nation. They would see that we created nearly 19 million new jobs for Americans of all income levels. And it may shock the Clinton Administration to discover that most of the economic gains of the 1980's were made by low- and middle-income citizens, not the wealthiest Americans.
Earlier this week, President Clinton said, "I know we have learned the hard lessons of the 1980's." I didn't realize they were so hard to learn. The fundamental lesson of the 1980's was that when you cut taxes for everyone, people have the incentive to work harder and invest, to make a better life for themselves and their families.
If the new Administration doesn't want to look back as far as the 1980's, maybe it will at least look back at the summer of 1992. Candidate Bill Clinton was promising that, if elected, he would provide a tax cut for the middle class. Now, in less than one month of his Presidency, that promise of a tax cut has not only been broken but it has been reversed into a tax increase for middle-income workers.
During the campaign, Bill Clinton said he would tax only the very rich. Last week, he defined this category as those making $200,000 a year. On Monday, the definition came down to $100,000 and now the "very rich" seems to be anyone making $30,000 a year.
Somehow, as the Administration raises everyone's taxes, it wants us to take comfort in knowing that others are getting theirs raised even more. Unfortunately, that kind of "comfort" doesn't put food on the table of the hard-working middle class, buy new shoes for the kids or make it easier to pay the mortgage, let alone put some money aside for savings. The fact is, every dollar the politicians take back to Washington means less spending power for average Americans and more opportunity for the Federal bureaucracy to waste money.
We must also listen for the sound of the other shoe to drop: the Clintons' health program. This will almost certainly involve proposals for another round of taxes later this year, and you can bet those won't be levied on a handful of millionaires.
In the Middle Ages, it was believed that alchemists could turn base metals into gold. Now it appears that alchemists in President Clinton's Administration hope to turn a huge tax increase into economic growth. Alchemy didn't work then and it won't work now. Taxes have never succeeded in promoting economic growth. More often than not, they have led to greater economic downturns.
In his campaign, candidate Clinton described himself as a "new Democrat," implying that there would be no more tax-and-spend dogma, no social engineering, no class warfare pitting one group against another. This week, however, he has begun to sound like an "old Democrat." That's the kind who does not understand one simple fact: the problem is not that the people are taxed too little, the problem is that the Government spends too much.
Until President Clinton and the liberals in Congress accept that principle and act accordingly, I'm afraid we are headed for a repeat of the late 1970's. And that is something we can all live without.
No one can dispute that the enormous budget deficit is a major threat to the economic security of our country. But let us remember that deficits are caused by spending. By the very terms of our Constitution, only Congress has the power to spend.
For more than four decades, one party, the Democratic Party, has controlled the House of Representatives. The solution to the deficit problem is not to ask heavily taxed working Americans to "sacrifice" even more.
It's the big-spending liberals controlling the Congress who need to show some restraint and "sacrifice" a few of the pork-barrel measures they've been slipping past the taxpayers for far too long. Only when the Clinton Administration and Congress summon the will to put the brakes on Federal spending will they get the deficit under control.
While I'm flattered that President Clinton admits to taking a page out of my communications plan, I wish he'd use it to sell an economic program of growth and expansion, not the failed liberal policies of the past.
Just as positive signs of economic recovery are appearing, Mr. President, please don't blow it. Although it goes back well before the 1980's, may I offer you the advice of the 14th century Arab historian Ibn Khaldun, who said: "At the beginning of the empire, the tax rates were low and the revenues were high. At the end of the empire, the tax rates were high and the revenues were low."
And, no, I did not personally know Ibn Khaldun, although we may have had some friends in common!

HEADLINE: America's Better Self Got Lost in Aliens Law

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We share A. M. Rosenthal's sense of solidarity with immigrants in "Aliens: Let Them Work" (column, Feb. 9). A nation of immigrants, the United States has at various stages of history turned its back on its best self and let its fearful face show. Xenophobia and racism -- both strong currents in American life -- often combine in the making of immigration policy. 
 The American Friends Service Committee and many others who work closely with today's immigrant communities opposed employer sanctions when the 1986 immigration law was under consideration. Our fundamental objection to the proposed law was that we saw the sanctions provision as a denial of a strong religious tradition in this country that calls on us to welcome the stranger.
We saw the employer-sanctions provision as leading to discrimination in hiring by employers, who would reject a foreign-looking applicant, rather than risk hiring undocumented people. Such has proved to be the case. We saw the provision as leading to a market in forged documents. Such a market thrives.
We saw the employer-sanctions provision creating a highly vulnerable group of employees, unable to protect themselves from economic exploitation and other abuse. This has come to pass: witness the new sweatshops across the country.
We saw the law as asking employers to be part of a governmental effort designed to starve immigrants out, to drive them home again and to deter others from coming -- to become, as Mr. Rosenthal says, "an unpaid work-police."
The issues immigration policy seeks to address would be better dealt with by investment in enforcement of labor laws concerning fair wages and working conditions for all workers, documented or undocumented, meaningful foreign debt relief and international economic cooperation directed to achieve sustainable development. Let us welcome the stranger. Let us repeal employer sanctions.
 
BARBARA W. MOFFETT
Natl. Community Relations Secy.
American Friends Service Committee
Philadelphia, Feb. 10, 1993
