HEADLINE: America's Better Self Got Lost in Aliens Law;
'Victims' Who Exploit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I cannot fathom why Anthony Lewis and others have painted Zoe Baird and Kimba Wood, President Clinton's first two nominees for Attorney General, as victims of a male-dominated society simply because they employed illegal aliens as child care workers (column, Feb. 8). 
 Admittedly I am not a mother or a highly paid professional woman. However, I have worked with immigrant rights groups, and I can tell you the main reason people employ illegal aliens is that they will work for much less, and because of their tenuous status with the Immigration and Naturalization Service they are more compliant and more easily exploited.
With regard to the consequences of the actions of Ms. Baird, Judge Wood and any men whose wives have employed illegal aliens, this is not about keeping women in their place. I wish somebody would keep me in my place as a Federal district judge or a $500,000-a-year general counsel for a Fortune 500 company.
If these women were low- or middle-income workers who would be put into a serious financial bind by paying the prevailing rate for legal nannies, I might feel different. However, this issue has nothing to do with feminism and everything to do with the wanton, callous, capitalistic exploitation of the reserve army of the unemployed.
We've come a long way, baby. Is this the direction we want to continue going in?
 
BETSY SHACKELFORD
New York, Feb. 8, 1993

HEADLINE: Japan's Economy Will Emerge Stronger

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Behind Japan's Economic Crisis" (Op-Ed, Feb. 1): Isn't Akio Mikuni's description of Japan's economic difficulties, as reflected in a sharp stock market decline over the last two and a half years and by declining growth, rather exaggerated? 
 It is true the Ministry of Finance has exercised extraordinary powers over Japan's financial community for the better part of four decades. With the Bank of Japan, the ministry did indeed ration credit as it guided the country's reconstruction after World War II.
But over the last two decades the Ministry of Finance has changed course and turned toward a policy Mr. Mikuni seems to ignore: it has both liberalized and internationalized Japan's financial markets.
During the 1970's and 80's, when I was assigned to the United States Embassy in Tokyo, my colleagues and I observed a series of important changes that have transformed the entire Japanese financial system.
Gone are the days when American brokerage houses couldn't be members of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, when Japanese corporations preferred to raise funds in London and New York, instead of Tokyo, and when the ministry decreed the interest rates banks paid their depositors.
As Mr. Mikuni notes, Japan's banks and brokerage houses overextended themselves with cheap credit for speculation on stocks and real estate during the late 80's, and many will soon be paying the piper.
But this is not necessarily the complete disaster Mr. Mikuni says it is. From the wreckage there will surely emerge a healthier, stronger and more competitive Japanese financial industry, one in which American companies will be active participants.
 
JAMES H. MC NAUGHTON
Bethesda, Md., Feb. 8, 1993

HEADLINE: Keep Electric Boat Busy in Post-Cold War Era

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You have been reporting that the Electric Boat Company in Groton, Conn., will have large layoffs in connection with the end of the cold war and a reduced need for new submarines (front page, Feb. 9). The facility evidently must be subsidized to preserve it to make submarines, should the need arise. 
 In connection with the need to keep this facility intact, someone should point out that Electric Boat could not be better situated and equipped to build modular tunnel sections for sinking into an underwater trench to construct a new underwater highway and rail connection between Orient Point on Long Island and New London in Connecticut. Such a tunnel might well pay for itself from toll revenue without any net cost to the government at all. The improved transportation access between Long Island and New England would aid the economies of both regions. The Electric Boat facility could remain fully em ployed on the project for a decade, while remaining intact for the manufacture of submarines as national security needs might dictate.
Defense industries are national resources that should be preserved by putting them to work on civil infrastructure improvements that will pay for themselves. Electric Boat could build a marvelous tunnel and remain ready to build new submarines. There can be no better time to begin a tunnel across Long Island Sound and no better facility than Electric Boat to build it.
 
STEPHEN R. BOLGER
New York, Feb. 10, 1993

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: The Overview;
CLINTON PLAN TO REMAKE THE ECONOMY SEEKS TO TAX ENERGY AND BIG INCOMES

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
President Clinton tonight proposed a comprehensive program of tax increases and spending cuts designed to trim the Federal deficit over the next four years by $500 billion, or 38 percent, and to revitalize the nation's economy.
In a speech to a joint session of Congress that is expected to shape at least the early stages of his Presidency, Mr. Clinton outlined a series of new taxes that would fall most heavily on business and on relatively wealthy individuals, both active and retired. But families earning as little as $20,000 a year -- members of the "forgotten middle class" whose taxes he promised during his campaign to cut -- will also be asked to send more dollars to Washington under the President's plan. 
 Largely because of a new energy tax, the average middle class family of four would pay about $17 a month more under Mr. Clinton's program.
 
Spending to Create Jobs
 Mr. Clinton was exuberantly greeted by Congressional Democrats who had waited a dozen years to see a President of their party among them. He said pointedly, "Americans have called for change, and now it is up to those of us in this room to deliver for them," and spoke as a believer in the efficacy of government to a nation that views Washington with deep skepticism. [Transcript, pages A20-21.]
Hoping to convince voters that he is different from the free-spending liberal Democrats of the past, Mr. Clinton said he intended to cut military spending by $76 billion more than previously announced and to slash spending on more than 150 civil projects ranging from the space station to agricultural subsidies. He called as well for a freeze on all Government salaries and limits on payments doctors and hospitals receive under Medicare.
But the President also offered $30 billion in additional spending on such projects as highways and summer jobs, designed to rev up the economy over the next six months. The goal is to create 500,000 jobs by the end of next year, he said -- a start on the 8 million he hopes to create by 1997.
 
Stressing Fairness of Plan
 "This economic plan is ambitious, but I honestly believe it is necessary for the continued greatness of the United States, and I think it is paid for fairly, first by cutting Government, then by asking the most of those who benefited the most in the past," said the President, who tinkered with his text all day, then used it only as a guide.
He is "asking more Americans to contribute today," Mr. Clinton added, stating his political theme, "so that all of us can prosper tomorrow."
"The test of this plan cannot be: What is in it for me?" the President said. "It has got to be: What is in it for us?"
The prospects of the plan, on which the President has worked for weeks and on which he is staking much of his political well-being, are uncertain. It is a substantial gamble, taken in the first month of his first term, when his political leverage should be at its strongest. It will work only if he can persuade the public that the proposed taxes are fair, that new revenues will really be used to cut the deficit and that the proposed cuts are genuine.
 
Plea to Accept Whole Package
 Only at the end of his address, which was televised nationally, did the President turn to taxes, and when he did he begged his listeners not to focus on one or two items.
"This economic plan can't please everybody," he conceded. "If the package is picked apart, there'll be something that will anger each of us, won't please anybody. But if it is taken as a whole, it will help all of us. So I ask you all to begin by resisting the temptation to focus only on a particular spending cut you don't like or some particular investment that wasn't made."
Led by Ronald Reagan, whose policies Mr. Clinton seeks to reverse, Republicans in the Senate and House of Representatives accused Mr. Clinton of reverting to the Democrats' old "tax and spend" traditions. Democrats on Capitol Hill quickly made loyal noises but also reported heavily anti-Clinton telephone calls and said that modifications could be expected.
In a televised rebuttal, the leader of the Republican minority in the House, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, warned the country: "When you hear a Democrat call for taxes, do not ask for whom the tax rises; it will rise for you."
 
Importance of Perot
 Although the same party now controls Congress and the White House for the first time since 1980, the task facing Mr. Clinton remains onerous. Members of Congress are more susceptible in the era of mass communications to constituent pressures than to Presidential entreaties and White House favors.
The attitude of Ross Perot, whose Presidential candidacy last year drew almost 19 percent of the total vote, could have a major impact on public attitudes. In his campaign, he called for deficit reduction and budgetary honesty, and Mr. Clinton telephoned him today to seek his backing.
After working so long on his speech that the text was not available until moments before he walked into the House chamber, Mr. Clinton used what he and his staff had drafted only as an outline, looping in and out of the printed document the way a stump speaker does during a campaign.
He insisted that his was not a State of the Union message and said at the start that he would confine himself to the economy. But he talked as well about campaign reform and health care and gun control in his 58-minute speech.
The Cabinet, the Supreme Court, the members of Congress and the Diplomatic Corps were arrayed beneath the lectern as the President spoke. Many of his staunchest supporters were in the balcony, including Hillary Rodham Clinton, in an outfit of brilliant red, flanked by two important economic players: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and John Sculley, the chairman of Apple Computer, who has been one of Mr. Clinton's main business backers.
In his speech, the President asked the nation to take some bitter medicine, not unlike that proposed last year by a rival in the primaries, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts. Such an approach helped doom Jimmy Carter's Presidency and wrecked the 1984 Presidential campaign of Walter F. Mondale.
 
Putting Promises Aside
 Mr. Clinton and his advisers believe that Americans now consider the deficit more repugnant than higher taxes. But it has been difficult for Presidents in the last quarter-century to generate public commitments to large-scale projects like the broad attack on the nation's economic ills that the President's plan constitutes.
As George Bush discovered when voters turned on him after he broke his vow not to raise taxes, broken promises have proven to be electoral poison, and Mr. Clinton ignored some of his campaign pledges, retreated from others and contradicted still others in his economic presentation tonight. His political strategists can only hope the commentators and the public focus on deficit-busting rather than on promise-busting in the coming months.
The skittishness of public opinion and business sentiment was exemplified by an 83-point drop in the stock market on Tuesday after a speech in which Mr. Clinton dwelt on taxes.
Perhaps the most sweeping of the taxes proposed by the President is a new levy on energy that would raise prices on gasoline, natural gas, coal and heating oil -- and on manufactured goods whose production consumes energy. He also proposed raising the top tax rate to 36 from 31 percent on individuals with taxable incomes of more than $115,000 and couples with taxable incomes of more than $140,000.
 
Revoking Gains of 80's
 Mr. Clinton urged Congress to enact higher corporate taxes, impose a surtax on families earning $250,000 a year or more, raise the taxes employers and employees pay to support Medicare and increase the taxes on Social Security benefits for more well-off recipients. He suggested an increase in various government fees, like those for grazing livestock on Federal lands.
To further boost his job-creation program, however, the President offered a tax break to businesses. Big companies would be rewarded for increased spending on new equipment in 1993 and 1994, and firms with gross receipts under $5 million would permanently enjoy such investment tax credits.
Mr. Clinton said he wanted a four-year, $160-billion package of increased spending -- which would, of course, partly offset his spending cuts. It would be concentrated on transportation facilities, including highway construction, mass transit, high-speed rail links and improvements at aging airports.
According to government tax analysts, about 57 percent of Mr. Clinton's total tax increase of about $60 billion a year would be paid by those with annual incomes of $200,000 and over. The President argues that they profited most from the tax cuts of the 1980's and must therefore bear the heaviest burden in the future.
 
Striking Perk for the Rich
 Hoping to give his program as strong a populist cast as possible, Mr. Clinton went after the wealthy in a number of ways, starting with the new 36 percent top rate on high earners. The maximum rate on capital gains, however, would stay at 28 percent. A 10 percent surtax would be imposed on people with taxable incomes, excluding capital gains, over $250,000 -- mostly millionaires, according to the Treasury.
Furthermore, all wages, not just the first $135,000 a year, would be subject to the 1.45 percent tax that pays for Medicare, the vast program of health care for the elderly and disabled. In a flourish of disdain for the perks of the rich, the President proposed to eliminate the deductibility of club dues and cut the percentage of expense-account spending qualifying for business deductions to 50 from 80 percent.
 A front-page article about the economic plan referred imprecisely to the amount by which it would reduce the Federal budget deficit. The miscalculation is discussed today in an article on page A15.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 19, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page summary of the Clinton economic proposals yesterday described a proposed income tax change incorrectly in some copies. The proposed surtax would raise the tax rate on taxable income above $250,000 by 10 percent, from a rate of 36 percent to one of 39.6 percent.
A table of case studies showing the impact of the proposal calculated the surtax incorrectly in one case. A family with a taxable income of $283,746 would owe a surtax of $1,215; the family's total tax would be $94,692, an increase of $12,545 over the tax bill under current rules.

Charts: "Highlights of the Clinton proposal"
Over four years, tax increases and spending cuts would reduce the deficit by $493 billion. This year, the defecit would increase by $30 billion to stimulate the economy.
 
TAX INCREASES
 
Personal
Rates: Top income tax rate, now 31 percent, would increase to 36 percent for couples with taxable incomes of $140,000 or more and individuals with taxable incomes of $115,000 or more.
Capital gains: Top rate would remain 28 percent.
Surtax: Families with taxable incomes above $250,000 would have their top rate increased to 39.6 10 percent.
Medicare tax: All earned income would be subject to the Medicare tax; $135,000 ceiling would be lifted.
Social Security: Relatively well-off people would pay taxes on 85 percent of Social Security benefits, up from 50 percent.
Energy tax: A tax placed on almost all forms of energy would eventually raise each family's annual fuel bills by $100 to $150.
 
Business:
Rates: Top corporate tax rate, now 34 percent, would rise to 36 percent.
Limited deductions: 50 percent of the cost of business meals and entertainment could be deducted, down from 80 percent.
Ending deductions: Businesses would be denied deductions for executives' pay above $1 million a year, for club dues for executives and for lobbying expenses.
 
TAX CUTS
Personal -- Credits for virtually all families with incomes below $30,000 to insure they pay no additional taxes.
Businesses -- A special capital gains break would be given for investments in small businesses held at least five years. Businesses would get an investment tax credit for the purchase of new equipment.
 
SPENDING INCREASES
New -- New spending would be allowed this year for construction projects, summer jobs, wastewater clean-up and childhood immunization.
Later -- Spending would be increased for transportation, education, job-training, technological research, Head Start and nutrition for pregnant women and small children.
 
SPENDING CUTS
Pay: Federal workers would skip a raise.
Science: Spending for the space station and the superconducting supercollider would be slowed.
Health: New limits on some payments to doctors, hospitals and laboratories under Medicare and Medicaid.
Articles and charts are on pages A16-A21.
A guide to the coverage is on page A16. (pg. A1)

"How Families Feel the Change"
The Treasury Department yesterday calculated the impact of its proposals in terms of what it called Family Economic Income, a figure that combines adjusted gross income with other forms of compensation or assistance. Treasury officials were not able to say how many households fall into each bracket.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: The President's Day;
Clinton Is a Revisionist Even With His Writers

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Dozens of aides spent hundreds of hours of endless toil drafting the speech that President Clinton took to Capitol Hill with him tonight. But that was not the speech that Mr. Clinton actually delivered.
In the end, much of the President's address -- whole paragraphs even -- were completely ad libbed by a politician who loves nothing more than to tinker with, and rewrite, his own words. 
 As Mr. Clinton rambled on, one passage seemed to come out of nowhere, and provoked the extraordinary spectacle of loud, even disrespectful laughter from the Republican side of the House chamber. That was when Mr. Clinton talked about the "independent figures" from the Congressional Budget Office.
Undaunted by his opponents' derision of the budget office, which was virtually always at odds with Administration estimates of the Federal deficit and other important numbers in the Reagan and Bush years, Mr. Clinton forged on. "Well, you can laugh, my fellow Republicans," he joked. "But I'll point out that the Congressional Budget Office was normally more conservative on what was going to happen and closer to right than previous Presidents."
 
An Unaccustomed Fact
 Besides the spontaneity in the speech, the scene was one that has not taken place in a Presidential address to Congress for more than 12 years. Throughout the terms of Ronald Reagan and George Bush, it was the Republican side of the aisle that always jumped first to standing ovations or wild acclaim for their party's President.
Tonight, the Democrats -- some of whom will no doubt pick apart Mr. Clinton's economic program in the days ahead -- reveled in the unaccustomed fact that their President belongs to their party.
But the mood in the hall seemed noticeably subdued at other times, as the camera panned to the deadpan, and sometimes grim-looking, faces of Mr. Clinton's aides. Robert Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, and Alice Rivlin, the White House deputy budget director, seemed exhausted from the ordeal of putting together the economic package.
Except for the occasional laughter, the Republicans paid their respects to the President. Even Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the outspoken House Republican whip, joined in several standing ovations at the beginning, including the prolonged greeting of the President as he entered the chamber. But by midway through the speech, Mr. Gingrich stayed stuck in his seat, offering no more than occasional tepid applause.
 
Writing and Rewriting
 Mr. Clinton's ad libbing seemed surprising since he had spent the day displaying the trait that sets him apart from his more disciplined predecessors: He likes to write, and rewrite and rewrite speeches until moments before he delivers them.
The fact that tonight's speech was the most important on the economy of any President since Ronald Reagan's in 1981 did not hasten the drafting process. Mr. Clinton was surprised to learn of the noon deadline to get the speech to the printers so it could be published and bound. (Needless to say, he missed the deadline; the speech was duplicated on copying machines.)
Congressional officials said it was the first time in at least 20 years that the White House did not distribute copies of the President's speech on Capitol Hill before Mr. Clinton's appearance.
When he was not seeking support for his economic program, Mr. Clinton shuttled between the Oval Office and the Roosevelt Room with a handful of aides, still trying to settle on the precise language he wanted to use to enlist support for the brew of tax increases and spending cuts that some feared would be unpopular.
As his speech writers stood by in frustration, Mr. Clinton reviewed the draft line by line, scrawling last-minute fixes in the margins in his illegible handwriting. He also thought out loud the passages he wanted in the speech as his aides scribbled every word. All day long, an ever-growing cadre of aides wandered in and out of the room to offer counsel.
 
More Cooks, More Soup
 Elsewhere in the West Wing, aides said Hillary Rodham Clinton was working with Robert E. Rubin, the economic policy adviser, to try to insert more human language in a section of the speech he had helped draft.
As if they were still in college cramming for that big final, three energetic speech writers, David Kusnet, David Dreyer and Michael Waldman, were said to have pulled an all-nighter at the White House Tuesday night, toiling over the speech that their boss reworked the next day.
It is harder, they say, to trim a speech than to make it longer. And the involvement of so many hands served only to elongate the speech. By the end of the day, White House aides said it had nearly doubled its original length, to more than an hour.
 
Pitch to Anchors and Perot
 Although Mr. Clinton fussed and toiled over the language, he never wavered in his aggressive salesmanship. He went so far as to invite the network anchors to the White House (no cameras allowed) for a private sales pitch over a lunch of mixed grill and broccoli. As the anchors took notes, Mr. Clinton put his own spin on major portions of the plan.
"This was a regular feature of the Reagan Administration, but it never occurred in the Bush Administration," said Peter Jennings of ABC News. "The purpose was obvious: to see to it that the people who are going to speak to the largest audiences tonight at least have the President's view of what he's trying to accomplish."
After lunch, Mr. Clinton called Ross Perot to seek his support, well aware that Mr. Perot, who made the deficit his central issue as a Presidential candidate last year, was scheduled to appear on the ABC News program "Nightline" after the address.
"He wanted to tell Mr. Perot what was in the package," said Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary. "He believes the package does many of the things that Perot called for in the campaign."
Mr. Clinton was known during last year's campaign for his down-to-the-wire massaging of speeches. So his aides said people should not be surprised that even a team of White House speech writers could not break him of the habit.
"He's not making changes for change's sake," said Bruce Reed, a domestic policy aide. "He poured his heart and soul into it."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 19, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday under the heading "The President's Day," about President Clinton's preparations for his economic address to Congress, misidentified the Deputy Treasury Secretary in some copies. He is Roger Altman.

 Mr. Clinton and his advisers believe that Americans now consider the deficit more repugnant than higher taxes. But it has been difficult for Presidents in the last quarter-century to generate public commitments to large-scale projects like the broad attack on the nation's economic ills that the President's plan constitutes.
As George Bush discovered when voters turned on him after he broke his vow not to raise taxes, broken promises have proven to be electoral poison, and Mr. Clinton ignored some of his campaign pledges, retreated from others and contradicted still others in his economic presentation tonight. His political strategists can only hope the commentators and the public focus on deficit-busting rather than on promise-busting in the coming months.
The skittishness of public opinion and business sentiment was exemplified by an 83-point drop in the stock market on Tuesday after a speech in which Mr. Clinton dwelt on taxes.
Perhaps the most sweeping of the taxes proposed by the President is a new levy on energy that would raise prices on gasoline, natural gas, coal and heating oil -- and on manufactured goods whose production consumes energy. He also proposed raising the top tax rate to 36 from 31 percent on individuals with taxable incomes of more than $115,000 and couples with taxable incomes of more than $140,000.
 
Revoking Gains of 80's
 Mr. Clinton urged Congress to enact higher corporate taxes, impose a surtax on families earning $250,000 a year or more, raise the taxes employers and employees pay to support Medicare and increase the taxes on Social Security benefits for more well-off recipients. He suggested an increase in various government fees, like those for grazing livestock on Federal lands.
To further boost his job-creation program, however, the President offered a tax break to businesses. Big companies would be rewarded for increased spending on new equipment in 1993 and 1994, and firms with gross receipts under $5 million would permanently enjoy such investment tax credits.
Mr. Clinton said he wanted a four-year, $160-billion package of increased spending -- which would, of course, partly offset his spending cuts. It would be concentrated on transportation facilities, including highway construction, mass transit, high-speed rail links and improvements at aging airports.
According to government tax analysts, about 57 percent of Mr. Clinton's total tax increase of about $60 billion a year would be paid by those with annual incomes of $200,000 and over. The President argues that they profited most from the tax cuts of the 1980's and must therefore bear the heaviest burden in the future.
 
Striking Perk for the Rich
 Hoping to give his program as strong a populist cast as possible, Mr. Clinton went after the wealthy in a number of ways, starting with the new 36 percent top rate on high earners. The maximum rate on capital gains, however, would stay at 28 percent. A 10 percent surtax would be imposed on people with taxable incomes, excluding capital gains, over $250,000 -- mostly millionaires, according to the Treasury.
Furthermore, all wages, not just the first $135,000 a year, would be subject to the 1.45 percent tax that pays for Medicare, the vast program of health care for the elderly and disabled. In a flourish of disdain for the perks of the rich, the President proposed to eliminate the deductibility of club dues and cut the percentage of expense-account spending qualifying for business deductions to 50 from 80 percent.

 CORRECTION:
A table on Thursday showing the effects of President Clinton's proposed energy tax misstated the effective date. It would be July 1, 1994. The chart also misstated the unit of measurement by which the tax was calculated for natural gas; it was thousands of cubic feet. An expanded and corrected chart appears today on page 6.

Over four years, tax increases and spending cuts would reduce the deficit by $493 billion. This year, the defecit would increase by $30 billion to stimulate the economy.
 
TAX INCREASES
 
Personal
Rates: Top income tax rate, now 31 percent, would increase to 36 percent for couples with taxable incomes of $140,000 or more and individuals with taxable incomes of $115,000 or more.
Capital gains: Top rate would remain 28 percent.
Surtax: Families with taxable incomes above $250,000 would have their top rate increased to 39.6 10 percent.
Medicare tax: All earned income would be subject to the Medicare tax; $135,000 ceiling would be lifted.
Social Security: Relatively well-off people would pay taxes on 85 percent of Social Security benefits, up from 50 percent.
Energy tax: A tax placed on almost all forms of energy would eventually raise each family's annual fuel bills by $100 to $150.
 
Business:
Rates: Top corporate tax rate, now 34 percent, would rise to 36 percent.
Limited deductions: 50 percent of the cost of business meals and entertainment could be deducted, down from 80 percent.
Ending deductions: Businesses would be denied deductions for executives' pay above $1 million a year, for club dues for executives and for lobbying expenses.
 
TAX CUTS
Personal -- Credits for virtually all families with incomes below $30,000 to insure they pay no additional taxes.
Businesses -- A special capital gains break would be given for investments in small businesses held at least five years. Businesses would get an investment tax credit for the purchase of new equipment.
 
SPENDING INCREASES
New -- New spending would be allowed this year for construction projects, summer jobs, wastewater clean-up and childhood immunization.
Later -- Spending would be increased for transportation, education, job-training, technological research, Head Start and nutrition for pregnant women and small children.
 
SPENDING CUTS
Pay: Federal workers would skip a raise.
Science: Spending for the space station and the superconducting supercollider would be slowed.
Health: New limits on some payments to doctors, hospitals and laboratories under Medicare and Medicaid.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: In the Nation;
A Split Congress Sits Back and Listens, and Waits

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Democratic lawmakers broadly supported President Clinton's economic proposals tonight but said the plans would have to be modified to win majority support in Congress. Republicans heaped scorn on the whole package, saying it would unfairly sock the middle class with new taxes.
But Ross Perot, who still seems to informally represent a bloc of swing votes Mr. Clinton will need to get his programs passed, said he thought it was "a good speech." The President was so eager for the support of Mr. Perot, who got 19 million votes as an independent candidate for President in the last election, that he briefed him on his economic proposals by telephone before delivering them to Congress. 
 "I thought it was a very positive speech," Mr. Perot said in an appearance on the ABC news program "Nightline." "I would expect the American people to react favorably to it."
 
Reserving Judgment
 But Mr. Perot made clear that he was reserving final judgment on the Clinton program until after "we get into the details, and I can hardly wait to see the details." He said he and his supporters were still "skeptical" about giving Congress more money to spend through higher taxes, and that he still favored a balanced budget amendment that would tightly control spending.
While senators and representatives were also quick to voice their opinions, which predictably split along party lines, Clinton aides said they were eager to see how the package was being received by the voters.
Before Mr. Clinton spoke, lawmakers of both parties said their telephones had been ringing nonstop all day, with calls running heavily against the President's proposals, based on his own presentation of the economic package in a preview speech that had been broadcast from the Oval Office on Monday night.
Even Democrats said telephone calls to their offices were largely negative -- as much as 50 to 1 against new taxes, which Mr. Clinton, significantly, did not mention until toward the end of his address.
 
Little Bipartisan Support
 Whether that initial opposition will reflect the public mood now that Mr. Clinton has laid out his full program and embarks on a national campaign to sell it is impossible to predict.
What is already clear is that Mr. Clinton is not going to get the immediate bipartisan support he hoped for from Capitol Hill. Republicans lost no time in signaling that they would not accept Mr. Clinton's program with the ease with which many Democrats accepted President Ronald Reagan's economic program 12 years ago.
Indeed, Mr. Reagan himself, in an article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times on Thursday, is leading the charge against Mr. Clinton's plan, dismissing it as another version of "the failed liberal policies of the past."
 
Blows From Republicans
 In the official Republican rebuttal to Mr. Clinton, the House minority leader, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, clearly tried to avoid appearing obstructionist, saying Republicans "want our new President to succeed."
Some of the new programs Mr. Clinton is proposing, Mr. Michel added, may even be "laudable," but paying for them will require too many new taxes from too many Americans.
"When you hear a Democrat call for taxes, do not ask for whom the tax rises; it will rise for you," he said.
Given the Republican opposition, Clinton aides said the success of the plan would depend on how much weight the Democratic leadership in Congress would put behind it, in the face of the expected public outcries about higher taxes. Democrats control both houses by substantial margins.
"I am convinced the Congress will enact the program in its overall dimensions," said Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington state. "It is not going to be every line of the President's recommendations, but I think in great substance it will be enacted."
Just as crucial will be whether Mr. Perot throws his support behind the plan. As the President's staff courted Mr. Perot and his supporters, the White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, said Mr. Clinton called Mr. Perot to brief him on the plan. "A lot of the things that the President is addressing in this economic plan are things that Mr. Perot agrees with," she said.
In the view of many lawmakers, Mr. Perot, and the swing voters who have followed him, may be more influential than the Republicans.
 
View From Wall Street
 On Wall Street, Morris W. Offit, the chairman of Offitbank, an investment bank, predicted that business would, after some initial grumbling, support the program. But Mr. Offit warned of trouble if the White House asked for additional taxes to pay for other social welfare programs of the sort advocated by the President's wife, Hillary. After a substantial decline on Tuesday, stocks were mixed today as investors awaited details of the Clinton plan.
Republicans did not even wait for Mr. Clinton's speech to begin disparaging his proposals. They spent day passing out buttons around Capitol Hill that said, "It's Spending, Stupid!" and "Tax and Spend. Again," while taking turns lambasting Mr. Clinton's proposals from the House and Senate floor.
The Republicans based their attacks on two themes. One is that Mr. Clinton's proposals would soak the middle class, not the rich, and that this is exactly the opposite of what he promised in the Presidential campaign. The other is that new taxes now will smother the economic recovery and that what Mr. Clinton should instead cut more spending.
Republicans also criticized Mr. Clinton for emphasizing the new programs he plans to introduce, while minimizing exactly how he will pay for them with new taxes.
"Christmas came early," said Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader. "We haven't seen the spending cuts. He talked about what he's giving away, and that's about it."
Democrats, in the meantime, rallied behind Mr. Clinton, accusing the Republicans of trying to drum up hysteria. But behind their display of unity, many lawmakers expressed private concern about the public mood. Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said the President was going to have to "spend every day of the next 30" explaining his plan.
"Nobody likes taxes," said Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. "I assume Clinton wants to be fair, and from what I interpret, he is fair."
 
Deluge of Calls
 Nevertheless, lawmakers from both parties said their phones had been jammed for the past two days. Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, said he received "an overwhelming volume of calls" -- 50 to 1 -- opposed to tax increases. Elderly voters, in particular, were urging cuts in welfare rather than in Social Security payments or Medicare.
The initial negative reaction could be reversed by Mr. Clinton's public relations efforts, starting tonight. And early reactions to economic programs always change over time, especially when there are taxes involved.
But what the calls before the speech did suggest, lawmakers said, is that the President's speech on Monday night may have backfired. He had intended it to lay the political groundwork for his proposals tonight by letting Americans know how serious the economic problems were and how everyone would have to sacrifice to solve them. But his talk of new taxes and his playing down of Federal spending seemed to have triggered a wave of anxiety.
Mr. Dole said on the Senate floor this morning that his office had received 900 calls, which were running 17 to 1 against the Clinton plan.
But Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, predicted that the Clinton plan would ultimately be well received by the people, and he promised to cooperate with the President to secure speedy enactment of the proposals.
 
Some Changes Are Likely

 But Mr. Mitchell said it would be unrealistic to assume that even the Democratic-controlled House and Senate would not seek at least some changes in the President's proposals.
Some lawmakers, Democrats and Republicans alike, have expressed a fear that Mr. Clinton, in his zeal to persuade middle-class voters that the heaviest burdens of his program will be borne by the wealthy and corporations, may be treading dangerously close to encouraging class conflict.
"What is striking is that there is this class-warfare rhetoric, but what is creepy is how cynical it is," said William Kristol, who was chief of staff to former Vice President Dan Quayle. "He doesn't really believe in this rhetoric. He has a Cabinet full of lawyer millionaires."
Clinton aides say that the President needs a few enemies to cement a broad-based coalition behind his program, but that he is not out to attack the rich per se -- only those who came by their wealth by supposedly taking advantage of the relaxation of tax laws in the Reagan-Bush years.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: News Analysis;
Taste of Harsh Medicine

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Bill Clinton campaigned last year on the promise of economic change. Tonight he described in detail how difficult and painful that change would be.
Not since World War II has a President proposed such strong medicine. And not since Ronald Reagan 12 years ago called for a popular program of deep tax cuts and much more money for the Pentagon has a President recommended such a fundamental shift in how the Government operates. 
 After 12 years of Republican emphasis on low taxes and less Government involvement in domestic affairs, Mr. Clinton wants to raise taxes and expand Government investment in such areas as education and public works projects. He also wants to cut the budget deficit, which ballooned in the Republican years.
"Tonight," the President said at the outset of his address to Congress, "I want to talk about what Government can do, because I believe our Government must do more."
Mr. Clinton seemed to go out of his way to develop a plan that Americans would perceive as fair -- one that would require the wealthiest Americans to pay the most, that would put no particular industry or region of the country at a disadvantage while letting none off the hook completely, and that would wring some wasteful expenditures out of the Government.
 
Hitting Close to Home
 But fair or not, it would sting. Every household would pay more for gasoline and utilities, a reversal of the campaign promise to cut taxes for the middle class. Those families with incomes below $30,000 would have the new taxes all but offset by increased benefits. And Government programs that affect the pocketbooks of ordinary Americans -- Social Security, Medicare, student loans -- would be trimmed.
In his speech to Congress, Mr. Clinton played down the austerity at first, emphasizing instead his still unformed plans to change the health and welfare systems and establish a national service corps for young people. An hour into the speech, when he finally got around to tax increases and asked his audience for courage and contribution, he may have lost many of his television viewers. But the documents his staff distributed throughout the day left little doubt of the pain in what he was proposing.
The belt-tightening would not begin in earnest until next year. As a prelude, Mr. Clinton would try to create 500,000 new jobs nationwide this year by expanding Government spending on construction projects and giving tax breaks to businesses.
But the President's top economic planners said the main purpose of the program -- and the basis on which it should be judged -- was not what it would do to the economy this year but what it would do about turning the economy around over the long term.
The goal, said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of Mr. Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, was to "reverse a number of disturbing economic trends."
 
Too Much, Too Little
 Over the last two decades, Americans have consumed too much and saved and invested too little.
Family incomes have stagnated, even though many more families have two earners. The gap between the rich and the poor has widened.
And most important for budget purposes, the Federal deficit -- the difference between what the Government spends and what it gets in revenue from taxes -- is rising inexorably. Unless changes, big changes, are enacted, Leon E. Panetta, the budget director, said today, the deficit will exceed half a trillion dollars by the end of the decade.
 
What Kind of Solution?
 No economist disputes that those unhealthy trends exist. The only question is whether Mr. Clinton is attacking them the right way.
Republicans on Capitol Hill accused the President of insufficient zeal in reducing spending. Mr. Panetta said he welcomed suggestions for further reductions. He challenged them to come up with the programs they wanted to take the ax to.
"They'll give you a hell of a speech on the deficit," Mr. Panetta said of the Administration's critics. "Obviously, our confrontation is going to be on the specifics. If you're just going to give me the regular speech you give at the Rotary Club, forget it."
Mr. Panetta said during his confirmation hearings last month that he was shooting for $2 of spending cuts for every $1 of tax increases. The deficit-reduction package announced tonight was split almost evenly between lower spending and higher taxes.
 
A More Palatable Term
 And one of the most controversial items on the spending side of the ledger was actually a tax increase -- the higher-income taxes that would be imposed on Social Security benefits received by individuals with pretax incomes over $25,000 and couples with incomes over $32,000.
"We call it a spending cut because it actually reduces benefits," said Jack R. DeVore Jr., the chief Treasury spokesman. Ronald Reagan also called it a spending cut in 1983, when he signed the law first placing taxes on the Social Security benefits of more affluent retirees.
But this one shift allowed Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen to maintain today that Mr. Clinton's program, expected to raise taxes by $253 billion over five years, would not amount to the largest tax increase ever enacted.
The tax law Mr. Reagan proposed and signed in 1982, which mostly took away tax breaks enacted in 1981 and never put into effect, resulted in a tax increase on paper of $268 billion in 1993 dollars, Mr. Bentsen observed.
 
'A Sigh of Relief'
 "There was a sigh of relief when I saw that," Mr. Bentsen said. But if the $21 billion in higher taxes on Social Security benefits are counted, the Clinton program would be the largest tax increase ever.
The higher taxes on Social Security would affect fewer than one-quarter of retirees. Those taxes aside, the Administration's figures show that the wealthy would bear the brunt of the tax increases. Thirty percent of the higher taxes would be paid by taxpayers with incomes below $100,000, the Administration calculates; 70 percent would be paid by those with higher incomes.
Taxpayers earning more than $200,000 would see their taxes rise by about 3 percent. For those with incomes of $20,000 to $30,000, taxes would go up one-tenth of 1 percent, but that would be virtually offset by increased benefits.
Taxpayers with incomes of $30,000 to $50,000 would get a tax increase of about one-half of 1 percent, and those with incomes of $50,000 to $200,000 would have an increase of about three-quarters of 1 percent.
 
Embracing Pessimism
 For all but the most affluent, the higher taxes would be in the form of an energy tax passed on to customers by public utilities and gasoline stations. The typical cost to a family with an income of $40,000 would be about $120 a year, according to Treasury calculations that were confirmed by private authorities.
"There are no gimmicks," Mr. Panetta said. "There are no smoke and mirrors."
The Administration adopted the most pessimistic forecasts, worse than what Mr. Clinton's own Council of Economic Advisers recommended.
By forecasting the deficit to be much higher in the 1997 fiscal year than would have been the case with more optimistic projections, Mr. Clinton has an added excuse for breaking his campaign promise to cut the deficit in half. And if the size of the actual deficit has come down four years from now, his accomplishment will appear to be larger.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1205 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Then Again, It Could All Backfire

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
President Clinton's economic plan might not produce the burst of growth and new jobs he hoped for because of a phenomenon that economists love to dissect: unintended consequences.
On one hand, consumers could, as the President no doubt hopes, be cheered by his package of stimulus and deficit reduction measures and nudge the economy forward with increased spending. 
 But the opposite effect is also possible: If the specter of higher taxes drags down consumer confidence and frightens corporations and investors -- a mood in evidence in the stock market's jittery behavior this week -- it could be a recipe for slower growth.
And another unexpected factor emerged: Mr. Clinton's proposal got ashot in the arm today as investors pushed long-term interest rates to their lowest level since the mid-1980's in reaction to his plan to cut the deficit. This shows that many investors, who vote with their dollars, are convinced that he is serious about cutting the deficit and that his plan is credible.
 
Heavy on Deficit Reduction
 "The way I see this package is it's an ounce of stimulus and a ton of deficit reduction," said Laurence H. Meyer, an economist who heads a consulting firm in St. Louis. "He plans to cut the deficit by $140 billion in fiscal 1997 -- that's a lot."
Still, Mr. Clinton and his economic advisers are facing other problems. One is that the $31 billion stimulus package that the President proposed for the economy may take longer than anticipated to get off the ground because of possible delays in Congress.
For example, his popular proposal to create a new tax credit to encourage business investment could get bogged down in Congress along with the less welcome tax increases. This kind of delay means that much of his stimulus program might not have an effect until next year.
"It might really take a while for some of these projects to gear up, so you might need a microscope to see the stimulus this year," said Lawrence Chimerine, a senior economic consultant for DRI/McGraw-Hill, a consulting firm in Lexington, Mass.
Put another way, this means that President Clinton's plan to create 500,000 jobs this year through his stimulus program might be exaggerated. Many economists put the number of news jobs closer to 300,000.
Shortly after the November election, when Mr. Clinton's advisers were talking about a stimulus program without much pain attached and a larger investment tax credit than the one proposed, several economics consulting firms predicted that the stimulus plan would increase growth by one-half of 1 percent above the 3.1 percent forecast for this year. But now, as a result of the worries about tax increases and delays in enacting Mr. Clinton's package, many economists suggest that the stimulus package might increase growth by less than that.
Many companies are not rushing to do what Mr. Clinton hopes they will -- make new investments in plants and equipment -- because of concerns about a higher corporate income tax and because of possible delays in Congressional enactment of the proposed investment tax credit. These factors could also delay new hiring.
 
Welcoming Lower Interest
 All this negative news makes the recent decline in interest rates all the more welcome for Mr. Clinton. Lower rates should encourage a new wave of home-building and mortgage refinancings as well as give a new boost to business investment while his plan for an investment tax credit makes its way through Congress.
"The instrument of their growth stimulus package is increasingly one of low long-term interest rates rather than of lower taxes," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist with Morgan Stanley. "Lower interest rates might be a powerful enough stimulus to overcome some of the fears about jobs and taxes."
Interest rates fell in reaction to the President's speech Wednesday night because many investors were persuaded that he plans to chop forcefully at the deficit, a development investors believe will reduce risks of future inflation.
To be sure, investors recognize that Mr. Clinton's proposed deficit cuts are not yet set in concrete and that Congress may scale them back, or reject them altogether. But they seem so impressed by Mr. Clinton's commitment to deficit reduction that many economists expect long-term interest rates to fall under 7 percent. This would bring them to their lowest level since the 1970's.
In Congressional testimony today, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen sought to comfort middle-class Americans by noting that the benefits of low interest rates might offset the pain of a new energy tax. He said that while a typical middle-class family would lose $17 a month to the new energy tax, refinancing its mortgage at a lower interest rate would save it several times that much.
 
Clinton's Salesmanship Helps
 Despite some unintended pitfalls, there is still a chance that Mr. Clinton's economic plan could end up giving the economy as large a shot in the arm as he hoped. For example, consumer spending could continue to grow if he proves such an expert salesman in selling his economic plan that he keeps consumer confidence rising, notwithstanding the dismay about a new energy tax.
Besides, Mr. Clinton could receive some surprise help from the Federal Reserve. If economic growth falls far short of Mr. Clinton's expectations, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, could help bail out the President by lowering short-term interest rates.
"It's gong to take some time to pass a lot of this, said Henry Kaufman, who heads his own economics consulting firm in New York. "'In the front line of sustaining the economy, we'll continue to have the Federal Reserve. It was more than symbolic to have the chairman of the Federal Reserve sitting next to Hillary Clinton." He was referring to when the President spoke.
Mr. Kaufman said that giving Mr. Greenspan the seat of honor showed that the President was seeking no conflict with the central bank. He added that he thought the decline in long-term interest rates and the downward trend in inflation, despite the surprising jump in the January consumer price index, indicated that the Federal Reserve should be willing to cut interest rates further if the fragile economy stuttered again.
 
Hoping for a Thumbs Up
 Mr. Greenspan is scheduled to testify on Friday before the Senate Banking Committee, where he will no doubt be asked to give his opinion of the President's economic package. If he gives a thumbs up, it will be a boon for Mr. Clinton because it will reassure investors.
The fall in long-term interest rates may also bring some good news for the President's longer-term plans to rebuild the economy. For one, if the spending cuts and tax increases start to take effect next year, these factors would be a substantial drag on growth. Low long-term interest rates could go far to offset that.
Not only that, the Administration has touted its plan to invest more in education and in rebuilding highways and other public works as keys to increasing the nation's long-term prosperity. But it might turn out that lower long-term interest rates prove just as important in fueling long-term increases in investment and productivity.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: The Overview;
Battle Lines Begin to Form on Clinton Economic Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
The political debate over the budget began in earnest today as Republicans said President Clinton wanted to raise taxes without reducing Government spending enough and the President defended his program for improving the economy.
The debate over the President's program, on Capitol Hill and around the country, was fueled by new figures published by the White House showing that almost all the deficit reduction proposed for the next two years in the package Mr. Clinton outlined Wednesday would come from tax increases, with almost none from spending cuts. 
 The new, more complete budget tables made public today also showed clearly just how much the deficit would be cut under the Clinton plan. Instead of the $500 billion reduction over four years that was emphasized in some documents Wednesday and reported by The New York Times and some other news organizations, the cumulative reduction would be $325 billion, figuring in new spending the President proposes.
 
Cabinet on the Road
 Mr. Clinton promoted his plan at a rally in St. Louis, his first stop in a two-day trip to Missouri, Ohio and upstate New York. Almost all the members of his Cabinet and many other top officials were also on the road today to pitch the proposals. By the end of the day, Administration officials had appeared in more than 25 states.
Meanwhile, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and the budget director, Leon E. Panetta, went before the Congressional budget committees, the first step in what will probably be a tortuous journey as Congress deals with the proposals. Congressional Democrats were largely supportive of the President today, but Republicans took aim at what they called insufficient spending cuts.
The bond market showed strong support for the President. The 30-year Treasury bond, the best gauge of the long-term interest rates that must drop if Mr. Clinton's economic program is to succeed, fell to 7.02 percent, the lowest since the Government began selling such securities in 1977. [Page D1.]
Mr. Clinton acknowledged the Republican criticism in his speech at Union Station in St. Louis, but he and his Cabinet secretaries maintained that the new Government spending they sought was a new kind of spending: a down payment on jobs and economic growth, not money to finance wasteful consumption today.
"I do propose to spend some more money," Mr. Clinton said, "but not in the old way. Look at what we spend it for. We have reduced Government consumption. We have reduced inessential programs.
"But we increased spending on jobs, a jobs program to create a half a million jobs starting right now -- in building roads, repairing streets, fixing airports, cleaning up the environment with water systems and sewer systems, a million summer jobs for young people, if I can get the private sector to contribute to the 700,000 we're going to create in the Government."
Overnight polls showed strong support for the President. A CNN/USA Today telephone poll of 514 adults who said they watched the address Wednesday night found that 79 percent supported Mr. Clinton's plan, while 16 percent opposed it.
Mr. Clinton's package, the toughest budget-cutting program proposed by a President since World War II, would raise taxes and lower Government spending so that the annual deficit, now more than $300 billion, would be reduced by $140 billion by the 1997 fiscal year, the last of Mr. Clinton's term.
Over five years, the deficit reduction would come almost equally from spending cuts and tax increases.
The main elements would be higher income taxes on families with incomes above about $180,000, new taxes on energy that would cost most families $100 to $150 a year, reduced military spending, a freeze in the pay of Government workers, limits in Medicare and Medicaid payments to doctors and hospitals and relatively small spending cuts in many other Government programs.
The budget documents published today show that while the deficit would be cut by $39 billion next year and $54 billion in 1995, Government spending, now more than $1 trillion a year, would be reduced by only $5 billion next year and $6 billion in 1995. All the rest of the deficit reduction in those years would be accomplished by tax increases. Only in the last two years of Mr. Clinton's term would spending cuts begin to bite.
 
The Politics of Economics
 Questions about taxes and spending have been the main battleground of partisan conflict in American politics over the last two decades. When Republicans have been able to persuade the public that taxes were being wasted, they have generally been elected. When Democrats have been able to show that the Government was paying insufficient attention to the public's needs, they have normally won.
In their appearances before the Congressional committees, Mr. Panetta and Mr. Bentsen were assailed by Republicans as being big taxers and spenders.
In a typical exchange, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, declared: "What I'd like to know is what the heck went wrong in Year 1? Why not have the cuts now and the taxes later rather than what we always see, which are the taxes now?"
In response, Mr. Panetta argued that deep cuts in spending now would "cause even greater consternation with regards to the economy."
Mr. Panetta was chairman of the Budget Committee until he left Congress this year to join the Clinton Administration. Normally mild and affable, he is popular among Democrats and Republicans. But in exasperation today, he finally told the Republicans, "You are the perfect example of the gridlock the American people are tired of."
In the Senate hearing, Mr. Bentsen challenged the Republicans to name the precise places they wanted to cut spending.
The Treasury Secretary, a Senator from Texas before he joined the Cabinet, was questioned sharply about his assertion that an increase in the taxes on Social Security payments received by affluent retirees was a spending cut and not a tax increase. Mr. Bentsen said it was properly characterized as a spending cut because Social Security benefits would, in effect, be taken back by the Government.
At a breakfast meeting with reporters, Vice President Al Gore said that the Administration was prepared to work with Congress on modifications in the economic plan but that "the main components all have to be there in order for the plan to be successful."
While it is far too early to gauge how the Clinton plan will fare in Congress, the Administration could take heart that the criticism came almost entirely from Republicans.
The Democratic leaders in the Senate and House went out of their way to praise the program and to emphasize the importance of demonstrating that the President and Congress could work together for the good of the country.
Some Democratic backbenchers objected to particular proposals that would harm their constituents. For example, Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota said he was worried about proposed cuts in farm subsidies. But the public support for the overall program among Democrats was solid, at least for today.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: News Analysis;
Fragile Plan for Change

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
It was a staggeringly long agenda that President Clinton laid before Congress and the nation Wednesday night, and his aides say he plans to press for much of it in his first year in office.
Not only does he intend to undo the Reagan revolution by increasing taxes, slashing the military budget, trimming spending here on some old projects, increasing it there on some new ones; he also proposes to create an entirely new system of health care, to reform campaign laws, to launch a service corps, to "end welfare as we know it," to impose gun controls, and on and on. 
 The last President to try anything on that scale was Lyndon B. Johnson, and he had a lot of things going for him that Bill Clinton does not have.
But Mr. Clinton believes that after months of talking about change, the moment for action is at hand, a genuinely pivotal moment for the nation, and that only a bold challenge from the White House stands a chance of success.
As a senior White House strategist said today, "The voters gave us a mandate for change, if they did anything, and we have to make everyone and everything that stands in our way look like a roadblock on the highway to the progress the country demands."
 
A Winning Combination
 So Mr. Clinton expresses exasperation with "all the naysayers" and earnestly seeks the cooperation of Ross Perot. Together, with both opposing the status quo, they won 62 percent of the popular vote last year; together, they might move Congress in their direction. In an interview today, Mr. Perot outlined an agenda that goes well beyond the President's, which could help Mr. Clinton by making his list of programs seem a more temperate alternative.
But Mr. Perot is not ready to put his stamp of approval on the Clinton plan, and even if he did it is not clear that he can transform votes for him into effective pressure on Republican and Democratic members of Congress.
Much will depend on how deeply the nation believes that the mushrooming deficit represents a true national crisis, and how persuasively it communicates its feelings to Capitol Hill. In the two years that Johnson pushed through the main elements of his Great Society legislation, he benefited from a sense of crisis brought on by the civil rights movement and from the shock delivered to the national psyche by the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
 
The Battle of Perceptions
 Beyond that, much will depend on the battle of perceptions that was joined today. Republicans, led by the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, argue that the proposed attack on the deficit relies too much on new taxes and too little on spending cuts.
The White House's own figures, ambiguous on Wednesday night, showed clearly today that all of the deficit reduction in the next two years will come out of new taxes rather than a combination of taxes and spending cuts. The cuts will begin to contribute only in 1995 and 1996.
In one of the more damaging thrusts in a long diatribe against the President's proposals, Senator Dole noted that both Lloyd M. Bentsen, the Treasury Secretary, and Leon E. Panetta, the budget director, had pledged to seek $2 in spending cuts for every $1 in new taxes, and that the nation's governors had suggested a 2.75-to-1 ratio. The new White House figures suggest that over the next four years the Administration is now aiming at gaining only 43 percent of deficit reduction from spending cuts, and 57 percent from tax increases -- a ratio of slightly more than $2 in cuts for every $3 in taxes.
Mr. Clinton responded by challenging the Republicans to suggest further targets for cuts, hoping to portray them as barons of gridlock.
 
Johnson's Big Advantage
 
 
But all of this is preliminary skirmishing. Johnson was able to push through his programs not only because of a mood of national peril, but also because of huge majorities in the Senate and House of Representatives that Mr. Clinton simply does not have. The Democrats began 1965 with a 36-seat majority in the Senate and a 118-seat majority in the House, making success all but automatic. This year the Democratic majorities are 14 and 84, which means the President will have to work much harder to keep his party in line.
That is no longer as easy as it was 30 years ago, to say the least. The evolution of the mass media has made direct communication between voter and representative more important, in many cases, than the influence of the White House. Party leaders on Capitol Hill no longer control very many votes.
If the radio and television talk shows begin over the next week or so to produce a consensus unfavorable to the President -- if, for instance, the idea takes hold that, as in the past, the new taxes are sure to materialize and the spending cuts may not -- the fairly solid Democratic front that was on display today may start to crumble.
"We want to vote with our President," said a leading moderate Democrat in the Senate. "We have waited a long, long time to have one of ours at the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue. But some of us will find it hard to support this package in the end, if the public sees it as all tax and no cut."
A special target for Mr. Clinton is the lower-middle-class suburban voter. In the thousands, these so-called Reagan Democrats deserted George Bush last fall, voting either for Mr. Clinton or for Mr. Perot. William Kristol, who was chief of staff to former Vice President Dan Quayle, commented today that the President tried Wednesday night to convince them that government could again be their friend by distributing the tax burden as he did and by emphasizing government programs of direct help to them, like education and jobs, and not divisive social initiatives.
But such voters, whose decisions to give Mr. Clinton a try made it possible for him to carry such swing states as Ohio, Michigan, Illinois and Missouri, remain highly skeptical about government and its propensity to tax.
 
Picking the Package Apart
 Equally dangerous to Mr. Clinton, as he himself said candidly on Wednesday night, is the possibility that the lawmakers might start to pick the package apart under pressure from constituents or lobbyists or both, choosing to accommodate one industry but not another, to penalize one interest group but not another -- and undo a very subtle, careful political balancing act.
The President had to get something from the middle class, for example, even though he had promised them a tax cut. There were not enough rich people to generate the revenue he needed. But he sought to retain his populist political cover by socking the rich hard and limiting the increased demand on most middle-class families to $100 or $200 a year. That, in turn, required reassurance to business, which took the form of interpolated pledges in his speech and a number of investment incentives and other concessions.
But pull this string or that, and the whole thing might unravel quickly, no matter how skillful the knitting that put it together in the first place.
And if Mr. Clinton's economic program cannot be pushed through more or less intact, some of the wind will go out of the Administration's sails, and the prospects for reforming health care, an even more divisive subject, will dim, however brave the resolve at the White House. Finding an Attorney General and dealing with homosexuals in the military may have been one-week wonders; the results of the struggle that began in earnest today will play and play.

GRAPHIC: Photo: During President Clinton's address to the nation on Wednesday night, Democratic members of Congress broke into applause as the President proposed a new system of health care and to "end welfare as we know it." The Republican members of Congress showed much less enthusiasm. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. A15)
