HEADLINE: Germans Feel Pain of Unity, Squabbling Over Who Pays

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Feb. 18

 BODY:
When Germany was reunited in October 1990 and the way ahead looked clear and rosy, Chancellor Helmut Kohl told his people that no one would feel any pain.
More than two years later, the industrial powerhouse in the western half is sinking fast into recession, with unemployment now at 7.4 percent and rising. Instead of blooming, the formerly Communist economy in the eastern half collapsed under the pressure of competition, dragging the rest of the country with it and stirring widespread anger and frustration. 
 As in the United States, talk of "sacrifice" is now the order of the day, and there is also little agreement here on the need for it.
Mr. Kohl has begun telling the 62 million western Germans that helping their 16 million poorer cousins in the east to rebuild their part of the country is going to cost so much that they will have to pay higher taxes and suffer deep cuts in the welfare state that made Germans the envy of most of the rest of Europe for 40 years.
Investors and employers have also begun to tell eastern Germans that they cannot expect to have, overnight, the same high standard of living as the west. The business executives are also saying they want to go back on rash promises they made while the economy was booming last year to raise salaries quickly.
 
Crackdown on Extremists
 Hostility between German haves and have-nots is rising by the day, part of the frustration that led to more than 2,000 attacks against foreigners, mostly asylum-seekers, by right-wing radicals and neo-Nazi skinheads last year.
The Government authorities say the pace of those attacks has diminished since a crackdown on extremist groups that began in November.
Thomas Petereit, a fitter in the Thyssen steel works in the western German industrial city of Duisburg, hard hit by a crisis in the steel industry caused largely by cheap competition from eastern Europe, put his finger on the mood in the Ruhr industrial district.
"I'm sorry to say it, but some people on the factory floor are saying we shouldn't have let the Berlin wall be torn down," he said.
Many people in eastern Germany, having been led to expect nearly instant economic gratification from unification, felt cheated when they lost their jobs, and they do not understand the argument that raising wages to western levels now will guarantee that they lose still more.
Last week, 16,000 east German metalworkers took to the streets of Magdeburg to demand that employers honor an agreement to raise their average wages by 26 percent this year, to bring them to 82 percent of western levels.
"After the biggest demonstration in Magdeburg since the collapse of Communism, I see no way we should let the employers go back on their word," said Claus Martecki, a union leader there. "If we do without wage increases, that isn't going to bring a single additional order to any factory here."
 
'Solidarity Pact' Proves Elusive

Last fall, in an appeal similar to the one President Clinton voiced this week, Mr. Kohl called for a "solidarity pact" among the major political parties, labor unions and industry to agree on the tax increases, spending cuts and wage restraints to make unification work. But the public debate about such an accord has been raging for weeks, and is not sounding much like "solidarity" at all.
The squabbling over the costs of reunification has given all German politics a bad name, with many people wondering whether the country is capable of tackling its most pressing problems. Mr. Kohl's popularity ratings have sunk almost continuously since he won the election in 1990, but nobody else is doing much better.
Mr. Kohl's many critics charge that the Chancellor has asked for less sacrifice from business and the independently wealthy than from western German workers who have long since begun feeling the economic pinch. But the debate also reflects a broader European undercurrent of unease about just what the well-off welfare states of western Europe are in for now that the Iron Curtain is gone and those who lived under Communism are beginning to demand a piece of the good life.
Only a year ago, in the midst of the now-vanished boom, it had not really dawned on western Germans that life might no longer be one annual salary raise after another and ever-shorter working hours. Last April, public-sector labor unions in western Germany threw the country into chaos, with bus, rail and garbage strikes demanding double-digit wage increases on top of even larger raises that the easterners were demanding, from a much lower base.
The unions ended up last year with 5.4 percent raises, but this year, sobered by the realization that the state is short of money and already mortgaged to the hilt by record debts incurred to pay for unification, they have just settled for 3 percent -- a percentage point below inflation.
 
Official Plans Touch Off Protests
 The Government's plans for a package of spending cuts and extra taxes as part of the solidarity pact began leaking out last year, touching off the first ripples of resentment in the west against those in the east. Newspapers warned direly, for instance, that people using municipal swimming pools in the west would shiver because the water temperature would have to be lowered a couple of degrees to pay for similar luxuries in the east.
When the Government's proposals for cuts in social programs were formally announced last month, they were roundly rejected by the Social Democratic opposition and the labor unions for placing what the critics said was too great a burden on the western Germans least able to pay.
With total unemployment rising to 3.5 million, the governing coalition led by Mr. Kohl proposed reducing unemployment insurance payments from 68 percent of net pay to 67 percent for jobless people with dependents and 65 percent for single people.
The governing coalition also proposed a surcharge on income taxes for all taxpayers, but not until 1995. It allowed a one-year, 7.5 percent unification surcharge on western Germans' income tax to lapse in June.
The new tax would apply to corporations as well as individuals, but the Government did not say how big it would be. Nor did the Government ask well-off taxpayers to give up state child payments that now go to rich and poor alike, or suggest that highly paid civil servants and self-employed people should contribute to unemployment insurance, from which they are now exempt. These steps had reportedly been under consideration.
"The plan is a huge disappointment from the eastern German point of view," said Wolfgang Thierse, an opposition Social Democratic leader from the east. "It picks on the weak and forces them to bear most of the burdens. It will create a growing mood of hostility among the little people to the 'Ossis.' " That is the derogatory term western Germans use for people from the east.
The Social Democrats suggested this week that the wealthy should start paying more taxes this summer, a proposal immediately rejected by the Government. But even the opposition concedes that the high-spending welfare state has to cut back on spending to finance the $65 billion a year that reconstruction of the east is expected to cost, for the next ten years.
 
West Sees East As Just Greedy
 In the east, officially, there are 1.2 million jobless, 14.7 percent of the labor force, but many more than that are in retraining programs and short-hours programs that keep them off the jobless rolls. A majority of the unemployed in the east are women.
In the eastern German state of Saxony, after the metalworking industry asked for a revision of a contract that called for wages in eastern Germany to rise this year to 82 percent of western levels -- and 100 percent by next year -- the unions insisted on sticking to the original contract.
Today the industry responded by unilaterally canceling the contracts, and the union threatened to strike. As part of worker unrest, 20,000 East German steelworkers took to the streets in Chemnitz to demand their raises.
Many people in the west see the eastern attitude as short-sighted and greedy. But if wages do not rise quickly to western levels, politicians and economists say, eastern Germans will just move west to get them, as more than a million have done since 1989.
"In a population that has accepted the fact that up to 70 or 80 percent of the employees in some factories in our part of the country have been let go, the idea that people in the west are undergoing real hardship is simply incomprehensible," Dr. Kurt Biedenkopf, the Governor of Saxony, said last month.
"Any agreement on a solidarity package has to make it clear and understandable to people that it would be no catastrophe for the 80 percent of Germans who live in the west if their disposable income were not to grow for a considerable time," he said.
 
Steelworkers Worried by Layoffs
 In Duisburg, in the heart of the gritty Ruhr, a visitor to the giant Thyssen works found steelworkers uneasy.
"We've already made our sacrifice," said Manfred Siebierski, chairman of the factory's works council. Steelworkers settled in December for an 18-month contract that gives them a wage increase of only 3.1 percent. "What we hear on the factory floor is: 'It's somebody else's turn,' " Mr. Siebierski said.
One reason why German labor relations have been viewed as a model by most other Europeans for 40 years is that many disputes are resolved by institutions like works councils, where labor and management work out problems before they become major disputes.
With no substantial labor unrest, Thyssen has retired thousands of steelworkers in the last few years, and other have accepted short shifts to save their jobs.
But Thyssen also plans to eliminate 8,000 more of its 37,000 steelmaking jobs here and at other plants in western Germany over the next couple of years.
Steelworkers demonstrated in the Ruhr today and have called for a protest march on Bonn on March 26 to force the Government to come up with a plan to protect their jobs.
How Germans handle the problems of unification has effects far beyond their borders. Heavy Government borrowing to finance unification caused the independent central bank, the Bundesbank, to push up short-term interest rates to record levels to forestall inflation, now running above 4 percent, but the increase pushed Germany into recession.
Central banks all over Western Europe have tried to avoid devaluing their currencies by also raising interest rates, making the recession bite deeper and creating political tensions through most of the European Community.
 
Will the Burdens Be Shared Fairly?
 Mr. Kohl, who had originally intended to have the solidarity pact in place by the end of last year, now wants to thrash out agreement with political leaders and state governors a month from now.
"The key question is whether the package is seen to be a fair distribution of the burdens on all taxpayers," said Ernst Kock, an official of the national public employees' union in Berlin.
With the post-unification boom now clearly over and joblessness rising, there are signs of moderation in wage demands by western German unions, but this could bring tensions of its own.
"At the same time as we are experiencing an economic crisis, we are beginning to see that even hard work will not necessarily lead to a higher standard of living," Edzard Reuter, managing board chairman of Daimler Benz A.G., the Stuttgart automotive giant, warned in an article in the weekly Die Zeit recently.
Many experts believe that the German standard of living, like the American one, is probably in for a long period of stagnation, and perhaps even some decline, for the first time in the history of the Federal Republic.
A recent manifesto by former Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, Mr. Reuter and five others poses the key question: "Will democracy continue to be accepted if it can't justify itself by constantly improving the well-being of its citizens?"

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: The President's Day;
CLINTON CAMPAIGNS FOR TIGHTER BELTS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 18

 BODY:
President Clinton and his top aides today began a cross-country public relations blitz to sell his economic proposals, with the President urging receptive spectators in St. Louis to let their Congressmen know they will not be punished for making "tough, hard decisions."
Addressing several thousand people packed into the old passenger hall and stairways of Union Station here, the President said that giving elected lawmakers political breathing room on budget cuts and tax increases was the only way his program would get through Congress. 
 Mr. Clinton also opened his counterattack against Republicans, who assert that his plan calls for too many new taxes and too few spending cuts.
 
Energized by Campaigning
 "I have already heard some people on the other side of the aisle say, 'He should have cut more,' " said Mr. Clinton, who seemed to be energized by being back on the campaign trail. "I say: 'Show me where, and be specific -- not hot air. Show me where.' "
While Mr. Clinton's trip here was the most visible, most of his Cabinet fanned out around the country today to join in the drive. Some members returned to their home states as favorite sons or daughters.
Like a candidate taking his basic stump speech on the road, Mr. Clinton repeated the main themes of his address to Congress on Wednesday night, again using most of his time to talk about his proposed spending cuts and new programs and soft-pedaling how much in new taxes it would all cost.
But there was no doubt about his main argument to the St. Louis crowd and the rest of the country -- that people should reject the notion that nothing in Washington can ever change and let senators and representatives know they will not be thrown out of office if they agree to raise taxes or cut spending programs.
"There are already people saying that we really can't make fundamental change -- you can't bring the deficit down, or nobody will hang in there and make these tough budget cuts the President's proposing, or you can't really reform the health-care system," Mr. Clinton said. "I am tired of all the naysayers. I think we can make some changes, but we need your help."
 
Wearing Their Buttons
 A random sampling of the crowd gathered in Union Station -- many clearly Clinton supporters, some wearing leftover campaign buttons, but many just passing by on their way to the shopping center in the old depot -- showed support for the main themes in the President's speech to Congress.
Virtually every one of 30 or more people interviewed said they endorsed the view that it was time to sacrifice to turn the country around, and that they felt that Mr. Clinton's proposals would evenly spread the tax burden.
"I don't have a problem with it," said Carla Green, a 30-year-old waitress. "I am not in a big-income bracket. He is going to help me. That itty-bitty energy tax is like the difference between whether my son and I order a pizza in the house one night, or not. My dad, who is in the income bracket that is going to be affected, said to me: 'You're going to give up a pizza. I am going to give up a $200 dinner with wine, but we've all got to do something.' It's just the way it is."
Mr. Clinton seemed intent on casting the terms of the political debate in a way that put him and his program on the same side as the public in a battle against business as usual, special interests, Republicans and whatever other opposition he might face in Congress.
 
Which Price Is Higher?
 "We need you to tell your members of Congress that we will support you if you make the honest, tough, hard decisions," he said. "We know we didn't get into this mess overnight. We know we are not going to get out of it overnight, but we cannot keep doing the same old thing. The price of doing the same thing is higher than the price of change."
Mr. Clinton also sought to paint some lawmakers as being in the grip of special interests, who he said were already choking the halls of Congress to block many of his proposals.
"The second thing you can do," said Mr. Clinton, who was introduced by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, "is support your members of Congress by demanding real political reform that will protect them in making courageous decisions."
 
Bonanza for Lobbyists
 Mr. Clinton's own economic and health-care proposals have created a bonanza for Washington lobbying organizations, who have been signing up customers who want to influence the package. And while Mr. Clinton has been urging campaign-finance reform, it is unlikely that he will press that too heavily on Congress this year, when he is already asking for some very tough votes on the economy.
While most of the signs echoed Mr. Clinton's message, there were a few that carried the Republican warning that people should watch their wallets. Or as one sign put it, "The Devil is in the Details: Proceed with Caution."
The President pointed that one out himself, chuckled and said, "That's right, the devil is in the details."
Mr. Clinton and his aides seemed buoyant, not only at their reception in St. Louis, but at the early polls that show strong support for his proposals. Aides say they think the success or failure of Mr. Clinton's campaign, which is to move to Hyde Park, N.Y., Friday and to the West Coast over the weekend after a stop tonight in Ohio, will set the tone, and may determine the fate, of his Presidency. They said the President's trip is only the first in what could be weekly whistle-stop tours for the next six months.
 
'A Lot of Courage'
 Kitty Coyne, a 34-year-old biologist who waited for hours to hear the President, said she thought his speech was "honest and told people that they will have to pay something, if they expect to get something. I thought it took a lot of courage."
Diana Rickard, a 39-year-old title researcher, said what she liked most in Mr. Clinton's proposal was "how he said that everyone is going to have to make a sacrifice."
But some people remained highly skeptical that his initiative would survive. "I enjoyed every moment of his speech," said Marcella Haessig, a 68-year-old retiree. "But I think he will have great difficulty passing some of this because of the Congress. But we've just got to make some changes."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: The Vice President;
In Selling His Boss's Domestic Program, Gore Is Also Selling Himself

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore kicked off a high-profile effort to sell the Administration's economic package today with a round of meetings and travels that could enhance his stature as an important adviser to President Clinton.
Mr. Gore has been a constant presence at the economic policy meetings and Cabinet sessions that the President has held since he took office. But his role has often been overshadowed in news reports by accounts of the influence of Mr. Clinton's wife, Hillary. 
 Mr. Gore set out to alter that impression today. He appeared on three television talk shows this morning and spent the rest of the day meeting with reporters and members of Congress. He will leave Friday on his own sales trip, traveling to Raleigh, N.C.; Atlanta; Birmingham, Ala., and Tampa, Fla. And on Sunday he will join the President on a trip to the West Coast.
Seated behind Mr. Clinton at Wednesday night's speech to the joint session of Congress, Mr. Gore nodded his head in agreement as the President made his points. On one occasion he even motioned silent Republicans in the chamber to join their Democratic counterparts in applauding Mr. Clinton's call for gun controls.
"Maybe there was a slight bit of a taunt in it," Mr. Gore acknowledged today, smiling.
 
Vivid Sailboat Image
 He did more than taunt his former colleagues. He goaded them, and made it clear where his loyalties lie.
"Political change has sometimes been described as the metaphor of a sailboat tacking against the wind," the former Senator from Tennessee said at a breakfast meeting with reporters. "When one side comes up out of the water, it's a vivid image. That image and that metaphor remind me very much of what happened in the chamber last night.
"I saw the mirror image of it during the beginning of the Reagan era, when one side of the chamber stands and applauds wildly and the other side sits with their hands folded in their laps," he continued. "Visually, the image is very much that of a great ship changing course, with one side out of the water and the other, sort of sinking."
Mr. Gore played the role of negotiator today, meeting in his Capitol Hill office with three Democratic Senators, Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland and Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina.
 
'Time to Face the Facts'
 For critics of Mr. Clinton's economic program, the Vice President, who normally measures every word for weight and diplomacy, carried an unusually blunt message. "Put up or shut up," he said at the breakfast meeting. "It's time to face the facts."
In a New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted last week, 44 percent of the registered voters surveyed said they did not know enough about Mr. Gore to have an opinion of him, up from the 14 percent who offered that response in October. The evidence that he has been shrinking in the public eye mirrors a similar phenomenon with Vice President Dan Quayle in 1989.
The difference between the two men, however, is that most of those who say they are familiar with Mr. Gore have favorable impressions of him. The opposite was the case with Mr. Quayle.
Mr. Gore's aides insist that the Vice President, who jokes about references to how stiffly he stands behind the President at public sessions, is not trying to change his image.
"It's all about the same thing," said Marla Romash, the Vice President's press secretary. "And that is doing as much as possible to help President Clinton."
 
Few Scores to Settle
 But before he gets to the American people, Mr. Gore, who the President said would be his chief emissary to the Congress, seems to have a few other scores to settle on his old turf.
He was not happy at all, for instance, when Republican members of Congress laughed at the President outright on Wednesday night when Mr. Clinton sought to illustrate the veracity of his budget numbers by crediting the underlying assumptions to the Congressional Budget Office.
Mr. Clinton, a bit rattled by the outburst, snapped at the lawmakers, challenging them to come up with better spending cuts.
"It was a serious overplaying of their hand," Mr. Gore said sternly today. "And the President yanked them up short. And they knew it. And the laughter from the Republican side was consciously dishonest."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Projections on Interest Costs Confuse the Treasury Market

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Traders and dealers in the Treasury market were confused yesterday by the Clinton Administration's projections that the Government would save $11.5 billion in interest expense over the next four years by shifting away from longer-term securities and selling more shorter-term issues instead.
The subject is of vital importance to Treasury dealers because a shift in the mix of securities sold would influence the price of outstanding long-term notes and bonds, as well as the direction of long-term interest rates. For one thing, a scarcity of longer-term issues is likely to push up their prices, thereby reducing yields. 
 Speculation remained intense that the Treasury, which began to reduce the size of 30-year bond auctions during the Bush Administration, would continue and perhaps accelerate the shift with the Clinton Administration in power.
 
 
Potential Windfall
 On the surface, a shift away from long-term notes and bonds to short-term bills looks like it could be a potential windfall for the Government, because short-term interest rates are currently about four full percentage points lower than 30-year bond yields.
Still, analysts said they were skeptical about the projected interest savings. Short-term interest rates would need to remain low over the next four years to meet the projections, they said, and that assumption may rest on increasingly shaky ground as the economy recovers.
Moreover, huge amounts of debt now sold through 10-year notes and 30-year bonds would need to be sold instead as three-month Treasury bills in order to meet the estimated savings.
Finally, with 30-year bond yields at historic lows, traders and analysts questioned the wisdom of selling less long-term debt. "The Treasury makes every effort to sell its debt in the least costly, most efficient way," said Richard M. Kelly, chairman and chief executive of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a primary dealer in Government securities. "But given their huge borrowing needs currently and prospectively, it makes no sense to be cutting back in any maturity area."
 Questions about the Administration's projections and tactics intensified as the day wore on, especially so after Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen told reporters that while the Treasury was studying the matter there would be no "radical change" in the mix of Treasury securities to be sold.
"I had been assuming that a major reduction in the amount of bonds to be sold was virtually assured," said Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, a Wall Street economic consulting firm. "But Secretary Bentsen's muddied the waters all over again."
In fact, Mr. Bentsen's comments yesterday seemed consistent with what the Treasury said and did late last month, when it announced the quarterly refunding auctions held in early February.
At that time, the Treasury cut the amount of 30-year bonds sold to $9 billion from $10 billion.
However, the estimated interest savings released late Wednesday were not produced by the Treasury Department, but by White House budget director Leon Panetta's Office of Management and Budget.
 Last year, the Bush Administration, seeking to take advantage of low short-term interest rates, cut the size of the 30-year bond auctions from $11 billion.
Mr. Crandall said he assumed the Treasury would move to eliminate the bond auctions altogether because according to his estimates the more than $11 billion in projected interest savings could not be realized unless the Treasury increased the size of its three-month bills by around $36 billion.
Currently, the Government sells about $20 billion of three-month and six-month bills each week.
A spokesman at O.M.B., who asked not to be identified, said the budget office had been in close consultation with the Treasury before making its projections.
"There are ways of accomplishing this that are entirely reasonable," the spokesman said.
But some analysts said they were not so sure. They wondered if, under intense pressure to produce evidence of savings on a tight deadline, the budget office made some unrealistic assumptions.
 "It's called a plug, and I wouldn't be surprised if that isn't what they did " said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear Stearns & Company who served as David Stockman's chief economist at the budget office during the first Reagan Administration. "You find you have a hole in your numbers, and you plug it."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: Ross Perot;
Perot Sees Some Good Intentions But Too Much Old-Time Politics

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Ross Perot said today that it was "completely unrealistic to expect meaningful cuts in Government spending from Congress" as long as the present political ground rules remain in force.
Speaking on the morning after President Clinton unveiled an economic program combining spending cuts and increased taxes in an effort to reduce the deficit, Mr. Perot praised Mr. Clinton for "assembling a team full of wonderful intentions." He also said he thought the President understood "the disaster of these huge deficits." 
 But Mr. Perot, who was briefed by Mr. Clinton on the plan Wednesday afternoon, said he was not prepared to take a definitive position on the President's package, because he was unsure how large the spending cuts would be. He had not yet seen the detailed charts, made public by the White House only this morning, that indicated that the net spending cuts were much smaller, especially in the first two years of Mr. Clinton's term, than had originally been suggested.
Mr. Perot, who opposed Mr. Clinton in the 1992 campaign, controls no votes on Capitol Hill, but his populist ideas have a wide following throughout the country. He is organizing intensely in many states; this weekend, he has planned appearances in six Florida cities.
 
The Importance of Perot
 The question is whether he can convert his personal popularity into effective pressure on senators and representatives. The President thought enough of Mr. Perot's potential to make the telephone call on Wednesday, and some Clinton aides consider backing from the Texan an important element in building a coalition behind the economic plan.
"If you want the American people to pay more taxes, then I think they're willing," Mr. Perot said. "But first we need honest government."
For himself and his pressure group, United We Stand, America, "job No.1 is political reform, because we won't get our finances in order until you change the system," Mr. Perot said in a telephone interview from his private jet as he flew from New York to Dallas. As things now stand, he asserted, lobbyists for corporations and interest groups will find it "easy pickings" to persuade Congress to block the President's proposed cuts.
"If you wanted to get rich, there's no place better to be than a Washington lobbyist," Mr. Perot said. "They've got all these senators and Congressmen who need to raise all this money for their campaigns. Well, those officeholders will get enough in the next 30 to 60 days to take care of them for years, and the payoff will be elimination of most of the cutbacks."
 
A Barely Addressed Agenda
 For that reason, he said, his group has a detailed agenda that Mr. Clinton barely began to address in his speech to Congress on Wednesday night.
The agenda includes a balanced budget amendment, a line-item veto power for the President, the elimination of all political action committees and their contributions to candidates, an end to the use of the Social Security trust fund for general Federal purposes and the curbing of foreign lobbyists.
Mr. Perot, who won almost 19 percent of the vote in last November's election, said he had little confidence in the Congressional leadership because "there is still a compulsion to spend, but there's no compulsion to cut."
"The key question is whether we get what we pay for," he added. "Are the taxes really going to be used on the deficit, or on more spending? Is spending really going to be cut, or are you going to end up with $1.83 in new spending for every dollar raised, the way we have so many times in the past?"

HEADLINE: Republicans Honor Weinberger

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
At a gathering of conservatives attended by three of the men pardoned by President George Bush for their roles in the Iran-Contra affair, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas tonight paid an emotional tribute to Caspar W. Weinberger, the Defense Secretary in the Reagan Administration, for having escaped the relentless efforts of the special prosecutor in the case, Lawrence W. Walsh.
Senator Dole, the minority leader, called Mr. Walsh, "Not a prosecutor, but a persecutor," and added, "It seems to me that the time has come for Lawrence Walsh to move on to another line of work." 
 The banquet was the culmination of the Conservative Political Action Conference. Early in the day, conservative politicians like the Rev. Pat Robertson and Patrick J. Buchanan made it clear in a string of stinging speeches that they were not ready to go along with the trend toward greater moderation that many Republican leaders have urged in the wake of Mr. Bush's defeat last fall.
 
Attacking Clinton Plan
 The Weinberger dinner provided the Republicans with a forum not only to criticize Mr. Walsh but to take aim at the economic package President Clinton unveiled Wednesday night.
In his remarks to the audience of about 300 people, Mr. Weinberger referred briefly to his case, which ended on Christmas Eve, when he and five others were pardoned.
Mr. Weinberger otherwise chose not to dwell on the past, declaring "I'm heartily sick of Iran-contra, and I want to talk about something else" before going on to attack Mr. Clinton's proposed tax increases.
Among others pardoned by Bush who joined Mr. Weinberger at the dinner were Clair E. George, a former top official of the Central Intelligence Agency, and Elliot Abrams, a former assistant Secretary of State. The three others who received pardons were Robert M. MacFarlane, the former national security adviser; Duane Claridge and Alan Fiers.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: New Spending;
The President's Fine Print Asks Fundamental Change

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Embedded in the fine print of President Clinton's budget request are fundamental changes in Federal policy: less money for the military, more aid for children, greater emphasis on the prevention of disease, and a new view of environmental protection as a source of jobs, not a drag on the economy.
Whereas in January 1992 President Bush anticipated a yearly Pentagon budget of $289 billion by 1997, Mr. Clinton's plan calls for cutting military spending to $249 billion in that year, mainly by cutting troop levels and outlays for the Star Wars antimissile defense program. 
 Mr. Clinton would pump more money into the Head Start preschool program, the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, known as WIC, the immunization of preschool children, summer school and summer jobs for teen-agers from poor families.
Head Start, currently budgeted at $2.8 billion a year, would get an extra $500 million this year and a total of $13 billion more over five years.
WIC's current budget of $2.9 billion would be increased $75 million this year through a supplemental appropriation, followed by a total of $3.6 billion more by 1998. With the extra money, the WIC program could serve 300,000 more children under 5 years old this year, in addition to the 5.6 million people already getting assistance.
 
Praised by Child Advocates
 President Clinton also proposed a huge expansion of Federal tax credits that aid low-income working families with children.
Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, and Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, who rarely had a good word to say about budgets in the George Bush and Ronald Reagan years, lavishly praised Mr. Clinton for making a big investment in children.
Environmentalists also saw a shift in priorities. Environmental projects, like sewage treatment plants, account for a significant share of the public works proposed by Mr. Clinton. His plan, for example, calls for $1 billion a year in grants to local governments for water-quality improvement projects and a total of $2 billion over the next five years dedicated to improving parks and wildlife areas.
 
'Environmentally Smart'
 "The Reagan and Bush Administrations continually told us that jobs and the environment don't mix -- that if you spend Federal money on the environment, you're hurting the economy," said David D. Doniger, a lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council. "Clinton is saying that there are lots of ways to spend Federal dollars that are environmentally smart and create jobs."
William Roberts, chief lobbyist for the Environmental Defense Fund, said Mr. Clinton's proposals reflected "a major shift in the way our Government approaches economic and environmental problems."
"New investments in mass transit, waste-water treatment and energy efficiency will create jobs while cleaning our water and air," Mr. Roberts said. The Administration maintains that construction of environmental projects and development of new environmental technologies will stimulate economic growth and create jobs.
 
Familiar Budget Themes
 Mr. Clinton repeats many budget-cutting proposals that Mr. Reagan or Mr. Bush had made unsuccessfully. The proposed justifications are similar. But Mr. Clinton's language is different. He does not repeat the zealous attacks on wasteful Government spending that became a familiar theme in budget documents over the last decade.
Like his predecessors, Mr. Clinton wants to reduce or eliminate Government subsidies and charge fees for Government services. Democrats and some Republicans resisted such user fees when they were proposed by the Reagan Administration, but lawmakers of both parties have become more receptive to the idea in recent years.
For example, Mr. Clinton wants the Securities and Exchange Commission to charge higher fees to corporations registering new securities for sale to the public. And he wants to charge higher fees for public use of national parks, forests, recreation areas and camp sites.
In addition, Mr. Clinton wants to charge higher fees to ranchers grazing cattle, sheep and horses on Federal lands. He wants to require slaughterhouses to reimburse the Government for the full cost of meat and poultry inspections.
 
Walking Well-Worn Paths
 Many of Mr. Clinton's proposals are hardy perennials, made year after year. He wants to slash "impact aid" payments, made to local school districts to offset the cost of Federal installations that are exempt from the local property taxes that finance schools. He wants to eliminate Federal subsidies to honey producers and to limit Federal payments to producers of wool and mohair (a program adopted in 1954 to insure a "strategic reserve" of wool in time of war).
In addition, Mr. Clinton wants to eliminate Federal payment of crop subsidies to farmers who have adjusted gross income of $100,000 a year or more from sources other than a farm. The Administration says this proposal would direct Federal aid to small family-owned farms, away from big agricultural enterprises.
Mr. Clinton would also reduce Federal subsidies paid to growers of wheat, corn, barley, cotton and rice.
These proposals, which look simple and appealing to budget examiners at the White House, invariably prove more complex on Capitol Hill. Lawmakers like E. "Kika" de la Garza, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Agriculture Committee, warn that such proposals will undermine the farm economy, threatening the output of "food and fiber" on which the nation depends.
 
Eliminating Programs
 When members of Congress have tried to cut popular Government subsidy programs one-by-one, they have usually failed. But when the cuts were bundled together in comprehensive deficit-reduction bills in 1981 and 1990, the efforts were successful.
Whereas Mr. Bush proposed eliminating several hundred Government programs, Mr. Clinton would eliminate a handful.
For example, Mr. Clinton asked Congress to eliminate the trade adjustment assistance program of the Commerce Department, which provides aid to businesses harmed by imports. Mr. Clinton would also eliminate subsidies for nuclear reactor research that have no commercial applications.
In addition, Mr. Clinton wants to eliminate fertilizer research conducted by the Tennessee Valley Authority, saying the fertilizer industry was "fully capable" of conducting such research without Government subsidies.
Mr. Clinton also proposed freezing the pay of Federal employees, including uniformed military personnel, in 1994. In the three years after that, he wants to raise the pay of Federal workers by less than the increase in the cost of living. Congress has often refused to go along with such proposals in the past.
 
'A Poor Way to Do It'
 Gregory O'Duden, general counsel of the National Treasury Employees Union, said Mr. Clinton's pay proposal was "as bad as what Reagan proposed."
"We have heard much talk from the Clinton Administration that it wishes to reinvent Government," said Mr. O'Duden. "This is a poor way to do it. Congress just passed a law recognizing the need to make Federal pay comparable to pay in private industry. Clinton's proposal would frustrate that goal."
The politics of Capitol Hill suggest that lawmakers are more likely to approve new taxes than cuts in Federal spending of the type proposed by Mr. Clinton.
Senator Pete V. Domenici and Representative John R. Kasich, the ranking Republicans on their respective Budget Committees, applauded Mr. Clinton's emphasis on deficit reduction but said they were sorry to see him propose large tax increases.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Clinton Plan
Debate over President Clinton's economic program began as new White House figures showed that almost all of the deficit reduction proposed for the next two years would come from tax increases, with almost none from spending cuts. [Page A1.] New budget tables showed that the cumulative deficit reduction for the next four years would be $325 billion, not $500 billion. [A15.]
The proposed energy tax based on the heat content of fuels would alter costs for fuel producers more than it would change consumption patterns, analysts say. [D1.] 
 Wall Street firms say the Clinton plan is good for their business because a slimmer deficit helps markets. [D16.]
Two top Clinton economic aides went to Wall Street and were praised for deficit reduction, but questioned on spending cuts. [D16.]
Projections for $11.5 billion savings in Federal interest expense confused some bond traders and dealers. [D16.]
Many large companies would have to report sharply lower earnings if corporate income tax rates were raised because of a new accounting rule. [D1.]
Most public finance economists say higher corporate taxes coupled with a temporary investment tax credit will raise revenue without discouraging new investment. [D17.]
Business executives gave the Administration qualified support, but adopted a wait-and-see attitude about the plan's details. [D17.]
 
The Economy
Consumer prices jumped a surprisingly strong five-tenths of 1 percent, to an annualized rate of 6.1 percent. Unemployment claims fell, the industrial operating rate rose, and exports and imports grew. [D2.]
The trade deficit widened last year as the recovery revived Americans' appetite for imports while economic stagnation overseas dampened demand for American goods. [D2.]
The New York Mercantile Exchange's chairman was asked to resign after charges of trading violations, but he refused. [D2.]
 
Companies
Boeing will eliminate 28,000 jobs over 18 months because of slumping orders from the world's struggling airlines. [D1.]
Paine Webber agreed not to open new accounts at five offices to settle Federal charges of poorly supervising employees. [D2.]
Fifteen big cellular phone companies allied to make it easier for people to call between cities in the U.S. and Canada. [D5.]
Nationsbank will exercise its option to buy MNC Financial of Baltimore in a deal valued at $1.3 billion. [D5.]
Two top Coca-Cola executives emerged as possible front-runners to become the next chief executive. [D5.]
The Big Three auto makers will develop new paint systems that produce less air pollution at 50 automotive plants. [D5.]
The New York Times appointed Russell T. Lewis president and general manager. Other changes were also announced. [D18.]
 
Markets
Long-term Treasury yields fell to an all-time low as the bond market focused on President Clinton's plan for the deficit and the prospects for reduced Government borrowing. [D1.]
Blue-chip stocks careened in an 81-point range. The Dow lost 10 points and the Nasdaq gained 3.02 points. [D6.]
The dollar was mixed at home and higher overseas. Gold prices declined. [D15.] Cold weather drove natural gas futures to a two-month high. Oil futures also advanced. [D15.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 17; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1129 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: In the Region;
Tax Package Seen as Net Gain for New York Area

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
President Clinton's fiscal program would be a net plus for the New York metropolitan region, fiscal and energy policy analysts say. And that would be a big change for a part of the country that has grown accustomed, under recent Republican Administrations, to feeling neglected by Federal taxing and spending policies.
The energy tax will bite less deeply here because households and businesses are more energy efficient than in the rest of the country, and the region's industries are favored by the President's economic stimulus program. Where the region would pay is in income tax increases, because household wealth is greater than average. 
 "The bottom line, on a regional basis, is that this is the first budget in 13 years that is pro-New York and pro-New York region," said Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn. "We've had 12 years of budgets that were decidedly anti-New York, but surprisingly the strongest cuts in the President's budgets are in rural programs, and the strongest increases are in urban and suburban programs."
New York City alone stands to gain at least $515 million from the President's one-shot economic stimulus package, Mr. Schumer estimated, including $130 million in community development grants and an additional $140 million in mass transit subsidies that would be paid this year.
 
An Energy Tax Benefit
 The region's high concentrations of poor people stand to benefit in particular from the President's proposed expansion of programs for low-income home ownership and improvement. The President's economic stimulus package also offers incentives to the region's research-based industries in electronics and pharmaceuticals and promises to inject billions into mass transit, highway and community development programs.
The key to the region's advantage on the tax side of the President's program is his decision to use a broad-based tax that would apply to the energy content of nearly all fuels, as measured by the British Thermal Unit, or B.T.U.
 
More Rigid Conservation
 Because energy prices are higher in the region, owing partly to a heavy reliance on oil for generation of electricity, homes and industries here have adapted more rigid conservation measures than in many states where energy is cheaper, said David Nemtzow, energy adviser to Representative. Edward J. Markey of Massachussetts, a member of the House Energy Committee.
Using this broad-based tax, instead of focusing on oil imports or gasoline consumption, rewards states that are most efficient in overall energy consumption, he said.
"The B.T.U. is favorable because the Northeast has been doing exactly what it should have been doing since the energy crisis of the seventies, which is making its economy more energy efficient," Mr. Nemtzow said. "New York is one of the most forward-looking states in the nation in terms of energy policy. As a result, the region just uses less energy per capita than the rest of the country."
According to Representative Markey's New England Energy Caucus, New York comprises 7.2 percent of the country's population but would pay just 4.6 percent of the energy tax once it is fully phased in in 1997. Connecticut has 1.3 percent of the population but would pay 1 percent of the tax, which would raise $22 billion nationally. New Jersey, with 3.1 percent of the population, would pay 3 percent of the tax, the caucus says.
 
Long Island Is an Exception
 The caucus says the Northeastern states would pay 79 percent of the average per-capita national energy tax, while the South and West would pay 111 percent. Those states had favored a tax on imported oil, which would have raised domestic oil prices to the disadvantage of the Northeast.
The Northeast-Midwest Institute, which is associated with the congressional delegations from those regions, calculated that the average extra cost from the energy tax for each household would amount to $233 annually in Connecticut, $199 in New York and $273 in New Jersey. The national annual average household cost would be $236, the Institute reported.
These figures exclude use of energy in industry.
The one area of the region that will be hit hard by the the energy program is Long Island, where 70 percent of the homes are heated by oil and where reliance on automobile travel is heavy.
 
Higher Costs on Long Island
 Francis J. Murray Jr., commissioner of the New York State Energy Office, estimated yesterday that household energy costs on Long Island would increase by an average of $320 for each household under the President's proposed tax, compared to $120 in New York city and $265 upstate.
Meanwhile, the President's $56 billion economic stimulus package contains elements that are favorable to the region, said Norman Glickman, director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University.
"This is a region that does a lot of research, in pharmaceuticals in New Jersey, in electronics in Connecticut, and making permanent the research tax credit, which amounts to about a third of the total investment credits the President proposed, is a boost to this area" Dr. Glickman said.
 
Effect on Housing Values
 Others, however, have raised flags about how Mr. Clinton's vow to rein in health care costs would affect the pharmaceutical industry.
Dr. Glickman also noted that the President's program foresees more spending on community development and enterprise zones for poor cities, a particular benefit to places like Trenton, Buffalo and Bridgeport.
Because the President's roads, bridges and mass transit spending package is aimed at boosting employment quickly, it will favor places like New York City and New Jersey that have already filed plans with the Federal government for construction projects that are ready to go, awaiting only funding, Dr. Glickman added
Because Connecticut and New Jersey are ranked first and second in household income nationally, with New York ranked sixth, the President's proposed increase of top income tax rates from 31 to 36 percent, plus a surcharge on incomes over $250,000, will fall harder on the region than elsewhere, Dr. Glickman said.
 
Ending Tax-Break Bonanza
 In part, the new taxes would take away the tax-break bonanza of the Reagan years that many economists believed helped fuel the region's housing and consumer spending spree during the 80's.
But even higher income taxes may offer a silver lining, several economists said. By increasing the value of tax deductions, higher income tax rates may stimulate demand for larger mortgage loans, which have deductible interest payments, and so help housing values. And because state and local taxes are also deductible, higher Federal income tax rates might make it easier for states to raise taxes.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Nationsbank Using Option To Buy MNC

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 18

 BODY:
The Nationsbank Corporation said today that it was exercising its option to buy MNC Financial Inc. of Baltimore in a deal valued at $1.3 billion.
Nationsbank will remain the fourth-largest bank in the country after acquiring MNC, which has $16.7 billion in assets and nearly 250 bank branches in Maryland, Virginia and Washington, D.C. Nationsbank, which is based in Charlotte, said the purchase might be paid for entirely in Nationsbank stock or up to 49.9 percent in cash. 
 Stock in Nationsbank, which is continuing a string of major acquisitions, rose 12.5 cents today, to $51.125, on the New York Stock Exchange, as MNC's shares jumped $1.375, to $14.25.
 
Quick Action
 Under an agreement last year, Nationsbank acquired a 16 percent nonvoting stake in MNC for $200 million and the option to acquire the company outright for about $1.2 billion more by Sept. 30, 1997. MNC, which has struggled under the weight of bad real estate loans, desperately needed the cash infusion to bolster its capital levels.
Moving rather quickly to exercise its option, Nationsbank said its action reflected a "clear" improvement in MNC's financial performance. If MNC's condition continued to improve, the price of the acquisition would have increased.
 A Nationsbank spokeswoman, Lynn Drury, said it was too early to estimate how many layoffs or branch closings might result from the merger, which is expected to be completed in the second half of the year. She said, however, that Nationsbank expected to cut MNC's costs by about 25 percent.
 
Little Overlap
 "We have some overlap, especially in the Maryland suburbs, but the two franchises are complementary," Ms. Drury said, adding that Nationsbank does not anticipate any antitrust problems.
Nationsbank said it had not yet decided if it would pay any of the purchase price in cash. The Federal Reserve usually discourages cash purchases, unless more stock is issued, because it likes to keep capital in the banking system. The deal is subject to approval by banking regulators.
Nationsbank has not discussed the payment issue with the Fed, Ms. Drury said. "We are certainly sensitive to maintaining strong capital levels," she added.
Diane Glossman, an industry analyst with Salomon Brothers, said that the MNC acquisition "cements Nationsbank's market share in the metropolitan D.C. area, which under normal conditions is a good market." The region and many of its banks have been hit hard by the regional recession and plummeting real estate values.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: The Deficit;
Another Look at the Figures: A Smaller Trim in the Deficit

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
The deficit reduction proposed by President Clinton on Wednesday night would total $325 billion over the next four years, not nearly $500 billion, as The New York Times and some other news organizations reported today.
This became clear in more complete budget tables issued today by the Administration. The $500 billion figure -- actually $493 billion -- represents the total amount of tax increases and specific spending cuts that Mr. Clinton proposed. It was emphasized in documents the White House handed out Wednesday. But it does not take account of $169 billion in tax cuts and new Government spending Mr. Clinton wants for programs he favors. 
 Since deficit reduction is the combination of the net change in revenues and in expenditures, the total reduction would actually be $325 billion, rounded off. That correct figure was reported today by some news organizations.
 
'A Failure to Communicate'
 Mr. Clinton did not mention either figure in his address to Congress, and Administration officials insisted that no deception was intended. They said the problem stemmed from the haste in putting together the final elements of the package; the final tables were not put together until just before the President began his speech.
The problem, said Bruce Lindsey, one of Mr. Clinton's closest advisers, was "a failure to communicate."
Asked about the situation today as he boarded a helicopter on the White House lawn, Mr. Clinton said: "Call Panetta. That's his department."
A spokesman for Leon E. Panetta, the budget director, said the problem developed because the Clinton Administration regards proposals to lower the deficit and proposals to stimulate the economy (which the Administration calls "investments") as two separate tracks.
"There was no intention not to be honest," said the spokesman, Barry J. Toiv. "We feel very strongly that there is about $500 billion over four years of deficit reduction measures, the combined total of tax cuts and spending increases. Next to that we had the investments of approximately $160 billion."
Asked at a hearing today of the House Budget Committee which number, $500 billion or $325 billion, was correct, Mr. Panetta said, "They're both correct," one a gross figure and the other a net one.
At a briefing for reporters on Wednesday afternoon, Mr. Panetta did not distinguish between the conventional definition of deficit reduction and the new one the Administration has adopted, using one definition in one sentence and the other one in the next sentence.
He said: "With regards to deficit reductions, it tries to achieve close to $500 billion in deficit reduction by 1997 -- almost $708 billion in deficit reduction by 1998. Two-thirds of that amount goes for deficit reduction and one-third of that amount goes for investments."
 
What the Documents Say
 The documents passed out after the Panetta briefing did not contain a year-by-year breakdown of taxes and spending. A White House summary called "Highlights of the President's Economic Program" declared, "The President is proposing the largest deficit reduction package in U.S. history -- almost $500 billion over four years and over $700 billion over five years."
Elsewhere, the documents mentioned about $160 billion in "long-term public investments in economic growth and jobs" but gave no indication that this figure should be subtracted from what they called deficit reduction.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: Defining the Terms;
Surtax: Whatever Its Name, It Still Equals 39.6% Tax Rate

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Although Clinton Administration officials have long referred to it as a "millionaires' surtax," the proposed 10 percent surtax on high-income households would in effect establish a new top tax rate. It would affect Americans with taxable incomes of $250,000 or more (a figure that translates into adjusted gross income of $305,000 or more).
In practice, the surtax would create a new top tax rate of 39.6 percent. 
 President Clinton is proposing to raise the current top tax rate to 36 percent, from 31 percent, for all taxable income over $140,000 for joint filers or above $115,000 for single people. The surtax would be an extra tax on the income earned over $250,000. It would be 10 percent of the base tax on that income.
Here's how it would work for a household with $350,000 in taxable income:
The $100,000 in income in excess of $250,000 would be taxed at 36 percent, a tax of $36,000. Then the surtax would levy an additional 10 percent of that amount, or $3,600 more. Together, that would mean a tax of $39,600 on the $100,000 in income in excess of $250,000, equaling a 39.6 percent rate.
Another way to view this is that for the taxable income between $140,000 and $250,000, the taxpayer would be subject to the proposed 36 percent rate. Then, for the household's $100,000 in taxable income above $250,000, the taxpayer would be subject to a tax rate of 39.6 percent.
Administration officials today indicated that it was politics, rather than economics, that drove the President to propose a surtax rather than officially asking for a top new marginal rate of 39.6 percent. They suggested that for many Americans, including many earning far less than $250,000, officially creating a new top tax bracket of nearly 40 percent might have sounded exorbitant.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN: The Cabinet;
Pitching Clinton Program, the Cabinet Hits the Road to Talk of Better Times

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 18

 BODY:
Members of President Clinton's Cabinet were deployed around the country today to plead for passage of his economic-recovery package, mixing promises of better times with warnings that they would not come soon.
"There will be no big turnaround the first year," Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen told students at a high school auditorium here. "That's not going to happen. It is too complex a problem." But Mr. Bentsen, citing job-training programs and the youth service component of the President's program, pledged to the students, "We're investing in you." 
 Several other Cabinet secretaries returned to their home states to deliver a pitch for the program, which combines spending cuts and tax increases intended to cut the budget deficit by nearly $325 billion over four years.
 
'A Call to Arms'
 In Brooklyn, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown toured Metrotech Center, a high-tech complex built with public and private money, and called the President's speech "a call to arms" to boost the economy. "The public wants to unite," he said. "They're ready for the truth."
Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy spoke before a joint session of the Mississippi State Legislature in Jackson and urged support for the program "because it represents real change."
And Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, speaking at University Hospitals in Cleveland, where she grew up, focused on the health-care overhauls proposed by Mr. Clinton. "We're going to deal with it," she said, listing a litany of problems with the nation's medical system ranging from people who had lost insurance benefits to the high cost of drugs. "And we're not going to take 50 years."
Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, speaking in Tucson, Ariz., and echoing one of the theme's of Mr. Clinton's speech to Congress on Wednesday night, sought to minimize the tax increases by casting them as a burden that would fall mainly on the rich. "Those who got benefits in the 1980's are going to be asked to bear the lion's share," he said.
The stops by the various secretaries were clearly coordinated to highlight different aspects of the program and were aimed for consumption by much larger audiences than the few hundred students Mr. Bentsen addressed here or the dozens of workers Ms. Shalala encountered in her tour of the hospital.
Mr. Bentsen's remarks, for instance, were ultimately aimed at a far larger audience: the nearly seven million students who are scheduled to watch his speech on Friday on Channel One, the commercial and news program broadcast in about 300,000 classrooms.
But if there was any expectation that the students in Austin might go easier on the Administration than their parents, it was dashed when several of the teen-agers peppered Mr. Bentsen with sharp questions about how tax increases would help businesses create jobs or how their community could hope to recover from cuts in the military budget.
Mr. Bentsen countered by saying that the taxes on businesses would only rise slightly and that they were necessary to keep the Federal deficit from choking the economy and destroying the prospects for job creation. "You have to cut this deficit," he said. "That means you have to raise some funds."
Despite expressing skepticism about the tax increases, Alex Kuperman, a 17-year-old junior at the school, the A. N. McCallum High School, did speak approvingly about both Mr. Bentsen and the overall program.
"It really pertained to my generation," he said. "He focused on things that would really help us, not just the nation."
Asked by reporters why he traveled to a high school to plug the program, Mr. Bentsen said, "Because what we're talking about is the young people of the country and what's going to happen to them, what kind of economy they're going to have."
In Mississippi, Mr. Espy told the state legislators, "It's better to build on the future rater than borrow against our future." He also drew loud applause when he said the Clinton program was aimed at asking foreign corporations that "make a profit in the United States to pay the same as U.S. corporations."
But he still drew a largely negative reaction from the Gov. Kirk Fordice, a Republican, who told reporters afterward, "You can't bring prosperity to America with a tax increase."
In New York City, Mr. Brown's pitch for the plan, and Mr. Clinton's speech the night before, did seem to go over well, even with one person in the audience, Bruce Ratner, who said he would be hit in the wallet by the new program.
"It's clear we have to cut our deficit and it's a real plan to do that, which hits everyone fairly," said Mr. Ratner, president of the Forest City Ratner Companies, the real-estate developer of Metrotech. "I'm one of the well-to-do. I should be hit."
 
'Somebody's Got to Pay'
 Others at Metrotech who heard the President's speech were a bit more ambivalent. "The realities are he's going to save the world and somebody's got to pay for it," said Bob Nawn, a 50-year-old computer analyst.
Metrotech is generally regarded as one of the city's success stories. It is home to the Polytechnic University, an engineering school, and the computer operations or corporate offices of businesses like Chase Manhattan Bank, Brooklyn Union Gas, and the New York and American Stock Exchanges. Mr. Brown described the complex as "a model of what should be going on in America -- a real public-private partnership."
And he said that recent news of large layoffs by the International Business Machines Corporation and other large corporations was "exactly why we put forward a stimulus" program.
In Cleveland, Ms. Shalala staunchly defended Mr. Clinton's program but seemed, at one point, to make a small jibe at her boss, who was overheard swearing on a microphone the other night.
Tapping the wireless microphone she wore at the hospital, she said: "I hope you've noticed I don't swear. Even in private. Particularly not with my mother here." Ms. Shalala was accompanied by her 80-year-old mother, Edna Smith Shalala, a lawyer.

HEADLINE: Senate Opposes Immigration Of People With AIDS Virus

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
In a sharp rebuff to President Clinton, the Senate voted overwhelmingly today to stop the Administration from allowing the immigration of people infected with the virus that causes AIDS.
Although the Senate action has little chance of becoming law, the 76-to-23 vote, in which 34 Democrats voted against the President, illustrated both the lingering discomfort in the Senate over AIDS and immigration issues and the new President's lack of control over the Senate. It could foreshadow trouble as Mr. Clinton moves beyond economic issues to pursue his social agenda, which includes support for actions long advocated by homosexual-rights groups. 
 The vote followed an emotional debate between Republicans, who argued that the country could not afford to risk admitting AIDS patients, and liberal Democrats, who said Americans should show no less compassion than other industrialized countries that offer sanctuary to such immigrants.
 
Shifting the Focus
 The Administration did not lobby strenuously against the Republican-sponsored measure, fearing that it would become as intensely disputed as the President's insistence on allowing openly homosexual people to serve in the military.
Gay-rights advocates privately expressed disappointment in the Administration's inaction. But Senate Democrats said it was understandable that the White House chose to focus its attention on the economic program that Mr. Clinton introduced on Wednesday, particularly since the immigration measure will probably die in the House. Powerful liberals there, reinforced by the Congressional Black Caucus, are mobilizing in opposition and are given an excellent chance of killing the amendment.
Only one Republican, Senator Mark Hatfield of Oregon, voted against the measure.
The restriction that prevents people with the AIDS virus from entering the country is now included in regulations, and the President could simply reverse these. The measure passed by the Senate would make the restriction a matter of law that could be reversed only by Congress.
The current rule includes infection with H.I.V., the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome, on a list of medical conditions that disqualify people seeking to immigrate legally into the United States.
 
Haitians Are Detained
 The White House announced two weeks ago that Mr. Clinton planned to eliminate all diseases from the list except contagious tuberculosis. The action has been delayed pending a review of policies regarding immigration from Haiti. Some 215 Haitians hoping for admission to this country have been detained at the United States naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, because they are infected with H.I.V.
"The Senate has spoken firmly," said George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director. "The President has to take this vote into account as he reviews the policy." Mr. Stephanopoulos added that the President and his aides have not yet discussed whether Mr. Clinton would veto the bill to kill the amendment, were it to pass both houses.
Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, who was a sponsor of the amendment, estimated that every H.I.V.-infected immigrant would cost American taxpayers $100,000 or more in medical expenses. "I do not think it is compassionate to open up a sign that says, 'Come to America and Uncle Sam is going to take care of your medical expenses,' " he said.
"Compassion begins at home," Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said in agreement.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who led the opposition to the measure, argued that the ban jeopardized public health by forcing infected immigrants to go underground, since the disease could subject them to deportation. Mr. Kennedy offered a substitute amendment that would have retained the current ban for 90 days, then allowed the President to lift the regulation without approval of Congress. His measure was defeated 56 to 42.
 
'An Outrageous Act'
 Michael Ratner, a lawyer for the Center for Constitutional Rights, which represents the Haitian refugees on the Guantanamo base, called the Senate action "an outrageous act" comparable "to the days when we kicked kids out of high school for having H.I.V."
The overall bill to which the immigration measure was attached was the National Institutes of Health Reauthorization Act, and it passed the Senate today by a vote of 93 to 4. It now goes to the House. The overall legislation died in the Senate last year because conservatives opposed a provision that would permit research using tissues derived from aborted fetuses. That issue was settled when Mr. Clinton lifted the research ban with an executive order.
Of the $5.9 billion authorized in the health package for 1994, most of it is earmarked for research into AIDS, cancer and heart and lung diseases.
The immigration prohibition dates to 1987, when a similar measure was enacted by Congress. But Congress backtracked three years later, passing legislation that allowed the Secretary of Health and Human Services to determine if H.I.V. infection, like tuberculosis, should disqualify a person from entering the country.
 
International Opposition
 The former Health and Human Services Secretary, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, concluded that it should not be a bar to immigration and recommended that President George Bush lift the ban. But Congressional conservatives lobbied successfully to convince Mr. Bush to keep the rule in effect.

HEADLINE: A View From a High-Tech Perch

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MENLO PARK, Calif., Feb. 18

 BODY:
Like many of the engineers in Silicon Valley, Geoffrey S. Goodfellow, a computer hacker turned high-tech entrepreneur, is a cynic when it comes to Washington. Normally rising at 5:30 A.M., he has little time to ponder politics, and he was still working Wednesday night when President Clinton gave his economics address.
Despite Mr. Goodfellow's detachment, he acknowledged that after catching up with the news this morning he was grudgingly optimistic about the President's economics plan, which would give small companies like his a permanent investment tax credit. 
 Looking around his crowded two-bedroom apartment here, where he works alongside his 10 employees, Mr. Goodfellow said the tax credit might allow him to buy some more computers and communications gear and even hire a couple more people.
 
Electronic Postmaster
 In the grand tradition of the Apple Computer co-founders, Stephen Wozniak and Steven P. Jobs, Mr. Goodfellow, who is 36 and single, founded his tiny Radiomail Corporation in his bedroom five years ago. A pioneer in a new software technology, he now serves several hundred customers and finds his company at the intersection of Silicon Valley's most promising business: an electronic post office for the wireless communicating gadgets that many in the valley believe will be the next computer industry boom.
Radiomail has developed a service, including the necessary software, for routing messages between its customers' wireless devices. The service makes use of the public telephone network as well various wireless data networks like the RAM Mobile Data system. The Clinton plan could help Radiomail grow with the industry.
Mr. Clinton, in his address to Congress, singled out small businesses for special incentives.
"Because small businesses generate most of our nation's jobs, our plan includes the boldest targeted incentives for small business in history," the President said. "We propose a permanent investment tax credit for small business, and new rewards for entrepreneurs who take risks."
Silicon Valley venture capitalists today were trying to assess how the entire tax package would affect the investment community. Despite grumbling that some provisions seem intended mainly to tax successful people, some venture capitalists voiced clear support for the incentives aimed at small businesses.
"It can't hurt," said Roger McNamee, a fund manager at Integral Partners, a Palo Alto, Calif., high-tech investment firm. "If you think about computers, they are the kind of things people want to spend money on. And in small business, a little more automation can often have a big impact."
Under the Clinton plan, medium-size and large businesses would get a 7 percent credit in each of the next two years for buying new equipment. Small businesses with annual revenues under $5 million would get a 7 percent credit for two years and a permanent credit at a slightly reduced rate of 5 percent thereafter -- or until they grow beyond the $5 million range. For the companies, the credit would free up money to spend on other things, like employees.
Despite such enticements, Mr. Goodfellow is not prepared to enthusiastically back Mr. Clinton -- or any other politician. "Right now," he said, "it seems they're more concerned about whether there is a dial tone in the White House than about getting on with things that will really make a difference in this country."
 
Remembering Kennedy's Move
 But the president that Mr. Goodfellow recently hired, an executive with long experience in the data networking business, seemed pleased.
"This will clearly allow us to make better use of our funds," said William R. Hipp, the new president, who is old enough to remember the success of a similar tax investment credit offered by the Kennedy Administration in 1962. "The economy took off like a rocket at a time when we were suffering."
Mr. Hipp said the latest investment tax credit might give Radiomail the money to support at least 2 of the additional 20 employees the company plans to hire this year. For each additional $20,000 of equipment the company buys, Mr. Hipp said, it will generate enough additional business to hire another person.
"The biggest thing for us," Mr. Hipp said, "is improving consumer confidence, and an intelligent President who makes good decisions will have a significant impact."
Mr. Goodfellow did say that at least one facet of Mr. Clinton's plan was an improvement over the policies of the previous Administration. "The most promising thing is that he is so pro-technology," he said, "especially the idea of backing the creation of a data superhighway."
 
Fine Dining Can Wait
 On the verge of closing a new round of financing from some large corporate backers, Mr. Goodfellow said he planned to move his company into a real office in May.
Mr. Goodfellow, who as a teen-ager dropped out of high school to concentrate on computers, now presides over a home office crowded with 20 of the machines, including a collection of Next Inc. work stations. He has been known to use a powerful minicomputer as a coffee table, and in November he removed his dining room table to bring in two new desks.
Like a number of other small-business men in Silicon Valley, Mr. Goodfellow said he had not set out to become a high-tech pioneer. Instead, his invention was a child of necessity.
"This is actually something I didn't want to do," he said. "I wanted to be a subscriber. But I talked to the big companies, and nobody was willing to set up this kind of service. So I had to do it myself."
And that is precisely the type of initiative the Clinton plan is supposed to foster.
