HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Mixed Greeting for Clinton Plan; Bonds Jump

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The yield on the long-term Treasury bond sank to an all-time low yesterday as the credit market focused on President Clinton's plan for reducing Government borrowing by cutting the budget deficit.
As prices of Government securities soared, the yield of the 30-year Treasury bond sank to 7.02 percent, down from 7.10 percent on Wednesday and the lowest level for the issue since the Government began selling 30-year bonds in 1977. 
 Stocks, however, drew little direction from the Clinton plan. The Dow Jones industrial average gyrated in a wide range until closing only 10 points lower. [Page D6.]
Bond traders shrugged off Government reports that consumer prices edged up five-tenths of a percent in January, an unexpectedly strong increase, and that the economic recovery continued to strengthen on a number of fronts. [Page D2.]
Such data usually depress bond prices because inflation erodes the value of fixed-income securities. But yesterday, the bond market found its strength mostly in the plan outlined by the President on Wednesday night for cutting the deficit by $500 billion over four years.
"For all intents and purposes, the C.P.I. came in higher than expected," said Kevin Flanagan, an economist with Dean Witter Reynolds. "But the Treasury market is still dealing with a political agenda."
Smaller Federal deficits would have a profound impact on the overall bond market, since the Government is the largest borrower. If the Treasury were to issue less debt, the overall supply of new securities would fall, and so would interest rates, because issuers attract buyers for their debt by offering higher interest rates than competing issuers.
Active trading yesterday in the 30-year Treasury bond pushed its yield down to as low as 7.014 percent, as the offered price rose to 10112/32 , up 14/32 from Wednesday. By the close on the New York cash market, the offered price was at 10112/32 , up 11/32 , or about $10.33 for each $1,000 of bonds held. Bond yields fall as prices rise.
Some bond market traders said yesterday that Mr. Clinton's plans for higher taxes to help close the budget deficit would be good for debt securities. They argued that higher taxes would reduce the disposable income available to consumers, slow growth and lower inflation.
"The market recognizes that by zapping disposable income, you in effect put a brake on economic expansion and a temporary brake on the standard of living," said Joseph Battipaglia, director of research for Gruntal & Company. "All of which has the effect of keeping demand from bringing back forms of inflation."
Mr. Battipaglia also pointed to a part of the Clinton plan that calls for the Government to issue more short-term securities, where interest rates are lower. Such a shift would reduce the supply of 30-year bonds, helping to drive up prices and lower yields.
Mr. Battipaglia also said that the market drew confidence from the fact that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, had played an early role in devising the Clinton plan. Today, Mr. Greenspan will present his semiannual testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, and the market will no doubt be watching closely.
Traders also said another factor in the rally was talk of another cut in the discount rate.
In when-issued trading, two-year Treasury notes to be auctioned next week were offered at a price to yield 3.96 percent, down sharply from 4.07 percent on Wednesday. In when-issued trading, the yield for a five-year note that is also to be auctioned next week was 5.26 percent, down from 5.43 percent.
 
Municipal Bonds
 Municipal bonds were up 1/2 to 3/4 point in active trading as investors continued to buy the tax-free issues to hedge against the proposed tax increase, traders said.
Yields of some long-term bonds plunged 10 basis points. One actively sought issue was the North Carolina Eastern Municipal Power revenue bond due in 2017, with a 5 1/2 percent coupon. The bond gained 1 1/4 points to an offered price of 96 1/2 to yield 5.791 percent. For an investor in the top 36 percent tax bracket proposed by Mr. Clinton, the bond's tax-equivalent yield would be 9.011.
Investors in municipals also shrugged off yesterday's economic data since they are more focused on taxes, one bond trader said. Retail bond demand is up and the question of higher taxes has become a reality, another trader said.

HEADLINE: Moscow Journal;
Who'll Speak Up for Russia Now? Nixon, No Less

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Old cold warriors need not fade away. Take Richard M. Nixon -- at 80, he is battling on with much of the same fervor he showed in his celebrated jousts with Nikita S. Khrushchev 34 years ago. Only he is not fighting against Communists now, but for Russia.
In speeches, on Op-Ed pages and today in Russia, the former President has become one of the most dedicated advocates of the notion that the United States must not ignore Russia now that Communism has collapsed. 
 Interviewed in the official guest house where he was staying, Mr. Nixon ranged over the arguments he planned to press on business executives and politicians when he returns home: the new Russia was an investment in peace, prosperity and freedom. Success of Russia's economic and political reforms would spell billions in investments and thousands of jobs; failure could mean redoubled military spending. A successful Russia would be a powerful antidote to the Chinese model, living proof for the third world of the benefits of freedom.
Mr. Nixon couched his arguments in the hard logic of national interest -- "gooey friendship" and sentimentality, he declared, have no place in the upper reaches of international affairs. But there was a keenness to his arguments that belied the professions of pure realpolitik.
"I'm an anti-Communist but a pro-Russian," Mr. Nixon confessed. "That's an unusual combination."
 
No Weak Leaders
 This was his ninth visit to Moscow, he said -- he made one as Vice President, two in the 1960's, two as President and four since -- and he seemed still captivated by the land that had figured so largely in his life, that launched his political career as a crusading anti-Communist, and provided some of the greatest triumphs of his tragic Presidency. Now it seemed almost a point of personal pride that Russia be given proper credit for throwing off Communism.
"I've been around a long time; I knew Khrushchev, Mikoyan, Kosygin, Brezhnev, Gromyko and so forth," he said, listing powerful men who had run the Soviet Union after Stalin's death. "There's an interesting thing about Russian leaders, and that includes the current crop -- I have yet to meet one who is a weak one.
"They are strong, very strong. Believe me, they are strong. Perhaps it's the system, perhaps it's in the genes. I would say that under the circumstances, because they are so strong, it's quite remarkable that this revolution has occurred in a peaceful way."
What was remarkable, Mr. Nixon said, was not that President Boris N. Yeltsin's ratings were down, but that he not only remained at his post but could continue to pursue reforms in such daunting conditions.
"His popularity is down, that's quite evident," Mr. Nixon said. "It's down because the economy is down. When you consider, just taking the number I have seen, when you consider that this country is going through a recession much deeper than the Great Depression in the 1930's in the United States, how any government could still go forward with reforms is just amazing."
 
'A Very Tough Sell'
 However obvious his own admiration and support for the processes under way in Russia, Mr. Nixon had no illusions about the difficulty of rousing interest in an America that was turning increasingly inward. But that, he said, was a President's job.
"It's a very tough sell," he said. In the debates in the Presidential campaign, he said, aid to Russia was raised in only one question to Ross Perot. "Since then it's been dropped. The reason is polls: the latest Gallup Poll I saw found 4 percent of American people care about foreign policy -- any foreign policy. Last week we had another example -- Clinton appeared on a town meeting in Michigan, a national town meeting, where he took questions, no holds barred. There was only one question about foreign policy -- it was about Bosnia, not about Russia at all.
"In view of that, any politician is going to say, well, I'm going to concentrate on domestic policy. But it's the responsibility of a leader to educate the people so they will support what needs to be done. Putting it more simply, you don't take people where they want to go, you take people where they ought to go."
Foreign and domestic policy, Mr. Nixon argued, are like Siamese twins: "separate them and they die." That is what he would argue when he returned home, that if economic and political reforms fail in Russia, "you can kiss the peace dividend goodbye and you have to raise defense spending by billions instead of cutting it.
 
'This Wave of Freedom'
 "That failure would have a far greater impact on the American economy than anything President Clinton can do with his 50 billion here and 50 billion there in a $6 trillion economy."
Furthermore, he argued, the success of democracy in Russia would give "dramatic impetus to this wave of freedom that is sweeping over the world."
Mr. Nixon recalled his first trip abroad in 1953, when he visited 17 third world countries. "Over and over, I heard people say they were looking for a model of quick progress. For some this was China, but mainly it was Russia, where they were sending students and so on. Now instead of having Russia exporting Communism, it will be exporting freedom to the world."
Their very pride, he said, would push Russians toward reform. "Today they're being treated as a second-rate power," he said. "This hurts them. That's one of the reasons why a strong case can be made for reforms. If Russia does not reform, it's dooming itself to being a second-rate power."
That same pride, he warned, could turn Russia against the West if it felt it was being patronized.
"One of the things that is absolutely essential is that we not consider Russia to be a defeated enemy," Mr. Nixon said. "It was the Russian people who gave the coup de grace to Communism in December last year. We played a role, the United States, but it was the Russians who finally defeated it. So we should treat them not as a defeated enemy, but as an ally."

"I'm an anti-Communist but a pro-Russian," Mr. Nixon confessed. Upon his return home, he plans to tell politicians that the success of political reforms in Russia means billions in investments for the United States. (Otto Pohl for The New York Times)

 NEW YORK CITY
 
 ALERT ON DAY CARE WENT UNHEARD
Less than a month ago, police officers alerted the New York State's child abuse phone line about an unlicensed day-care center in a house in Hollis, Queens, a police spokesman said. HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Rose At 6.1% Rate in January

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Consumer prices jumped five-tenths of 1 percent in January, the biggest increase in two years, and industrial output recorded its fourth straight monthly advance, the Government reported today.
The latest outpouring of economic statistics also included a third weekly decline in first-time claims for unemployment benefits, the highest industrial operating rate in 15 months, and record volumes of both exports and imports for December. 
 Taken together, the data pointed to a business expansion that has now found solid footing, even in light of continuing layoffs by major companies and weak economies abroad.
But it was the unexpectedly large increase in the Consumer Price Index that captured much of the attention, setting a pace that if compounded would be 6.1 percent annually. Analysts disagreed whether the rise was an aberration or a sign of revived inflation that could threaten the Clinton Administration's plans to stimulate the economy.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is to appear before Congress on Friday to discuss the central bank's view of the economy and inflation, and to outline monetary strategy. He has recently indicated approval of the Administration's deficit-reduction plans, and most analysts said today's inflation report was not likely to change that.
The bond market apparently reflected that view today, as prices soared.
Today's inflation report may have been a fluke, according to Richard S. Peterson, chief economist at Continental Bank in Chicago. "If it happened twice in a row," he said, "I'd start taking notice. Three times and I'd change my forecast."
Other forces may also have clouded the market's message, including details of the deficit plans of the Administration and its hopes for shifting borrowing away from bonds with the longest maturities, which carry the highest interest rates.
Some analysts found elements of the inflation figures worrisome, particularly when combined with other results since early autumn. "While inflation appeared dead in the summer, it was really just playing possum," said Joel Popkin, a former Labor Department price specialist and now a Washington consultant.
 
Core Inflation Rate
 Mr. Popkin, who has been less optimistic than most, noted that all seven major expenditure groups reported in today's index posted bigger increases in January than in December, and that the so-called core inflation rate averaged about 4.5 percent from October through January.
Patrick C. Jackman, one of those who compiled the index, said, "We do not believe this signals a significant acceleration" in the inflation rate. Among other things, he said, some of the January increases -- for apparel, gasoline and home furnishings -- were natural rebounds from exceptionally big December declines, while price rises in products like tobacco were unlikely to be sustained.
Among the factors in the price report were a 1.7 percent increase in the cost of beef, the biggest since January 1990, and a sharp rise in automobile finance charges that followed a 22-month period during which these costs fell 20.7 percent. Airline fares rose again, too.
Before rounding, the Consumer Price Index rose 0.4922644 point for urban residents, a 6.1 percent annual rate. Over the last 12 months, the index has risen 3.3 percent.
Today's report on the output of factories, mines and utilities showed a four-tenths of 1 percent increase for January. This was a bit better than December's two-tenths of 1 percent gain -- revised down from three-tenths -- but not as strong as in October and November.
The Fed also reported that the nation's industries, nearly one-third of the economy, operated at 79.5 percent of capacity last month, two-tenths of a point higher than in December and the highest since October 1991.
The Labor Department said that initial jobless claims declined by 19,000, to 321,000, for the week ended Feb. 6. This was the lowest level since Christmas.

HEADLINE: Boeing Will Cut One-Fifth Of Work Force in 18 Months

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
The Boeing Company, responding to a slump in orders from the world's struggling airlines, said yesterday that it would eliminate 28,000 jobs over the next 18 months.
Three weeks ago, the company said that declining aircraft orders would force a cutback in production of all its commercial planes and that significant job reductions would be made. Yesterday it provided the details of the cuts, which were at the high end of analysts' estimates. 
 Boeing, the largest producer of commercial aircraft and one of the world's leading aerospace companiers, began 1993 with a work force just over 143,000. The reductions announced yesterday, therefore, mean that every fifth employee will lose his or her job.
There was little effect though, on Boeing shares. They closed yesterday at $33.875, up 12.5 cents.
Boeing, which is based in Seattle, estimates that in 1993, it will eliminate 15,000 jobs in Washington state, with an additional 6,000 in Wichita, Kan. A further 2,000 jobs will be cut at other Boeing locations nationwide.
The company said it expected the process to continue in the first half of 1994, with about 5,000 jobs to be cut.
Economists generally agree that every job lost at Boeing results in 2.8 additional jobs lost in the Puget Sound area. When Boeing scales back, its subcontractors will presumably also reduce their work forces, and other businesses that prospered from sales to Boeing's workers will suffer as those newly unemployed cut back all but essential spending.
Boeing's work-force reduction "eliminates virtually all of the growth you might have seen in Seattle in 1993," said Paul Sommers of the Northwest Policy Center at the University of Washington. The area created about 30,000 new jobs in 1992 and stands to lose that many in 1993 as a result of the Boeing cuts, he said. But "it's not as bad as either the 1969-70 period," he said.
Between mid-1968 and 1971, Boeing's payroll for commercial aircraft fell precipitously -- from 85,000 to just 21,000, prompting the posting of billboards at the edge of town asking, "Will the last person leaving Seattle please turn out the lights."
Today, thanks to high-tech companies like Microsoft, the city is less vulnerable to the business cycles of one company. Still, Boeing is a major source of high-wage jobs.
Frank Shrontz, Boeing's chairman and chief executive, said at a news conference this morning: "These reductions reflect the realities of the current market in the aerospace industry. We recognize the impact on our employees, their families and the communities we live and work in, and will try to minimize the effects."
Mr. Shrontz said Boeing would seek to reassign people within the company, replacing contract workers with regular employees. Boeing said it also planned to explore alternatives to layoffs, including a two-year education leave with paid tuition and continued benefits, and job placement of Boeing employees with suppliers.
Larry McKean, the vice president for human resources, said early retirement would not be offered, as it is company policy to place its most senior employees in crucial positions.
William Whitlow, an analyst with Pacific Crest Securities in Seattle, cited some cushioning effects. "The 777 buildup is going to mitigate it somewhat," he said, referring to Boeing's next midsize airliner, which is due to enter production next year. "Defense has been a mitigator in past cycles," he added, "but will be less of one this time."
The job reductions accelerate a process well under way last year, when several thousand positions were eliminated. Boeing said a company-wide hiring freeze, begun in October 1991, would continue.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Among Traders, Words Of Qualified Approval

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
A disembodied voice began to give a report card on President Clinton's economic address at 7:40 A.M. yesterday as broad-shouldered young men in shirt-sleeves who trade stocks sipped coffee in plastic foam cups.
It was the morning huddle on the trading floor of the First Boston Corporation, and the traders were listening to a a call from London on the early optimism of the overnight European markets. 
 "The dollar is stronger across the board," the unseen First Boston official said in clipped British tones. And he noted that in early trading in London, American stocks and bonds were also up sharply.
 
Adding Up Clinton's Proposals
 The principal business of Wall Street is to set prices on stocks, bonds and money itself. And yesterday, hundreds of professionals in this bright, cavernous room used their computers and telephones to calculate how prices were affected by the economic proposals outlined in Mr. Clinton's hourlong address Wednesday night.
At First Boston and elsewhere on Wall Street yesterday, traders and analysts complained that the proposed spending cuts might be too low and that the tax increases might be too high.
For the most part, however, they concluded that the worst part of the plan for business, the higher corporate tax rates, would not have dire consequences and that a smaller deficit would probably help most markets. In short, the President's medicine for the country seemed good for their business.
One of the President's proposals would increase taxes on firms like First Boston by taxing the value of securities that rose in value before they were sold. This could cost First Boston $35 million over the next three years, the firm said. Yet Archibald Cox, Jr., the firm's president and chief executive, said he was not opposed to the idea.
 
 
Sharing the Pain
 "Yes it's painful, but everyone has to share some of the pain," Mr. Cox said. "If every special-interest group starts fighting the things that affect them, you don't get anywhere at all."
And over all, the President's plan should help Wall Street.
"If interest rates stay low, that's obviously beneficial for our fixed-income business," Mr. Cox said. Since low rates tend to lead investors to continue putting more money into stocks, the trend would likely improve the firm's equity business as well, he predicted.
During yesterday's morning huddle, Joyce M. Albers-Schonberg, a health-care analyst, called in with some bad news. She said that the proposed cuts in Medicare and Medicaid might lower earnings of hospital companies by 5 to 10 cents a share. But since the health-care stocks had fallen so much recently, she recommended investing in drug company stocks like Merck and Pfizer for the short run.
Although a detailed health-care plan is not due from Mr. Clinton until the spring, she is wary of the pharmaceutical industry's long-term prospects.
 
 
Optimism on Oil
 On the other hand, James F. Clark, an oil company analyst, was optimistic. He predicted that oil industry stocks would rise in the next few months. "These taxes aren't going to be a big deal for the industry, nor will they be so offensive to OPEC that there will be a reaction," Mr. Clark said as he hunched over a microphone that looked like a brown dinner plate.
Mr. Clark and the dozen other stock analysts sat yesterday morning in a room of glass walls that looked out on the trading floor as their opinions were broadcast to First Boston offices in Tokyo, London and across the United States.
And unlike the nearly all-male trading floor, half the analysts were women. They took turns commenting on a different industry, with the opinions ranging from the cautiously optimistic to the enthusiastic.
 The investment picks of the morning were the stocks of pollution control companies, which would benefit from Mr. Clinton's continued emphasis on environmental issues and from a new investment tax credit.
Speaking to the firm's bond traders, Neal M. Soss, the firm's chief economist, predicted a strong bull market for bonds. "The fact that Alan Greenspan was seated next to Hillary Clinton, indicates he has signed on to the program and the Fed isn't going to raise rates soon," he said.
A few minutes later, some traders crowded around Mr. Soss and asked him what the proposals would mean for bond investors.
"The spirit of the market is that the funds rate isn't going above 3 for the rest of your life," he said, referring to the Federal funds rate, the interest charged banks in the Federal Reserve system for overnight loans. "So anything that yields over 3.01 is a buy," he said.
With long-term bonds now yielding more than 7 percent, rates could fall sharply, he said.
 
Giddiness on the Bond Desk
 Over on First Boston's Government bond desk, traders were giddy as prices jumped sharply in early trading. Traders and their customers were particularly impressed with the financial sophistication and command of the material that Mr. Clinton exhibited in his speech, said John P. Costas, First Boston's head Government bond trader.
"The level of experience that Clinton has in terms of the financial markets is unprecedented," Mr. Costas said. "The market appreciates facts and reality, not smoke and mirrors."
While First Boston is an investment bank that works mainly with corporations and institutions, it also serves wealthy individuals.
Off to the side of the trading floor, several dozen brokers in densely packed cubicles, spent yesterday morning chatting about the speech with their clients. There were more orders than usual, largely from customers who worried about higher income tax rates trading in Government bonds and buying tax-free municipal bonds.
"You could not have heard a more clear message that taxes are going up, and we started having people say, 'Enough is enough, let's buy munis,' " said Anthony Werley, the head of the retail department.
Away from the trading floor, the firm's investment bankers saw opportunities in Mr. Clinton's plan.
"Whenever the President creates change or even the specter of change, corporations need financial advice. That's what we do," said Charles P. Murphy, the firm's head of investment banking.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Foes of Corporate Tax Say It Hurts Investment

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
If President Clinton wants to jump-start investment and kick the American job machine into higher gear, why would he raise corporate taxes?
Arguing that the corporate tax makes capital more costly, favors debt financing and gums up the tax system, conservatives from Milton Friedman to Alan Greenspan have long advocated that it be abolished. The Treasury could easily replace the $100 billion or so it raises from corporations, they point out, by treating all businesses as partnerships and then taxing business owners -- the shareholders -- for profits or losses. 
Many public finance economists are inclined to agree that the corporate tax has serious drawbacks. But as a practical matter few are particularly upset by the President's proposal to raise the tax rate on large companies to 36 percent, from 34 percent. Combined with a temporary investment tax credit, they say, the increase is apt to raise money without discouraging new investment.
 
'Hard to Get Alarmed'
 "It's hard to get alarmed about a 2 percentage increase in the corporate tax rate," said Alan J. Auerbach, an economist at the University of Pennsylvania and, until recently, the chief economist at the Joint Tax Committee.
"I prefer lower rates and fewer preferences, including investment incentives," said Joel B. Slemrod, director of the Office of Tax Policy Research at the University of Michigan. "But it's not the biggest deal in the world."
James M. Poterba, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said, "It's a tax on past investments," adding, "A tax on something that can't be changed is a public finance economists' idea of a terrific tax."
In general, economists favor low rates over high ones because they believe that the free market allocates resources better than government tax writers. And the existence of two parallel tax systems, one for corporations, another for individuals, creates opportunities for people to shift income back and forth in hopes of evading the tax man, along with plenty of make-work for tax lawyers.
 
Reporting Less Here
 What is more worrisome to economists is that in a global economy populated by huge multinational corporations, raising corporate tax rates could actually reduce the Treasury's take by encouraging companies to report less income here and more in tax-friendlier nations.
"The lower the rate," Professor Slemrod said, "the greater incentives multinationals have to report income in the United States."
Still, the proposed increase would push the United States rate up only to 42.3 from 40.3 (including 6.5 percent of state and local taxes). That is higher than Britain's 33 percent rate but still comfortably below Germany's 45.5 percent and Japan's 51 percent.
The corporate tax also encourages debt financing, an inclination that got lots of companies in hot water when the 1980's economic boom abruptly ended. That is because the corporate tax is a double whammy. The I.R.S. peels off 34 cents of a dollar earned by a company and if the remaining 66 cents are paid out in dividends, Washington collects another 20 cents (31 percent times 66 cents) from shareholders. Since interest is deductible, the company can avoid the second whack by borrowing to pay for its new plant rather than selling stock to shareholders.
Anxiety about corporate debt has waned as corporate balance sheets have gotten lighter. Besides, economists point out, the rate increase is modest and still leaves the corporate tax 10 percentage points below its level in 1985 of 46 percent.
 
Bar to Investment?
 The biggest worry is that higher corporate taxes will raise the cost of capital to corporations and therefore discourage investment in new equipment and plants that would help the growth of productivity and living standards.
A higher rate would indeed make capital more costly for the following reason: Say investors demand a return of 8 percent. If the corporate tax is 34 cents for a dollar of profits, a company has to earn 12.1 cents for every dollar invested to pay them the return they want. With a higher 36 percent rate, they would have to earn 12.5 cents, roughly 3 percent more.
"If President Clinton simply raised the corporate income tax and did not change the investment tax credit or depreciation rules," Professor Poterba at M.I.T. said, "that would raise the cost of capital and discourage investment."
In fact, though, the Clinton Administration also wants to revive investment breaks that were done away with in the 1986 tax revision. It is proposing a two-year, 7 percent investment tax credit for big businesses and a permanent one for small companies, which would decline from 7 percent to 5 percent after two years. The credits would apply only to investments above and beyond some base amount.
The Treasury estimates that the credits would cost about $28.9 billion a year over the next five years, a bit less than the $30.6 billion the rate increase is expected to bring in.
"If you raise a dollar by increasing the corporate tax and gave it back through an investment tax credit, on balance, you lower cost of capital," Professor Auerbach said. "The two things together increase taxes on existing income and decrease taxes on future incomes."
 
Tax Not Permanent
 A drug company, say, that is earning lots of profits from a 10-year-old patent will pay more tax on those profits. That hurts the bottom line and may reduce the value of the company, but it does not affect decisions about whether to develop a new drug.
The real trouble with the Clinton proposal, experts said, is that the investment tax credit on big businesses is temporary.
"That's a big mistake," Professor Auerbach said. "they're trying to jump-start the economy and they have to catch it first to do that. We certainly do need more capital formation but we don't need it just in the next year or two."
A temporary credit, most evidence and experience suggests, does not increase the level of investment permanently. But by speeding up investments that companies planned on anyway, it risks robbing from future spending.
"A temporary I.T.C. will speed up investment now and then create a problem two years down the road," Professor Auerbach said. "Having more investment now at the cost of more investment later is not a good idea unless we want to find ourselves in another recession two years from now."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Industry Gauges Costs Of Proposed Energy Tax

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Energy analysts and industry officials said today that the new tax that President Clinton has proposed on the heat content of most fuels would alter costs unevenly among producers in the coal, oil and natural gas industries. Most said the impact on producers would outweigh any reduction in fuel consumption.
For instance, producers of thick, heavy-grade oil from California fields would face higher costs not only from the new tax on the oil itself but also because of new taxes on the natural gas they pump into reserves to loosen the oil and cause it to flow to oil wells. 
 Moreover, natural gas producers would be forced to add the taxes to their production costs at a time when cash prices in some areas remain depressed below $1.25 for 1,000 cubic feet. Some producers will be able to pass along the increases more easily than others because their relative costs are now lower.
Denise Bode, president of the Independent Petroleum Association of America, a trade group that represents small oil and gas drillers, said that various officials, including Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, had recently led natural gas drillers to believe that the Administration's policy proposals would favor increased production.
But after attending a White House briefing on the energy taxes this afternoon, Ms. Bode said she was taken aback. "We're talking about a serious problem," she said. If those California oil drillers produce less, demand for natural gas could fall.
But she added that the proposal is not yet final. Officials at the White House briefing welcomed comments that could lead to significant changes in the tax formulas before a bill is sent to Congress in late March.
In all, the oil industry will confront $3.5 billion in taxes on crude supplies purchased for the nation's refineries, according to Philip K. Verleger Jr., visiting fellow and energy economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
Refiners had recently shown signs of recovering from two years of weak profits caused by the recession, slack demand and stiff competition. If demand is adequate, they will add the higher taxes to prices for gasoline and other refined products, but if the economy sputters, profit margins could be squeezed anew.
Allen E. Murray, chairman and chief executive of the Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil company after the Exxon Corporation and a big refiner and gasoline retailer, attacked President Clinton's call for a higher tax on oil, compared with other fuels like natural gas and coal.
"Any tax designed to discriminate against particular segments of society is clearly unfair and not in the best interests of the nation," Mr. Murray said. He added that a tax on consumption would be more equitable.
In choosing a tax on the heat content of each fuel, as measured by British thermal units, President Clinton picked a tax that will affect all corners of the American economy, many in indirect ways. A British thermal unit, or B.T.U., is the quantity of heat needed to raise the temperature of a pound of water one degree.
The Clinton proposal is for a tax of 59.9 cents for each million B.T.U.'s of oil, or about $3.50 a barrel, and 25.7 cents for a million B.T.U.'s for natural gas, coal and nuclear power.
Some natural gas producers said that by taxing natural gas and coal equally, the Clinton proposal would delay or diminish the gas industry's hopes for displacing coal as a source for electric power generation.
"The biggest growth in gas usage in the United States can come from utilities, where gas competes directly against coal," said Anthony R. Lentini, a spokesman for the Mitchell Energy and Development Corporation in Houston. "This B.T.U. tax just keeps things the way they are. We think gas should get more favorable treatment because of its environmental benefits over coal."
Theodore R. Eck, chief economist at the Amoco Corporation, which holds the biggest natural gas reserves in North America, said: "I wouldn't think that many environmentalists think this is very good. This is not a 'green' bill. It's a greenback bill that puts greenbacks into the Treasury."
 
See Harm to Competiveness
 Large manufacturers in the Midwest that can heat or power their plants with coal or natural gas said that an energy tax probably would not change their consumption patterns because the tax as proposed would not favor one fuel over the other.
Rita Castle, a government-affairs manager at Caterpillar Inc., in Peoria, Ill., said the taxes would raise Caterpillar's production costs. And some economists said that companies like Caterpillar that are engaged in pricing wars with global competitors would be hurt by an energy tax.
"The Administration doesn't realize the trade impact here," said Mr. Eck of Amoco. "This bill would be a major problem for heavy industry that has to compete either in export or import markets like steel."
The Northeast-Midwest Institute, a research firm that analyzes the impact of Federal policy on states in those regions, estimated that the B.T.U. tax would raise the most revenue in the 14 Southern states from Virginia to Texas.
The institute said those states would contribute $7.6 billion of a total of $21.7 billion that the tax would generate yearly by 1997. The 6 New England states would pay $1.2 billion in higher energy taxes; the 5 Middle Atlantic states, including New York and New Jersey, would pay $3.4 billion; the 8 Midwestern states would pay $3.9 billion, and the 17 Western states would pay $5.7 billion, according to the institute.
 
Praise and Criticism
 Some large industrial energy suppliers and users applauded the President's proposal as a necessary step toward curbing the nation's widening budget deficit, even though their operations would be hurt.
Al Becker, a spokesman for American Airlines, said the nation's largest airline could see its yearly jet-fuel costs rise by tens of millions of dollars. Over all, the airline industry has lost $10 billion in the last three years.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Clinton's Aides Sell Message on the Trading Floor

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Two of the top economic aides to the President went to Wall Street yesterday and were greeted with praise for the Administration's efforts to reduce the deficit but were questioned on his commitment to cut spending.
The aides, Robert E. Rubin, chairman of the National Economic Council, and Alice M. Rivlin, deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget, met about 45 executives for lunch in the New York Stock Exchange board room to assure them about the President's plans. 
 The meeting, attended by the leaders of the nation's largest banks and investment firms and several other corporations, came at the Administration's request.
 
Friendly but With Doubts
 Mr. Rubin, in familiar surroundings as former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, and Ms. Rivlin received a friendly reception spiked with some doubts about whether Mr. Clinton would keep the best interests of business at heart.
"There's a general fear among some business executives that the President might well be taking a harder position than they expected," James A. Harmon, chief executive of Wertheim Schroder, said later as he was sending a note of thanks to Mr. Rubin. "To my point of view, Bob was very effective in alleviating those concerns."
But Mr. Harmon, noting the tone of the President's attacks on the pharmaceutical industry, added that he still worried about whether the Administration could retain business support.
The support of financial executives and investors is crucial for the President's economic plans, because stock and bond prices determine how readily companies can raise money to expand and hire.
 
Strong Support
 The President's aides found strong backing for their efforts to cut the deficit and ready acceptance of the need for tax increases. "We were concerned about the same issues," said Donald B. Marron, chief executive of Paine Webber and a major supporter of President George Bush.
He said he found the President's Wednesday night speech generally persuasive, adding, "This is the first time that the deficit has been so much on people's minds."
Several executives, however, pressed for more spending cuts and said that the President should have discussed them in more detail Wednesday night.
"There were people who wished there were even more -- the 2-to-1 ratio Panetta wanted," said Stephen Robert, the chairman of Oppenheimer & Company, referring to calls by Leon E. Panetta, the budget director, for twice the level of spending cuts as tax increases.
The President proposed greater tax increases than spending cuts and some at the meeting wondered whether Congress might grant him the spending cuts he requested. "They were all worried that by the time you finish with Congress, you get tax increases but less expense reduction," Mr. Harmon said.
 
Attracting Attention
 After the lunch, top executives of the exchange led Mr. Rubin and Ms. Rivlin onto the littered floor of the stock exchange. They attracted far more notice from a gaggle of photographers than from the scurrying traders and specialists.
In a news conference, the President's aides said Mr. Clinton deserved credit for the bond market's rise, but argued that the stock market's recent decline had nothing to do with his policies.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell almost 83 points on Tuesday -- the worst decline in 15 months -- after the President announced his broad budgetary themes on Monday evening. The stock market finished relatively even after swinging wildly yesterday, while yields on long-term Treasury bonds hit record lows.
In his decades of experience as a trader and executive, Mr. Rubin said, the stock market's response to new policies is more difficult to judge than the bond market's. "I don't view the stock market's behavior as related to anything the President has or hasn't done," he said.
 
The Alice and Bob Rally
 He jokingly noted, however, that the Dow Jones industrial average gained sharply during his stock exchange visit. "It was down 45 points when Alice and I went in to lunch, and it was up one point when we came out," he said.
Asked about Goldman's recommendation this week that in view of the President's program, clients should reduce their stock holdings, Mr. Rubin said, "It shows you how independent my former firm is from me."

Donaldson, the Big Board chairman, spoke with Alice M. Rivlin, deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: When the President Comes to Hyde Park;
Selling a Plan in the Town Where the Spirit of Roosevelt Is Everywhere

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 18

 BODY:
Verne Newton, director of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library here, received the strangest phone call at his home last Sunday afternoon.
It was from a guard at the library who said that some New York Telephone technicians were at the front gate and needed permission to install 20 new phone lines there. Immediately. To the amazement of the guard, and of Mr. Newton, the President of the United States was planning to come to town on Friday to sell his economic plan. 
 By the way, he wanted to stop at the library that housed memories of another President who led the nation through difficult times.
 
How to Get a Ticket?
 Forty-five minutes later, the White House called Mr. Newton to confirm that the trip was under consideration. And less than an hour after that, a Presidential advance team was knocking on his door. Little in Hyde Park has been the same since.
"A year and a half ago, I was a police sergeant," said Michael C. Clinch, a former New York City transit police officer who is the town's police chief. "Now I'm worrying about security for the President."
And he's not the only one. Secret Service agents, joined by dozens of other Federal and local law-enforcement officials, have spent the week combing the darkest corners of the library and the Haviland Middle School, where President Clinton will address about 500 people on Friday afternoon as part of a cross-country tour to rally support for his program.
Ever since word of the President's two-and-a-half hour visit to Hyde Park leaked out, the phone at the Town Supervisor's office has been ringing constantly: each of the town's 21,230 residents, it seemed, wanted to be in the audience. But no one -- certainly not town officials -- had any idea how the townspeople could get tickets.
"That's the question on everyone's mind," Merrilee Brown, the administrative assistant to the Town Supervisor, patiently told one caller who was angling for a seat. "We don't have a lot of firm information."
They do know why Bill Clinton is coming here: Hyde Park is Franklin D. Roosevelt's hometown -- and his spirit is everywhere.
The town's unofficial trademark, a silhouette of F.D.R.'s profile with a cigarette holder clenched in his mouth, is stenciled on the the menus at the Town n' Country Diner, on the Rotary Club banner and even on the business cards of the Town Supervisor, Nancy Alden.
The library and its adjoining museum -- crammed with President Roosevelt's papers and mementos, and run by the National Archives -- sit on the 188-acre Roosevelt estate, near the home that the President used as a vacation White House. A few miles down the road is Val-Kill, the house that Eleanor Roosevelt called home after her husband's death in 1945 and until she died in 1962. Both are buried in Hyde Park.
 
Invoking Roosevelt Aura
 Fiercely protective of the Roosevelt legacy, many people here said they were honored that President Clinton had chosen their town to sell his message of sacrifice in tough economic times.
"I think it's nice for the townspeople to have that here," said 99-year-old Helen Fink, who recalled shaking hands with President Roosevelt after he was elected Governor of New York and worshiping with him at St. James Episcopal Church. "I voted for Bush, but I do think we needed a change."
Some here cautioned the President, as he invoked the Roosevelt connection, not to overemphasize the parallels between the early 1930's and 1993.
"We're not in a depression," said Mary Ann Lohrey, who lives in nearby Poughkeepsie and once shared a memorable Washington cab ride with President Bush when he was a Congressman. "If Bush came up with too little too late, is this guy Clinton coming up with too much too early?"
Nevertheless, in a town heavily populated by people who work -- or once worked -- at one of the three struggling I.B.M. factories nearby, Mr. Clinton's address to Congress on Wednesday night provided fresh reasons for optimism, however cautious.
"I'll pay the tax, I'll pay my share," said Herman Staats, 65, the retired owner of a trucking company, as he ate an English muffin and sipped coffee this morning at the Town n' Country Diner. "The only reservation I have is that I would like to have some confirmation that this money will address the deficit and not be spent by Congressmen at their leisure."
After watching the President's address Wednesday night with about a dozen people gathered at the Town Supervisor's home, Katrina Brown, 18, said she was encouraged that Mr. Clinton was thinking about her generation.
"I just like how he said we had to do everything together," said Ms. Brown, a senior at Franklin D. Roosevelt High School. "I liked his environmental stance."
With the President's visit looming, however, his economic proposals took a backseat today to one, overarching question: Who will get to hear him speak?
Word had it that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, both Democrats, would accompany the President's motorcade from Stewart Airport in Newburgh, about 25 minutes away. But an official who saw the list of invited guests, and who insisted on anonymity, said prominent Republicans were on it too, including Representatives Hamilton Fish Jr. and Gerald B. Solomon, whose districts include parts of the Hudson Valley.
The Town Supervisor, Ms. Alden, said she will be there, as will the four-member town board. The rest of the audience, selected in part with the assistance of the Governor's office, will be filled out by business and civic leaders, as well as by officials from state, county and local governments.
The superintendent of the Hyde Park School District, Lloyd Jaeger, said he had been given "a substantial number" of tickets to distribute to students and teachers from the elementary, middle and high schools. How did he make his selections?
"We've made some determinations on an equitable basis," he said cryptically. "That's how we're doing it."
With many people frantically turning their schedules upside down just to be in town on Friday, it was clear that life in Hyde Park has, of late, been anything but normal.
"I had planned on a very quiet week, making plans with my 11-year-old daughter that I have since had to cancel," said Virginia Carrig, executive director of the Hyde Park Chamber of Commerce. "But I told her that this is what Chelsea Clinton has to go through all the time. She only has to do it for a week."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Executives Mix Worry With Praise

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Business ex ecutives found much to praise and worry about -- in President Clinton's economic program.
"Everybody's watching and waiting to see what happens," said Kenneth Pontikes, chairman and chief executive of Comdisco Inc., the nation's largest independent computer leasing company. Mr. Pontikes said that after speaking with his tax advisers and several customers, his growing optimism about the economy had been tempered by a feeling of caution that would persist until it was clearer what Congress would do with the proposals. 
 "Once it gets into the tax committees in Congress, you don't know what will come out," he said.
 
Churning Out Numbers
 But accounting firms and business consultants were quick to jump into any information void, racing to churn out analyses today of the impact of the proposals. In most cases, the numbers they used were provided by the Treasury Department. The analyses underscored how hard it is to pinpoint all the details of the Clinton program.
Consider, for example, the proposal to deny tax deductions for lobbying expenses. The Administration calculates that eliminating the deduction will add $978 million to Government revenues by the end of 1998. "What about trade association memberships?" asked Andre Fogarasi, managing director in the office of tax services for Arthur Andersen & Company in Washington. "How much of that is lobbying? How much of that is good will? How much of that is charitable? That's unresolved."
 
Waiting for Facts
 But a wait-and-see attitude was prevalent among business executives. The first impression of top management at the Sara Lee Corporation, for example, was that the new energy tax could be passed on to customers and that investment tax credits would more or less offset the proposed increase in corporate taxes. The provision to lessen tax breaks for United States companies operating in Puerto Rico would not have a major impact on Sara Lee's factories there.
A reduction in deductions for entertainment from 80 percent to 50 percent might lead to some belt-tightening, and a limit on the deductibility of executive compensation over $1 million might alter some compensation packages, suggested John H. Bryan Jr., Sara Lee's chairman and chief executive. But major investments are dictated by long-range strategic goals and the proposals would not affect those decisions, he said.
"It's interesting theater, but it's not going to change the way we do business," said Mr. Bryan, who was one of Mr. Clinton's most prominent supporters during the Presidential campaign. A longtime critic of using taxes to shape policy, Mr. Bryan said he was dismayed at the prospect of raising overall tax levels as a means to finance specific tax relief. But he said that the general program was "courageous" and did not push corporate taxes out of line with those paid by most foreign competitors in their home countries.
"The key thing that makes this palatable is that it is the first dramatic move against the deficit," he said.
 
Troubling Outlooks
 To be sure, some companies foresee a major negative impact on their operations from the proposals. And some saidd they are already planning to lobby Congress against certain parts of the Clinton plan.
"The energy tax is a major concern," said Donald J. Schneider, chief executive of Schneider International Inc., the nation's largest trucking firm. Fuel accounts for 18 percent to 20 percent of his company's costs, Mr. Schneider said, and the industry is too competitive for price increases to be passed on to customers.
"This gives railroads an unfair advantage, and it penalizes people like the paper industry with operations in remote areas," he said.
 
Entrepreneur Commitments
 Some executives said the most important aspects of the Clinton plan were not changes in policies but commitments to existing policies. "When I heard his technical agenda, I had to rub my hands and say, that's us," said Joseph Engleberger, founder of Transitions Research Corporations Inc. in Danbury, Conn. The start-up company has been designing robots to work as nurses' aides in hospitals and in home maintenance tasks and would benefit from Government funding of high-technology programs.

HEADLINE: Solid if Unheroic, Regan Leaves Books Tidy

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Edward V. Regan, who announced his resignation as State Comptroller today, leaves behind a record as a sound manager of the state's pension funds, a prolific auditor of state agencies and local governments and a consistent critic of the state's heavy borrowing and fiscal gimmickry.
But he also leaves a legacy as a government official who, despite more than 14 years as Comptroller, never really became a major force in either the fiscal or electoral politics of the state. 
 Mr. Regan, a Republican, announced his resignation today at what arguably may be the pinnacle of his influence.
After lobbying for years against the state's growing indebtedness, he succeeded this year in negotiating with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo a package of changes in how the state handles its debt. He also played a role in turning public opinion against the Governor's economic-development bond act, which failed at the polls last November. It was the second major bond act rejected in two years after being criticized by Mr. Regan.
 
He Cites Goals Met
 Mr. Regan suggested strongly today that he was stepping down at a time when many of his goals had been accomplished.
"For the first time in 30 years, school districts, New York City and local governments received their vital state-aid payments on time because the state's practice of rolling over deficits each year was eliminated," he said in a statement. "The acquisition of debt by the state is, with the enthusiastic leadership of the Governor and many legislators, about to be disciplined and put under the oversight of the voting public. And the state and local retirement fund has an international reputation for excellence."
And yet Mr. Regan, partly because of the limitations of his office and partly because of the tentativeness of his personality, still has not won the political respect afforded Mr. Cuomo or the leaders of the Legislature. His critics complain that he rarely used the strongest devices at his disposal to force the Governor and the Legislature to change their fiscal practices.
Never, they said, did Mr. Regan refuse to certify the state budget as balanced -- which is necessary for the state to sell bonds -- in order to force the Governor and the Legislature to reorganize the state's finances. And only once did Mr. Regan file suit to block one of the state's budgetary gimmicks for creating cash.
That was in 1991, when Mr. Regan challenged the state's decision to borrow $80 million from the Thruway Authority for its general fund. Mr. Cuomo eventually killed the scheme, and Mr. Regan withdrew the lawsuit.
 
Dogged by Early Reputation
 Mr. Regan earned a reputation for weakness and naivete early in his career in Albany and never succeeded in shedding it.
He was on a ski slope in Vermont, unavailable to reporters, when he authorized an aide to announce that he would run for Governor in 1982. Shortly thereafter, he withdrew from the race after Edward I. Koch, a Democrat, joined it.
In 1988, prosecutors investigated Mr. Regan's fund-raising practices after the disclosure of a memorandum from a top aide that suggested that financial firms contributing to Mr. Regan's campaign would receive state business. He also faced enduring criticism for recommending in the early 1980's that school districts place money in a high-risk investment fund that collapsed.
But Mr. Regan, who is the administrator of the state's pension fund, the second largest in the country, generally had a good record as an investor.
 
Managerial Role
 The state's pension fund grew to $56 billion from $10 billion during his 14 years in office. Over time, Mr. Regan invested a much larger percentage of the fund in the stock market, and it averaged annual growth of 13.4 percent over the last 10 years.
The Comptroller has long been a leading voice in Albany for fiscal responsibility. During his tenure, he helped persuade state leaders to change accounting practices so that the practices now account for appropriations and not just cash expenditures. He also was instrumental in encouraging Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature to end the annual practice of borrowing huge sums every spring to make aid payments to school districts and local governments.
The 62-year-old Mr. Regan, who married for the second time last year, was first elected Comptroller in 1978 after losing a race for the office in 1974. He is a former Erie County Executive and Buffalo City Councilman.

HEADLINE: A Revised Cuomo Budget Reduces Cuts for Schools

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo released a revised budget today that gives an additional $78 million in aid to public schools, greatly reducing proposed cuts for dozens of middle-income school districts on Long Island and in Westchester County.
The revised budget still calls for a $52 million reduction in the $8.6 billion school aid package. But by tinkering with his proposed school aid formula, Mr. Cuomo softened, and in some cases eliminated, cuts for 255 districts. Yonkers, for instance, which would have lost $536,841 under Mr. Cuomo's original budget, would now gain $1.5 million in aid. 
 Mr. Cuomo's budget and his proposed school aid formula still face an uncertain future in the Legislature. His formula, which is intended to give significantly more money to poor school districts, has come under fire from suburban legislators whose districts stand to lose the most aid.
But by altering his formula to give more money to suburban districts of average wealth and by sweetening the total school aid pot, Mr. Cuomo is seeking to broaden support for what had been a highly unpopular proposal, his aides said.
 
'Responsive to Concerns'
 While that is not likely to lead to wholesale support for his plan, it means that aspects of it could pass the Legislature this session provided the school aid cuts are reduced even further, legislators said.
"If there is overall increase in aid, the Senate might go for some changes in terms of redistribution," said Senator Charles D. Cook, a Republican who is chairman of the Senate Education Committee. "I'm pleased he has apparently been responsive to concerns he's heard."
The $78 million in new school aid was shifted from other parts of the budget and will not increase Mr. Cuomo's proposed $31.5 billion general-fund budget, his aides said. The largest part of the money came from recalculations in Medicaid costs, which were found to be $34 million less than anticipated, budget officials said.
Mr. Cuomo portrayed his changes to the proposed school aid formula as minor tinkering that hewed closely to his goals of simplifying the complex aid system and redistributing aid to poorer districts. "It more truly reflects wealth, it more truly reflects people's cost of living," Mr. Cuomo said of the revisions in a radio interview tonight.
 
Targets Some Districts
 But his aides acknowledged that the original plan had cut aid to some districts with large concentrations of poor students. The new formula restores much of that aid by targeting districts of average or below-average wealth that also pay relatively high school taxes. It also creates a safety net that insures that no district will lose more than 2 percent of its total budget next year.
"We wanted to make sure no district was disproportionately hit in the transition year," said Andrew J. Zambelli, Mr. Cuomo's chief of staff. "This increases its probability of success in the Legislature."
New York City's aid would not change under the revised formula, remaining at $2.76 billion, $6.2 million more than last year. But Mr. Zambelli said the revised formula would provide much more money to the city in better economic times.
 
3 Districts That Benefit
 Other districts that benefit from Mr. Cuomo's revisions include Hempstead in Nassau County, whose cut was reduced from $1.9 million to $359,993, and the Three Village School District in Suffolk County, whose cut was reduced from $2.9 million to $254,709. In Westchester County, the Port Chester School District would receive an additional $331,863 in aid instead of the original proposed increase of $93,937.
But scores of wealthier school districts, most of them in New York City's suburbs, would continue to receive sharp cuts under the revised formula. School administrators in those districts have said the aid reductions could lead to teacher layoffs, larger classes and higher property taxes.
While Republican applauded Mr. Cuomo's revisions as "a step in the right direction," they said they will fight any cuts in school aid.
And they remained critical of other aspects of his budget, saying it still gives too much money to welfare programs, still takes money from a dedicated fund for transportation projects known as the "locked box," and is still based on predictions for the economy that are too gloomy.

HEADLINE: Comptroller Resigns Albany Post To Head Institute at Bard College

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 18

 BODY:
State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, the top-ranking Republican in state government, announced today that he was resigning the job he has held since 1979 to become president of an economics institute at Bard College.
Mr. Regan's announcement stunned his staff and the state's political establishment, setting off a whirl of speculation about whom the Legislature would select to replace him. 
 Carol Bellamy, the former New York City Council president who narrowly lost the 1990 state comptroller's race to Mr. Regan, quickly announced her candidacy. Assemblyman G. Oliver Koppell, a Bronx Democrat, said he was considering the race.
 
Other Possibilities
 Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi, a Queens Democrat who has been planning a race this year for New York City comptroller, will not formally announce a campaign for state comptroller, his political consultant, Hank Morris, said. "But if lightning were to strike, he wouldn't step out of the way," Mr. Morris added.
Several prominent black legislators said they would push for a minority candidate to be elected to a statewide office for the first time, and they said their first choice would be H. Carl McCall, president of the New York City Board of Education.
The State Constitution calls for the 211 members of the Legislature, sitting in a joint session, to select someone to fill the Comptroller's unexpired term. Because 127 of the 211 lawmakers are Democrats, the election of a Democrat is virtually assured. The numbers will give a king-making role to Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat who presides over the 101 Democrats who form the majority in his house.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who may run for re-election in 1994, also is likely to play a central role. He almost certainly will want a comptroller who would help balance his ticket and pull out Democratic votes in next year's election.
Mr. Regan, whose term runs through 1994, said he would leave office at the end of April. Mr. Weprin, who returned to New York City from a Florida vacation this afternoon, said he "hadn't had time to digest" the situation but saw no need to rush a vote.
In both a statement and a news conference in Manhattan, Mr. Regan offered few clues about why he was leaving his job in the middle of his term to become president and governor of the Jerome Levy Economics Institute. The center describes itself as a nonpartisan research center and is on the Bard campus in Annandale-on-Hudson.
 
Contributor to Campaigns
 Founded in 1986, the institute makes economic forecasts, keeps 10 scholars in residence, sponsors conferences and publishes books and papers. Mr. Regan had served on the institute's advisory board for the last two years. Leon Levy, who founded the institute in memory of his father, has been a contributor to Mr. Regan's campaigns, giving $2,500 in 1991.
Mr. Regan, who makes $110,000 a year as Comptroller, is to receive a salary of $175,000 at the institute. Officials in the Comptroller's office said Mr. Regan would immediately be eligible to receive a state pension estimated at $49,370 a year.
Mr. Regan called his new job a "prestigious national post" and said he was excited by the prospect of trying "to improve the capacity of the United States to create jobs and employ people."
Several state officials could not shake off their amazement, however, that Mr. Regan was stepping down to take what they characterized as a decidedly low-profile job.
 
'Hard to Fathom'
 "If he was resigning to become president of the Rockefeller Foundation, maybe I'd say, 'O.K., I understand,' " Mr. Koppell said. "But this doesn't sound like a very prestigious position. It's hard to fathom."
Several state officials close to Mr. Regan, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said Nr. Regan had decided to resign after concluding that he would not run for governor and that he wanted to change careers before he grew too old to do so.
Some Republican leaders faulted Mr. Regan, who is 62 years old, for giving the Democrats the chance to fill the vacancy with a Democrat, which would leave Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato as the only Republican official elected statewide.
Mr. Regan did not inform his closest aides of his decision until late Wednesday night. Those who work with him daily, many of whom may find themselves looking for work, said they had no idea that he was considering a change.
"Do you have any more information?" one Regan aide asked. "I mean, this is nuts. You'd think we would have seen signs. The only sign I can think of is that he's been in a really good mood the past three weeks."
While many in state government pondered Mr. Regan's reasoning, politicians around the state wasted little time jockeying for a job that could serve as an instant springboard to statewide prominence.
 
Some Quick Support
 Ms. Bellamy, a Democrat, made a point of getting out of the box first by announcing her candidacy at an afternoon news conference in Manhattan. She received a quick boost from the State Senate minority leader, Manfred Ohrenstein, a Manhattan Democrat, who issued a statement urging "my fellow Democrats to strongly consider Carol Bellamy." Mayor David N. Dinkins said he would also support her.
Mr. Ohrenstein's endorsement was significant because even if a candidate received all 101 Democratic votes in the Assembly, the candidate still would need 5 Democratic votes from the Senate to compile a majority.
One Albany-based political consultant, William Cunningham, joked that it would only be fair for Ms. Bellamy to get the job because "she got 49 percent of the vote in 1990 and there's about 49 percent of the term left."
 
Balance for Ticket
 Looking ahead to the 1994 elections, the state Democratic chairman, John A. Marino, said that "it would be preferable at this point" to appoint a woman or a member of a minority group to the comptroller's job. That would provide some balance to a Democratic ticket that would include three white men if Mr. Cuomo, Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine and Attorney General Robert Abrams all run for re-election.
Two black Democratic members of the Assembly, Clarence Norman Jr. and Albert Vann, both of Brooklyn, called for a minority candidate to be appointed. They both mentioned Mr. McCall as a top choice, but Mr. McCall's spokeswoman, Linda Scott, said he had not decided whether to seek the job.
Republican leaders, including the state party chairman, William D. Powers, and the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, quickly united around Clarence D. Rappleyea Jr., the Assembly minority leader from Norwich.
"I would welcome the opportunity to wrestle with New York's fiscal problems as state comptroller," said Mr. Rappleyea, who also has been considering a 1994 race for governor. "But since the Democrats in the Legislature will pick who gets the job, I'm not optimistic about my chances."

Regan, left, who resigned as State Comptroller to accept a position with an economics institute at the college. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times) (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Student Lending Stocks Plunge

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
President Clinton's plan to phase in direct Government lending to students sent the shares of companies in the business into a virtual free fall yesterday.
Investors feared that the plan -- called a "national service loan" by the President in his speech Wednesday night -- would ravage the business of the Student Loan Marketing Assocation, known as Sallie Mae, as well as the Student Loan Corporation, which is controlled by Citicorp. 
 Sallie Mae shares dropped $9.375 each, or 17 percent, to $47.25. It was the most actively traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange, with more than 3.6 million shares changing hands. Student Loan also fell 17 percent to $15.50, down $3.25.
Sallie Mae, a federally chartered company based in Washington, does not originate loans, but it buys and services about a third of all student loans made by banks. Student Loan, based in Rochester, which went public late last year, is the second-largest holder, with 6.5 to 7 percent of the market.
The companies had already been under pressure for weeks on speculation that the Administration would propose a radical change in the guaranteed student loan program.
Under the proposed changes, student loans would be changed to 50 percent direct lending beginning in 1997, with the total shift taking place the following year. The phase-in was an attempt to cushion the effect on the agencies.
While the plan announced on Wednesday seeks only a gradual shift to direct lending, analysts said the companies still faced big political uncertainties.
Comments by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen that "valuable dollars" could be saved from the fees being paid to commercial banks to operate the program helped to depress the stocks, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Shifts in Tax On Income Are Blocked By Weicker

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. ignored a last-minute plea by legislative leaders today and vetoed legislation that would have given tax relief to the middle class by shifting the burden to those with higher incomes.
Almost two years after Connecticut enacted its first income tax, Democrats controlling the Legislature adopted revisions that they said would make the tax more fair. 
 But Mr. Weicker, who had repeatedly said he would veto the measure, scoffed at that notion. In his veto message he said the proposal "faintly whispers of tax relief, but shouts loud and clear that our revenue system will again be subject to political tinkering."
Under the plan, couples earning more than $145,000 and single people earning more than $75,400 would have had their incomes above that threshold taxed at 6.25 percent. The current rate is a flat 4.5 percent.
 
Seeking an Override
 The $156 million generated by the tax increase would have paid for some middle-class tax cuts, like a deduction for dependents and property tax credits.
Mr. Weicker's veto was attacked by legislative leaders.
"This veto is a slap in the face for every working man and woman," said the Senate President Pro Tem, John B. Larson. "It just seems to me Weicker doesn't get it. He doesn't have to struggle to make ends meet."
Mr. Larson and House Speaker Thomas D. Ritter promised to seek votes for an override. "We're not going to have this session be dominated by this, but I think in the next couple of weeks, we'll see whether there are votes," Mr. Ritter said.
In the House, the bill passed 84-66 -- far short of the 101 needed to override the veto. However, Mr. Ritter said he might seek support by tacking on items Republicans had sought, such as day-care tax credits.
 
A Warning of Instability
 In his two-page veto message, Mr. Weicker, an independent third-party Governor, said that the income tax was enacted to bring stability to Connecticut's tax system, which had become a victim of the state's volatile economy.
In part because of dwindling revenues and in part because of unwieldy spending in the 1980's, the state had accumulated a $2 billion debt by the time Mr. Weicker took office in January 1991.
To tinker again with the income tax, Mr. Weicker said, would inject another dose of instability.
"The introduction of a new, higher tax rate into our current flat rate tax system shatters our recently reacquired fiscal order and confirms the worst fears of those who believe Connecticut has not learned anything from its painful past," he said.
The Governor also disputed lawmakers' contention that the proposed changes in the tax system would not bring in additional state revenue.
Mr. Weicker said it would increase revenue by $13 million in the next fiscal year and $29 million in the following year.
Several days before the Legislature voted on the bill, Mr. Weicker said that it would raise an additional $38 million. Legislators then added another $38 million in middle-class tax cuts to fulfill their pledge to keep the revisions revenue-neutral.

HEADLINE: Mark Ellingson, 88, Educator Who Led Technology Institute

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Dr. Mark Ellingson, educator and president of Rochester Institute of Technology for 33 years, died at his home in Rochester on Feb. 12. He was 88.
Complications from a stroke caused his death, William McKee, the spokesman for the institute, said. 
 During Dr. Ellingson's lengthy tenure in office from 1936 to 1969, enrollment in day and evening classes rose from 2,250 to 16,000. The endowment increased from $1.5 million to about $22 million and total assets climbed from $2.4 million to about $111 million.
 
Introduced New Programs
 Through Dr. Ellingson's vision, the institute built the present 1,300-acre campus in Henrietta, a suburb of Rochester. Under his direction, new programs were introduced in science, engineering, printing, photography, the crafts and business administration.
One of his first acts as president was to incorporate into the institute the Empire State School of Printing, founded by Frank E. Gannett. Dr. Ellingson also brought to the university the School for American Craftsmen in 1950 and the National Technical Institute for the Deaf in 1966.
He joined the faculty of the Rochester Athenaeum and Mechanics Institute, forerunner of the Rochester Institute of Technology, in 1926. He served as an economics instructor for 10 years before becoming president.
Born in Magrath, Alberta, Canada, he graduated from Gooding College (Idaho), receiving a master's degree from the University of Rochester and a Ph.D. from Ohio State University.
He is survived by his wife, the former Marcia Cooke Randall; three daughters, Laura Kathryn Allen of Carlsbad, Calif., Louise, of Rochester, Karen Marie Trueheart of Pittsford, N.Y.; a son, Jon Eric, of Missoula, Mont., and nine grandchildren.
