HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Deficit Grew 29% in 1992

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit widened last year as the economic recovery revived Americans' appetite for imports and as economic stagnation in Japan and Western Europe dampened demand for American goods there, the Commerce Department said today.
The amount of merchandise imported into the United States exceeded the amount exported by $84.34 billion, a 29 percent increase from $65.40 billion in 1991. The deterioration in the overall trade balance followed four years of steady improvement from a trade deficit of $152.12 billion in 1987. 
 "It basically shows us how much our recovery depends on recovery in our major trading partners," Robert D. Hormats, a vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, said. Rising exports accounted for half the economic growth during the Bush Administration, while weak demand abroad is hurting the American economy now.
 
Administration Response
 Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, issued a statement saying the trade imbalance shows how real President Clinton's concerns about the economy are. "As long as we invest too little, as long as we neglect the budget deficit, as long as we fail to stimulate the natural creative energy of this country, we will continue to suffer trade deficits and leave Americans idle," Mr. Kantor said.
Stephen L. Cooney Jr., the senior policy director for international investment and finance at the National Association of Manufacturers, said he expects the trade deficit to widen in 1993, as the American economy continues to pick up steam and foreign markets languish. After four years of trade surpluses with the European Community, the United States had trade deficits with the community in November and December, he pointed out.
The seasonally adjusted trade deficit for December narrowed slightly to $6.95 billion from $7.35 billion in November, the Commerce Department also said today. Exports rose by 4 percent in December, to $39.73 billion, while imports increased by 2.5 percent, to $46.69 billion.
Total merchandise trade exports last year were $448.16 billion, while imports totaled $532.50 billion, the Commerce Department said. Critics have suggested that the figures may be misleading because the exports tend to be underreported and because the merchandise trade figures do not include trade in services, like insurance. The United States consistently runs a small trade surplus in services. Overall trade figures, including services, will be published later this winter.
As other industrialized economies remain mired in recession, American businesses have been shifting their sights to the developing world. Almost all of the nation's growth in exports last year came from sales to poor and middle-income countries, which rose 13.6 percent.
Accounting for much of the increase, exports to Mexico rose to $40.60 billion, from $33.28 billion in 1991.
 
Fewer Exports to Japan
 Exports to other developed countries rose only 1.7 percent last year, and exports to Japan dipped by three-quarters of a percentage point. The trade deficit with Japan widened to $5.09 billion in December, the largest monthly deficit since $5.21 billion in October 1988.
Japan's Finance Ministry announced on Tuesday that the Japanese trade surplus with all countries, including the United States, widened in January to a seasonally adjusted figure of $9.82 billion from $9.48 billion in December.
 Most of the increase in the American trade deficit last year came in consumer goods other than automobiles. Imports of cotton apparel showed the biggest increase, surging by $3.09 billion, to $13.80 billion. Imports of toys, games and sporting goods rose to $11.35 billion, a $1.94 billion increase.
By contrast, the nation's trade deficit in automobiles was virtually unchanged at $44.86 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Mixed After Advancing Overseas

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mixed yesterday after advancing in foreign markets, as traders worldwide assessed President Clinton's sweeping economic plan.
Gold prices declined. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $330.70 a troy ounce, down 30 cents from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 10 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $330. 
 The dollar rallied in overseas trading in an early technical response to Mr. Clinton's $500 billion plan to cut the deficit through tax increases and spending cuts.
When activity shifted to domestic markets, trading started with a jolt after stocks on Wall Street shot up early in the trading session and bond prices soared as interest rates declined. But the stock market soon retreated.
 
Rally Was Expected
 "The foreign exchange market thought the dollar ought to rally, too," said Lisa Pazer, an analyst with MMS International. "But then rationality set in, and the market started to consider the contractionary implications of the Clinton plan."
Higher taxes levied at both corporations and consumers could cut back on spending over all. And Mr. Clinton's pledge to work toward lower interest rates was also negative for the dollar.
Low interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors, thereby decreasing their need for the United States currency.
Trading was active and choppy. Dealers essentially ignored Government reports showing a five-tenths of a percent surge in consumer prices in January; a modest decline in jobless claims earlier this month, and a deterioration in American's trade balance last year.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 119.97 yen, up 0.72 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 119.60 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 119.15 yen, down from 119.65 from yen on Wednesday.
In London, the pound rose to $1.4460, from $1.4435 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.4475 to buy one pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.4455.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6310 German marks, up from 1.6250; 1.5060 Swiss francs, up from 1.4990; 5.5210 French francs, up from 5.5025; 1,554.00 Italian lire, up from 1,542.00, and 1.2604 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2636.

HEADLINE: Tax Provision on Donations Could Be a Boon to Museums

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
Buried in the sweeping economic plan outlined by President Clinton on Wednesday is a provision on tax deductions for charitable gifts that would produce far-reaching benefits for museums, universities, conservation groups and other nonprofit organizations.
The provision, by eliminating a measure in the 1986 Tax Reform Act, would make all major gifts to nonprofit organizations fully deductible at current market value rather than at the purchase price, which is nearly always much lower. This would encourage art collectors, for example, to donate paintings to museums rather than holding onto them or selling them on the open market.
 
The Cost in Lost Revenue
 The proposal would cost the Federal Government about $70 million a year in lost revenue, the Treasury Department estimated in a document released yesterday. 
 Mr. Clinton's proposal, included yesterday in an elaboration on his televised economic address, was greeted enthusiastically by officials at a number of nonprofit cultural organizations, which have seen a steep decline in gifts as a result of the 1986 act.
"It's superb news," said William H. Luers, the president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. "It means that the Clinton Administration supports investment in our large cultural institutions around the country."
As part of the President's new tax package, the proposal must clear the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. The same provision was passed by Congress last year in a comprehensive tax bill that was vetoed by President George Bush.
Under the 1986 provision, a collector who gave a painting to an art museum could claim only the purchase price as a deduction, not the full market value, as the earlier rules provided. For example, a donor who bought a painting for $100,000 in 1970 and saw its market value soar to $1 million in 1986 would be allowed a charitable deduction of only $100,000. In the booming art market of the 1980's, such increases were not all that unusual.
Museums and other nonprofit institutions were hit hard by the change. In the two years after the 1986 Tax Reform Act was passed, gifts to museums dropped more than 60 percent, according to a survey conducted by the American Association of Museums, a professional organization that represents 2,700 American museums.
Congress suspended part of the 1986 rule for the 18 months between Jan. 1, 1991, and June 30, 1992. The suspension applied to tangible property, like paintings or scientific specimens, but not to nontangible property, like securities, or to real estate.
The change caused a surge in gift-giving that museum officials cited when speculating on the probable impact of the Clinton proposal.
The Art Institute of Chicago, for example, received 1,895 works of art as gifts in December 1991. In December 1992, after the temporary suspension of tax restrictions expired, that number declined to 27. The Metropolitan Museum experienced a fourfold increase in the value of its gifts during the suspension, Mr. Luers said.
 
To 110 Gifts From 10
 Monticello, the museum at the home of Thomas Jefferson in Charlottesville, Va., received 10 gifts of objects in 1991. That number jumped to 110 when the 1986 rule was suspended.
Museum officials said they expected Mr. Clinton's proposal to have a similar effect. And officials at universities, which depend heavily on donations of securities and real estate, also expressed optimism that they would now reap the same kind of benefits as art museums did under the lifting of the 1986 rule.
Although discussion of the 1986 rule tends to focus on wealthy donors giving artworks valued in the millions of dollars, it has affected small and medium-sized institutions that depend on donors of modest means.
"It makes gift-giving possible for people who do not have a lot of money," said Susan Stein, the curator of Monticello. "Many of the gifts we received in 1991 were valued at perhaps $10,000."
Ms. Stein said she hoped the new provision would make it possible for Monticello to avoid competing with wealthy private collectors on the open market for acquisitions.
"Now we can tell people that if they give the object, it will be as valuable to them as if they sell it," she said.
 
Big Impact in New York City
 Evan H. Turner, the director of the Cleveland Museum of Art, said: "The window that closed last June led to our receiving gifts that donors had long considered giving us, and when the window was opened they did so immediately. The opening of that window again will have a significant impact."
New York City, because it has such a large concentration of major museums, would feel the impact of the proposed change perhaps more than any other city. Luis R. Cancel, the city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, said: "Restoration of the full tax benefit for the donor is going to immediately translate into a windfall of important cultural objects coming to New York City. This is something that the museum community has championed for many years now, and we are very, very pleased."
The proposal's sponsor in the Senate will Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who in his first public remarks as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee two weeks ago reiterated his strong support for it. "If there is a tax measure I will vote for, it will have that measure," he said.
Some museum officials described the proposed changes as a return to sanity. Mr. Luers of the Metropolitan said: "The paradox of this whole thing is that at the time when the 1986 law was passed, putting an end to decades-old patterns of behavior, the Europeans were trying to institute it. They had discovered over the last 30 to 40 years that one of the benefits that made our cultural institutions world-renowned was that the Government had encouraged this type of philanthropy through tax policy."
Referring to the Clinton proposal, James R. Wood, the director of the Art Institute of Chicago, said: "It's good on many levels, and it comes at an important time. The museum world has no illusions; the next four to five years are going to be tough. But this gives us an incentive to go out and make it on our own."

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

A Collection in Danger
The London art world is in an uproar over what may turn into de-accessioning at the highest level. An internal British Treasury Department document that was leaked to the press last week proposed selling off the Government's extraordinary holdings of paintings and furniture. These works of art, which include paintings by artists like Gainsborough, Walter Richard Sickert, Augustus John and Frank Auerbach, adorn British Embassies and Government offices around the world. 
 "It's outrageous," said George Levy, a former president of the British Antique Dealers Association. "To denude our embassies -- well, we would be made a laughingstock all over the world. Next we'll hear the Government wants to sell off the pictures in the National Gallery so they can turn the building into a hotel."
The Treasury Department takes a less passionate view. "This area, like all areas of public expenditure, are routinely kept under review," said Irene Campbell, a spokeswoman for the department. "It's natural that the value be examined."
Meanwhile, the Department of National Heritage, the arm of the Government in charge of overseeing the nation's art treasures, is trying to minimize the document's importance. "The Treasury Department is looking into all aspects of Government spending, so it is not surprising that they would examine the art holdings," said Frances Elliott, a press officer for the arts, libraries and museums at the National Heritage Department. "But we have no plans to sell off anything at the moment."
In the House of Commons on Monday, Anne Clwyd, a Labor M.P., asked the National Heritage Department to detail the value and size of the Government's collection and specify in which public buildings the works are kept. Robert Key, the Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for the department, responded, "No market valuation of the Government art collection exists, because the art is not actively traded."
He did say, however, that the collection includes 2,464 paintings, as well as other works of art, and that they are in about 600 British Government buildings throughout the world. Mr. Key himself is said to have a Cecil Beaton photograph of the composer Benjamin Britten on a wall in his office, while Sir Peter Brooke, the Secretary of State for National Heritage, has two paintings by John Piper and a painting by Mr. Auerbach in his office. They are all Government property.
In Washington, Peter Beene, who heads the press office at the British Embassy, said that no requests had been made to give up works of art in the embassy and that he knew of no plans to sell off any of the furniture and paintings in either the embassy or in the ambassador's residence, which was built by Sir Edwin Lutyens and which is currently occupied by Sir Robin Renwick.
If the British Government does put any of its art treasures up for sale, it might have a bit of a problem: many of the works would probably be declared national treasures and therefore could not be sold for export, a stricture that would significantly limit the market for these pricey works of art.
 
Mallett's, Anyone?
 Mallett Plc., an institution in the London antiques world, may be up for sale, too. Or it may become the victim of a takeover. Since December, the word among furniture experts has been that the 128-year-old publicly traded London gallery was so battered by the recession that it was looking for a white knight. Sales at Mallett's, which is based on New Bond Street, began suffering in the early 90's, when many Americans, discouraged by a highly unfavorable exchange rate, stopped coming to London to buy furniture; they had accounted for about 45 percent of Mallett's business.
The House of Fraser, owner of Harrods, holds 29.9 percent of Mallett's stock. Another major presence is Asprey, the venerable silver, jewelry and antiques store on New Bond Street, which purchased 6.8 percent of the gallery's stock in December. "It's a business in tune with ours," said Edward Green, the director of Asprey in New York. "It's good to have friends in the same camp. What the future holds, at this point I can't say." 
Other parties who have expressed interest in becoming involved with Mallett's include Bruce Newman, the owner of Newel Art Galleries, on East 53d Street. "I had discussions with them in November, geared toward working out a merger of sorts," he said. "It's a great company. I don't want to take them over, but to expand is another thing." Mr. Newman said he was still hopeful that the two businesses could work together.
Peter Dixon, Mallett's finance director, said that the company had also been approached by a suitor, whom he declined to name but who had offered to buy the entire business. "But at this point there have been no concrete developments," he said.
 
This Round, to Sotheby's
 In New York, Sotheby's and Christie's are scrambling to get what few name collections are up for grabs. Recently, Sotheby's snagged one, the Old Master paintings, Renaissance bronzes, European furniture and decorative objects, and color bookplates amassed by the real-estate magnate Peter Sharp, who died in April. The works are estimated to be worth more than $15 million.
Diana D. Brooks, the president and chief executive of Sotheby's in New York, confirmed that the auction house had secured the sale but said that no auction date had yet been scheduled.
In the hope of winning over Mr. Sharp's heirs, Christie's had inserted a brochure advertising his Manhattan apartment into catalogues for its sale of Impressionist and contemporary art last May. But Sotheby's won out in the end.
Some in the art world say that Sotheby's offered the Sharp heirs a more attractive financial package. Whether this means an advance on the property is uncertain. All Mrs. Brooks would say is that "there is a financial deal attached" but that "the family told us the financial aspects were a secondary consideration."
 
DeathMurder of a Young Artist
 Fifteen-year-old Christopher Hernandez, one of six people slain in a Bronx apartment on Sunday, was a member of the artist collective Tim Rollins and K.O.S. (for Kids of Survival) and was considered a promising young artist.
Mr. Hernandez joined the group, which is led by Mr. Rollins, when he was only 11, two years earlier than most of the members. Mr. Rollins accepted him early as a favor to the youngster's mother.
"He was one of the most involved members of K.O.S.," said Michael Lerner, who works with Mr. Rollins and K.O.S. "Chris was preparing a portfolio for High School of Art and Design." He was in the eighth grade at Intermediate School 52 in the Bronx and had worked worked on the Tim Rollins K.O.S. show last June at the Mary Boone Gallery in SoHo. The police said yesterday that they still had no idea about the killers' identities or motives.
Recalling that "Christopher was one of the most innocent kids," Mr. Rollins said: "In the 19th century we have the allegory of the massacre of the innocents. Now the allegories are realities."

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber

 BODY:
The author of 'Jacob Zulu' faces an unpleasant choice: giving up a Broadway production or his Dramatists Guild membership.
A rancorous dispute between the Dramatists Guild and the Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago surfaced this week when five leading playwrights aired their grievances over a Broadway production contract they say Steppenwolf bullied another playwright into signing. 
 Calling the terms of the agreement signed by Tug Yourgrau, whose first play, "The Song of Jacob Zulu," is to open at the Plymouth Theater on March 24, "quite literally the worst  the Guild has ever seen," the five playwrights -- Michael Weller, Craig Lucas, Paul Rudnick, Wendy Wasserstein and Marsha Norman -- spoke in an informal meeting at guild headquarters in Manhattan. They said they had the support of three other members who were unable to be present: David Henry Hwang, George C. Wolfe and Arthur Kopit.
"Their posture was 'Take it or leave it,' " said Mr. Weller, referring to Steppenwolf and to the production's general manager, Albert Poland. Steppenwolf, he added, is supposedly in the business of fostering new work. "But if the end result of the process is you get the worst possible deal, how is that encouraging new playwrights?"
Ms. Norman added, "If that's the way they think of writers, then we have to rethink how we think of them."
"The Song of Jacob Zulu," an unusual drama about apartheid that features the a cappella singing group Ladysmith Black Mambazo, was developed at Steppenwolf and has had two successful runs in Chicago. Last fall, after a first attempt by the Shubert Organization to bring the play to New York went awry because of a labor dispute with the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers, Steppenwolf stepped in and decided to produce the play on its own, raising $1.4 million to do so.
That would ordinarily be a happy ending. The problem, the guild now says, is that the money was raised on the basis of the playwright's having signed a substandard contract, forgoing all royalty payments in favor of a flat fee until the production recoups its investment.
In effect, the guild says, Mr. Yourgrau has been asked to help finance the play and shoulder what should be the investors' burden. Further, the guild contends the offer was made to Mr. Yourgrau in the spirit, if not the exact form, of an ultimatum: accept these terms, which would mean losing guild membership, or the show does not go on.
Under the terms of the deal, Mr. Yourgrau is to receive $3,750 a week until the investors have been repaid; from then on he is to receive 16.7 percent of the weekly operating profit. Neither stipulation meets the requirements of the guild, which says that a reasonable royalty arrangement, based on established standards, would grant the writer 18 or 19 percent of weekly operating profits throughout the run. That means for every $100,000 the show earns above its expenses, Mr. Yourgrau would earn $18,000 or $19,000.
Mr. Poland said that under the agreement signed by Mr. Yourgrau, before recoupment the potential weekly operating profit of "Jacob Zulu," if the show sells out, is $167,000. The calculations get a little dicey (if Mr. Yourgrau is paid more, the profits dwindle), but under the guild stipulations Mr. Yourgrau could earn more than $20,000 a week from the time the play opens.
Steppenwolf's position is relatively simple: without concessions from the creative partners in the show, it would not have been able to raise the money to put on the play. Mr. Poland pointed out that both the director, Eric Simonson, and the producer, Steppenwolf, who would have been the other participants in a royalty pool, had also accepted flat fees. Adding that Mr. Yourgrau could make as much as $35,000 a week, after recoupment, Mr. Poland said, "We don't view that as sticking it to the author."
Stephen B. Eich, Steppenwolf's managing director, said the financial package was put together so that investors would have the opportunity to recoup their money as quickly as possible, optimally within eight weeks.
"In this economic climate, to find a way to prioritize the investor is a very important concept," said Mr. Eich, speaking from Perth, Australia, where "Jacob Zulu" is now being performed. The idea is that if investing in plays can be made more attractive, more plays -- and more unusual, riskier plays -- might find their way to the Broadway stage. He said Mr. Yourgrau signed the agreement "without any coercion."
Dana Singer, a co-executive director of the guild, agreed the numbers would create a public perception that "the writer will make a fair amount of money, so what's he complaining about?" But, she added, it's the writer's job to write; it's the investor's job to take the risk that a play might not recoup. "The whole enterprise is taking place because the writer wrote a play," she said. "And even in a royalty pool situation, it's not like the investors aren't getting money every week. They take home the lion's share of it."
The dispute emphasizes anew the struggles of the Dramatists Guild, which, in fighting for the claims of writers in a difficult economy, has suffered its share of setbacks, including the resignation of one of its officers, A. R. Gurney, two years ago over a matter in which the guild refused to sanction a contract for one of his plays with a regional theater company.
And indeed, the guild seems uncertain of its clout. For example, at a time when Wendy Wasserstein's play "The Sisters Rosensweig" is set to move to a Shubert theater, the guild decided not to protest that organization's involvement in "Jacob Zulu" (the Shuberts own the Plymouth and have invested $500,000 in the production) or to ask that the Shuberts intervene on its behalf. Is this lily-livered or wise? Bernard B. Jacobs, the Shubert president, is squarely with the producers.
"The arrangement is a fair arrangement," he said. "It's the kind of situation in which the guild should cooperate."
The five playwrights at the meeting this week did say they would not submit plays to Steppenwolf unless this situation were redressed. This creates an interesting problem for Mr. Kopit, whose play "The Road to Nirvana" is to be staged at Steppenwolf this spring.
Reached on a skiing vacation in the Berkshires, Mr. Kopit said he would not withdraw his play because it was a done deal long ago. But he added, "I wouldn't dream of allowing Steppenwolf to do another play."
In danger of being lost is everyone's good will toward "Jacob Zulu." And everyone seems to agree that Mr. Yourgrau does not deserve his central place in the tug of war. The guild, reluctantly, has suspended him.
"I feel like a guy whose wife is giving birth at the same time there's a sickness in the family," he said from Los Angeles before leaving for Perth. "I really regret having to choose between a Broadway production and sticking in the guild."
Told that it sounds as if Steppenwolf gave him an ultimatum, he replied: "I think there were times in the negotiations where it was 'This is it.' I might experience that as an ultimatum. They might experience it as negotiation."

HEADLINE: Review/ Art;
Exploring A Labyrinth Of Ambiguities

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
THE exhibition of Joseph Beuys's drawings, which opens Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art, is the largest and best survey in this country in more than a decade of the man who can fairly be called Europe's most influential postwar artist. Still, an exhibition of Beuys's drawings, even one that encompasses installations and multimedia pieces as this one does, can go only so far. Seven years after Beuys's death at 64, his art remains a maze of conundrums and enigmas. And what show could do more than hint at the charismatic persona that became the essence of Beuys's work through the performances and political activities that made him world famous?
One of the canonical images of 20th-century art is surely the death-masklike image of Beuys himself: gaunt, hollow-eyed and hollow-cheeked, invariably dressed in vest and battered hat. Shaman or charlatan? For more than one generation of politically minded artists, and especially for his fellow German artists, Beuys has been regarded with a reverence matched in its ferocity only by the ridicule that has also been heaped upon him. It was part of his openness of spirit that he reacted to mockery with disarming courtesy. Among the many aspects difficult to reconcile about Beuys was that he was both a kind of megalomaniac and also virtually indifferent to art-world success in the traditional sense. 
 A member of the Hitler Youth and then a pilot with the Luftwaffe, he emerged from a period of mental and physical collapse during the 1950's to become a leader of the student movement, a founder of the Green Party, an advocate of women's rights, the ultimate anti-establishment man. Art became for him a means of healing morally a society that he saw as deeply wounded, and in the case of postwar West Germany, obsessed with economic rather than spiritual recovery.
Yet in the absolutism of his vision and in his self-appointed role as savior, there is something in Beuys's later life that harks back to the Germany of his youth. Certainly he was aware of the potent ambiguity of his art. In his drawings, he repeatedly uses the symbol of a cross, for example, which can bring to mind the Iron Cross as well as the Christian cross or the Red Cross. No wonder Beuys is such a difficult man to come to terms with, quite apart from the daunting eccentricity of his materials and of his visual vocabulary.
Beuys (it rhymes with voice) identified the roots of all his art in his drawings, and you can clearly see why from this exhibition. Here are to be found in their first incarnations the Beuysian images evocative of ancient myth and religious symbolism: the stags, elks, sibyls, priestesses, swans and bees, the references to creation and metamorphosis. Here is the early evidence of his penchant for natural materials, like blood, fat, pressed flowers and felt made from hair.
From the start, Beuys drew incessantly, producing thousands upon thousands of drawings: on the backs of envelopes, on newspapers, on calendar pages, on scraps of paper. During the 1950's, when as a shy, intense veteran recuperating in isolation from the war, he devoted himself almost exclusively to drawings. Beginning in the 60's, when he joined the faculty of the Dusseldorf Academy and increasingly turned into a public figure, the notes he made in conjunction with ritualistic performances, or actions, became drawings, as did the blackboards on which in later years he outlined lectures, which were themselves actions.
The later works, because they are fragments, or souvenirs, from larger events, can seem dry, without context. The early works are different. It's wrong to talk of Beuys's drawings in relation to conventional "good taste," about which he couldn't have cared less. Nonetheless, many of these early works are peculiarly exquisite. Beuys reveals in them a formal sensibility, a feel for the poetry of materials and a delicacy of touch that belie his anti-art posture.
There is, for example, a drawing from 1951 called "Stag, Woman, Child," whose almost vaporous lines demonstrate how meticulous a draftsman Beuys could be. There is the "Nude" of 1954-55, a kind of inky Rorschach blot that emerges on close inspection as an elegantly drawn woman, redolent of sexuality. There is "From: Intelligence of the Swans" (1956), a work of condensed power that contains within its frantic crisscross of sweeping pencil lines a series of subtle pirouettes representing the swans' curved necks. And there is "Death and the Maiden," from 1957, an astonishing shadowy ink and watercolor image of a skeleton and woman in stiff embrace, drawn on the back of an envelope stamped with the word "Auschwitz."
Beuys's early drawings are remarkable, as well, in their sheer diversity, sometimes scrawled as they are like children's sketches, sometimes mimicking the Romantic landscapes of Friedrich or the Expressionist figures of Lehmbruck, sometimes all over the page in their energy, sometimes barely more than a few nervous, nondescript lines so faint you have to put your nose right next the page to make them out. As a group, these works express, above all, the sense of someone tirelessly, painfully, searching for his identity, not just his identity as an artist but as a man.
Both the early and later drawings demonstrate the intertwining of art and science that became one of Beuys's principal aims. Leonardo was a major influence on him. Many of the drawings here, and most of the blackboards, resemble scientific charts or circuitry diagrams. Some of them depict imaginary gadgets. There are lots of lists among the drawings, typed and written out longhand, that suggest the artist's obsession with ordering and categorizing things. It is yet another contradiction that Beuys's art aspired to a total vision of the universe at the same time that it embraced freedom, happenstance and individual will.
The drawings prove that Beuys looked at lots of art. Despite the weighty reverence with which he is sometimes treated, he was full of wit in the way he playfully referred to Pop, in works like "Cascade" (1966), or to Lucio Fontana's punctured canvases, in "Fontana Cinnabar" (1966). Other drawings are reminders that however much of an individual he was, he came of age professionally at roughly the same time as the Fluxus movement, as the Arte Povera artists in Italy, as John Cage and Robert Rauschenberg and Cy Twombly and Claes Oldenburg and the Minimalists in the United States, all of whom his work, in various ways, summons to mind.
What separated Beuys from them, ultimately, were his actions. At the center of the exhibition has been installed his "Directional Forces" (1974), a painstaking reconstruction of a space in which he lectured for hours on end using 100 blackboards, each blackboard tossed to the floor once Beuys finished writing on it. The effect is like coming to a party after everyone has left: you're clearly missing a crucial part of the action. Still, this performance-turned-sculpture epitomizes the interconnectedness in Beuys's work among drawing, theater, politics and pedagogy.
"Words That Can Hear" (1979) illustrates a similar point in a different way. A suite of 92 sheets of paper, it presents variations on the theme of a spiral, or an ear, each image made up of words, one word drawn on top of another as if to simulate a cacophony of voices. The work exemplifies the use of repetitive structures that links Beuys to Minimalism. But more to the point, it suggests a visual metaphor for the relationship between drawing and sound, or speech, that became essential to Beuys's art.
The spiral has another possible meaning. Beuys's life and his art increasingly became one, not only in the sense that he made an art of his political activities but also in the sense that he retrospectively shaped his life's story as a work of art. The shape was a bit like a spiral, with events from his youth echoed in later years. Who knows whether drawings like "Herb Robert" and "Lucko (Croatia)" are from the 1940's, as Beuys said and as the exhibition presents them, or whether they are, as they look, later works to which he gave earlier dates?
The important issue is that the dating underscores how Beuys wished to see his life as neatly cyclical. "Lucko" presages drawings of the 1950's, while "Herb Robert," with its dried and pressed flowers, prefigures the very last group of drawings on which he worked before his death, "Ombelico di Venere Cotyledon Umbilicus Veneris" (1985).
At the Modern, the difficult underground galleries in which this exhibition has been installed are arranged something like a spiral, with the works proceeding chronologically from the outside in. The show, including about 180 works, has been organized by Ann Temkin of the Philadelphia Museum of Art and Bernice Rose of the Modern.
It is to take nothing away from what they have done to say that Beuys remains at least as difficult to grasp after seeing the show. His example set the stage for the complex and serious work of compatriots like Sigmar Polke and Anselm Kiefer, and well as for a lot of political and didactic art that carries none of the moral and historical weight of his own achievement. It's not his fault that so many people took him up on his famous declaration: "Everyone is an artist." No one, however, is quite like Beuys.
"Thinking Is Form: The Drawings of Joseph Beuys" opens Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, and remains there through May 4. It travels to the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles (May 30 to Aug. 15); the Philadelphia Museum of Art (Oct. 10 to Jan. 2, 1994), and the Art Institute of Chicago (Feb. 15 to April 25, 1994).

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
Pride and Craftsmanship in a Blue-Collar Family

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
The place is Queens, the time the mid-1950's and the occasion the wake for Papa Vitelli (Joe Paparone), an immigrant carpenter from Italy who came to America as a young man to make a new life. Amid the rich confusion of talk, arguments and laughter, the old man's three sons, Niccolo (John Turturro), the eldest, who's called Mac; Vico (Michael Badalucco), and Bruno (Carl Capotorto) stare down at the embalmed remains.
Their silent recollections are shattered when the old man suddenly sits up in a fury to point out the shabby craftsmanship of the coffin. How could they have allowed it? Doesn't anybody care? Doesn't anybody pay attention anymore? Just as abruptly, the tirade is over and the corpse lies back, exhausted. Again properly dead. It's almost as if it didn't happen. 
 This is the wonderfully vivid introduction to "Mac," Mr. Turturro's loving and contemplative eulogy to his own father, who died in 1988, and to a kind of immigrant experience that is probably forever gone. "Mac," which Mr. Turturro wrote with Brandon Cole, is the actor's very self-assured debut as a director, something that is evident in almost every frame of the film. A more experienced journeyman director, a gun-for-hire type, might have insisted that "Mac" have a stronger, clearer, more conventional story line, one with a more dramatic payoff.
Instead, "Mac" is very much an actor's film. Mr. Turturro conceived it as a screenplay in 1980 and then, with Mr. Cole, turned it into a play, scenes from which were staged and revised over the years at various theaters around New York, apparently with the collaboration of the actors, including Mr. Badalucco and Mr. Capotorto. The result is a movie that is rich in characters and scenes, that wanders, often creatively, and that expresses as much affection for the craft of the actor as it does for the craft of the blue-collar laborer who takes pride in his work.
Mac enthusiastically carries on his father's tradition. Working as a member of a construction gang building private houses, Mac has repeated run-ins with the foreman, who objects to his meticulous attention to detail. Time and money are being wasted. Vico is in the same crew; he works in construction because it's the only thing he knows. He's good-natured, lazy, something of a ladies' man. Bruno, the one brother to attend college, wants to be an artist but goes into construction to make ends meet. The three sons still live at home with a mother who, throughout the film, remains a nagging, unhappy off-screen voice.
In the course of the 8 or 10 years covered by the film, Mac marries and begins his own family while continuing to live at home. The brothers start their own construction business, come close to financial disaster, fall out and then move on. Vico and Bruno enthusiastically embrace the progressing postwar American culture and economy. By the end of the film, only Mac has some idea of the cost of that progress.
Compared to "Riffraff," Ken Loach's new English comedy about nonunion construction workers in London, "Mac" is an intensely romantic work. It reflects the differences not only between American and British labor, but also between the concerns of one very American artist and one who is quintessentially English.
"Riffraff" is politically sophisticated. It's obsessed with particular conditions. Nobody has to tell its characters that the world is old and often unfair. They know that too well. "Mac" seems to be surprised that standards of excellence are slipping. It expresses a longing for the way things were when America was still a dream in the process of being realized. It's not about today, but rather about the past, about things lost that, in time, become idealized.
Mr. Turturro has written a good role for himself and realizes it beautifully, though not at the expense of those around him. Mac is a difficult, exacting man who is out of step with everyone else. Among other things, he likes his work. He's a perfectionist. He has a temper so short that he almost self-destructs. Complementing Mac, and saving him on occasion, is his wife, Alice, nicely played by Katherine Borowitz (who is married to Mr. Turturro), a woman who turns out to have surprising entrepreneurial skills.
"Mac" is the kind of movie in which all of the principal cast members have scenes that define them both as actors and as the characters they play. Mr. Badalucco's is a night out with the boys in which he tries, unsuccessfully, to teach his younger brother how to pick up women. Mr. Capotorto's is a casual encounter on the bus with a woman with whom he manages to have a heated if brief affair without a word being spoken.
Ellen Barkin is very funny as an artist's model, first seen in Bruno's sketching class, who comes to represent all of the glamour that Vico and Bruno are convinced awaits them outside Queens. Also noteworthy is Olek Krupa, who plays the crooked Polish foreman of a construction gang whose men (white, black, Irish and Italian) passionately hang on to their bigotries as a way of asserting themselves.
There are times when Mr. Turturro appears to shoot scenes too safely. He depends entirely on a succession of close-ups to emphasize the emotions in a crucial encounter among the three brothers toward the end of the film, which is movie making for television. More often, though, he loosens up to let the actors have more than just their heads. "Mac" is a very good movie with a mind.
"Mac," which has been rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), has a lot of vulgar language and some sexual situations.

Running time: 118 minutes. This film is rated R.

HEADLINE: Corrections

 BODY:
A front-page summary of the Clinton economic proposals yesterday described a proposed income tax change incorrectly in some copies. The proposed surtax would raise the tax rate on taxable income above $250,000 by 10 percent, from a rate of 36 percent to one of 39.6 percent.
A table of case studies showing the impact of the proposal calculated the surtax incorrectly in one case. A family with a taxable income of $283,746 would owe a surtax of $1,215; the family's total tax would be $94,692, an increase of $12,545 over the tax bill under current rules. 
 A front-page article about the economic plan referred imprecisely to the amount by which it would reduce the Federal budget deficit. The miscalculation is discussed today in an article on page A15.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Political Body Language

BYLINE: By BRENT STAPLES

 BODY:
Scenes from the economic speech: Bill Clinton throwing away the script as he chides Republican snickerers in the balcony. Vice President Al Gore, perhaps thinking he was off camera when he was still on, baldly gesturing to the chamber for more applause.
Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois wearing a curdled face, preoccupied by scandal. Colin Powell, seeming a bit on the surly side after battling Mr. Clinton on military budget cuts and homosexuals in the armed services. 
 Hillary Rodham Clinton, leading cheers from the balcony -- and annotating her husband's remarks for her strategically placed seatmate, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, whose impassive countenance seemed equal to any challenge, including being surrounded by Democrats.
Body language speaks as loudly as words, and often louder. The cutaway shots during Wednesday's speech revealed an array of silent conversations and brooding concerns worthy of a Bruegel canvas.
The gooniest gesture was surely Al Gore's appeal for more applause. Mr. Gore later said he was taunting Republicans about Mr. Clinton's call for gun control. But at the time, he looked like a warm-up act. One can imagine his handlers wincing. Is their man running for the White House or a slot on the new Letterman show?
For Mr. Clinton, Dan Rostenkowski's scowl and feeble clapping bode ill. Mr. Rostenkowski is either the unhappiest Democrat or the most worried. The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, he faces a wide-ranging investigation that, if it leads to indictment, would force him to resign his chairmanship. That could mean rougher sailing for Clinton initiatives.
For his part, Mr. Clinton seemed to be having a good time, perhaps because he was the one person in the hall who knew when, or whether, his speech might end. His pet gesture -- the hammering thumb and forefinger lifted from J.F.K. -- saw heavy use on Wednesday. His vitality and penchant for complete sentences seemed a striking new style of Presidential communication after George Bush's more self-effacing but twitchy style.
Mr. Bush at least educated people to body language. The man who said "read my lips" might have been able to read Mrs. Clinton's when her husband made a point about health care. Mrs. Clinton turned to Mr. Greenspan and, if we read her lips correctly, said in her firm and increasingly familiar way, "He's exactly right." Mr. Greenspan presumably heard this, but his expression gave nothing away.

HEADLINE: The Vision Beyond the Plan

 BODY:
All President Clinton promised was an economic plan, but his speech to Congress offered something even rarer along the marshy rim of the Potomac -- a vision. If Republicans and Democrats in Congress will only step back from Mr. Clinton's specific proposals, they will discover, perhaps to their horror, that he has assumed the best about them -- namely, that they are capable of conducting business in a brand new way, lifting their sights beyond the short political horizons that normally govern Congressional deliberation.
So what is Mr. Clinton's vision? At its simplest, that it doesn't matter whether you tax and spend by Democratic or Republican rules, as long as you are willing to make politically difficult choices. Ronald Reagan did not much like choosing, so he came up with the idea of cutting taxes, revving up defense spending and assuming that diminished revenues would strangle spending on pesky social programs. 
 The Democrats in Congress did not like choosing either. So their habit has been to mix the stew of taxes and debt ever richer and thicker, making sure that lots of it got ladled into things like unneeded military bases and consulting fees for Democratic Congressmen and cabinet secretaries who had retired to the law-and-lobbying firms.
Comes now Mr. Clinton, who may actually be a new Democrat if he has the grit to follow the map he sketched on Wednesday night.
Like most Clinton speeches, it was long-winded and lanky. But the core was clear enough. Republicans say no new taxes are needed. Mr. Clinton said he wanted more revenues and that he was willing to risk his political health by saying exactly which taxes would go up and who would pay them. He went on to say that not all the spending of the Reagan-Bush era could continue, and that as President he was willing to start choosing.
He advocated stopgap savings in Federal wages and Medicare-Medicaid. Then there were 150 piecemeal cuts touching some sacred Democratic porkpies like rural electrification. Mr. Clinton's trickiest wrinkle was to declare as "investments" a variety of social programs such as Head Start and the Job Corps. Even so, he managed to slam-dunk the Republicans when they snickered at his figures by reminding them that both Mr. Reagan and President Bush favored fictional budget numbers.
But the real hook was his invitation to his hosts. If Congress had a better idea, he was eager to see it step up and make its choices in public. You had to wonder why the Democrats kept jumping up and applauding this approach. The House leadership, in particular, is larded with plump fellows who never saw a tough choice they could not dodge.
At least the Republicans seemed to know what was going on. Never in recent memory have they been so thoroughly wrong-footed. It was no accident that cagey old Bob Dole let his House counterpart, Bob Michel, grin and grind through a threadbare opposition speech.
Presidents must seem to grow larger in office. By that standard Wednesday evening was a plus for Mr. Clinton and for the nation. But it is too early to rejoice. The man's record in Arkansas shows that his vision is sometimes greater than his guts, and the obstacles of entrenched interests and parochial greed that sometimes stalled him in Little Rock are nothing compared with what lurks in the heart and habits of this Congress.
Mr. Clinton urged its members to "have no sacred cows except the fundamental interest of the American people." The instant polling showed that 79 percent of the American people endorsed this view and the harsh prescriptions dashed off by Mr. Clinton. Now let the Congress earn its keep by either enacting this program speedily or coming up with something more honest.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
That $100,000 Ilk

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Between President Clinton's first economic speech and his second, two days apart, something important turned up missing.
The best thing that could happen to Mr. Clinton and his chances of becoming a successful President would be to keep it missing -- the divisive class-conflict tone that ran through parts of the first speech. 
 That talk, laying the ground for the Congressional address, carried too much of the old, dreary, left-wing cant that implies that making money is inherently nasty, that people who had worked hard to earn more could be taxed painfully without a by-your-leave and that "special interests" are all evil unless of course they turn out to be your own cabinet members.
After voting once for George Bush, I decided that was plenty and cast my vote for Bill Clinton. So I knew I could expect more taxes, and should be prepared to put my wallet where my vote was.
Like many others of my dark ilk -- Americans who after a lifetime of work are earning more than the $100,000 a year that now is the economic mark of Cain -- I believe that the U.S. can bear up under more taxes.
I do not believe that makes me a patriot, as Mr. Clinton said folks think back where he comes from. But I will not be happy if my epaulettes are stripped from me by the President if I do not agree with the justification for this tax or that new spending.
And however Arkansans define patriotism, I am sure they are also brought up to say please and thank you and to talk straight.
On Monday, Mr. Clinton said that the $100,000 rich folk were going to pay 70 percent of the raise in income taxes. He did not bother to say please or that he hoped they would think about it and see the necessity. Treated without contempt, they just might.
And then there was that strange bit about how higher taxes were justified because of tax breaks the upper-income people got in the 80's.
But those who received tax breaks had not committed any crime for which they should now be flogged. And the President must know that a lot of people did not even attain the $100,000 punishment level until the 80's and then only because of years of risk-taking and fruitful work, not tax manna.
And he might have had the good humor to acknowledge that $100,000 is not all that guilt-laden an income if you do not have free government housing, limousines, weekend retreats, jogging tracks and household help, know what I mean?
But on Wednesday, Mr. Clinton just about dropped the class-struggle tone. He said some pleasant things about business and actually asked the $100,000 pariahs for support. Nice, polite.
Also he dispensed with that time-honored Arkansas Patriotism Test that he had just invented. Good for you, Wednesday.
We have weeks to examine the Clinton program. Long and groundbreaking as it is, Mr. Clinton will have to put considerable flesh on it for certain Americans.
We are the people who are ready to pay more, even painfully more, provided we also know more -- about where the new money is going, and what it will do to reduce what we detest most. In his speeches, Mr. Clinton barely mentioned it -- the daily violence of life coming from race hatred, AIDS, crime, drug addiction.
During the campaign, America acted as if the world did not exist. Fantasy time is over. So how will the new taxes help America fulfill its international role, if at all? Doesn't seem too much to ask, for the money.
The same man created and gave both speeches. This is a complicated man, this young, open-faced President of ours -- as are most people of great achievement. Many people are struggling for his mind -- and he is one of them.
So his tone and rhetoric are extremely important. If he cannot rid himself of divisive us-against-them, if he echoes the left's eternal paranoid suspicions about business, success, endeavor and visions of America other than its own, he will hobble himself and be unable to lead the country to the fullness of his talent and energies.
One Clinton mind or another will have to prevail, or a rational and candidly explained compromise between them. He has it in him to lead, but not if he sets one tone on Mondays, another on Wednesdays.

HEADLINE: Taxes vs. Growth

BYLINE: By Jack Kemp; Jack Kemp was President Bush's Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Clinton campaign that promised a plan for economic growth has suddenly turned into an Administration demanding across-the-board sacrifice from the American people. Indeed, the myth that Americans are undertaxed has become the defining principle behind President Clinton's economic policy. The truth is that Americans are overtaxed, not undertaxed.
Sacrifice is not an economic policy and it's certainly not a goal for which the nation should be striving. Besides, it's not the people who need to sacrifice, it's the bloated Government. 
 More important, raising tax rates will not reduce the deficit but weaken our fragile economy. The faulty premise behind the 1990 budget agreement was that higher taxes would lead to more revenue, lower deficits and growth. Instead, the deficit increased from 3.1 percent of G.N.P. in 1990 to 5 percent by 1992 because the anticipated tax revenue failed to materialize, as it always does when taxes rise.
According to some estimates, the slowdown in growth after the budget agreement cost the Treasury $183 billion, six times the amount of Mr. Clinton's $31 billion "stimulus" package. Expanding growth and opportunity for everyone, not redistribution of wealth, must be the highest goal of economic policy. In fact, we should set a goal of doubling the size of our economy, to $10 trillion from the present $5 trillion, in no more than 12 years.
Achieving the needed 4 to 6 percent growth rates requires a radically different path than the Clinton plan of higher income taxes, surtaxes, new energy taxes and taxes on Social Security recipients. Instead, we must build a strong foundation of incentives for entrepreneurship and productivity.
* Taxes. In his campaign, Bill Clinton accepted the principle that cutting capital gains taxes spurs growth. Our unindexed gains tax is a huge barrier to capital formation and job creation. We should eliminate this tax or at least reduce and index it for inflation. We must also reverse the trend toward higher income taxes with a flatter, fairer and simpler tax code, one that rewards, not punishes, success.
* Government spending. Government at all levels spends too much, consuming nearly 40 percent of G.N.P., up from 26 percent in 1960. If the private sector is the engine of economic growth, then we must restore the balance between the public and private sectors. One proposal would be freeze spending and limit the growth rate of entitlements, except Social Security, to inflation plus population growth. This would still allow a 5 to 6 percent annual increase, permitting us to meet social obligations while producing substantial savings.
* Trade. Restricted trade forces companies to compete for special treatment from government instead of competing to develop better products. Open trade forces governments to compete to lower taxes and reduce regulations to make their economies more competitive.
Unfortunately, the Administration seems intent on a protectionist path of higher tariffs matched by retaliation by our trading partners. Tariffs averaging 27 percent on imported steel and restrictions on U.S. purchases of European communications equipment have already been proposed. While Mr. Clinton has endorsed the North American Free Trade Agreement, our goal should be nothing less than global trade liberalization.
Mr. Clinton has outlined some laudable goals: : creating new jobs, ending welfare as we know it, reducing the deficit, encouraging the private sector as the engine of growth. Unfortunately, his tax increases directly conflict with these goals. While at times he sounded like John Kennedy and Ronald Reagan, tragically his policies are closer to those of Herbert Hoover and Jimmy Carter.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: New Clinton. New Era.

BYLINE: By Paul E. Tsongas; Paul E. Tsongas, former Senator from Massachusetts, sought the Democratic Presidential nomination last year.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The Bill Clinton you saw on TV was not the Bill Clinton I ran against. I am pleased the evolution has taken place. Finally, a President who talks about the deficit, competitiveness, long-term growth and generational responsibility. A new era. A hard look at hard choices.
Does the economic package go as far as I, Warren Rudman and my Concord Coalition colleagues would go? Not really. We're more focused on deficit reduction. Are the savings as real as claimed, and will they survive the Congressional journey? I don't know. 
 We're on a new path, led by a very intelligent President who can absorb data and the realities they represent in a way his immediate predecessors could not or would not.
What are the true options? I believe there are four. First, steady as she goes, status quo. If Bill Clinton did nothing else, he awakened America to the stark consequences of doing nothing. Doing nothing means catastrophe. Status quo is not an option. Second, follow the Congressional alternative. Ha! What alternative? You will hear the cries of outraged Republicans. No new taxes! We need a strong defense! These positions and deficit reduction are incompatible! Listen to the Democratic committee chairmen and caucus activists. You will hear pleas for expanded entitlements and increased domestic appropriations. You will never see a specific Congressional alternative. And certainly not one that comes close to the President's deficit reduction package. Remember, these are the same people who lay dormant as Ronald Reagan and George Bush racked up $3 trillion of debt. They are incapable of a true balanced budget proposal.
Third, the Clinton plan. To use very rough numbers, the package breaks down as follows: a little over $202 billion in savings (from the 1994 to 1997 fiscal years) and $267 billion in new taxes in that same period; that's $469 billion in possible deficit reduction. From that total, subtract $109 billion in stimulus and people-first investments and $60 billion in investment tax incentives. This results in about $300 billion in deficit reduction plus $24 billion in interest payments that will not have to be paid -- $324 billion less debt. Not bad.
The danger is that a package will pass without some of the tougher measures and deficit reduction will fade to a low-impact number. Instead of the fiscal 1997 deficit going from $346 billion to $206 billion, it could end up at $260 billion. After all the agony and tax increases, the public will feel deceived.
As for the fourth option, a growing consensus says that the deficit reduction bottom line has to be raised. The original hope expressed by Leon Panetta, director of the Office of Management and Budget, of a 2 to 1 ratio of spending cuts to new taxes is now seen as less than 1 to 1. Congress could add new cuts here and there and reduce the level of investment and stimulus spending just enough to cause the fiscal 1997 deficit to drop below $200 billion -- to, say, $180 billion. Thus, the mystical goal of reducing the deficit in half in four years would be realized (close enough), and we would enjoy business confidence. The public would feel it is on the path to fiscal solvency and Bill Clinton would sweep to re-election.
A caveat. If a $30 billion to $90 billion health care proposal is dropped on the table in the middle of all this, it will disrupt everything. Fast-tracking a health care proposal that requires extensive deliberations and vast new revenue sources is to undertake an initiative that will compete with the economic package in a way that will harm both. We need a health care package, but it must delay its debut until after the economic plan has been passed, taken root and begun to bear fruit.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
'What Will Happen?'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
Bangladesh has a land area small er than Wisconsin and a population of 114 million. Its numbers are growing so fast that by the year 2025 it will outstrip the present U.S. population of 250 million.
"What will happen to those poor people?" M. F. Perutz of Cambridge University asked last fall in a piece in The New York Review of Books. "Even if by some miracle of science enough food could be produced to feed them, how could they find the gainful employment needed to buy it?" 
 The case of Bangladesh is just one among many stark examples of a profound world concern. World population is growing at a staggering rate, and almost all the increase is occurring in the poorest countries.
The earth's population was around one billion in the year 1800, two billion in 1920, three billion in 1960. Today it is five billion. By 2025 it is expected to be more than eight billion, and 95 percent of the increase will have been in the third world.
Prof. Paul Kennedy of Yale makes this demographic outlook -- the overwhelming of already overcrowded and poverty-stricken lands -- a main focus of his new book, "Preparing for the Twenty-First Century." He makes the point that the situation will affect not just those countries but all.
The population explosion in South Asia, Latin America and Africa leads in all those areas to overgrazing, soil erosion and clearing of tropical rain forests. But, Professor Kennedy argues, it also tends to produce regional conflicts, global warming, flows of refugees and great pressure on developed countries to admit emigrants from the underdeveloped.
Anyone who has visited there knows that the pressure of population is taking its toll already, in nature and human psychology, in many places. In the cities of China the crowds can be claustrophobic. In the mountains of India and Nepal people desperate for fuel have denuded forests, so topsoil is being washed into rivers and out to sea.
India has about 880 million people now. It is growing so fast that experts say it will pass China as the most populous country by the year 2035, and the growth may not end until there are two billion people in India. China, with about 1.165 billion now, is expected to reach 1.5 billion.
Mexico is a telling example of population growth and its social and political consequences. It has made dramatic progress in reducing the birth rate recently. But the increase had been so great in previous years that the population is very young and will therefore continue to grow rapidly.
With about 85 million people now, Mexico is expected to have 150 million in 2025. In Professor Kennedy's vision, that means a terrible strain on schools, health care, the environment. It means the crowding of more and more people into "mega-cities."
Already 20 million Mexicans live in Mexico City, many under appalling conditions. Half the country's people live without sewers and a quarter without safe water. Can anyone be surprised that, despite the country's improving economic record, many Mexicans are desperate to get into the United States?
Rational self-interest, not just humane concern, should make the rich countries do all they can to prevent overpopulation and the suffering and strife it brings.
But rationality has not been the mainspring of American population policy lately. Presidents Reagan and Bush shaped their policy to please the anti-abortion movement and the Christian right.
The Reagan Administration sabotaged the world population conference here in Mexico City in 1984 by taking the position that rapid growth was a "neutral" phenomenon. That was, ironically, the classic Marxist view of population growth.
Since then the U.S. has drastically reduced aid to population-control efforts abroad, at a time when underdeveloped countries were recognizing the need for restraint. Michael S. Teitelbaum, writing about the policy in the current issue of Foreign Affairs, calls it "self-inflicted blindness."
Here is one problem that President Clinton can address quickly, without great legislative complications. He has ended the Reagan-Bush distortions of domestic policy on birth-related matters. The need for change in foreign policy is even more urgent: the need to face a reality more menacing in the long run than just about any on earth.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 463 words

HEADLINE: Get the Cancerous Pesticides Out of Our Food;
Time for Irradiation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Tainted Hamburger Raises Doubts on Meat Safety" (news article, Jan. 27): 
 The Western United States epidemic of Escherichia coli 0157:H7 caused by contaminated undercooked hamburger patties raises the question of how these disease-causing bacteria can be eliminated from the food that human beings consume. It is natural for someone to say, "It is unbelievable that such a low level of Federal meat inspection exists."
Federal inspectors examine about 117 million animals annually, of which 30 million are cattle, from which most of the hamburger is prepared. More than two million pounds of raw beef are imported from Canada, Australia and New Zealand. This beef is thoroughly inspected, as in the United States. E. coli 0157:H7 was first identified in 1983 in the northern United States. In an unpublished 1987-90 survey of raw beef, only two samples were positive out of more than 1,600 samples taken.
E. coli 0157:H7 is not known to cause any diseases with clinical signs in cattle. Cattle are passive carriers of this virulent form of colon bacteria, and there is no way Federal inspectors can identify a carrier animal by physical examination. This problem is not limited to examination for E. coli, but is the same for determining what animals and poultry may be carriers of salmonella, campylobacter, listeria and yersinia. The presence of these pathogens in raw meat is undesirable, but unavoidable.
However, irradiation of the raw product is one way to eliminate the pathogenic bacteria. All of these bacteria can cause disease in humans of varying severity and are especially dangerous to older people, sufferers from chronic diseases and those receiving therapy that compromises their resistance. Children are even more susceptible.
Food irradiation research to eliminate pathogenic bacteria has been in progress by Federal agencies since the 1950's. These studies have demonstrated that pasteurization of meat and poultry by irradiation is effective, economical and safe. The results have been reviewed by the Food and Drug Administration, the Public Health Service, the Department of Agriculture and the Department of the Army. Some 14 countries have approved irradiation of poultry to prevent food-borne disease.
Public health officials and administrators face a problem similar to one 100 years ago, when pasteurization of milk was proved effective in prevention of disease. It took 50 years more for pasteurization to be widely accepted. Do we have to wait 50 years and treat 50 million more cases of food-borne illnesses before we institute food irradiation of raw meat and poultry?
 
JAMES H. STEELE
Houston, Jan. 29, 1993
The writer retired as professor of environmental sciences at the University of Texas.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 366 words

HEADLINE: Corporations Have to Pay Fair Tax Share

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Press Harder on Deficit Reduction" (editorial, Feb. 5) couldn't be wronger. For a clear explication of our deficit, I suggest the book "Who Will Tell the People?" by William Greider. He analyzes the deficit in about four pages following page 71: 
 It started as a result of bipartisan Administration-Congressional effort in President Carter's term; during President Reagan's and President Bush's terms it was brought to its present, engorged, state when it carried the national debt to heroic pro portions. The keystone of this program was to excuse American corporations from paying Federal tax.
The real snowball began in 1981, when the corporate segment of our country, which controlled 65 percent of our national wealth and income, was freed from the obligation to pay taxes. It had been paying 25 percent of the national tax burden. I think that's the 25 percent "tax reduction" Senator Phil Gramm takes credit for in his campaign oratory.
The immediate result was a $50 billion yearly shortfall which, with interest on the resulting debt, as well as increased (untaxed) corporate profits, is now around $300 billion. No gasoline tax, no tax on yachts, no tax on wealthy individuals, no suspension of cost-of-living adjustments, no cap on welfare, no diddling with aircraft carriers and missiles, no management of health care -- or any combination of the above -- can make up for the tax giveaway to the corporations since 1981.
By all means, let us have efficiency and economy in all affairs. But the deficit must be made up by those who created it.
The rest of us will have enough to do to achieve full employment, wage, price and profit control, universal single-payer health care, training and education (to all levels) for our youth, adequate food and housing for all and a progressive tax structure that rises to 50 percent for the upper income of individuals and corporations.
That last may seem Draconian -- except for those of us who are trapped in the maelstrom called spending down. To us, all the one-liners about "paying our share," "no free lunch" and "the truly needy" are hypocritical.
 
HAROLD L. KRIVOY
Richardson, Tex., Feb. 6, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 2; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 626 words

HEADLINE: U.S. and Allies Discuss Sanctions To Force Mobutu to Yield Power

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
In the aftermath of the rioting and looting this month that claimed hundreds of lives in Zaire, the United States, France and Belgium are considering political and economic sanctions against Zaire and its leader, Mobutu Sese Seko, Western diplomats said today.
Such a move would put pressure on President Mobutu, who has ruled for 28 years, to hand over real power to an interim government. 
 A State Department paper outlining possible steps describes Zaire's plight as extremely dire. Zaire, one of the world's poorest countries, is developing into "Somalia and Liberia rolled into one, with vast potential for immense refugee flows, regional destabilization and humanitarian disaster," the paper said.
 
Clinton's Approval Expected
 The paper, dated Feb. 11, added that if the United States and its allies "allow Mobutu, one of Africa's strongest and longest dictators, to destroy the country in order to prevent the emergence of democracy, United States efforts to foster democracy in Africa may suffer a tremendous setback."
The final form of the sanctions has not been decided, but officials said they would be debated and probably approved by President Clinton within the next few days. An official indicated that at the very least, the allies would seek to freeze Mr. Mobutu's personal bank accounts in the United States and Europe.
African and Western diplomats say President Mobutu has used his position to make himself one of the world's richest men. Critics estimate his personal fortune at $4 billion.
The State Department paper said seizing "personal assets (plane, yacht, and houses) would send a strong message to him, without affecting the Zairian economy or, for that matter, seriously disrupting United States or European business."
But the paper cautioned, "It may be difficult to identify the personal bank accounts of Mobutu and his supporters: they may be under aliases."
 
Other Options
 Other steps being discussed are the ouster of Zairian diplomats from various posts, the denial of visas to Zairians closely associated with Mr. Mobutu, suspension from the International Monetary Fund, an arms embargo and a ban on exports from Zaire, particularly copper and cobalt.
The options were discussed in a meeting last week of senior officials, including Herman J. Cohen, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs. The subject was also raised Wednesday in Washington in a meeting between Secretary of State Warren Christopher and the Foreign Minister Willy Claes of Belgium. Zaire was once the Belgian Congo.
Western diplomats involved in the discussions acknowledge, however, that even if stringent sanctions are imposed, it is far from certain that they will have much impact on Mr. Mobutu, who has repeatedly defied predictions of his imminent ouster.
So far there has been little indication that recent efforts to pressure Mr. Mobutu have made any headway. Early this month, in a pointed rebuff to the Western allies, Mr. Mobutu dismissed Etienne Tshisekedi, who was Prime Minister and head of the interim Government, and indicated he would not relinquish his tight control over the treasury and the armed forces.
Still, moves to impose sanctions mark a dramatic change in United States policy. During most of his tenure, President Mobutu has had close links with Washington, and the Central Intelligence Agency in particular.
The current crisis began early this month when soldiers rioted after being paid in new high-denomination bank notes that were issued by the President but outlawed by Mr. Tshisekedi and rejected by traders. Among those killed was the French Ambassador.
As the pillaging and unrest spread, France and Belgium flew in hundreds of troops to evacuate their citizens.

LENGTH: 602 words

HEADLINE: MORTGAGES;
Old Refinancing Rules Are Out the Window

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:
WITH the nation gripped by the third mortgage refinancing boom in slightly more than a year and mortgage interest rates at their lowest levels in 20 years, the question of when and how to refinance is affecting more and more homeowners.
Until the mid-1980's, there were widely accepted rules of thumb for estimating the appropriateness of a refinancing. Among them: the new rate must be at least 2 percentage points lower than the old rate, you must remain in the home for at least two more years and you must have lived there for at least two years. 
 Now those rules are pretty much gone with the wind. And the major reason is the great variety of mortgages currently available to people contemplating a refinancing.
"You used to traditionally refinance a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage with another 30-year fixed-rate mortgage," said David Lereah, chief economist of the Mortgage Bankers of America. "Now there is a varied menu of mortgage products out there."
Among them are many kinds of adjustable-rate loans as well as some esoteric kinds. There are balloon mortgages, which are amortized on a long-term basis yet have short-term maturities, and there are two-step mortgages, which have fixed rates for five to seven years and then convert to adjustable rates.
In addition, some lenders have been offering refinancing without closing costs in recent years. With such loans, the mortgage rate is increased slightly to compensate for the absence of closing costs, which otherwise might add from $1,000 to $5,000 to the price of the mortgage. "You don't have to come up with any money at all and the outstanding balance remains the same," said Sidney Lenz, executive vice president of the Countrywide Funding Corporation.
Thus the decision whether to refinance has become more subjective, based on such goals as cutting monthly payments or reducing the term of the loan. Another consideration is the market value of the home.
"If the value of the property has been clobbered, there isn't much that can be done other than paying down part of the mortgage debt or not refinancing," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. "My advice is pay down the debt and refinance. It's one of the best deals around."
In making a refinancing determination, a time frame evaluation comparing your current mortgage with a new mortgage is essential. As outlined in a Refinance Kit sold for $3 by HSH Associates (Department Refi, 1200 Route 3, Butler, N.J. 07405), all of the costs of a refinanced mortgage -- points, lawyer services, application fees and title search and insurance -- should first be totaled, with 10 percent of the total added for miscellaneous expenses. Each point is equal to 1 percent of the loan amount.
The monthly payment for principal and interest on the refinanced mortgage is then subtracted from the higher payment on the existing mortgage. Then the difference is divided into the refinancing costs to determine the number of months it will take to recoup the costs.
"Ask yourself if you are going to remain in the house long enough to recoup your closing costs on the refinancing," said Paul S. Havemann, vice president of HSH. "Your break-even point should be short enough that you enjoy at least a year or two of savings."
But with changes in mortgage rates occurring more frequently than in the past, it makes sense to consider the possibility of refinancing more frequently, too. "You should look at your mortgage every six months and see what packages are being offered on refinancing," said Howard Culang, managing director of Prudential Home Mortgage.
