HEADLINE: Clinton, in Hyde Park Visit, Urges A Renewal of Roosevelt's Legacy

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 19

 BODY:
President Clinton paid homage to the memory of Franklin D. Roosevelt today and then, walking arm in arm with the grandson of the 32d President, laid a red rose on the grave of the statesman to whom he would like to link his policies and his political fortunes.
"I think of President Roosevelt in the depths of the Depression having gone through his personal journey to cope with his personal problems, summoning interior strength and reserve to lift the nation's vision," Mr. Clinton said in a speech at the Haviland Middle School, which was built by Roosevelt's Works Progress Administration during the New Deal. 
 Now, the President added, "we need that kind of experimentation, based on the plain evidence that we are in a rut."
Mr. Clinton's words made clear the special purpose of his visit today to this Hudson River town, and his appearance with Roosevelt's grandson, James Roosevelt Jr. As the 42d President sought to evoke the personal spirit and political presence of his predecessor, he was clearly trying to make the nation believe that its current economic difficulties are a crisis of nearly similar magnitude to the Depression, and require the same spirit of national unity that fueled the New Deal.
The more he can make that case, Mr. Clinton's advisers believe, the more pressure he can bring to bear on Congress to enact his economic programs and the more sacrifice he can demand of the American people. And, evoking Roosevelt's memory, the President seemed to be searching for a way to persuade Americans that they could trust the Government to work for their common good.
 
Tempest Over Casual Remark
 Mr. Clinton came to Hyde Park, Roosevelt's home north of Poughkeepsie, from Chillicothe, Ohio, where he and White House staff members scrambled to dampen a tempest spawned by the President's casual mention of the possibility that "in the years ahead," the Government might consider applying a national sales tax, or value-added tax.
That comment sparked a flurry of press interest, and Mr. Clinton and his aides quickly assured reporters that it did not reflect the President's current thinking and that it could be a decade or more before such a tax might be necessary.
Addressing his audience here, Mr. Clinton said: "We've got to do things that make it possible to create high-wage, high-growth jobs so that all the students who go to school here will have a future, and so that America will be strong. That's what I think we have to do. In other words, that is my vision. That is not what we have done. What we have done is to try for 12 years to cramp the role of government."
Such policies "have lowered the taxes on the wealthiest Americans," Mr. Clinton said. "Taxes on the middle class have actually gone up in the last 12 years. We have run a horrendous Government deficit."
 
Political Experimentation
 Defending his spending priorities, Mr. Clinton once again turned to Roosevelt's legacy of political experimentation. "You know what an experiment is in science -- it is trying out a new thesis," he said. "If it works, you incorporate it, you build on it, you go on to the next experiment. If it doesn't work, you quit. Government has a one-way experiment. We're very good at starting things and absolutely terrible at stopping them."
Thus, Mr. Clinton said, he wanted to spend less Government money on the special fund to clean up the worst pollution sites and make businesses shoulder more of the burden. He added that he wanted to spend money on programs like Head Start and his vision of a national service program, under which college students would be able to work off their tuitions by serving as teachers or police officers or mentors to distressed children.
On Saturday, the President will meet with children at the White House to discuss issues in a 90-minute program to be broadcast by ABC at 11:30 A.M.
In Chillicothe, a market town of 25,000 people south of Columbus, Mr. Clinton addressed a crowd of about 1,700 packed into a high school. The audience, picked by lottery, was quite receptive to his economic proposals, but asked many questions about the details. One woman asked why the President had not proposed a national sales tax, instead of the tax on energy prices that he did offer Congress.
"It is something I think we may well have to look at in the years ahead," Mr. Clinton replied, going on to discuss the notion of a value-added tax in detail.
But later in the day, Clinton aides found that the reports of news organizations were focusing on those comments, threatening to overshadow Mr. Clinton's efforts to drum up support for his economic package. The President then went out of his way to back away from the national sales tax idea.
He told reporters while shaking hands with schoolchildren on the way out of Chillicothe: "It is not something that is now under consideration. If we start considering it, I'll tell you. I did not mean to float a trial balloon."
Aides said the idea of a national sales tax was considered when Mr. Clinton was drawing up his economic plan in the last three months, but was rejected for political and economic reasons.
It came back to Mr. Clinton's mind, a senior White House aide said, after a meeting this week with Senator Ernest F. Hollings Jr., Democrat of South Carolina, who had been circulating a paper on Capitol Hill calling for a 5 percent value-added tax.
Senator Hollings tried to persuade Mr. Clinton to support the idea, and received in reply only a polite "maybe down the road," the aide said. The value-added tax is favored by many labor leaders and manufacturers because of its potential to make imports more expensive.

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
CLINTON'S PROGRAM GETS ENDORSEMENT OF FED'S CHAIRMAN

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
President Clinton's hand in the coming budget struggle was strengthened today when the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, who is a Republican and a staunch conservative, endorsed Mr. Clinton's proposal to cut the budget deficit.
Testifying before the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan, who is widely respected on Wall Street, called the plan "serious" and "credible" and praised it for including detailed cuts, rather than relying on vague goals to cut the deficit. 
 Mr. Greenspan said the deficit and the mounting Federal debt, "are corrosive forces slowly undermining the vitality of our free-market system."
"If we fail to resolve our structural deficit at this time, the next opportunity will doubtless confront us with still more difficult choices," he said.
 
Effect on Interest Rates
 The Administration has vigorously courted Mr. Greenspan's endorsement because a thumbs-up from the Fed chairman, a Republican appointee, could help push long-term interest rates down further and could persuade some ambivalent Democrats and Republicans that the President's program is solid. The rates on 30-year Treasury bonds fell to another record low today. [Page 33.]
The Administration was so eager to show that Mr. Greenspan was on board that Hillary Rodham Clinton invited him to sit next to her when the President unveiled his plan in a televised speech to Congress on Wednesday night.
In more good news for the President, Mr. Greenspan signaled that the Federal Reserve thought there was no immediate need to raise short-term interest rates, saying that there was still enough slack in the economy to allow it to grow fairly rapidly without a threat of inflation.
 
Hints at Lower Rates
 In fact, he indicated that the Federal Reserve would consider lowering rates if Mr. Clinton's plan began to drag down economic growth. Speaking in his usual understated, indirect way, Mr. Greenspan said the central bank would "certainly need to take into account" cuts in the Federal deficit and their effect on the economy when it adjusted interest rates. But he added that it was not possible for the Federal Reserve "to specify in advance what actions might be taken."
In a strong signal to the financial markets, Mr. Greenspan said that the President's plan to reduce the deficit, if enacted, would reduce inflationary pressures, something that should help drive down long-term interest rates. Mr. Greenspan, whose term as Federal Reserve chairman expires in March 1996, formerly ran an economics consulting firm in New York.
The Federal Reserve chairman defended the President's program on a day when Republican lawmakers stepped up their attacks on Mr. Clinton's proposals for cutting the deficit by $325 billion over the next four years. The Republicans asserted that the plan relied too much on tax increases and not enough on spending cuts.
Leon E. Panetta, the White House's budget director, fueled the Republican resistance when he told members of Congress that the Administration was considering additional taxes on tobacco and alcohol to help pay for its plan to overhaul the health-care system.
 
Wouldn't Be Baited
 Mr. Greenspan, in his three-and-a-half hours of testimony, turned aside repeated invitations and entreaties from Republican senators to attack the President's plan, especially for not relying more on spending cuts.
"I just don't think that it is appropriate for any of us at the central bank to be involved in the debate which is in the process of emerging on the various priorities within the total budget system," Mr. Greenspan said. "Our concern is the end result, and we wish you well."
The Federal Reserve chairman said he was not worried by President Clinton's plans to spend $30 billion to stimulate the economy this year. Some Republicans have attacked that proposal for short-term stimulus, saying it was unnecessary and threatened to overheat the economy.
 
Downplays Stimulus Spending
 "The argument that the Administration is making is that what they perceive they need is an insurance policy, so to speak, on economic growth," Mr. Greenspan said. He added that the size of the stimulus package was not "particularly of concern to us."
"If it were a big number, I would tell you," he said. "It would really concern us."
Unveiling the central bank's annual economic forecast, Mr. Greenspan said the economy would grow by 3 to 3.25 percent this year. He predicted that inflation would remain low and that the jobless rate would dip from its current rate of 7.1 percent to between 6.75 percent and 7 percent by the end of the year.
Throughout the hearing, Mr. Greenspan took pains to avoid commenting on whether Mr. Clinton's ratio of spending cuts to tax increases was desirable. But he did assert, as he often had in the past, that efforts to cut the deficit should concentrate on spending cuts. He said this was important because Federal spending had been growing far faster than the tax base.
 
Empathy for Budget Cutters
 Nonetheless, he displayed some unexpected understanding for why Mr. Clinton's plan ended up focusing less on spending cuts than many Republicans wanted and less than several Clinton advisers had hoped.
"It is very difficult to cut spending when we get down to specific programs," he said. "There is a constituency under every single item in the Federal budget for anybody who has endeavored to squeeze it down. When you get to the details, it gets very difficult."
Mr. Greenspan noted that the 3.3 percent core rate of inflation in 1992 -- the rate after factoring out volatile changes in energy and food prices -- had been the lowest in two decades. He expressed pride that the central bank believed that inflation had nearly achieved price stability.
He said price stability "does not require that measured inflation literally be zero, but rather is achieved when inflation is low enough that changes in the general price level are insignficant for economic and financial planning."
"At current inflation rates, we are thus quite close to attaining that goal," he said.
In an almost mocking tone, Mr. Greenspan said it was wrong for lawmakers to worry that they might cut the deficit by such a large amount that it would dangerously weaken the economy. Borrowing a phrase from his predecessor, Paul A. Volcker, he said the notion of too much deficit cutting was "nothing I would lose sleep over."
In Mr. Greenspan's view, deficit cuts might pull down long-term interest rates by so much that the stimulative effects of low rates would offset the drag that tax increases, for example, could have on the economy.
The Federal Reserve chairman said that if he could have one wish to help the economy, it would be to lower mortgage rates. That would unleash a flood of home building, which would spur sales of durable goods like sofas and dishwashers.
 
Lower Money-Supply Target
 Mr. Greenspan announced that the central bank's main policy-making panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, had decided to reduce its targets for growth in the money supply this year. The new target for M2 -- the most closely followed gauge of the money supply -- is growth of 2 to 6 percent, down from the current range of 2.5 to 6.5 percent. M2 includes cash, savings and checking accounts, and money market funds.
Mr. Greenspan said that lowering the target was just a technical move, asserting that recent developments show that less growth in the money supply is needed to produce a desired level of economic growth.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The Federal Reserve chairman endorsed President Clinton's economic plan. Alan Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee that the plan would reduce inflation if it was enacted. He also indicated that the Fed would consider lowering rates if the plan were to drag down economic growth. [Page 1.]
The era of supply-side economics begun by Ronald Reagan could end with President Clinton's proposal raising income taxes and reviving many deductions. Economic Analysis. [33.] 
 New York and New Jersey reported substantial increases in state tax revenues late last year. [25.]
 
 Companies
The sale of The New York Post to Steven Hoffenberg was approved by a bankruptcy judge, who noted the hard financial realities facing The Post and called Mr. Hoffenberg's offer "just about the only game in town." [1.]
The Saudi prince who helped Citicorp out of its financial difficulties in early 1991 wants to sell millions of shares of the bank company's stock at a profit of at least $127 million. [33.]
General Motors offered salaried employees paid leaves of up to 15 months, after which they would have to leave the company. The auto maker is hoping to cut 8,000 jobs by the end of the year. [33.]
Teledyne agreed to pay $2.15 million to settle charges that it failed to test electronics components sold to the military. The settlement partly resolves a whistle blower suit. [35.]
Eli Lilly said a Federal grand jury was investigating its compliance with a 1989 F.D.A. agreement in which the company was to improve its quality-control systems. [35.]
Westinghouse remade top management, forming an eight-member executive committee and five operating groups. [35.]
Circus Circus's president and chief financial officer resigned unexpectedly in part because of a failed expansion effort. [35.]
 
International
The European Community abandoned development of its technology for high-definition television, acknowledging that more advanced systems under consideration in the United States will almost certainly become the worldwide standard. [46.]
 
Markets
The Treasury bond yield fell to 7 percent, another record low, as many investors shifted from short-term to long-term issues [33.]
Stocks finished a dizzying week with a healthy bounce. The Dow gained 19.99 points, most of it in the last 15 minutes. [34.]
The dollar fell to a new low against the yen after Treasury Secretary Bentsen called for a stronger yen. [44.]
Silver, platinum and palladium fell on fears that an economic slowdown would reduce demand. Gold also fell somewhat. [44.]
 
 Your Money
Financial advisers are beginning to devise investment strategies for those most affected by the Clinton plan, even amid the many uncertainties over whom the plan affects most. [31.]
More than 300 mutual funds now cater to very small investors by allowing minimum investments of $250 or less, and some will start accounts with as little as $25 a month. [31.]
Stock investors can protect their price gains by placing stop orders, which direct brokers to sell a stock if the price falls to a predetermined level. [31.]
Some of the old rules that govern when it is advantageous to refinance a mortgage no longer apply. The major reason today is the great variety of mortgages available. [32.]
A Long Island family completely furnished their home at low cost by buying at auctions. [32.]

HEADLINE: Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Report Tax Revenue Increases

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
New York, New Jersey and Connecticut this week reported substantial increases in tax receipts for December, with income tax revenue in New Jersey and Connecticut rising almost 40 percent over the previous year. The increase in New York was more than 20 percent.
The figures came within days of the release of a national study that found that growing economic activity had increased the sales tax and income tax receipts of most states in September, October and November. 
 In Connecticut, the state hardest hit by the recession in the metropolitan region, the national study found that tax receipts had declined for the three months ending in November. However, yesterday, Connecticut officials said their collections had jumped sharply in December.
In all three states in the region, analysts said the improvement resulted in part from unusual factors -- including a tendency for high-income people to take their bonuses and deferred paychecks at the end of last year, thereby paying income taxes at the 1992 rate and avoiding higher rates expected under President Clinton.
Much of the increase in receipts, they said, may therefore be temporary. And while the report on Tuesday led analysts to predict that there would be calls for lower state tax rates elsewhere in the nation, experts in the metropolitan region said they see little chance of reductions soon.
"I'm not sure that this all means anything more than we had very strong Christmas sales," said James W. Wetzler, the Commissioner of Taxation and Finance in New York State, which said its sales tax receipts in January, reflecting Christmas sales, rose by 3 percent, to $945.7 million, from $917.5 million for the year-earlier period.
 
The 'Clinton Effect'
 January income-tax receipts in New York State soared by more than 20 percent, to $1.752 billion from $1.456 billion the year earlier. In New Jersey, the increase in January income tax receipts was 39.6 percent, to $662 million, from $474 million.
Mr. Wetzler said most of the income tax gain resulted from what he called the "Clinton effect," and the disproportionate number of high-income executives in the region -- particularly on Wall Street -- who elected to take their bonuses and pay their taxes in 1992.
Still, other officials said the expanded tax revenues in New York and New Jersey reflected an end to the recession and better times ahead, if not a fiscal bonanza.
"We are seeing real increases, and they will continue," said Samuel F. Crane, the State Treasurer of New Jersey, who predicted the income tax receipts in his state would increase 6 percent for the fiscal year that ends in June.
The national tax study, released on Tuesday by the Center for the Study of States, a research group in Albany, found that New York's receipts in personal income tax, corporate income tax and sales tax rose by a total of 9.3 percent in the fourth quarter. Since receipts precede tax payments by a month, they reflected incomes and purchases in September, October and November.
The increase in New York compared with an average increase for all states of 6 percent.
 
Other States Less Fortunate
 In the study, researchers said they accounted for things like changes in tax rates and collection techniques to measure the actual increase of funds flowing into the states.
Fourth quarter tax receipts increased by eight-tenths of 1 percent in New Jersey, and declined by 2.4 percent in Connecticut, the study found.
For the states in the metropolitan region, as elsewhere, analysts said any increase in tax receipts is particularly good news now, not only because it reflects increased economic activity but because it may relieve the pressure to raise taxes at a time when increased Federal taxes are being proposed by the Clinton Administration.
In New Jersey, officials said their sales tax receipts in January -- reflecting Christmas sales -- fell to $372.8 million from $397.4 million the year earlier. But the state's sales tax rate, currently 6 percent, had been lowered from 7 percent in 1992, and it said its receipts would have actually increased by 9.4 percent if the lower rate had not been enacted.
In Connecticut, the state's Department of Revenue Services released data yesterday showing that sales taxes collected for December had increased by 9 percent, to $234 million from the year earlier. It said income tax collections for the month had jumped 39 percent, to $280.2 million.

HEADLINE: Proposal for Sludge Plant In Brooklyn Is Withdrawn

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
After a torrent of local opposition and mounting political pressure, the Dinkins administration yesterday withdrew its proposal to build a large sludge-treatment plant along the waterfront of Sunset Park in Brooklyn.
The administration's announcement that it would reconsider its plans came only three days before the City Planning Commission was to vote on the $250 million plant. 
 The commission's members had become the focus of intense lobbying by elected officials from Brooklyn, who said the plant would pollute the environment and harm the struggling economy of the largely Hispanic, working-class neighborhood. Those officials rejoiced last night.
"It's a victory," said Joan Griffin McCabe, the City Councilwoman who represents the neighborhood and led the opposition to the plant. "I think it shows that the city has listened."
 
Unpopular Plants
 The decision to withdraw plans for the plant -- one of five sludge-treatment plants to be built, one in each borough, at a cost of $1 billion -- leaves the administration with the difficult task of finding a new site in Brooklyn. Administration officials said they would have to look for a new site in Brooklyn, a search that could include the Sunset Park site with modified plans for the plant.
"We spent a long time looking for a site," said Albert F. Appleton, the city's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, who announced the decision to withdraw the plant in a letter to the Planning Commission yesterday afternoon. "Among a series of less-than-ideal sites, Sunset Park was the best."
The city's efforts to find sites for the plants, being built in response to a Federal law that bans dumping sludge at sea, has been fraught with difficulties. After proposing eight plants, the city reduced the number to five last April.
The plants will transform sludge -- the dark, thick liquid residue left after treating raw sewage -- into fertilizer and similar products. Contractors now haul the 13,000 tons of sludge the city creates daily to landfills in other states. Once the plants are built, scheduled to be by 1998, though, the city hopes to sell the sludge products.
The Planning Commission has approved plans for three plants -- on Wards Island, in Maspeth, Queens, and in Mariners Harbor on Staten Island -- and construction has begun on a plant in Hunts Point, the Bronx.
In a letter yesterday, Richard Shaffer, the commission's chairman, told the Department of Environmental Protection that the commission's 13 members believed that the department should reconsider the impact the plant might have on "the community's economic revitalization."
Mr. Shaffer said the opposition had raised legitimate issues about the site, along the waterfront between 45th and 50th Streets amid a bustling manufacturing area.
"We lobbied very hard," said Marilyn Gelber, an aide to Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn. "I don't believe they had the votes."
Residents and civic leaders in Sunset Park had raised concerns that the plant would cause congestion and pollution. They also said the plant would have displaced about 400 jobs in more than 20 businesses already operating on the proposed site.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
If Roger Finke and Rodney Stark are right, the current understanding of American religious history ought to be turned upside down. If Martin E. Marty is right, Professors Finke and Stark might want to wash their mouths out with soap and water, then offer other scholars an apology.
The cause of this difference of opinion is a pugnacious book, "The Churching of America, 1776-1990" (Rutgers University Press, 1992). The title sums up the two professors' overarching thesis: Since colonial days the United States has gone "from a nation in which most people took no part in organized religion to a nation in which nearly two-thirds of American adults do." 
 Historians have long pointed out that church membership hit its low point in the 18th century. But the authors, who are sociologists, draw upon a "sociology of frontiers," noting that colonial settlements like New York and Charleston were disproportionately populated by uprooted young males and no more "filled with God-fearing, Sunday-go-to-meeting folks" than later Wild West vacation spots like Dodge City and Tombstone.
"On any given Sunday morning there were at least as many people recovering from late Saturday nights in the taverns of these seaport towns as were in church," the authors write.
And in 18th-century New England, they write, "non-Puritan behavior abounded." At a time when only a fifth of New Englanders were church members, a third of all first-born children were born to mothers who had been married less than nine months. "Single women in New England," they write, "were more likely to be sexually active than to belong to a church."
Re-examining historical statistics for church membership, Professor Finke (pronounced FINK-ee), who teaches at the University of Washington, and Professor Stark, who teaches at Purdue University, conclude that 17 percent of the population were "religious adherents" in 1776, 37 percent in 1860, 53 percent in 1916, 59 percent in 1952 and 62 percent in 1980.
Among scholars, the most contentious part of the book has less to do with the thesis that America has become more "churched" than with the authors' explanations of how and why, best summed up in the book's subtitle: "Winners and Losers in Our Religious Economy."
The authors use an explicit market model in which churches are viewed as "firms" competing for souls. Competition is good; monopoly is bad. Growth in religious participation is due to the sharp conflicts and infighting among churches, not despite them, the authors say.
The "winners" in this process have been the "upstart sects" that once included the Methodists, Baptists and Catholics and today include Pentecostal groups like the Assemblies of God and the Church of God. The winners had entrepreneurial energy, organizational flexibility and a clergy who knew the needs and spoke the language of ordinary people.
The "losers," the authors say, have been the country's mainline churches, especially the Congregationalists, Episcopalians and Presbyterians, who insisted on a well-educated, seminary-trained clergy, spurned the raucous religion of tent meetings and tried to minimize rough-and-tumble competition for new members by interchurch cooperation.
The authors agree with the argument that the Rev. Dean M. Kelley made 20 years ago in "Why Conservative Churches Are Growing." Religious groups grow when they impose sacrifices on their members, Mr. Kelley argued, and decline when they ease the burdens of belonging.
But where Mr. Kelley was offering an explanation for the sharp drop in the mainline churches' membership in the 1960's, Professors Finke and Stark argue, in economic terms, that even when these churches were still gaining adherents, they were already losing "market share" to the upstart sects.
"Religion," they write, "is a collectively produced commodity." Its emotional and psychic rewards are greater, they say, if the believer interacts with others who display an intense confidence in the faith's tenets and a great readiness to sacrifice in time and money for the group and its projects.
Professors Finke and Stark complain that the religious history of the United States has been written largely as a story of the well-established churches and of religious ideas, with an implicit equation between progress and the refinement of these ideas to suit modern secular standards.
They propose instead a history of religious actions and groups in which "theological refinement is the kind of progress that results in organizational bankruptcy" and the heroes are the emotional and unsophisticated religious movements that respectable theologians have often derided.
Their chief example is Methodism, which ceased to grow once it settled its fervent circuit-riding clergy, sent them to seminary and de-emphasized sin, hellfire and damnation.
Applying their findings to recent changes in American Catholicism, the authors conclude that as the church modernizes its teachings and practices, it will change "from an energetic sect into a sedate mainline body," and its membership will begin to decline.
They acknowledge that there are limits to the sacrifices people will accept and that the Catholic Church may have surpassed those limits in its ban on contraception and its requirement of celibacy for priests. Unfortunately this qualification weakens the power of the authors' model to predict future trends.
Last month, "The Churching of America" came under fire from Dr. Marty, a pre-eminent historian of American religion and a man known for his equable temperament. In a recent issue of The Christian Century, Dr. Marty, a professor at the University of Chicago, accused the two authors of a "consistently sneering mode" toward previous scholarship.
They are guilty of reductionism, he said, writing a kind of religious history that "contains no God or religion or spirituality, no issue of truth or beauty or goodness, no faith or hope or love, no justice or mercy; only winning and losing in the churching game."
But Mark Noll, who teaches at Wheaton College in Illinois and has just published a history of Christianity in the United States and Canada, had a more serene view. "I don't see it as a new Bible for American religious history," he said of the book. "But this will be a real good discussion starter."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
G.O.P. SEEKS ALLIES AMONG DEMOCRATS

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Although they are virtually united in criticizing the Clinton economic plan as the same old Democratic tax-and-spend policies, Congressional Republicans concede that when it comes to fighting it they are outnumbered and outgunned.
So they are looking for help from an unexpected source: Congressional Democrats. The Democrats are unlikely to help them kill the plan, the Republicans reason, but it might be possible to seduce enough away from the party to modify the proposal along Republican lines, with more spending cuts and fewer tax increases. 
 Some conservative Democrats, like Representatives Pete Geren and Charles W. Stenholm from Texas, have already begun to grumble that the Clinton package is overly dependent on new taxes rather than spending cuts.
 
Off to a Slow Start
 Most Republicans think it is wishful thinking to believe they can enlist Democrats to abandon their President en masse. And they concede that they have got off to a slow start in developing a single alternative economic policy and selling it to the voters.
Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Senate Republican whip, said Republican lawmakers did not have to come up with a single alternative plan because the House Democrats and their special-interest allies would disembowel the program. "We'll just sit and watch," he added.
But the Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, predicted that the House Democratic Caucus "will stay together to enact a very large percentage of the program," even in the face of solid Republican opposition.
This view won support today when Leon E. Panetta, the Director of Management and Budget, was greeted warmly by Democrats on the Senate Budget Committee.
Later, Mr. Panetta agreed with Senator Trent Lott, a Republican of Mississippi, about the prospect of a second, later set of tax increases to pay for the Administration's health-care proposals. "It's a little early to say," Mr. Panetta said, "but I suspect that some of the sin taxes are going to be used."
Administration officials said earlier in the week that they were considering two dozen new taxes, including levies on alcohol, tobacco and guns, to pay for extending health coverage for all Americans.
The Republican predicament of opposing the new taxes underscores the broader problem they face of changing gears from cheerleaders of the Bush White House to minority opponents of the new Democratic Administration.
"I'm frustrated because it is hard for us to get our message out," said Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee. "We're going to come up with some kind of program. Leon Panetta has 500 staff people and I have 12, so it's going to take us a little more time but we are working at it."
Mr. Kasich is one of several Republican lawmakers working on alternative budgets and economic plans. Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the ranking Republican on the Budget Committee, supports a plan to cap the growth of certain programs with automatic benefits, like Medicare, Medicaid and some veterans programs.
Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican, wants to kill the President's stimulus package of $16 billion in new spending and enact a balanced-budget amendment.
A number of Republicans are putting out lists of expenditures they want slashed, like financing for the space station and the Superconducting Supercollider, a particle accelerator, but their efforts are opposed by still other Republican lawmakers whose districts would benefit from such programs.
Only hours before Mr. Clinton addressed Congress on Wednesday night, Republican lawmakers gleefully expressed confidence that his economic program was doomed. Telephone calls to Capitol Hill were running 10 to 1 against the plan. But polls after the speech show that Mr. Clinton halted the slide and won majority support for the broad outlines of his plan.
To counter such support, Republican lawmakers are fanning out across the nation this weekend, holding town meetings and appearing on local television stations. But with so many different Republican alternatives, Republicans concede that the party lacks a single voice voters can focus on.
Senator Gramm said that once the voters understood the details of the plan, public opinion could be changed. By Mr. Gramm's calculations, the Clinton plan will raise nonmilitary domestic spending by $13 billion over five years. The kernel of the plan is $313 billion of net tax increases. Therefore, he concluded, "This idea of shared sacrifice is totally fraudulent."
"Our first challenge now is to get the facts out," he said. "I can't defeat President Clinton's speech. There has got to be a reality check."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ECONOMIC PLAN;
Meeting Hope and Doubt Arm in Arm

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHILLICOTHE, Ohio, Feb. 19

 BODY:
The audiences hearing President Clinton's traveling salesman's pitch for his economic package have been friendly, even awe-struck, carefully stocked with Democrats and eager to be persuaded.
Yet beneath the ovations and the roars of approval, there has been a skepticism expressed by many who heard Mr. Clinton's hard sell firsthand over the last two days. 
 "I don't want to wake up in four years and have him tell me, 'Uh oh,' " said Jeri Sexton, a 30-year-old homemaker here who said she had voted for Mr. Clinton. "I'd like to be behind the program, but I don't want to be the rat following the Pied Piper. I want to trust him, but I still need to see the facts and figures."
Telling Mr. Clinton that "Ross Perot spoiled me with flip charts, pointers and poster board," Ms. Sexton asked him for such specifics at the President's appearance in a high school here this morning. But as much as she wanted to be a believer, she said afterward, she was not convinced by the statistics he gave and still wanted more details.
 
'A Lot of Enthusiasm'
 Tom McKean, a 49-year-old plant manager who heard Mr. Clinton in downtown St. Louis on Thursday, said he had voted for President Bush last year but added: "Clinton shows a lot of enthusiasm, which is good. I'm not wild about the higher taxes. But if there's a way to get the pork barrel out of politics, I would support it. And I won't be convinced until I see the spending cuts actually taking place."
This mix of cynicism and hope that often surfaced in last year's Presidential campaign emerged again and again in interviews with about 50 people who attended the President's question-and-answer session today in this gritty mill town in southern Ohio, or heard his speech at a restored train station now used as a shopping mall in St. Louis.
They praised Mr. Clinton for, as many put it, having "the guts" to propose tax increases and then to confront people who would have to pay those new taxes personally. But they also demanded proof that he intended to trim Federal spending enough to justify the tax increases. And some said they feared that the endemic problems of unrestrained spending by Congress and greedy influence peddlers in the capital were too overwhelming for any one person -- even a President -- to tackle.
Peg Grimes, a homemaker who also works with animals on her family's 100-acre farm near here, said the one remark by Mr. Clinton that encouraged her came when he assured the audience today that "I have no interest in raising a penny in taxes if we're not going to do the cuts."
 
'Show Me the Cuts First'
 But, she said: "I'm just uneasy. We're used to tax and spend. He's talking tax and spend and cut. And he can flip the numbers any way he wants to make them say anything he wants. We'll see."
Randy Howard, who sells recreational vehicles in St. Louis, said he, too, was waiting for proof that Mr. Clinton was serious about cuts. "Show me the cuts first, and then show me the tax increase one year from now," he said.
Mr. Howard, a 38-year-old Republican who voted for Mr. Bush, said that while it was important to reduce the deficit, it was unfair for middle class people like him to be expected to help foot the bill. "Every week when I stop to fill up my tank, when I turn up my thermostat, it's going to hit me," he said of the President's proposal. "He said he would not raise taxes for the middle class. It's almost identical to 'read my lips.' Show me the difference."
Mr. Clinton may not have won many converts, but his maiden barnstorming tour to promote his economic plan seemed to at least win him good will. Once again demonstrating his ability to charm audiences, the President today stood at the edge of the stage in the high school auditorium here, microphone in hand, looking earnest and concerned as he locked his gaze on his questioners.
While his audiences in Ohio and Missouri looked random, they were actually sprinkled with partisans. In St. Louis, for example, Doug Hall, a senior at Washington University, waved a hand-painted placard that read, "Sacrifice for Tomorrow."
The sign and others like it were nothing more than props for Mr. Clinton to mention as he opened his speech. Mr. Hall said he and others were given the signs by Democratic workers who had made them in advance.
But he insisted that he believed in the message. "I think our country's at a point of sacrifice right now," the psychology major said. When asked if Mr. Clinton would succeed with his program, Mr. Hall said, "The question is whether the average person gets talked out of it by propaganda and special interests."
The crowds also included uninvited spectators who were unwilling to cheer for the President and who were squeezed into the back, far from the cameras and the President. But even some of those people said they were encouraged.
 
'At Least He's Trying'
 "Even if it's a lot of window dressing, at least he's trying," said Christy Marshall, who said she worked in the United States Attorney's office in St. Louis and voted for Mr. Clinton. "Sometimes you can get lost in the rhetoric; he's very glib with the phrase. But I think he's trying very hard."
That was an assessment shared by some Republicans.
"I was impressed, and I'm a Republican," said Linda Yocum, a homemaker who came to the Ohio high school with a camera hanging around her neck. "He has so much information on the top of his head, and I liked his easy manner of communicating with people."
Her friend, Cindy Hanchin, a substitute teacher who said she had voted for Ross Perot, shook her head and added: "I don't agree with him, but it took a lot of guts for him to come to an area where this is going to be a hard sell. People are strapped, and a lot are going through tough times. But he seems to be really concerned."
Others, like Richard Gerding, a retired accounting manager in St. Louis, were still longing for the plain talk of Mr. Perot. "I'm glad I came because I saw a one-term President up there," he said, motioning toward the podium as crews took down the bunting after Mr. Clinton had left. "He's all symbolism. And he's no Perot. Perot had the necessary horsepower to pull off the change that's needed, to really put people's feet to the fire."
Despite their uncertainty about whether Mr. Clinton can press his plan through Congress, there were also plenty of people, including Republicans and independents, who said it was time for the nation to heed the President's call for sacrifice. It was precisely the message that White House officials wanted to hear.
"I'll pay the tax increase and smile the whole time," said Ed Warfield, a 33-year-old pastor who saw Mr. Clinton speak in St. Louis. " I didn't vote for President Clinton, but I will fully support him because if we don't stand behind him, we'll fall together."
Rick Proehl, an assistant manager of a gas station, was among many spectators in Ohio who said they were disappointed that Mr. Clinton did not mention something that won former President George Bush applause at virtually every stop in the campaign: calling for Congress to approve a line-item veto so the President could cut specific programs from the budget.
"He brought it up all during the campaign," Mr. Proehl said of Mr. Clinton, "but not once now. That's the one thing that will help him persuade the people. That's the way to go."

HEADLINE: White House: A Computer Nerdville

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In policy and practice, this is supposed to be a high-tech Presidency.
Bill Clinton's vision of America's future is of a nation linked by a "data superhighway" -- a web of fiber-optics wizardry able to bring everything from libraries to movies to blueprints into every home, school and office at the touch of a button. 
 On the campaign trail, his people regarded laptop personal computers as casual tools of everyday life, plugging them into computer bulletin boards and firing off electronic-mail messages around the country.
 
Big Job for 2 Mavens
 And through electronic town halls and electronic mail, President Clinton pledges to bring the Government to the people.
Perhaps, but the White House itself seems trapped in the technological dark ages. And it is the job of Andrew Aultz and Bill Krause, two technology mavens, to bring the telephones and computers in the Executive Offices into the modern world -- no small order, given the budget squeeze.
"We'd love to give this place all the latest toys, but we can't," Mr. Krause said, sitting beneath a freshly framed picture of President Clinton and leafing through a computer magazine.
Many phone calls in the White House are still connected manually by operators plugging cords into a switchboard. Mr. Aultz, a 35-year-old telecommunications specialist, says this archaic system is one reason callers cannot get through to register their views on the Presidential comments line, generating up to 50,000 busy signals a day.
Mr. Krause, a 42-year-old computer expert, complains of a chronic shortage of personal computers and tells of young staff members appalled to find typewriters on their desks.
The PC's that are there are a couple of computer generations old -- four years or more -- and are arrayed in a hodgepodge of 21 networks that cannot talk to one another. One result: the President's daily schedule is still printed on paper and distributed by hand, instead of by computer, so some people get it a couple of hours late.
In many ways, the challenge at the White House is similar to that confronted daily in corporate America as companies try to tailor fast-changing technology to their organizational needs.
"The White House is like a small holding company -- and a very important one," said Warren McFarlan, a professor at the Harvard Business School. "And it is grappling with the same technology issues that companies must address every day."
The Clinton staff got used to high-speed technology on the campaign trail, scouring the news wires constantly by computer and reacting almost instantly with statements, position papers and rebuttals to charges or controversies. These messages were distributed through an elaborate electronic mail system linked to campaign offices in all 50 states.
"Our motto on the campaign was that speed kills," explained Jeff Eller, the White House director of media affairs.
The technological hurdle for the White House is magnified by the generation gap between the Clinton and Bush Administrations and very different styles of government.
The use of modern technology to speed reaction times and deal with the public directly, whether in televised town meetings or a program for electronically distributing White House statements nationally, is a central tenet of the Clinton Administration. As much as possible, the President wants his message delivered as he presents it, not filtered, or analyzed, by the news media. The catch phrase, used by White House officials, is that Mr. Clinton intends to speak "to people" instead of speaking "through people."
It worked in the campaign, they say, and it will be used in the White House, especially to rally support for ambitious programs like the Clinton economic policy.
"Clinton plans to run his Government like a campaign," said Raymond Strother, a Democratic political consultant. "To do that, you need the technology to run at that speed."
The demand for technology by the young White House staff members is running well ahead of supply. Personal computers are being rationed and the backlog of PC's ordered but not yet delivered is 50, though that is down from 100 two weeks ago.
"Our people are hooked on the flow of information," Mr. Krause said, "so everybody wants his or her own PC."
 
A Flood of Daily Calls
 The jammed phone lines at the White House are apparently a result of the higher volume of calls from the public. During the Reagan and Bush years there would be about 5,500 calls to the White House general number on a busy day, though the numbers would rise in crisis periods like the Persian Gulf war.
By contrast, there are 40,000 to 65,000 calls a day now to the general number alone, according to Mr. Aultz. The steady flood of calls, White House officials say, is explained by the new Administration's more open, informal style.
"Where people might not have dared call when Reagan or Bush were in the White House, they will call here now," Mr. Aultz said.
While the White House phone service now badly needs upgrading, Mr. Aultz concedes it met the requirements in the past.
 
Working With Phone Company
 "In fairness, we found a telephone system that was suited for the way they did business," Mr. Aultz said. "But it is terribly inefficient for the way we do business."
The White House is working with the local phone company, Chesapeake and Potomoc, and American Telephone and Telegraph to streamline and expand the White House phone systems.
On the computer front, Mr. Krause plans to replace many of the White House PC's, mostly I.B.M. models dating to 1988 and 1989, with more powerful machines that run faster and can handle graphics and possibly even information in both video and audio form, so-called multimedia.
 
No Substitute for Decisions
 The Iran-Contra affair put a dent in the White House computer budget because all the hard disks had to be removed and replaced after a Federal panel ruled last month that all E-mail messages from the Bush Administration had to be saved. The Clintonites insist that the precedent for opening up E-mail messages to public scrutiny will not deter them from using the technology freely.
For the moment, the bigger problem is bringing the White House computer systems up to speed.
Not everyone is persuaded they should hurry. To be sure, cutting-edge technology lets organizations get, send and pore over more information than ever before. But more information and more technology are no guarantee that better decisions will be made, analysts warn. Banks with elaborate computer systems and E-mail setups have made terrible loan decisions in recent years, they note, and even the computer giant I.B.M. misjudged the computer market.
"I'm skeptical that technology really helps you all that much, particularly in getting big decisions right, like the ones the White House has to make," said Howard Anderson, managing director of the Yankee Group, a computer consultant. "And to think technology is a panacea is to ignore the experience of American industry."

Mr. Aultz, by the White House switchboard, aims to engineer the archaic system to handle the minimum of 40,000 to 65,000 daily calls. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 30-Year Bond Hits a Low Yield of 7%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The yield of the 30-year Treasury bond fell to another record low yesterday as many investors shifted from short-term to long-term issues.
The bond's yield fell to 7 percent, from 7.02 percent Thursday, which was then the lowest 30-year Treasury bond yield since the Government began selling the issue in 1977. 
 Short-term interest rates rose as Federal Reserve officials played down the chance of a rate cut anytime soon. Traders said the greatest factor for the rise in short-term rates yesterday was the realization that the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-making body, had abandoned its bias for lowering rates in December, and had apparently taken a neutral position.
 
No Easing Seen
 Analysts said that realization quashed any hope among investors of an imminent easing, which caused selling in shorter maturities and buying into the long end of the market.
Peter Meyers, a trader at Bank Julius Baer, called the current market a "win-win situation."
He said investors were buying bonds because of the deficit reduction and the prospect for lower long-term rates, but that they were still buying shorter-maturity notes through mutual funds as a shelter against tax increases.
By the close of the New York cash market yesterday, the 30-year Treasury bond was offered at a price of 10118/32 , up 7/32 , to yield 7 percent. The rise was equivalent to about $2.50 for $1,000 of face amount.
The two-year note outstanding lost 3/32 to close at 10018/32 , with a yield of 3.95 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note to be auctioned next week was offered at a price to yield 4.01 percent, up from 3.96 percent on Thursday.
Traders said the yield gap between the two-year note and the 30-year bond narrowed 4 basis points from Thursday, to 306 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. The narrowing indicates that the price of long-term debt is performing better than short maturities.
On Thursday, the yield on two-year notes dropped 11 basis points, with investors persuaded that the Fed was getting close to cutting rates. But short rates rose yesterday after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, made it clear in his semiannual testimony before the Senate Banking Committee that the Fed would wait to see how President Clinton's economic plan would work.
"The economy can grow more rapidly," he said, "while inflation is contained." He said that the economic outlook "is a lot more hopeful than it looked recently."
About $52.8 billion in Treasury securities traded yesterday through the major bond firms, down 38 percent from Thursday, according to Govpx Inc., a bond pricing service.
Among money market securities, the rate of a three-month bill was up four basis points, to 2.91 percent, or at the bond-equivalent yield of 2.97 percent. The six-month bill rate was up two basis points, to 3 percent, or the bond-equivalent yield of 3.09 percent.
Actively traded municipal issues gained a point for the week, as investors bought tax-exempt issues to hedge against the effect of the tax increases proposed by President Clinton.

HEADLINE: He Runs Trash Hauling With Silence and Pastry

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
Every Tuesday, with unshakable punctuality, a gray-haired man, hobbling on two canes, arrives at noontime at a tan-brick building in lower Manhattan, often bearing pastries that he shares over cups of espresso with other men.
Outwardly the man, James Failla, 74, has a grandfatherly appearance. But law-enforcement officials say he is a mobster who, at these cannoli klatches, carves up New York City's rubbish-collection routes in a way that creates the highest private carting rates in the country. 
 Mr. Failla runs the Association of Trade Waste Removers of Greater New York, the largest private garbage-haulers' trade group in New York City. He has held the job for more than 30 years.
 
Cautious, and Wearing Brown
 Law-enforcement authorities depict him as a senior statesman in the Gambino crime family and organized crime's pivotal figure in extracting payoffs from the city's private garbage-hauling industry, a $1 billion annual business.
In recent court testimony and affidavits, underworld defectors and Federal agents asserted that Mr. Failla has influenced many hauling companies and dominated the industry's principal teamsters local.
Mr. Failla (pronounced FYE-yal-lah) has been identified as a capo, or captain, who briefly served as the Gambino's acting boss in the mid- 1970's. Investigators say he is known in the underworld by the nickname Jimmy Brown, because of a penchant for brown clothes.
Authorities say they have driven the Gambino family out of many legitimate industries but they have failed in the hauling industry. They acknowledge that many attempts to obtain evidence against Mr. Failla have failed.
"He is one of the wiliest and most cautious suspects we have ever encountered," said Edward Wright, chief investigator for the state's Organized Crime Task Force. "He almost never says anything inside a building. If he has to conduct business, he always walks and talks outside in the street where he can't be overheard."
In the mid-1980's, the task force planted court-authorized bugs in the trade group's offices on Catherine Street near the East River and at the Veterans and Friends Social Club on 86th Street and 14th Avenue in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn.
The Brooklyn storefront, investigators said, is Mr. Failla's main meeting place and is emblematic of his prudence. It had no telephone and on the wall there was a large picture of a cockroach wearing a headset with the caption: "Our Bugs Have Ears."
 
Top Garbage Charges
 Mr. Failla refused to be interviewed about his role in the garbage-collection industry. Salvatore Spinelli, the Trade Waste Association's lawyer for 20 years, said, "The allegations that this industry is mobbed up are just not true."
"I have never seen any improper influence exerted by Mr. Failla on the employers or the union," added Mr. Spinelli.
The association, with offices now at 180 West Broadway, represents hauling companies that have most of the business in the city. Mr. Spinelli declined to say how many companies were in the association or the amount of their business. He also declined to disclose Mr. Failla's salary.
Studies by the Organized Crime Task Force and the Rand Institute, a research group, maintain that Mafia influence has created cartels in commercial garbage collection. The payoffs are made directly for sweetheart union contracts or routes and through secret partnerships with mobsters, investigators said.
Mark Green, the City Consumer Affairs Commissioner, has contended that haulers carve up and sell routes among themselves to insure large profits, even if the routes are inefficient and lead to excessive charges.
The department estimates that the city's 250,000 private businesses pay hauling charges that are the highest of any big city in the country, twice as much as in Chicago, Boston and Los Angeles.
 
A Throwback Style
 Ronald Goldstock, the director of the Task Force, said that mobsters discouraged outside companies from competing through threats of violence and vandalism. He said customers who complain or try to switch carters often receive higher bills.
A typical garbage removal bill for a grocery store is $15,000 a year, for a fast-food restaurant, $36,000, and for a medium-sized restaurant, $50,000, the city says. Macy's at Herald Square pays about $500,000 a year and Con Edison about $2 million.
Mr. Spinelli said hauling costs in the city were higher because of labor and dumping costs. He insisted that suggestions of monopolies and intimidation were "absolute fantasies."
Most of the Gambino group's reputed top leaders, including the family boss, John Gotti, are serving long prison sentences. But investigators call Mr. Failla the prototype of a previous generation of supercautious gangsters who were difficult to convict.
"In the carting industry, Failla resolves disputes, deflects attention and surrounds himself with trustworthy people," said Mr. Goldstock. "It's an approach that works well in the underworld."
 
'Dominant Guy in Garbage'
 Little is known about Mr. Failla's early career, except that he grew up in Brooklyn. He was first noticed when he became a chauffeur and bodyguard for Carlo Gambino -- the namesake of the crime family -- in the mid-1950's.
Mr. Gambino, after assuming control of the family in 1957, placed Mr. Failla in charge of the family's garbage-industry interests, said Ralph F. Salerno, the former head of the New York City Police Department's Organized Crime Detective Squad. "At that point he became the dominant guy in garbage," he said. "Without drawing too much attention to himself he has had a run of 30 years."
Mr. Failla was arrested on bookmaking and gambling charges in 1951 and 1966 in Brooklyn and each time paid a fine of $25. He was accused of criminal contempt of court in 1970 for refusing to testify before a state grand jury in Brooklyn. That charge was dismissed.
Undercover informants reported that after the death of Mr. Gambino in 1976, Mr. Failla was designated the acting boss. Paul Castellano, who became boss of the family soon after, kept Mr. Failla in his post in the garbage-hauling industry.
"He has always been a moneymaker for the family," Mr. Salerno said of Mr. Failla. "And nobody gets rid of moneymakers."
 
The Advantages of Silence
 Court records show that Mr. Failla visited Mr. Castellano's mansion in the Todt Hill section of Staten Island almost daily while F.B.I. agents monitored bugged conversations there for six months in 1983.
The F.B.I. inquiry produced the only felony charges ever brought against Mr. Failla. He was indicted in 1986 on Federal racketeering charges unrelated to his role in the garbage industry. He was accused of being a capo in the family and having engaged in a pattern of racketeering, involving loansharking, extortion and obstruction of justice.
He was acquitted of all charges in Brooklyn in 1987. Prosecutors said the case collapsed because, although he was present during conversations with Mr. Castellano and other reputed mobsters, he rarely uttered a word. Mr. Salerno said that Mr. Failla followed a maxim invoked by Carlo Gambino: "The man who says the least is the most powerful."
When Mr. Castellano was shot to death in Manhattan on Dec. 16, 1985, he was on his way to a meeting with Mr. Failla and other top Gambino capos at Sparks Steak House on East 46th Street near Third Avenue. Federal agents and prosecutors claim that Mr. Gotti then took over and retained Mr. Failla as a major capo.
From his roots in Bensonhurst, Mr. Failla moved 20 years ago into a red-bricked ranch home at 275 Evergreen Avenue in the Old Town section of Staten Island that realtors say is valued at $135,000 to $150,000. His home, in a blue-collar neighborhood on a dead-end street, allows him to see if he is under surveillance by law-enforcement agents in cars or vans.
Except for Mr. Failla's Tuesday meetings in Manhattan and Sunday visits to his social club in Bensonhurst, he is rarely seen in public. He has been walking with canes for several months but investigators said they did not know why.
Mr. Failla has been linked to Bernard Adelstein, the former head of the 2,100-member International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 813, by two former self-described mobsters and a former official of the local who became prosecution witnesses.
At Mr. Gotti's trial last spring, Salvatore Gravano, the former underboss, or No. 2 leader, in the Gambino family, testified that "Bernie Adelstein answers directly to Jimmy Brown so he controls the garbage industry for his family."
Mr. Gravano claimed that Mr. Failla kept 50 percent of the payoffs for himself and sent 50 percent "for our administration."
Frederick B. Lacey, a Federal court-appointed administrator, in September ordered Mr. Adelstein ousted from his union posts, citing his ties to Mr. Failla and other reputed mobsters. Mr. Adelstein has been succeeded by his son, Martin.
The Organized Crime Task Force has recommended a change in city policy as the most practical method of eliminating what it termed the Mafia's economic stranglehold on the industry.
Following that recommendation, the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins has proposed establishing two experimental trade-waste removal districts in Manhattan. Under a plan called "exclusive licensing," the city would supervise and grant one company the sole right to pick up refuse in each zone. Mr. Green said that a bill to create the zones would goto the City Council in March or April.

HEADLINE: Supply Side Goes by the Wayside

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Call it Reaganomics in reverse.
One decade and one $300 billion Federal deficit later, President Clinton wants America to roll back the supply-side revolution that toppled marginal income tax rates to 28 percent, from 70 percent in the 1980's. And he wants to bring back many of the tax breaks that favored certain kinds of investment and charitable giving, many of which were abolished in the 80's as the nation embraced a bold economic experiment of generating growth by blending low rates with fewer loopholes. 
 In his economic plan, President Clinton dials back the clock by proposing to raise the effective top rates to well over 40 percent, when several measures like a broader tax on Medicare are taken into account, socking it to a million or so of America's richest families. By lifting rates, the President expects to raise $155 billion more over five years from the top 1 or 2 percent of American families.
 
 
Bite of State Taxes
 In fact, the top marginal rate may be far higher, once state and local taxes are considered. For while America whittled away at Federal rates in the 80's, several states raised taxes on the rich, and still more states are contemplating such steps. This means that well-heeled residents of high-tax states like New York and New Jersey will likely pay 50 percent or so in taxes on the last dollar they earn.
Critics, who range from supply-side tax cutters to Democratic champions of the 1986 tax reform measure, contend that lifting rates will not raise as much revenue as the Administration hopes and will make the tax system even more complex. They also contend that soaking the rich will do nothing to reverse the inequality of the 1980's.
"The top 1 percent are the most productive people in the country," said Norman Ture, head of the Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation and a Treasury official in the Reagan Administration. "If you think this will have no effect on their contribution to the economy's progress, then you have to assume they are very peculiar human beings."
But others say fears that higher rates will damage the economy by discouraging saving and investment are probably overblown. "Nobody disputes the fact that higher rates will have some negative impact on work and savings," said Alan J. Auerbach, an economist at the University of Pennsylvania who until recently was chief economist for the Joint Committee on Taxation on Capitol Hill. "The real issue is whether the money goes to deficit reduction. If it does, it will certainly increase national saving."
What is clear is that the Clinton plan is a deliberate repudiation of the supply-side credo -- one that swept the globe as as government after government slashed top marginal tax rates in the 1980's. The focus on lowering marginal rates reflected a belief that a system of lower marginal rates would affect people's incentive to work, save, invest and take entrepreneurial risks. From that vantage point, the average tax rate -- the total tax bill divided by pretax income -- mattered far less than the rate an individual faces if he or she decides to do more work, saving or investing.
The 1981 Economic Recovery and Tax Act slashed the top marginal income tax rate to 50 percent, from 70 percent, and reduced all other brackets by nearly a quarter. The 1986 Tax Reform Act went even further, replacing numerous income tax brackets with just three -- 15, 28 and 33 percent -- and eliminating hundreds of tax loopholes.
"What we did in 1986 was to broaden the tax base, make it more equitable and more stable," said Robert Cline, research director of the Minnesota Department of Revenue. "What President Clinton is proposing is to unravel that agreement."
But Reagan supporters critical of Mr. Clinton's plan have only themselves to blame. The Reagan-Bush Administrations never succeeded in cutting spending. While taxes bobbed around 19 percent of the nation's gross domestic product, or the total cost of goods and services, spending spurted to 24 percent of G.D.P., from 22 percent in 1980. The resulting deficit became a paramount issue in America's tax politics.
What President Clinton wants is to raise the top rate to 36 percent, from 31 percent, on taxable incomes of more than $140,000, slap a 10 percent surtax on incomes over $250,000, and a series of other provisions that raise the top tax rate.
 
 
Rich Can Shift Income
 But all of it may not raise as much revenue as the Administration says, Mr. Clinton's critics argue. The rich, who have lots of flexibility in how they earn their incomes, might simply report less of what they receive. In a vivid demonstration of the flexibility of the rich, large numbers of Wall Street investment bankers, corporate chiefs and Hollywood stars rushed after the November election to collect bonuses and to cash in stock options ahead of the anticipated Clinton tax bite.
Economists like Lawrence Lindsey, a Federal Reserve governor, suspect that part of the surge in income among the top 1 percent of American families reflected more reporting of income after tax rates declined. Indeed, a recent study found that the biggest gains among the top 1 percent occurred immediately after rates dropped in 1986.
What troubles economists even more is that raising rates will resuscitate the tax-shelter industry. A lot of the tax law's complexity before 1986 stemmed from the gulf between tax rates on capital gains from investments and the earned income from wages and salaries. As long as capital gains were taxed at a lower rate, the wealthy -- who typically earn more than half of their income from investments -- have a strong incentive to reshuffle their income.
"It's axiomatic: if rates go up, loopholes will follow," said Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat who was a champion of the 1986 tax law that lowered rates.
Sticking it to the top 1 percent will not do much to reverse the income inequalities of the 1980's. Stagnating wages, not tax increases, were the root of income shifts in that decade that made the rich richer and the poor poorer. Slow productivity growth held down average income gains while changing technology rewarded the highly educated and punished the less skilled. "The consensus is that growth in inequality was not due to changes in tax rates," said Joel Slemrod, director of the Office of Tax Policy Analysis at the University of Michigan.
 
 
A New View of High Rates
 On the other hand, few economists are worried that higher rates will seriously damage the economy.
"Ten years ago, many economists thought high income taxes caused people to work less," said Robert Triest, an economist at the University of California at Davis. "More recent research suggests the effect is a lot smaller than we used to think."
The rich do, of course, account for a disproportionate amount of Americans' savings, with the top fifth of American families doing more than 60 percent of all saving. But during the 1980's, when marginal income rates fell by more than half and real interest rates were the highest in decades, the personal saving rate declined to historic lows.
"Based on the historical evidence, there's not a strong correlation between the tax rate and the saving rates," said Jonathan Skinner, a tax economist at the University of Virginia. "If anything, the tax-deferred nature of pensions would encourage savings through pensions."
Finally, there is concern that higher taxes will discourage entrepreneurs and stifle innovation and investment. The Microsoft Corporation, the computer software innovator, created more millionaries in the 1980's than many Wall Street firms. The 26-year-old engineers got rich by taking much of their pay in company stock. Under Mr. Clinton's plan, those capital gains will continue to be taxed at a 28 percent rate.

HEADLINE: Poverty Tied To Failures In Hartford

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 19

 BODY:
The state's final witness in its defense against a lawsuit challenging segregated conditions in Hartford's schools testified today that integrating them with suburban schools would not raise the achievement of city children because their basic problem is poverty.
As happened so many times in this 10-week-old trial, the state drew opposite conclusions from the plaintiffs, who also blame poverty for the poor performance of Hartford's schools, but seek to overcome it by linking them with schools in 21 surrounding towns. The suit was brought by a coalition of civil-rights groups on behalf of Milo Sheff, now a Hartford eighth-grader, and 18 other schoolchildren. 
 In the end, the essential disagreement is not whether the concentration of poverty in Hartford's schools harms their children, but whether the benefits of a court-ordered integration plan covering the entire metropolitan effect are worth the risks of public uproar and white flight.
 
'Integration Can Do Something'
 "One side answers that there's not much integration can do, and that in fact integration is extremely troublesome and problematic," said John Brittain, a lawyer for the plaintiffs. "Our side's coming down saying integration can do something."
"If you say there's nothing you can do about the socioeconomic status," he added, "then to a large extent we're saying that these poor children in cities are relegated to a class and caste of future poverty."
The state's final witness, Prof. David Armor, a school-busing expert at George Mason University in Virginia, said today that the city's children achieve less than suburban students almost entirely because they are poorer, not because of racial segregation or the quality of their schools.
As a result, he said, a metropolitan integration plan would have little effect on the performance of Hartford's students, 90 percent of whom are black and Hispanic and two-thirds of whom are poor.
"The differences in achievement between minority and white, and poor and affluent, are important and should be addressed, but I think we should be addressing the socioeconomic differences," Professor Armor said. "The schools can only do so much."
"Simple changing of racial composition of schools is not likely to change very much," he continued. "What appears to hold promise is improving the socioeconomic status of those who are disadvantaged in our society."
The state has never contested the segregation in Hartford's schools, or that it is harmful. Instead, it has argued that the segregation results from complex social and economic forces that have concentrated poor people in cities.
Schools alone cannot counter those forces, the state has argued, calling elected officials more able than a judge to address issues like housing and transportation and contributors to poverty like unemployment, discrimination, drug abuse and crime.
The Sheff lawyers will complete their cross-examination of Professor Armor next week and then present their final rebuttal witnesses. But the Assistant Attorney General who led the state's defense, John Whelan, said today that the state had accomplished its goals.
 
Not That Bleak, State Says
 "The first objective was to show that the state was deeply concerned about the effects of racial isolation and has tried to address that issue and the problems of minority children," Mr. Whelan said. "The second objective was to show that the Hartford schools are not as bleak as the plaintiffs have presented them."
"The third objective," he said, "was to make it clear that the problems that exist are highly complex and cannot be resolved by a court order -- that the kind of solutions needed to address the problem require action by the General Assembly."
Since the trial began on Dec. 16, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has proposed a school-integration effort that would divide the entire state into regions, which would have two years to develop and carry out plans to achieve greater racial balance between their towns and cities.
The proposal stresses voluntary measures, like new magnet and regional schools that would attract students across town lines. The state would support the effort by paying for new interdistrict schools and transportation of their students.
 
Voluntary Measures Backed
 In its defense, the state has argued that it has supported similar, though less ambitious, voluntary measures over the last 25 years, while calling for a statewide strategy. It has also greatly increased its aid to schools in Hartford and other cities to counter the effects of poverty.
Experts for the state have also testified about the practical difficulties of carrying out a metropolitan integration plan, and about the high proportion of white parents who have removed their children from public schools in cities where mandatory plans have been imposed.
Today, however, Professor Armor returned to one of the plaintiffs' main concerns, the wide social and economic gap between the populations of Hartford and its suburbs.
Drawing from state data, he showed that 55.6 percent of Hartford's black fourth-graders qualified for free or reduced-price lunches in 1988, but just 4.5 percent of the white fourth-graders in the suburbs.
 
Little to Do With Race
 Similarly, only 11.9 percent of Hartford's adults had college degrees, compared with 27.1 percent of suburban adults, and 51.0 percent of the city's families were headed by single families, compared with 11.3 percent in the suburbs.
But those disparities, Professor Armor said, had little to do with race. Among Hartford's blacks, only 7.9 percent had college degrees, but in a group of five suburbs 19.2 percent of the blacks had degrees. Single parents headed 70 percent of Hartford's black families but only 36.2 percent of suburban black families. And suburban blacks had incomes nearly twice those of Hartford blacks.
The Sheff lawyers say these poor children overwhelm Hartford's schools and so are denied an equal educational opportunity. The proof, they say, is their performance on Connecticut's standardized tests, where they rank last in the state.
But Professor Armor said that nearly all of the disparity in scores can be explained by differences in economic status between city and suburbs. Better-educated, more affluent parents are more likely to read to their children, to stress education, and to do other things that help children do well in school, he said.
There is no evidence that the city's schools are overwhelmed by the sheer numbers of poor students, and racial composition has no discernible effect, he said. The test scores of blacks were higher, he said, not when they attended integrated schools, but when their families were wealthier and better educated.
The disparity in test scores between Hartford and its suburbs, he said, "cannot be used on its face to conclude that there is inequality of educational opportunity."
John Brittain, a plaintiffs' lawyer, said that both sides agree that concentrated poverty "has tremendous burdens and impacts upon the educational performance of children."
As it comes time to decide what to do, he said, "one side answers that there's not much integration can do, and that in fact integration is extremely troublesome and problematic. Our side's coming down saying integration can do something.
"If you say there's nothing you can do about the socioeconomic status," he continued, "then to a large extent we're saying that these poor children in cities are relegated to a class and caste of future poverty."
